Dear Doctor,





RE:	PAUL CRAMP		DOB:	14/01/1979		UR:	8001659

							





														Diagnoses:
1.
Previous infective endocarditis.
- Giving rise to severe tricuspid regurgitation.
Tricuspid valve repair with a Cor-Matrix in 2017.
Previous intravenous drug user.
- Previously on methadone, now ceased.

Atrial flutter
    - likely trigger of viral infection
    - DCCV March 2022
    - anticoagulation ceased 3 months after DCCV

Current Medications:
metoprolol 50mg BD, aspirin 100mg daily, salbutamol PRN

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Paul Cramp in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today, accompanied by his wife.
He is known to this clinic after he required a tricuspid valve repair in 2017 as a result of infective endocarditis causing severe tricuspid regurgitation.
As you know, Paul is a 43-year-old gentleman who was a previous intravenous drug user,  who has now ceased using recreational drugs, since his admission for infective endocarditis in 2017.
He is a long-distance Truck Driver, which also has a significant physical exertion component to his role.
As a result of his long-distance transportation role, he often finds himself in different parts of Queensland.
As a result, when he had an episode of atrial flutter in March last year, he presented to Blackwater Hospital and was then transferred to Rockhampton Hospital for a TOE guided cardioversion.
This episode of atrial flutter was the first that he noticed since 5 years prior.
I understand that it was believed to be a precipitated event in the setting of a viral infection, so anticoagulation was discontinued approximately 3 months after successful cardioversion.
He does not have ongoing cardiology follow up at Rockhampton Hospital, however.
I am pleased to that Paul has been going well with no orthopnoea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, or chest discomfort since his last review.
Reviewing the investigations that had been done to date,  his most recent transthoracic echocardiogram prior to today was in May last year.
This was in Rockhampton.
It showed a normal left ventricular size and systolic function with an ejection fraction of approximately 60%.
There were no regional wall motion abnormalities seen on that study and he had normal diastolic function for age.
He had mildly dilated left atrium by indexed volume criteria.

He had a normal right 



RE:	PAUL CRAMP		DOB:	14/01/1979		UR:	8001659

														

														ventricular size and systolic function with an RVSP of 28mmHg.
A sclerotic mitral valve was described with mild regurgitation.
Tricuspid valve repair was noted with moderate regurgitation and a mean pressure gradient of 3mmHg.
We have repeated the transthoracic echocardiogram today.
The images have not been formally reported yet, but a preliminary report after review of the images, show a normal left and right ventricular function with no vegetation seen on any of the valves.
There was mild mitral regurgitation.
The tricuspid valve repair was evident with no significant tricuspid regurgitation.
The trans valvular tricuspid mean pressure gradient was 4mmHg at 68bpm.
On examination today, Paul appeared well and in good spirits.
His blood pressure was 130/90mmHg and his heart rate was 72bpm and regular.
As Paul has been well and stable, I have not changed his medication regimen today.
I will arrange to review Paul again in approximately 2 years with a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram, particularly to monitor his transvalvular tricuspid gradient.
Should his condition change, please write to us and we will move his appointment forward accordingly.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Cramp.

Yours sincerely,

Hypertension.

Dear Dr Hang,





RE:	LISA CROZIER		DOB:	26/04/1965		UR:	8090115

							



														

														I had the pleasure of meeting Ms Crozier in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
She is a 57-year-old lady currently working at TRI.
Ms Crozier had aortic valve replacement performed in 2020 for severe aortic stenosis.
She had a tissue aortic valve replacement and been clinically doing well since then.
There are no symptoms of shortness of breath or chest tightness.
Her last echocardiogram was done in November 2021, whereby it was mistakenly mentioned as a mechanical aortic valve, however, I have checked the surgical report and she had a tissue AVR done.
She was noted to have an increase intracavitary gradient of 50mmHg along with concentric LV hypertrophy pattern which is worsening to 100mmHg with Valsalva.
Currently she is asymptomatic.
In future, if she starts to have symptoms, she may be considered for Beta blocker.
I have discussed the above with Lisa and particularly as she has not had a recent echocardiogram in the last 13 months, I have offered her one.
Lisa does currently does not want to pursue any echocardiogram.
She is happy to accept another echocardiogram in 1 year.
I have explained to her that given the prosthetic valve in situ, she would need ongoing serial echocardiogram to progress the monitor of the valve status.
On examination today, her blood pressure was 140/70mmHg, heart sounds were dual with a prosthetic sound.
There was no appreciable murmur and chest examination was clear.
I have booked her to be reviewed in the Cardiology Clinic in 12 months with a repeat echocardiogram prior.
Please continue with your ongoing care and feel free to contact if you have any concerns in the interim.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Chris,





RE:	MICHAEL ANDREW CULLEN	DOB:	16/04/1955	UR:	287541

							



														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Ischaemic heart disease with previous coronary artery bypass graft surgery.
Previous CABG with LIMA – LAD, SVG – RPDA, SVG – OM in 1993.
Pseudo aneurysm of saphenous vein graft to right coronary artery.
Previous right ileac artery aneurysm with subsequent open repair.
Precious transient ischaemic attack.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Ex-smoker.
Obesity.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Other Conditions:

														Generalised anxiety disorder.
Major depressive disorder.
Post-traumatic stress disorder.
Obstructive sleep apnoea with no adherence with CPAP therapy.
Nephrolithiasis.
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Medications:

														Clopidogrel 75mg daily, Frusemide 20mg daily, Rosuvastatin 20mg daily, Trelegy Ellipta as directed.
I reviewed Michael Cullen today.
Michael has a degenerated ectatic vein graft to his right coronary artery demonstrated on CT scan.
There are 2 points of pseudo aneurysm formation.
The vein graft is diffusely ectatic on CT assessment.
There is 1 proximal area of pseudo aneurysm formation and another smaller distal area of pseudo aneurysm formation.
There does appear to be active contrast extravasation into the proximal pseudo aneurysm.
Michael has no definite angina,  no prolonged or pathological palpitations.
No syncope.
He is significantly obese.
He is a remote ex-smoker, having stopped 30 years ago.
Michael and I reviewed his CT imaging together.
His vein graft is quite ectatic and even in its normal portions, measures up to 10mm across.

It is likely he would require fairly extensive covered stent deployment, and this still may not be successful in achieving exclusion of the pseudo aneurysms given the presence of dual sites of origin and the diffuse degenerative nature of the vein graft.

An 



RE:	MICHAEL ANDREW CULLEN	DOB:	16/04/1955	UR:	287541

														

														alternative approach could be revascularisation of the right coronary artery with percutaneous coronary intervention and then coil percutaneous based occlusion of the saphenous vein graft.
To me this would seem to be the best potential treatment way forward.
I discussed the potential risk uncertainties of this procedure with Michael.

We discussed the risk of stroke, resulting in inability to walk or talk, blindness, nursing home placement and death, heart attack and heart failure, major vascular or cardiac complication, including dissection, rupture, bleeding and limb loss and the need for emergency heart surgery being in the order of 2 to 3% with these procedures.

An ongoing observational approach seems rather fraught, given that there has been evidence of gradual progression of the pseudo aneurysm and the unstable appearance on CT with what appears to be ongoing leak into the pseudo aneurysm cavity.
Michael would like to have something done.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Repeat CT in addition to invasive biplane coronary angiography and graft study.

Review of these imaging findings with a view to potential percutaneous coronary intervention to native right coronary artery and plugging / exclusion of the SVG-RPDA versus endoluminal stent graft to SVG-RPDA.

With kind regards,

														

														Yours sincerely,

														RE:	DAVID CUNNAH		DOB:	20/02/1964		UR:	2232006

																					

														

														

														Thank you very much for your referring.

Diagnoses:

														Persistent atrial fibrillation.
3 cardioversions.
Recent cardioversion in December 2022.
On Flecainide and Atenolol.
For AF ablation.
History of previous nephrotic syndrome.
Varicose veins.

Current Medications:

														Flecainide 50mg BD, Atenolol 25mg daily, Eliquis 5mg BD.
It was a pleasure to review David in the Cardiology Clinic, who came along with his wife.
David had atrial fibrillation in 2019 in Melbourne, when he had nephrotic syndrome, and he was on steroids and thyrotoxic medication.
Apparently, he had a couple of cardioversions there, the first one in 2020.
He has had a recent cardioversion at Redland Hospital in December 2022.
He was changed over from Sotalol to Flecainide, and he has maintained sinus rhythm so far.
In terms of symptoms from atrial fibrillation, he gets short of breath and decreased exercise tolerance when he is in atrial fibrillation.
His risk factors for atrial fibrillation include moderate alcohol intake and he has been abstinent from alcohol for the last couple of months.
He is a non-smoker and does not have a history of diabetes or hypertension.
I would assume that his thyroid function would have been checked, if not, then I will ask Dr Wang to check that.
He does snore at night and feels tired and lethargic during the day.
In view of his minimal risk factors for atrial fibrillation, I would suggest that Dr Wang refers him for a home sleep study.
His ECG confirms sinus rhythm.
His corrected QT was 440ms.
I understand his echocardiogram had shown normal LV function.
I have discussed with David, that he needs to lose 5 to 7 kg of weight.
He has already lost 3 kg recently.
He is abstinent from alcohol currently.
We discussed further treatment options.
We talked about either continuing antiarrhythmic therapy, with Flecainide or consider cardiac catheter ablation.
The procedure was discussed with him detail.

There is around 3% risk of any major complications, including pericardial effusion, heart attack, stroke, need for open heart surgery, vascular complications, atrio oesophageal fistula, pulmonary vein stenosis were discussed.
Written information has been provided.
David is keen to have AF ablation and I will organise this for him at the PA Hospital.
I have warned him about our long waiting list.
In the meanwhile, if he has further atrial fibrillation, his dose of Flecainide could be increased to 100mg BD as he is on a low dose for his body weight.
He will continue to have regular follow up at the Redland Hospital Cardiology Department.

Yours sincerely,

He has angina, despite medical therapy and we would normally offer him angiography with a view to angioplasty.
This would usually require stent insertion and therefore require between 7-10,000 units of intravenous Heparin at the time, a Clopidogrel load of 300mg and an Aspirin load of 300mg.
Once the stent is placed, he would be committed to dual antiplatelet therapy at the very minimum of 1 month and preferably for 3 to 6 months.
As you know he has had a subarachnoid haemorrhage and he has residual bilateral middle cerebral artery aneurysms.
I would seek you opinion as to the relative risk of bleeding should we proceed with an invasive procedure, so that I assess the risk benefit ratio for Mr Daly.
I would be most grateful for your opinion.

Yours sincerely,

Dear David,





RE:	GLIBERTO DALY		DOB:	3/06/1973		UR:	131206

								

	



Thank you for sending along Gilberto.
He has had a couple of months of typical angina, which he experienced while starting to get fit with jogging.
He has been placed on Aspirin, low does Beta blockade and low doe statin therapy and he went on to have a stress echocardiogram which I understand shows LAD ischaemia.
He tells me that he is having very little angina now, provided he does not overexert.
Today, his blood pressure was 138/84mmHg, his pulse is 70bpm on 12 Lead ECG.
His chest was clear and there was no cardiac murmur.
Mr Daly does not smoke.
There is no direct family history of coronary disease.
I note he has moderate hypercholesterolaemia and treated hypertension.
In the first instance, we will continue the Aspirin.
I have doubled his Beta blocker to 25m BD, and I have increased his Lipitor to 80mg daily aiming for an LDL <1.6mmol/L.
The issue for me, is the bleeding risk from his known cerebral aneurysms that I have contacted his Neurosurgeon for advice.
We will follow up with Mr Daly in about 4 to 5 weeks.
Hopefully we will have news from the Neurosurgical Team and can then assess the risk and benefits of proceeding with angiography with a view to intervention.
If not, we will need to continue on with medical therapy.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Bhadha, 





														RE:	PHILLIP CHARLES DALY	DOB:	31/08/1949	UR:	529381

																					

														

														

														Issues:
1.

T2DM
    - HbA1c 6.8% (Oct 2022)
2.

Hypercholesterolaemia
    - LDL 3.6 (Oct 2022)

Medications:
rosuvastatin 10mg daily, pantoprazole 20mg daily, fexofenadine 180mg daily, aspirin 100mg daily, magnesium


														I  had the pleasure of reviewing Phillip Daly today in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic, accompanied by his wife.
Thank you for referring Phillip to us for review of his elevated CT coronary calcium score in the setting of diabetes and hypercholesterolaemia.
As you know, Phillip lives with his wife at home and is independent.
He is very fit and active despite now being retired from his previous job at Bunnings, in the receiving area.
He looks after his grandson once a week and mows his neighbour’s lawn regularly.
He continues to drive and also enjoys playing golf 2 to 3 times per week.
From a cardiac risk factor perspective, Phillip is an ex-smoker, having quit using tobacco in 1996.
He smoked a pipe for 32 years.
He drinks 1 glass of wine with steak every couple of weeks.
He does not use recreational drugs.
Phillip cannot recall any cardiac family history.
I understand that the CT coronary calcium score was performed after a CT scan to investigate a potential lesion on Phillip’s lungs was found on chest x-ray in the setting of coryzal symptoms.
The initial CT scan showed coronary calcification which then led to quantifying the amount of calcium in his coronaries.
From a symptom perspective, Phillip denies any chest heaviness or discomfort with or without exercise.
As mentioned, Phillip is very active and despite all of that, including walking 18 holes of golf, he does not experience any chest discomfort.
He reports occasional dyspnoea, but this has resolved after deliberating losing 8 kilograms of weight after being told of his diabetes diagnosis.

Thank you for including the investigations you have performed to date, which include a CT coronary calcium score of 1753, predominantly showing calcium in the right coronary artery, and an LDL of 3.6, which was done in October prior to initiation of his Rosuvastatin.
On examination today, Phillip appeared well and in good spirits.
His blood pressure was 130/70mmHg and his heart rate was approximately 60bpm and regular, corresponding to sinus rhythm on ECG.
His chest was clear, and his heart sounds were dual with a soft 2/6 intensity ejection systolic murmur predominantly in the aortic region with mild radiation to the carotids.
There was no peripheral oedema, and his jugular venous pressure was no elevated.
Phillip was seen today in clinic by Dr Korczyk and we have recommended that he continue with his current medication regimen including the statin and Aspirin.
We would recommend titrating his Rosuvastatin to a target LDL of <1.6 or to the maximum tolerated dose.
We have recommended ongoing aggressive risk factor modification, particularly with respect to diabetes and any other conditions that Phillip may develop in the coming years.
We have encouraged Phillip to gradually escalate his exercise to increase his fitness level.

Given Phillip’s asymptomatic condition at present, we will not make another appointment to see him, but should he develop any symptoms, suggestive of typical angina (reviewed with him today), please re-refer to us for further review.
Thank you for  your ongoing care of Mr Daly.

Yours sincerely,

														Thank you for referring Louisa Davis to our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic for review of her increasing exertional dyspnoea and persistent fatigue.
This is on a background of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and previous episodes of syncope.
She was seen today in clinic with her family.
With respect to her symptoms, Louisa reports experiencing progressive exertional dyspnoea that started approximately 5 to 6 months ago.
She finds that she tires very easily and is persistently fatigued throughout the day, requiring frequent naps.
Her exercise tolerance is approximately 300 metres on flat ground assisted with a single point stick.
She is able to climb 12 stairs without stopping.
She sleeps on a single pillow and denies any orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea.
Incidentally, she reports having a nocturnal cough, but this may have preceded her decline in function.
Thank you for including a transthoracic echocardiogram that was conducted in the community in November last year.
This showed a normal left ventricular size and systolic function with an LVEF of approximately 60%.
There was a mildly increased left ventricular wall thickness seen on this study.
Normal right ventricular size and systolic function was described.
There was mild left atrial dilatation.
There was also a dilated ascending aorta with trans sinus measurement of 31mm, ST junction measurement of 26mm and ascending aorta of 38mm.
Moderate mitral regurgitation and a normal RVSP was also described in the report.
On examination today, Louisa appeared well and in good spirits.
She mobilised easily from the waiting room into the consultation room without significant dyspnoea.

Dear Doctor,





RE:	GEOFFREY DE JACKSON		DOB:	06/06/1956	UR:	830476

							



														Diagnoses:

														Atrial fibrillation.
Rheumatic heart disease.
Mitral valve replacement and tricuspid annuloplasty 2013.
Hypertension.

Current Medications:

														Warfarin, Digoxin 125mcg daily, Metoprolol 25mg twice daily (increased to 50mg twice daily today), Telmisartan 40mg daily.
I had the pleasure of talking to Geoffrey via telehealth from the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
Geoffrey is a 66-year-old incarcerated gentleman with a prior history of a mechanical MVR, tricuspid valve annuloplasty and atrial fibrillation.
I am pleased to see that Geoffrey is clinically doing well.
He does not have any symptoms of shortness of breath.
He had a stress echocardiogram performed at his last clinic review with no inducible ischaemia.
At his last clinic review we increased his Metoprolol dose to 50mg BD and since then he has had no more chest tightness or palpitation symptoms.
I wonder whether the chest tightness symptoms were happening due to the recurrent AF with rapid ventricular rate response.
His ECG was sent to from the Correctional Center, which was still in atrial fibrillation.
I have looked back through the last 7 to 8 years of ECGs and found him to be in atrial fibrillation all the time and also noted that his LA is several dilated with the index value of 88ml/m².
I believe that his atrial fibrillation would be permanent atrial fibrillation and hence he is following a rate control strategy.
At this stage, I have booked him for a review in 12 months with a prior echocardiogram and have not made changes to his medications.
Please continue with your ongoing care and feel free to contact us if you have any concerns in the interim.

Yours sincerely,

She is a 62-year-old lady with a bicuspid aortic valve for surveillance.
She is medicated on Rabeprazole 20mg and Fostair inhaler.
She has a large amount of familial stress.

Dear Dr Ansell,





														RE:	NEVIA DEKLIC		DOB:	23/12/1948		UR:	662011

																					

														

														

														Cardiology Issues:

														2:1 AV block requiring St Jude dual chamber pacemaker DDDR.
Device check September satisfactory.
LVEF on stress echocardiogram normal in 2022.

Medications:

														PPI and Vitamins.
I had the pleasure of reviewing Nevia following her pacemaker implantation electively in July last year.
This is her first clinic review since, although she has been seen by our Electrophysiology Scientist in September for her last device check and this was satisfactory.
She states that her exertional dyspnoea has improved since the pacemaker implant, however, she remains fatigued and tired all the time.
She is 74 years of age, and she still cleans a school for 3 hours every morning and looks after her husband, who unfortunately has dementia.
She has low mood and has family stressors.

She reports that 3 months following pacemaker implant she a sensation of the pacemaker impinging on her skin and causing her pain, disturbing her sleep but this has almost resolved now, and she uses simply analgesia for this She also does some upper limb exercises with a physiotherapist, and she has shown me what these involve, and they seem mild and not rigorous enough to cause any issues with her pacemaker.
She mentions that you investigated her with chest X-ray and ultrasound and that these tests were unremarkable.
We do not have the results of this, if you could please forward these results to us we would be grateful.
On examination, the pacemaker site looks fine and there is no evidence of swelling or any skin breach/ lead erosion.
There is a soft pan systolic murmur, and she is euvolaemic.

I have asked her to see yourself for further investigation of her fatigue and tiredness in the form of basic blood screen, depression screen and consideration of a sleep study and perhaps some counselling for her mood.

We will continue seeing her in our pacemaker clinic via our Scientists, but she does not need to come back to the Electrophysiology / Dr Gould’s clinic, but of course we can see her if any issues are flagged.
Nevia has the pacemaker clinic number and I have mentioned to her, if she deteriorates for if she has fevers or if her pacemaker site becomes tender again, she gives us a call on that number.

Yours sincerely,

														Dr Rob Gluer

														Toowoomba Hospital

														Dear Dr Gluer,

														

														

														RE:	THOMAS DELUGAR		DOB:	26/07/1938		UR:	960664

																					

														Cardiovascular diagnosis

														Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis

														NYHA II dyspnoea

														Mean gradient 41mmHg on echocardiogram 11/2022.

Normal left ventricular function

														Non-obstructive coronary artery disease at coronary angiography 01/2023

														Permanent atrial fibrillation (apixaban)

														Left bundle branch block

														Hypertension

														Dyslipidaemia

														Remote ex-smoker

														

														Other diagnoses

														Prior left nephrectomy with preserved renal function

														Recurrent right finger ulceration (healed at present)

														

														Medications 

														Apixaban 5mg bd

														Metformin XR 1g nocte

														Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg mane

														Duodart 1 nocte

														Atorvastatin 20mg daily

														Pregabalin 75mg nocte

														Ramipril 10mg daily

														Allopurinol 100mg daily

														Metoprolol 25mg BD - ceased

														Frusemide 20mg daily – commenced

														

														Thank you for referring Thomas for review regarding transcatheter valve intervention for his severe aortic stenosis.
Thomas has noticed progressive shortness of breath over the last 6 months.
At times, he feels short of breath at rest, but most commonly is able to walk 10km on the flat without significant limitation, although he now avoids hills as this prompts his dyspnoea.
He has not suffered angina or syncope, but did have one episode of exertional presyncope approximately 3 months ago.
Thomas’ echocardiogram is consistent with severe aortic stenosis with a mean gradient of 41mmHg and a DPI of 0.2, and he has normal biventricular function.
Coronary angiography last month shows a left dominant circulation without a significant left coronary stenosis, and a small non-dominant right coronary artery stenosis.
His CT TAVR has been performed, and at first assessment it appears he has satisfactory femoral access.
Thomas’ medical history is fairly limited and listed above.
He was widowed last year, and lives alone in Toowoomba with sons nearby.
He is a former real estate salesman turned avocado and rhubarb farmer and was very successful in manufacturing guacamole.
He does not drink significant amounts of alcohol.
He is allergic to the tetanus vaccine.
On examination today his blood pressure was 155/75mmHg and his pulse rate is 71bpm with typical fibrillation.
His ECG showed AF with left bundle branch block.
He had an ejection systolic murmur, but a preserved carotid pulse and no sign of heart failure aside from mild peripheral oedema.
I note most recently, in early December, his creatinine was 170umol/L, and haemoglobin 123g/L.

Assessment & Plan:

														I agree that Thomas has severe symptomatic aortic stenosis, and he appears suitable for TAVR.
I’ve ceased his metoprolol, and if greater rate control is required, this could be reintroduced at a lower dose or digoxin commenced.
I’ve added a small dose of frusemide and asked him to see his GP in two weeks for renal function testing.
I’ve had a preliminary discussion with him about the natural history of aortic stenosis, with an approximate 50% mortality within 1-2 years if left untreated.

We then discussed transthoracic valve replacement with a 5-10% risk of major complication including 1% risk of death, 2-3% risk of stroke (which can be permanently disabling), heart attack, infection, kidney damage, bleeding.
There is also a 20-30% risk of a permanent pacemaker.

He is aware of symptoms that should prompt an urgent medical review (progressive dyspnoea, chest pain or syncope), but otherwise we will be in touch with him in the next month with the outcome of our heart team meeting.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Blanco,





RE:	MARILOU VENECIO DEQUINA	DOB:	16/05/1977	UR:	8026219

							



														

														I reviewed this 45-year-old lady with her husband today in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.

Issues:
1.

PVCs
    a.

Admission MAPU 27.7.2018 with chest pain whilst at work, radiated to back, 

														        associated light-headedness and facial flushing; Ventricular bigeminy and 

														        trigeminy on telemetry; cTnI and D-Dimer negative; CXR normal; Commenced 

														        low-dose Metoprolol 12.5mg bd
    b. CTCA 23.8.2018 – Calcium score 0; Normal coronaries with no stenosis
    c. Holter 23.4.2018 – Average 70bpm (29-112); 11.1% VPCs (isolated, couplets, 

														        bigeminy and trigeminy), Monomorphic; Asymptomatic
    d. Holter 14.2.2019 – Average 78bpm (SR; 47-78); 13% VPC burden (isolated, 

														        couplets, bigeminy and trigeminy; Monomorphic); 1 x episode chest 

														        heaviness corresponding to SR with PVCs
    e. Holter 3.3.2020 – SR 77bpm (50-148bpm); 2.2% VE burden (Isolated, 

														        interpolated, couplets and sustained bigeminy); No pauses; No diary events 
    f. TTE 10.3.2020 – Normal LV size and LVEF 62%; Normal RV size and systolic 

														        function; No valvular pathology
    g. Repeat Holter 30.11.2022 – SR 8bpm; <0.1% SVEs; 15.6% VEs (No NSVT); 

														        No diary events

Background:
1.

Non-smoker, non-drinker
2.

Works in PAH sterilization unit; Live with husband and 3 children
3.

Did not tolerate Metoprolol - Fatigue

Medications:
Vit D and Mg2+

														

														More recently she has noted some exertional dyspnoea, walking from the carpark to work.
She has developed intermittent chest heaviness for the last 6 months, only when she gets upset, angry or emotionally stress.
She tells me that it is somewhat similar to her symptoms back in 2018 when we did undertake a CT coronary angiogram that demonstrated no evidence of coronary artery disease.
Importantly, she does not get any chest discomfort with physical exertion or at work lifting heavy items.
She gets palpitations 2 to 3 times a week.

She describes it as being a fast beat of seconds in duration, but they may also then occur intermittently for some 



RE:	MARILOU VENECIO DEQUINA	DOB:	16/05/1977	UR:	8026219

														

														minutes.
She has had no dizziness or syncope.
She has the occasional soft drink but no other caffeine intake.
On examination her blood pressure was 125/80mmHg, her heart rate was 84bpm, with the occasional palpable ectopic.
Her chest was clear.

Assessment:

														She does have a 15.6% ventricular ectopic burden.
There were no runs of non-sustained VT.  She has atypical chest discomfort precipitated by emotional stress only.
As mentioned about there was no evidence of coronary artery disease on her CTCA back in 2018.

Plan:

														She is happy to retrial a low dose Beta blocker (Atenolol 25mg once a day), for ectopy suppression.
If she does not tolerate this, I would grateful if you could switch her to Verapamil 80mg bd.
I will organise an exercise stress echocardiogram to exclude any inducible arrhythmia.
I will also organise a cardiac MRI to ensure that there is no myocardial pathology that may account for her ventricular ectopy.
I will see her in 4 months.
Thank you kindly for your continuing care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Betts,

														

														

														RE:	DAVID DIAMOND		DOB:	17/05/1951	UR:	8058115

																					

														

														

														Medical Issues:

														Previous MI, RCA territory scar, out of hospital cardiac arrest x 2 (scar related VT /VF).
Permanent atrial fibrillation.
Previous lower limb DVT.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
GORD.

Medications:

														Carvedilol 18.75mg mane, 25mg nocte, Dapagliflozin 10mg daily, Entresto 49/51mg 1 tablet bd, Esomeprazole 20mg daily, Rosuvastatin 40mg daily, Rivaroxaban 20mg daily.
Thank you very much for your referral for consideration of VT ablation.
David is a 71-year-old gentleman who has ischaemic heart disease with a current ejection fraction of 30%.
He has had 2 out of hospital cardiac arrests due to VT that deteriorated into VF post shocks.
He is currently on maximum tolerated medical therapy.

In October he presented with sudden onset VT after a PVC into a monomorphic VT for which he had 1 set of ATPs which slight accelerated the VT but the morphology remains consistent, then he had an ICD shock that had put him into VF and required ICD second shock that brought him back into sinus rhythm.
In between the episodes, he has NYHA class I symptoms.
He is tolerating his medical therapy very well.
There are no current symptoms suggestive of angina or heart failure.
He claims compliance with the medications.
I have discussed with him treatment modalities to reduce the risk of further ventricular tachycardia.
We talked about Amiodarone therapy versus cardiac catheter ablation.
Pros and cons of both approaches were discussed.
The procedure was discussed in detail with him.

There is around a 3% risk of any major complication, including vascular complications, pericardial effusion, heart attack, stroke, need for open heart surgery, and a small risk of death was discussed.
He has done his background reading and he is very keen to have the cardiac ablation performed.
I will organise this for him at the PA Hospital.
Of note, I have noticed that ECG back in October showed that he was paced all the time.
His previous ICD checks have shown that he was pacing in RV up to 65%, although last time if was changed to  VVI 50 and that has reduced his pacing burden to 30%.
I would ask you to keep an eye on this and if his LV function further deteriorates and if this is in the context of pacing burden of 40% or more, then he should be considered for an upgrade to CRT.
In this view, also, Amiodarone might not be very beneficial as this will increase his pacing burden.
He will continue to have regular follow up with yourself.
He will also get a focused echocardiogram to exclude LV thrombus prior to the VT ablation.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	DENA DIAZ SAENZ		DOB:	27/02/1977		UR:	2168786

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Dena a 45-year-old female, I performed a quick phone review on today.
As you are aware, Dr Ahmad saw her in clinic in November last year and planned on organising a transthoracic echocardiogram to exclude any structural causes for her syncope.
I am pleased to report that her echocardiogram was largely normal, with a mildly dilated left ventricle and an ejection fraction of 57%.
She also had a mildly dilated aortic root and proximal ascending aorta that will require a repeat echocardiogram in 12 months to make sure the dimensions are stable.

Given that now we have excluded a structural cause for her syncope, after discussion with Dena, we have decided to book her in for a category 2 EP study +/-  loop recorder implantation for further assessment of her syncope   In the meantime, I have reiterated that she should not be driving.
We will touch base with Dena once her EP study has been performed.
We will keep you updated of any progress.
In the meantime, please do not hesitate in contacting us should you have any questions or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Steinorht





														RE:	RHIANNON DIONYSIUS	DOB:	31/10/1994	UR:	342597

																					

														

														

														Past Medical History:
# ?POTS
   - does not meet criteria for POTS
   - previously recommended minimum fluid intake of 2L per day aiming for 3L daily 

														     and also to consider adding salt to her food to assist with elevating her blood 

														     pressure slightly
# Fibromyalgia
# Anxiety/Depression
# CVID
   - known to immunology PAH
# Iron deficiency
# Chronic fatigue syndrome
# Dry eyes
# Corneal hyperalgesia
# Possible hypermobility syndrome 
# Non-allergic rhinosinusitis
# IBS
# central pain sensitization (under care rheumatologist)

Medications:
Lovan 40mg, supplements, CyA eye drops, lubricating drops, naltrexone, PRN diazepam

														

														I had the pleasure of speaking with Rhiannon Dionysius in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
This appointment was performed as a telephone consultation.
She is known to this clinic after being referred initially for investigation and management of possible postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS).

As  you know, during our last clinic appointment in May 2022, Rhiannon’s condition was discussed with Dr Cox, and it was his opinion that Rhiannon’s symptoms do not satisfy the strict definition of postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome.
Nevertheless, it was recommended that Rhiannon increase her fluid intake to approximately 2 to 3 litres per day with addition salt to her food in an attempt to increase her blood pressure.

In this regard, Rhiannon has not been able to quite reach the recommended levels of fluid intake, drinking approximately 1 to 2 litres of fluid a day, but she is adding salt to her food as recommended.
She tells me that she has been having ongoing mild symptoms of dizziness, most notable during postural change.
Fortunately, she has not had a syncopal episode.

At our last clinic appointment, to be comprehensive, we arranged for Rhiannon to have an outpatient transthoracic echocardiogram to exclude structural heart disease as a potential contributor to her symptoms.
Unfortunately, Rhiannon was not aware of the appointment that was made for her today and missed her booking.
She has been quite occupied with her other medical conditions, which is completely reasonable.
During our consultation today, I reiterated the recommendation of increasing her fluid intake to at least 2 litres per day with ongoing additional salt to her food.
Furthermore, I have suggested that she consider a regular exercise program that may include activities, such as rowing – whether this be on a body of water or on a rowing machine.
Both are potentially beneficial.

With respect to excluding structural heart disease, I have asked that she speak with you at her next consultation to arrange a transthoracic echocardiogram at a more local facility as the PA Hospital is now not very convenient for her to travel to after her recent move.
At this time, I will not make another appointment to see Rhiannon.

However, should the transthoracic echocardiogram reveal unexpected structural abnormality, we would be happy to receive a new referral from you to address any issues uncovered by the transthoracic echocardiogram.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Ms Dionysius.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Predrag,





RE:	ZORAN DJURIC		DOB:	07/03/1961		UR:	2179034

							





Diagnoses:

Recurrent persistent atrial fibrillation.
Ischaemic heart disease.
3 vessel coronary artery disease on angiography May 2022.
For initial medical management.
Severe left ventricular dysfunction August 2021 (EF 31%), improved to 45% March 2022.

Medications:

Amiodarone 100mg once a day, Atorvastatin 40mg daily, Entresto 97/103mg BD, Metoprolol XL 190mg daily, Rivaroxaban 20mg daily.
I saw Mr Djuric after his previous care at the QEII Hospital.
Zoran is a 61 year old man who presented with persistent atrial fibrillation with severe left ventricular dysfunction along with palpitations and breathlessness.
He was cardioverted to sinus rhythm and is being maintained on Amiodarone.
He feels much improved in sinus.
He was incidentally found to have multivessel coronary disease, though this is for medical management in the first instance.
He is currently walking with no chest pain or shortness of breath on exertion.
On examination his heart rate was 70bpm and regular and his blood pressure was 130/70mmHg.
An ECG confirmed sinus rhythm with a normal axis.
His PR interval was 184ms, QRS 118ms, and QTc 458ms.
Zoran is maintaining sinus rhythm albeit on Amiodarone at this time.
We have discussed the risk of dosing duration dependence side effects with this agent, though also its efficacy.
I have spoken with him regarding an AF ablation is the most successful treatment for atrial fibrillation.

We have discussed risks including bleeding and vascular access issues as well as less frequent, though more serious risks such as stoke, atrioesophageal fistula or serious damage to cardiac structures.
Zoran would like to go onto an AF ablation, though he understands we have a significant waiting list for this.
I have continued his Amiodarone at this time.
He has ongoing review schedule at QEII Hospital, though I will also arrange a review for him in 12 months.

Yours sincerely,

														Problem List:

														Coronary artery disease.

It was a pleasure to catch up with Tahia in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
Since her acute presentation in 2021, she has generally been well.
She certainly has no cardiac symptoms and has remained fairly stable.
Unfortunately, she recently was diagnosed with papillary carcinoma of the thyroid which has been operated with a total thyroidectomy being done at the PA Hospital recently.
She is now more than 12 months with her dual antiplatelet therapy.
I would be happy for the Brilinta to be discontinued and she can stay on low dose Aspirin 100mg daily.
Her Lipitor dose can also be adjusted.
I have given her a request form for a repeat lipid profile to be done.

Her total cholesterol at the time of her acute presentation was only marginally elevated and I would suggest, if the total cholesterol is less than 4mmol/L, and the LDL cholesterol less than 2mmol/L, you could easily halve the dose of Atorvastatin and further monitor her lipid profile.
Her Metoprolol 25mg twice daily should continue.
I have not made any routine review appointments for Tahia to return back and asked her to keep a regular follow up with yourself.
I would be happy to see her at your request in the future, if you feel that is necessary.

Dear Dr Houghton





RE:	BRIAN JAMES DORE	DOB:	31/08/1951	UR:	225918

								



														Problem list:

														Coronary artery disease.
Coronary angiography confirming three vessel coronary artery disease.
Recent surgical revascularisation by Dr Wingchi Lo at the Princess Alexandra Hospital.
LIMA-LAD; SVG-OM1 on 14 December 2021.
Satisfactory LV remodelling post operatively (ejection fraction 55%).

Current Medications:

														Aspirin 100 mg daily, Metoprolol 25 mg daily, Rosuvastatin 40 mg daily.
Brian seems to be progressing quite satisfactorily.
He has returned back for an annual review this afternoon.
He certainly has no symptoms of angina.
His exercise tolerance is normal.
He did show me his stenotomy scar which seems to have healed quite satisfactorily.
The lower end of the scar does have a minor degree keloid formation.
He was reporting some symptoms of discomfort in the lower part of that scar when he exercises.
Very likely this is related to the soft tissue adhesions, and I have encouraged him to continue with regular exercise.
His repeat echocardiogram that was done in May last year, shows normal left ventricular size and function.
He does have some wall motion abnormalities in the inferior inferoseptal area, but the ejection fraction has improved to 55%.
His right heart function is normal.
I have explained these results to Brian and reassured him that he should continue with his current medications.
He keeps a regular watch on his blood pressure, which I have encouraged him to do once a fortnight.

Could I request you help to monitor his lipid profile on an annual basis and adjust the statin dose as needed with a total cholesterol target of less than 3.8mmol/L and an LDL cholesterol of less than 1.8mmol/L.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Donna,



														RE:	AZEEZ DOSHO		DOB:	08/05/1962		UR:	1061675

																					

														

														Thank you for asking us to see Mr Dosho.
He speaks reasonable English, but unfortunately, we did not arrange an Arabic interpreter in advance.
I used the Interpreter Service over the phone.
Mr Dosho tells me that he has left sided chest pain which radiates to the left arm.
It can last hours at a time but is predominantly exertional.

He went on to have a myocardial perfusion scan, which did not show a high-risk test, ie, there were no large wall motion abnormalities or perfusion defects, but he did get chest pain and there was some ST segment change.
Mr Dosho has a moderate family history of coronary disease with his brother having a heart attack in his 60s and his father died in his 70s.
Unfortunately, he has been a smoker until recently.
He has hypercholesterolaemia and is now on therapy of Rosuvastatin 20mg a day.
I note that his most recent LDL cholesterol is 1.3mmol/L, which is perfect.
He is also taking Aspirin.
Today there is no cardiac murmur, the chest is clear, no elevation of the JVP or oedema.
His blood pressure was satisfactory at 136/74mmHg, his pulse was 80bpm.
His 12 Lead ECG was unremarkable, a heart rate of 90bpm.
I have advised Mr Dosho that he must stop smoking completely.
My recommendation is that he also stops vaping.
I have asked him to continue the Rosuvastatin and Aspirin.
I have commenced Atenolol 25mg in the morning and asked him to see you in 2 to 3 weeks for up titration to 50mg a day.
Given that the stress test is not ‘high risk’, he will have an initial trial of medical therapy.
If that is successful, we will continue to manage him medically.
If he continues to have chest pain or there is any change in his symptoms, we will offer him angiography.
He says his wife speaks good English and he will not need an interpreter if she comes next time.
I have suggested that he do so, because if we want to discuss coronary angiography, she will need to be informed.
Thank you for involving us in his care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Mark,





RE:	KENNETH DOWLING	DOB:	09/10/1945	UR:	940129

							



														

														It was a pleasure to catch up with Ken in the clinic today.
As you know we see him for an ejection fraction of 35% with  moderate MR.
He has a lot of back issues.
He was quite breathless walking in today.
Having said that,  he does not have a  lot of objective signs of heart failure.
His blood pressure was 95/60mmHg, and his heart rate was 72bpm and regular.
His heart sounds were dual, and the chest just showed some dull inspiratory wheeze.
His jugular venous pressure was not elevated and there was no peripheral oedema.
The most striking finding was a lot of upper airways sounds.
It sounded like he needed to clear his throat, although  he was not really aware of this.
I also heard some borborygmi radiating up from his abdomen, whilst inspecting his chest.
I do not know whether he is suffering from chronic aspiration from oesophageal dysmotility, but he denied a chronic cough.
He is not compliant with his fluid restriction and his wife actually said he is drinking all day.
He is on the same medications, and I think given that there are no signs of heart failure today and he is euvolaemic, we should continue them the way they are.
I will see him again in 12 months with an echocardiogram.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Khan,





														RE:	ELAINE R. DOWNS	DOB:	16/05/1942	UR:	8116301

																					

														

														

														Elaine was admitted here in January this year with neck pain and palpitations in the setting of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
There were some initial concerns about ischaemic ECG changes but her troponins were negative.

This occurs on a background of:	

														Mild coronary artery disease on angiogram 2017.
Previous TIA.
Bilateral DVTs on Apixaban.
Sinusitis.
COPD.
OSA – unable to tolerate CPAP.
Hypertension.

Elaine was discharged on Apixaban 2.5mg bd, Rosuvastatin 40mg, Metoprolol 50mg bd, Isosorbide Mononitrate 120mg, Frusemide 40mg, Levothyroxine 100mcg, Esomeprazole 20mg, Domperidone 10mg BD, Trelegy Ellipita and Ventolin.
Elaine underwent an outpatient myocardial perfusion on 24.012.2023, which showed no evidence of significantly reduced coronary flow reserve in response to adenosine.
I caught up with Elaine via phone consultation today.
She has returned to her home in Burleigh Waters.
I also spoke to her daughter in law, Lauren Downs, who was our first contact given Elaine had been staying with her in Brisbane.
I explained the MPS was negative.
Elaine reports she has been tired since returning home.
She has had two episodes of mild neck pain since discharge, both of which have been self-limiting.
Elaine would like to follow up with her previously known private Cardiologist, Dr Gangasandra, closer to home.

If she continues to experience very symptomatic episodes of AF, then I have suggested that she might consider antiarrhythmic therapy for symptom control, but the risks would need to be balanced against the benefits given her age and comorbidities.
I have not made a routine appointment to see her again, but please feel free to contact me in the future with any new issues or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Weslyn,

														

														

														RE:	TIMOTHY R. DURHAM	DOB:	15/06/1961	UR:	893416

																					

														

														

														Issues:
# Atrial fibrillation
   - refractory to rate control
# Chronic kidney disease
   - secondary to IgA nephropathy.

- meant to be on 1.5L fluid restriction
   - Failed renal transplant
   - imminently starting haemodialysis (TBH, Dr. Alice Lee)
# Hypertension.
# Type II diabetes mellitus.

# TIA
# DVT in 2016.
# Multiple skin cancers.
# Gout.

Medications:
Mycophenolate 500mg bd, Cyclosporin 75mg bd, Prednisolone 7mg daily, Bactrim DS ½ tablet once a day, Apixaban 2.5mg BD started today, Prazosin 0.5mg TDS, Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg once a day, Metoprolol 100mg BD, Diltiazem 240mg daily (intended to have been increased to 360mg, but unable to source), Rosuvastatin 5mg once a day, Aranesp, Sodibic 840mg BD, Calcitriol 0.25mcg BD, Allopurinol 300mg mane, Acitretin 10mg mane, Duodart 1 tablet mane, Pantoprazole 40mg nocte.
I had the pleasure of reviewing Timothy Durham in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today, accompanied by his wife.
He is known to this clinic for atrial fibrillation that his refractory to medical therapy.

He has been seen in relatively quick succession in this clinic by Dr Cox, as well as one of my colleagues and has been up titrated on his rate control but has been unable to source the maximum of Diltiazem at 360mg extended release daily.
Therefore, he has continued on Diltiazem 240mg extended release daily and Metoprolol 100mg twice daily.

As you know, at the last clinic appointment at the end of December, my colleague started Apixaban at 2.5mg twice daily as therapeutic anticoagulation as it was yet unclear at the time as to when the portacath and haemodialysis were meant to begin.

Timothy has updated me today, that he has seen the Toowoomba Renal Team and they plan to insert the portacath next week or Thursday, followed by an immediate haemodialysis session for approximately 2 hours.
He will then continue on haemodialysis via the portacath twice a week.
It is hoped that a fistula can be created in February and then used for ongoing haemodialysis 2 months thereafter.
Peri-procedurally, Timothy  has been asked to withhold his Apixaban for at least 48 hours prior to the insertion of the portacath.
I will leave the management of the therapeutic anticoagulation to the Renal Team but would suggest ongoing therapeutic anticoagulation when it is safe to resume.
Clinically, Timothy has been doing relatively well from a cardiac perspective.
He does not experience any orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea.
Nor does he experience any chest discomfort.
Unfortunately, a as a result of the increased weight from the fluid accumulation in his lower limbs, he suffered a fall, resulting in significant bruising and multiple skin tears.
These were dressed today by his wife and so I did not disturb them.
He also continues to be able to walk at least 300 metres at a slow pace, without significant difficulties.
As you know, Timothy’s most recent transthoracic echocardiogram was done in November last year.
This study was performed in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and in that setting had a mildly dilated left ventricle with moderate global systolic dysfunction.
His LVEF was approximately 35 to 40% by visual estimation at the time.
His right ventricle was normal in size but had mildly reduced systolic function.
There was severe functional mitral regurgitation in the setting of fluid overload.
There was elevated  pulmonary pressures with an RVSP of 44mmHg.
There was also a dilated aortic root with a trans sinus dimension measured at 40mm.
On examination today, Timothy appeared well and was speaking in phrases.
He was in good spirits during this consultation.
His blood pressure was 105/70mmHg on his left arm.
His heart rate was irregularly irregular, which corresponded with atrial fibrillation on his ECG, with a heart rate of approximately 107bpm.
There was significant pitting oedema to the knees bilaterally.
As mentioned, there were multiple dressed skin tears in both his upper limbs and lower limbs.
With respect to the management of his atrial fibrillation, I have provided Timothy with a script for Diltiazem modified release at 180mg to be taken daily.
This is in addition to his 240mg dose to make up the intended 360mg total dose, as Timothy has found it difficult to source the 360mg modified release dose.
I have advised that should he obtain the 360mg dose to not take either the 240mg or 180mg doses as that would  exceed the maximum recommended daily dose.

As Timothy approaches euvolaemia after starting him with dialysis, it may be that his atrial fibrillation burden and/or rate will improve and so his Diltiazem dose should be adjusted based on the changes after initiation of dialysis.
I ask the Renal Team at Toowoomba please adjust the Diltiazem accordingly.
As mentioned, I would recommend therapeutic anticoagulation to continue long term, but in the peri-procedural period, I've deferred to the arrangement made by the Renal Team.

With respect to his functional mitral regurgitation and ongoing cardiac care, in discussion with Dr Cox, we would recommend considering transferring his cardiology care to Toowoomba in order to consolidate his medical care teams and also for Timothy’s convenience as he lives much closer to Toowoomba than to Brisbane.
Ultimately, the assessment of the severity of the functional mitral regurgitation must be after euvolaemic is achieved.

If Toowoomba Cardiology feel that, after haemodialysis has started and Timothy has reached euvolaemic state, his function mitral regurgitation remains severe and would like intervention to be considered, please re-refer to us at that time.
For now, to allow for the appropriate referrals to be made to Cardiology, we will make a back up appointment to review Timothy in approximately 6  to 8 weeks.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Durham.

Yours sincerely,

8.

NKDA
9.

Lives with husband; Independent ADLs

Medications – States similar to previous
Aspirin 100mg od
Irbesartan 300mg nocte
Metoprolol 50mg bd
Lercanidipine 20mg nocte
Atorvastatin 40mg mane
Tamoxifen 20mg mane
Metformin XR 1g mane
Gliclazide MR 60mg mane
Rabeprazole 20mg mane
Thyroxine 50mcg mane
Symbicort
Denosumab s/c q6monts
Ca2+/Mg2+; Macuvision; Gaviscon
Eliquis 2.5mg bd

														

														She tells me that she is going very well.
She gets occasional discomfort  under her right should blade.
She recalls that she did have that similar symptom at the time of myocardial infarction, but also had anterior chest pressure.
(The discomfort sporadic and is more a nuisance and often goes away if she stops thinking about it).There is no recurrence of this anterior chest discomfort.
She has no exertional symptoms, she denies any shortness of breath, dizziness or syncope.
She did recall the events of March 2022, where the Metoprolol was stopped in preparation for a myocardial perfusion scan.
It is unclear as to why the MPS was order.
She developed palpitations, the Metoprolol was recommenced, the MPS was eventually cancelled regardless, but she does not know who did that.
She has had no further palpitations since.

Assessment:

														She does not have any convincing recurrent angina.

If she does have recurrence of myocardial ischaemia, it would preferentially be medically managed in the first instance, given her age, need for anticoagulation for stroke prevent with concomitant antiplatelet which does not carry an insignificant bleeding risk.
She however does require review of the Apixaban dose, the Aspirin can be ceased as she is well beyond 12 months of her myocardial infarction and intervention.

Plan

														I would be grateful if you could review her Apixaban dose, the current 2.5mg BD dose is recommended only if they have 2 out of 3 criteria of age above 80 years of age, weight less than 60 kilograms and serum creatinine more than 133.
I would be grateful if you could check the status of this and alter the dose as appropriate.
The Aspirin can be stopped.
She is to remain on the rest of her medications.
I have not made any further appointments to see her at this stage.
Thank you kindly for your continuing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Problems:

														Long standing ischaemic cardiomyopathy with severe LV systolic dysfunction but stable symptoms.
Current LVEF around 20% with marked LV dilatation.
Class II NYHA dyspnoea.
CABG x 3 November 2017 with no angina.
AICD in situ with no therapies and awaiting generator change.
Colonic neoplasm under review.

Medications unchanged including:

														Dapagliflozin, Bisoprolol, Digoxin, Entresto, Spironolactone, Frusemide 40mg daily, Warfarin to keep INR between 2.0 and 3.0.
I saw Eric today.

He continues to enjoy his daily routines and works daily in his garage.
He may have overindulged in food over Christmas and his weight remains excessive.
On examination today he was warm and well perfused with a regular pulse at 70bpm and a blood pressure 100/65mmHg.
He had minimal peripheral oedema, a normal JVP and clear lungs.
His LV systolic function is around 20% with marked LV dilatation and mild to moderate MR.  His pulmonary pressures appear to be elevated.
I have made no changes to his medications.

It appears the introduction of SGLT2 inhibitor has stabilised his symptoms, however, there appears to be ongoing LV remodelling on his latest echocardiogram

														Dear Dr Heinricy,

														

														

														RE:	LENUTA ENACHE		DOB:	09/11/1958		UR:	693406

																					

														

														

														Diagnoses:

														Atrial fibrillation / atrial flutter / atrial tachycardia.
AF ablation – Dr Denman September 2019.
Attempted ablation for atypical atrial flutter / atrial tachycardia November 2021.
Recurrent atypical atrial flutter.
Treatment with Sotalol following by cardioversion.
For redo atypical flutter / atrial tachycardia ablation.
Sinus node dysfunction.
Pacemaker implanted at PA Hospital September 2021.
Hypertension.

Current Medications:

														Metoprolol 50mg bd, Apixaban 5mg bd, Nexium 20mg daily, Seretide inhaler.
It was a pleasure to review Lenuta in the Cardiology Arrhythmia Clinic.
She is a 64-year-old lady who had an AF ablation by Dr Denman in 2019.
She had presented to the PA Hospital in 2021, with sinus node dysfunction and a pacemaker was implanted.
A couple of months later she had an attempt at redo AF and atypical atrial flutter / AT ablation at TPCH with Dr Denman.
I understand that she had multiple atrial arrhythmias during the case, change from one to another, making it hard to map.
She had typical atrial flutter ablation, although the block could not be confirmed due to continuing atypical atrial flutters.
She was discharge home with Amiodarone treatment, but she has had multiple presentations to the PA Hospital and QEII Hospital with atrial arrhythmias, mainly atypical atrial flutter.
She has not tolerated Amiodarone very well and it has been stopped during her previous admission.
She is currently on Metoprolol 50mg bd.
She continues to have recurrent atrial arrhythmias and complains of shortness of breath and palpitations.
Her heart rate initially when she came to the clinic was 180bpm with the clinic nurse.
She had an ECG done today, which has shown atypical atrial flutter with a ventricular rate of 100bpm.
QRS is 90ms.
I first discussed with her that she could have regular follow up with Dr Denman or at the PA Hospital Cardiology Arrhythmia Clinic.
As she lives in Bethania now & she would prefer to have regular appointments here.
I have discussed with Lenuta treatment options.
I have discussed with her changing her Metoprolol to Sotalol and perform a cardioversion.
We also discussed an attempt at redo atrial flutter / ablation with the help of a multipolar catheter.
The pros and cons of both were discussed.
In the first instance we decided to have treatment with Sotalol and cardioversion & if she maintains sinus rhythm and tolerates Sotalol, then we will leave it at that.
If there is further recurrence or if she did not tolerate Sotalol, then we will attempt redo ablation.
I will review hr in 3 months after the cardioversion.
She will also get an echocardiogram performed as well.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Kramer,





RE:	GAYE L. ENGEMAN		DOB:	22/03/1949		UR:	640204

							



														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Bicuspid aortic valve disease with symptomatic severe aortic stenosis.
Patient aware of need to inform first degree relatives (siblings and children) to be screened for bicuspid aortic valve disease and aortopathy.
Non-obstructive coronary artery disease on CT coronary angiogram.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Impaired fasting glucose.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Other Conditions:

														Anxiety.
Primary hypothyroidism.
Chronic kidney disease.
Borderline osteopenia.
Female pattern hair loss.
Post-menopausal on hormone replacement therapy.
Primary hypoparathyroidism.

Medications:

														Rosuvastatin 20mg daily, Minoxidil as directed, Telmisartan 80mg daily, Calcitriol 0.25mcg daily, Calcium Carbonate 300mg daily, Thyroxine 75mcg daily, Topical Estradiol 0.75mg a directed.
I reviewed Gaye Engeman in the Heart Valve Clinic at the PA Hospital today.
She attended the appointment with her husband.
Gaye has a bicuspid aortic valve with haemodynamically significant stenosis.
Overall, she probably  has severe stenotic physiology.
Her echocardiographic images from a repeat study performed here at the PA Hospital were reviewed.
The echocardiogram report from Redland Heart Centre was also reviewed.
She has also had a CT coronary angiogram and CT aortic study.
She has non-obstructive coronary artery atheroma and is on statin therapy already.
Her symptoms are related to dyspnoea and chest discomfort which can be at rest but also with exertion.
Some of her pain is likely not cardiac.
At the same time, I suspect she also has symptoms related to aortic valve disease.
I have counselled her today around avoiding deliberate exercise and if she feels short of breath or uncomfortable performing an activity, to sit down and have a glass of water.
She drinks little in the way of alcohol and she is a lifelong non-smoker.
On examination, features are consistent with at least moderate aortic stenosis.

Heart 



RE:	GAYE L. ENGEMAN		DOB:	22/03/1949		UR:	640204

														

														sounds are dual, with a 3/6 ejection systolic murmur to the carotids with a reduction in carotid pulse upstroke and volume.
Lung fields are clear and there is no pitting peripheral oedema.
Her 12 Lead ECG shows sinus rhythm at 79bpm.
I had a detailed discussion with Gaye regarding her diagnosis.

Firstly, I discussed the importance of Gaye speaking to her family members including all brothers and sisters and all children, regarding the need for them to onward referred to a Cardiologist for screening for bicuspid aortic valve disease and aortopathy.
I also counselled Gaye around the importance of avoiding deliberate exercise and also when to call for help.
Gaye and her husband were educated that should she have any sudden change in her symptoms, (chest pain, increased shortness of breath or fainting / near fainting), to call 000 and call the hospital.

I explained to Gaye that given her valve morphology and her relatively young age, she would be best served by surgical aortic valve replacement, of course pending the opinion of a Cardiac Surgeon, regarding her suitability.
While specific risks of undergoing surgical aortic valve replacement will be discussed by the Cardiac Surgical Team with Gaye.
We had a general discussion around what this involves.
It was discussed that without a surgical intervention, Gaye’s risk of heart failure or death in the next 2 to 3 years would be 50% or more.
It was discussed that with aortic valve surgery she is likely to do well.

We did discuss the 2 to 3% risk of significant life altering complications that can include disabling stroke resulting in blindness, nursing home placement, inability to walk or talk, permanent disability and death, in addition to the risks of surgery that can include blood clots, nerve damage, infection, permanent disability, heart attack and death.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Onward referral to Cardiothoracic Surgical Unit at the PA Hospital regarding potential suitability for surgical aortic valve replacement (referral form submitted).
Gaye and her husband are aware, that should she have an change in her symptoms (chest pain, increased shortness of breath or fainting / near fainting) to call 000 and attend the hospital.

Gaye and her husband are aware that they need to communicate with Gaye’s first-degree relatives (siblings and children) regarding their need for ongoing onward referral for Cardiac evaluation for occult bicuspid aortic valve disease and aortopathy.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor,





														RE:	MARK EVANS		DOB:	07/09/1977		UR:	824684

																					

														

														

														Past History:

														Multifocal atrial tachycardia with AV node ablation at 15 years of age and permanent pacemaker since.
Fourth generator replacement since initial implant.
Multiple ablations in the past for multifocal atrial tachycardia, atrial flutter in June 2014 achieved sinus rhythm.
Previously had stenotomy resection for atrial arrhythmia focus at the age of 15 years.
Previous impaired ventricular function ?secondary to pacemaker induced cardiomyopathy and pacemaker pocket infection, admitted under cardiology 23.11.2020, with extraction at TPCH and reimplantation.
Recent admission with recurrent atrial tachycardia and possibly tachycardia induced cardiomyopathy.

Echocardiogram performed in December 2022, showed mildly dilated left ventricle with mild global systolic dysfunction, left ventricular ejection fraction 45% by visual estimation, dilated right ventricle, preserved systolic function, mild mitral regurgitation, moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation.

Permanent pacemakers check on 24.01.2023, 97% RA paced and 100% ventricular paced changed from DDD to DDDI non tracking mode to non-track atrial tachycardias and a non-sustained ventricular tachycardia at 10 beats on 20.01.2023 for 2 seconds at 9:40 in day.
The patient had no syncope, no presyncope, no palpitations and was unaware.
Mark is coping well with the change in pacing programs, and it is a non-tracking mode, so he does not present with atrial tachycardia sustained.
He is currently medication on 10mg of Bicor, 10mg of Perindopril and 20mg of Xarelto.
I am pleased with his progress.
The non-sustained VT we will observe currently.
He is playing basketball and this style of exercise is not good for him and we had a discussion on the day.
He will try to modify his activities, although would like to still play competitive basketball.
He is driving and he can currently do so, he will behave in a responsible manner.
Should he have any syncope, presyncope of palpitations he would not drive.
I have organised to review him in 6 months with a transthoracic echocardiogram.
The other options is to consider a repeat electrophysiological study with radiofrequency ablation in the effort to try and reprogram him to DDDR.
However, he is current performing all the activities he would like, and he is asymptomatic.
Many thanks for your ongoing care of the patient.
If there are any problems, please do not hesitate to contact me.

Yours sincerely,

CABG X 2 (LIMA to LAD; SVG to OM) 2010.
NSTEMI 08/2019.
DES X 2 to LMCA / LCx chronic total occlusion 09/2019.
Normal left ventricular function (LVEF 65%).

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Clopidogrel 75mg daily (cease), Amlodipine 10mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Esomeprazole 20mg daily, Folic Acid 0.5 tablet daily, Metoprolol 50mg bd, Perindopril 5mg daily, Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily.
It was a pleasure to see Bill and Denise.
Bill is now over 3 years since chronic total occlusion PCI of his left circumflex artery, and I am pleased to report he has not experienced any exertional dyspnoea or angina.
He continues to do fairly vigorous exercise such as boxing and skipping, and I have encouraged him to walk a little bit more, aiming for 5 times a week if he can.
His blood pressures were a little labile recently but have settled to the 120 to 130mmHg systolic range and thus his regimen above remains appropriate.
He does have an ejection systolic murmur, consistent with the sclerosed valve he had a few years ago.
I have provided Bill with a lipid profile request today.
Please add Ezetimibe 10mg daily if his LDL is >1.5mmol/L.
I have also ceased his Clopidogrel given he is over 3 years since stenting, but he understands he must continue his Aspirin daily uninterrupted.
I will see Bill in 1 year with an echocardiogram, but please let me know if there are issues in the interim.

														        severe (>75%) stenosis; No residual PDA shunt
    b. TTE 30.8.2021 – Normal LV size and LVEF 50-55%; Normal RV size and 

														        systolic function; Mild AR; Mild MR; Trivial pericardial effusion; No residual PDA 

														        shunt
     c. DSE 10.5.2022 – Normal resting LV systolic function; No inducible 

														         ischemia

Background:
1.

Heart surgery at 3yoa TPCH - Likely PDA repair 
2.

PVD
    a. Reduced/delayed left radial pulse and LUL BP – Occluded proximal left 

														        subclavian artery (~8mm) with distal recanalization on CTCA 13.9.2021
    b. CDS 15.8.2022 (Facial numbness) – Right carotid/proximal ICA plaque with 

														        6x4mm mobile thrombus – Rx DAPT by Vascular Surg PAH
    c. CTA 17.8.2022 – CTO left subclavian artery with left vertebral steal; Non 

														        calcified mural thrombus / atheromatous plaque within each carotid bulb with an 

														        exophytic appearance on the right; No high-grade carotid stenosis
    d. Repeat CDS 29.11.2022 - <50% right CCA/ICA/ECA plaque; Left <50% ICA 

														        and >50% ECA stenosis
3.

Hyperlipidaemia ?FH (Total chol 8.3, LDL 5.74 14.4.2021)

Hearing impairment

    a. TTE 5.2.2019 – Normal LV size and systolic function (LVEF 61%); Normal RV 

														        size and systolic function; No significant functional valvular abnormalities
    b. PPM check 3.11.2020 – 1 x 9 beat episode of high V-rate 174bpm ?Run of 

														        NSVT; Asymptomatic; Essentially 100% V-pace
    c. TTE 13.1.2021 - Normal LV size and LVEF 55-60%; Normal RV size and 

														        function; Mild MR; Mild-moderate TR 

2.

Recurrent runs of NSVT on PPM interrogation
    a. PPM check 3.11.2020 – 9 beat episode of high V-rate 174bpm ?Run of NSVT
    b. PPM check 4.11.2022 - 9 beat NSVT 192bpm
    c. Latest PPM check 3.11.2022 – 19 beats NSVT at 161bpm; Asymptomatic 

3.

Stable CAD (Investigations performed following initial NSVT detected at device 

														    interrogation 3.11.2020)
    a. CTCA 26.2.2021 – CAC 380.5 (75-90th percentile); pLAD calcified plaque 

														        causing moderate (50-69%) stenosis (Significant blooming artefact); mLCx 

														        (Dominant) non-calcified non-obstructive plaque; RCA no hemodynamically 

														        significant stenosis
    b. MPS 25.5.2021 – No chest pain; No ischemic ECG changes; LVEF 67%; Fixed 

														        defect in the mid-anteroseptum with normal wall motion (Unusual 

														        subendocardial infarction is not excluded); NO evidence of impaired coronary 

														        flow reserve

4.

Admission RLH 8.8.2021 with acute dizziness ?Self-resolved vertigo
    a. MRI brain 5.11.2021 – No old or acute infarction


														

														

														

														

														




RE:	JOY L. FEHRES	DOB:	04/04/1949	UR:	8023885

														

														Background:

?Hypertension
2.

OSA

4.

Renal cyst

7.

8.

Medications:

														Clinically she has been reasonably well.
She did have COVID back in October last year but has recovered.
She denies any chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, or syncope.
She still has runs of non-sustained VT on her pacemaker interrogation.
On examination her blood pressure was 125/80mmHg, heart rate was 60bpm and regular, JVP is not elevated, and chest is clear.

Assessment:

														She has recurrence of asymptomatic non-sustained VT.  We know that she has coronary artery disease but had no documented ischaemia on a myocardial perfusion scan.
These were done for investigation of non-sustained VT initially.
However, there was the previously noted fixed perfusion defect on the MPS in the mid anteroseptum, back on 25.05.2021  which was of uncertain significance.

Plan:

														I have increased the Metoprolol further to 75mg twice a day.
I will get a cardiac MRI to exclude any infiltrative process.
I will also request an opinion from my Electrophysiology colleagues regarding her arrhythmia.
I will see her again in 6 months with a transthoracic echocardiogram.
Thank you kindly for your continuing care.

RE:	ADRIAN FIELD		DOB:	07/12/1972		UR:	032928

								

	



Thank you for your ongoing care of Adrian, a 50-year-old gentleman known to Dr Ng for atypical chest pain in the context of multiple risk factors for coronary artery disease, including morbid obesity, type II diabetes, dyslipidaemia, ex-smoking, and strong family history of premature cardiovascular disease.

In the context of his risk factors, Dr Ng had organised a CTCA that, although has ruled out any haemodynamically significant coronary artery disease,  has unfortunately picked up bilateral pulmonary nodules concerning for metastatic disease.
I have seen Adrian today and broken this news to him.
I have also organised for him to have an urgent staging CT via Qld X-Ray to look for a primary lesion and given him a blood form to look at his haematinics, tumour markers, LDH and blood film.
I would appreciate if you could urgently review him and chase up these investigations.
He will subsequently need a referral to the appropriate specialty pending the above investigations.
From a cardiac perspective he does have a calcium score placing him in the 75th percentile, so he should have lifelong aggressive risk factor management and ongoing statin therapy.
He does not require Aspirin.
Thank you for taking my call and for urgently seeing Adrian later this week.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Kirat-Curtis,





														RE:	STELLA FISCHER		DOB:	30/06/1955		UR:	8111202

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Stella, a lovely 67-year-old female I had the pleasure of reviewing in Dr Hill Cardiology Outpatient Clinic as a post discharge appointment.
She was accompanied by her daughter.
As you are aware, Stella was admitted under our care in September, with AF with RVR and mild fluid overload.

She was discharged on Digoxin 250mcg, Metoprolol 50mg twice daily, Spironolactone 25mg mane, Irbesartan 300mg mane, Atorvastatin 40mg, Escitalopram 20mg, Thyroxine 150mcg, Oxycodone modified release, Paracetamol slow release, Warfarin variable dosing, Temazepam as required, and Tramadol as required.
Her Hydrochlorothiazide was ceased during that admission; however, she tells me that you may have restarted this since.

Stella is unsure if she is still taking Spironolactone or not, however, from a cardiac perspective this would be beneficial, and I would appreciate it if you could look into it and make sure that she is reinstated on Spironolactone unless contraindicated.
Since discharge she has been doing very well with significant improved breathlessness.
She has minimal palpitations, and her heart rate is normally well controlled between 70 to 80bpm.
She has had no presyncope or syncope, nor has she had any further leg swelling.
Stella is describing some obstructive sleep apnoea symptoms; however, her daughter denies any apnoeic episodes.
She drinks 1 can of bourbon a day and 1 cup of coffee per day.
On examination today, her JVP was mildly elevated however she had no pitting oedema.
Her chest was clear on auscultation and her heart sounds were dual with no murmurs.
Her heart rate was 80bpm irregularly irregular.
Her ECG today was rate controlled atrial fibrillation at 76bpm with an isolated ventricular ectopic.
Our impression is that Stella has persistent atrial fibrillation on the background of morbid obesity and probable untreated sleep disorder breathing.

Our recommendations are:

														Continue Digoxin and Metoprolol at current doses.
Please recommence Spironolactone unless contraindicated.
Despite the Spironolactone, if she has episodes of shortness of breath on exertion or peripheral oedema, she could take Frusemide 20mg PRN.
Please organise for Stella to have a sleep study, as the management of this would be important in better controlling her atrial fibrillation.
Stella has recently had some supratherapeutic INRs and in this case, please consider referring her to the Warfarin Service for tighter control.
We will review her in 18 months with a repeat echocardiogram.
We would be happy to see her sooner should she run into any troubles, or you have any concerns.

Yours sincerely,
