Dear Dr Bhushal,





														RE:	CARMEL FISHER		DOB:	1/07/1971		UR:	913183

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Carmel in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today for cardiac screening in the context of her myotonic dystrophy.
I note that she currently mobilises using a wheelchair and her exercise tolerance is very limited.
She has also had significant weight loss recently, likely due to suboptimal intake, but has declined PEG feeds at this time.
She suffers from COPD, bronchiectasis, obstructive sleep apnoea, sleep hypoventilation due to myotonic dystrophy and GORD.
Her current medications as far as I can tell include Rivaroxaban 20mg, Digoxin 125mcg and Esomeprazole.
Carmel denies any chest pain or palpitations.
She has long standing dyspnoea.
She denies any family history of cardiac disease.
It seems she had some paroxysmal AF or atrial flutter back in 2017 during a long hospital admission including an ICU stay for respiratory issues.
Rivaroxaban and Digoxin were commenced during that admission.
She has had no bleeding issues on Rivaroxaban.
Today, ECG showed her to be in atrial flutter at 82bpm.
The last ECG on record was from August 2021, when she was in sinus rhythm.
Heart sounds were dual with no murmurs, she had no significant peripheral oedema and had some scattered creps on her chest.
An echocardiogram performed recently showed normal left and right ventricular size and systolic function with no significant functional valvular abnormality.
In summary, Carmel has rate controlled atrial flutter of which she is asymptomatic.
We discussed ongoing anticoagulation in the setting of her CHA2DS2-VASc score of 1.
Given she has been anticoagulated for over five years now with no major bleeding issues, she has elected to continue with this currently.
I will see Carmel in 12 months with a repeat echocardiogram but please feel free to contact me sooner with any new issues or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Day,





RE:	DAVID FISHER		DOB:	16/03/1945		UR:	325781

							



														Thank you so much for your kind referral of David whom I saw today 18.012.023.
He is a 77-year-old gentleman who has had multiple syncopal episodes and the last being in August 2022.
He has a past medical history of polymyalgia rheumatic and a recent diagnosis of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
His CHA2DS2-VASc is 2.
He is current medicated on Apixaban 5mg orally BD, Prednisolone has been ceased and his is Metoprolol 25mg orally BD.
He does not imbibe alcohol, partakes of 2 caffeinated beverages in the form of tea per day which is permissible, and he is a non-smoker.
In August 2022, he had palpitations in the early morning and got up from bed and had a presyncopal episode for 2 minutes and then had a syncopal episode.
He had diaphoresis and was nauseated.
He was on the floor, but only lost consciousness for seconds.
He was dehydrated at the time;  he had no epileptic form of movements and no amnesia and no tiredness post.

Prior to this he has had a 10-year history of postural hypotension and vasovagal syncope and it was also noted when he presented to hospital he was in atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.
He gets occasional postural symptoms independently of this.
Echocardiogram performed at the Redland Heart Centre on 24.05.2022, demonstrated normal left ventricular ejection fraction at 68%, normal right ventricular function and mild tricuspid regurgitation.
He has had no further episodes of atrial fibrillation or palpitations.
He has normal thyroid function, normal urea and electrolytes and other bloods.
His ECG today demonstrates sinus rhythm at a rate of 58bpm with no conduction disturbances.
It is likely he has had vasovagal in the setting of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and also concomitant postural hypertension complicated by dehydration.
I have informed him to acknowledge the prodrome and maintain his hydration and retain recumbency.
He can continue driving as he has long prodrome and he has never had an episode while seated.

I have listed him for an electrophysiological study +/- an internal loop recorder to establish a rhythm symptoms correlation and exclude any other possible causes such as brady or tachy arrhythmias, however, I these are unlikely, and I have organised to review him in 6 months.

RE:	DAVID FISHER		DOB:	16/03/1945		UR:	325781

														

														

														I would be happy to see him earlier should the need arise.
Many thanks for your ongoing care of the patient.

Yours sincerely,

														Background:

														Idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy.

Moderate to severe LV dysfunction, EF 30%.
Left bundle branch block on ECG.
Unable to tolerate cardiac MRI.
Unable to tolerate further up titration of medications.
Hashimoto’s thyroiditis.
Currently hypothyroid on Thyroxine.

Current Medications:

														Bicor 5mg nocte, Entresto 24/26mg BD, Thyroxine 100mcg, Sertraline 50mg, Spironolactone 125mg.
I had the pleasure of meeting Kelly in Dr Ahmad’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic after your referral.

As you mentioned on the referral, Kelly has moderate to severe LV dysfunction and an inability to further up titrate much in the way of heart failure medications, despite multiple attempts by both yourself and a Cardiologist in New South Wales.
It is postural hypotension mainly limiting the up titration.
As such her EF has not shown much in the way of improvement.
Her blood pressure today was 105/90mmHg, heart sounds were dual, and she was euvolaemic.
Her ECG shows sinus rhythm and a left bundle branch block.
She was seen alongside Dr Ahmad today.
We agree that she is a candidate for both a defibrillation and cardiac resynchronisation therapy given her wide QRS complex and reduced ejection fraction.
We will book her in for a CRT-D to be done over the next few months.

We have had a discussion, both regarding the aim of cardiac resynchronisation including, hopefully improving her ejection fraction and symptoms; as well as the benefits and pitfalls of having a defibrillator.
She has received some notes to read on this matter.
We will be in touch once she is booked for her procedure.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Sudherra,





														RE:	NICOLE FLUX		DOB:	10/11/1962		UR:	8111423

																					

														

														

														Diagnoses:

														Non-STEMI in October 2022.
Invasive coronary angiogram showed severe posterior left main stenosis which was treated with PCI.
Hypothyroidism secondary to Hashimoto’s disease.
Impaired glucose tolerance.
History of smoking.
Dyslipidaemia.
Carer for father-in-law and works as a part time hairdresser.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg, Clopidogrel 75mg for 12 months until 05.10.2023, Bisoprolol 5mg, Perindopril 5mg daily, Crestor 40mg, Ezetimibe 10mg, Paracetamol, Thyroxine 100mcg, GTN spray sublingual.
I reviewed Nicole in my Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
As you are aware, she was admitted to the PA Hospital in October 2022, with troponin positive chest pain.
Her peak troponin was nearly 11000.
Her echocardiogram showed an LV ejection fraction of 45% with base to mid anterolateral and inferolateral wall motion abnormalities.
Her LDL cholesterol was 5, therefore her Dutch lipid score was 6, indicating probable familial hyperlipidaemia.
Her sister also has familial hyperlipidaemia.
Her invasive coronary angiogram showed severe ostial left main stenosis, this was stented with 4 x12mm stent.
She was discharged with a plan of dual antiplatelet therapy for 12 months.
She could stop her Clopidogrel after 05.10.2023.
Her echocardiogram performed on 20.01.2023 showed her LV function is now 60% and there are no regional wall motion abnormalities.
In addition, there is only mild mitral regurgitation.
There are no significant valvular abnormalities.
Nicole has been doing well since discharge from hospital.
She has not had any unstable cardiac symptoms.
She has been tolerating her medications reasonably well.
He lates lipid profile is excellent with a total cholesterol  of 2.7 and LDL cholesterol of 0.9mmol/L.
She has been getting some throat tightness when she negotiates stairs.
She informs me that this is unchanged and has only been happening after her heart attack in October.
On  examination today, she appeared euvolaemic, her blood pressure is 120/80mmHg, heart rate was approximately 60bpm.
I had a discussion with Nicole.
We have decided to perform and exercise stress echocardiogram, given her history of throat tightness.
I will catch up with her in 6 months with the results of her stress echocardiogram.
She is aware that if she gets any prolonged chest pain, she will seek medical assistance.
I would appreciate it if you could continue to up titrate her Bisoprolol.
Hopefully her symptoms will resolve once she is adequately Beta blocked.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Anderson,





														RE:	HELEN FORD		DOB:	20/07/1950		UR:	544954

																					

														

														

														I had the pleasure of catching up with Helen in Dr Wang’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
as you are aware she is an 82-year-old female with presumed ischaemic cardiomyopathy who is known to our service.
She last had an admission to the PA Hospital in July of 2022.

Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Presumed ischaemic cardiomyopathy.
LVEF 40 to 45% (05.07.2022) with segmental dysfunction.
Dyslipidaemia.

Other Diagnoses:

														 Type II diabetes mellitus.
HbA1c 7.4%.
PMR on long term steroids, current dose 7mg.
Hypothyroid on Levothyroxine 50mcg daily.

Medications
- Bisoprolol 1.25mg mane
- Ramipril 1.25mg mane
- Frusemide restarted 13/9/22 at 40mg mane + midday
- Pantoprazole 40mg at night
- Prednisolone 6mg mane for PMR - weaning
- Pramipexole 0.125mg night
- Dothiepin 25mg bedtime
- Gliclazide 80mg mane + extra 80mg lunch on days that she eats lunch.

- PALEXIA SR (Tapentadol) 50mg mane (replaced tramadol SR 7/9/22 per Rheum)
- Levothyroxine 50mcg mane
- Vit D 1 mane
- Mega magnesium 1 mane
- Cenovis women's multivitamin 1 mane
- Probiotic tablet 1 mane
- ATROVENT MDI PRN
- Salbutamol MDI PRN
- CELLUFRESH eyedrops PRN
- Paracetamol PRN 


														As mentioned, Helen had an admission to our hospital in July 2022.
She presented with acute pulmonary oedema, and she was treated primarily with diuresis and appropriate heart failure medications.
Her left ventricular ejection fraction on echocardiogram was mildly depression with an ejection fraction of 40 to 45% during that admission.
Since her admission she has been doing well.
She is maintaining a stable body weight, with no evidence of fluid overload.
She walks approximately 20 to 40 minutes per day without any significant limitations with her 4-wheelie walker.
She does have some family help from time to time, but she denies any significant issues at home.
Her current concern is more related to some vomiting that she has when she has when she is on the toilet.
She tells me that she plans to see you in regard to some possible investigations for this and consideration of a referral for a gastroscopy if this is indicated.
I wonder if she iron deficient, although she does not have any constitutional symptoms.
On examination today, her heart rate was 80bpm and her blood pressure was 130/80mmHg.
Overall, my impression was that she is stable from a cardiac perspective and given her comorbidities, we should focus on quality of life.
I plan to increase her Bisoprolol to 2.5mg daily to reduce her need for cutting her Bisoprolol in half which she finds quite troublesome.
I will make a review appointment for approximately 6 months for her symptoms.

I would appreciate it if you could review her for her vomiting and consider iron study to assess her for iron deficiency, as iron deficiency would necessitate  a more rapid review for public gastroscopy.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Hegazi & Dr Reimers,





RE:	ROBERT FOXWELL		DOB:	28/11/1978		UR:	8110421

							



														Thank you for involving me in Robert’s care.
He is a 44-year-old man.
In September he had an embolic stroke with expressive dysphasia.
He thinks he is back to normal.
He is back to work as a Plant Operator.
His wife says that he still has some intermittent memory troubles.
I have reviewed his investigations.
He had a negative bubble study, but his transesophageal echocardiogram does show a probably small tunnel shaped PFO.
Given the lack of other convincing causes for stroke, I have offered him PFO closure.
I have discussed with him, the pros, cons and imponderables of PFO closure, the less of 1% risk of stroke, surgery, bleeding or device embolisation.
He would be done as a day case.
He and his wife know that he would need to be supervised for 24 hours afterwards, because of the general anaesthetic.
In general terms, he would not work Wednesday, Thursday or Friday.
Have a quiet weekend and return to work the following Monday.
He will continue his Aspirin and Clopidogrel.
His Atorvastatin dose could be modulated depending on his lipid profile.

Interestingly, Robert tells me that 2 of his sisters have strokes and one of them had a PFO closure at this hospital, that seems most unusual despite to common occurrence of PFO’s in the general population.
I wonder if there is some undiagnosed prothrombotic state in the family.
In any event, PFO closure seems indicated.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Slee,





RE:	RUTH GABRIEL		DOB:	23/10/1953		UR:	512881

							



														Ruth attended the heart failure titration clinic following a referral for up titration of her heart failure medications.
As you know she was admitted in December 2022 for a routine angiogram, and she was found to have a 70% stenosis of the LAD/D1 at the bifurcation and a 50-60% stenosis of the LCx 50.
Mild Global LV dysfunction EF 40% was also noted during the admission.

Medications

														Ramipril increased today to 5mg nocte, Bisoprolol 1.25mg mane, Aspirin 100mg mane, Rosuvastatin 40mg mane, Levothyroxine 75mcg midday, Esomeprazole 20mg mane, Vit D/Calcium 1 tab nocte, Ferrous Sulphate alternate days, GTN PRN, Paracetamol PRN.
Her past medical history includes Sjogren's/Rheumatoid arthritis, hypothyroidism, GORD with Barrett's oesophagus, and previous breast lumpectomy.
Since discharge from hospital Ruth has felt well.
She attends aqua aerobics six times per week.
She describes class I-II NYHA symptoms, and denies any orthopnoea, PND, chest pain, dizziness or light headedness.
Blood test on the 14th December 2022 show Na 143, K+ 4.2, Urea 5.5, Creat 83, and eGFR 62.
On examination her blood pressure was 125/70mmHg sitting and 140/90mmHg standing, heart rate 60bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
Heart sounds were dual, and chest was clear.
Today I have increased the Ramipril to 5mg nocte.
I have asked her to have a blood test just prior to seeing Dr Connors in two weeks.
I will see her back in this clinic in four weeks.

Yours sincerely,

														Issues
- Ischaemic heart disease.

o 2003 – 3 x PCI PAH; LAD/D2 bifurcation PCI (Lim)
  o 2010 – angiogram, some ISR
  o 2022 - Aborted anterior STEMI September 2022
  o Angiogram 13/9/22 – right dominant, severe LAD ISR, D1 proximal stenosis

														     (1.5mm vessel), D2 severe ostial ISR, moderate pLCx, moderate ostial-prox RCA
  o CABG 22/9/22 (Lo) – LIMA-LAD only; D2 not amenable to grafting
  o TTE 13/9/22 (pre-CABG) – LVEF 35-40%, satisfactory valves
- Hypertension.
- Ex-smoker.

Medicines (*unsure of list, need to clarify*)
Aspirin 100
Bisoprolol 1.25
Spironolactone 12.5 ?

stopped
Rosuvastatin 40
Frusemide 40
Desvenlafaxine
Iron tablet

Bloods – nil since discharge from hospital 
September 2022 – Cr 87, K 4.9, Hb 89 (post op in hospital)
Lipid LDL 3.3 at admission 

														

														Review:

														I reviewed Mr Gale in Dr Singbal’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today at the PA Hospital.
He presented with an infarct in September 2022 and underwent a single vessel CABG as outlined in the issues list above.
Since that time, he has recovered well and is now back at work, exerting himself without any problems CCS  0 / NYHA I.
He remains compliant with his medications, although he is unsure of the list and this will need to be clarified in the near future.
He does have some ungrafted small vessel disease, this will be managed medically in the first instance, given the absence of chest pain.
On examination he looked well.
His heart rate is 51bpm and systolic blood pressure is 135mmHg.
There were no signs of fluid overload.
The focus now will shift on secondary prevention for his coronary disease and also medications for his LV dysfunction.

The plan is as follows:

														- Clarify medicines – recalls that GP did put him on ramipril after CTS clinic review
- Refer to HF titration clinic – HR will limit BB up titration, need to up titrate ACE/add back spironolactone,
- Continue aspirin, statin 
- Has blood form to get done with GP in next 1-2 weeks
- TTE in 3-4 months + follow up in Dr Singbal clinic for review

Dear Dr Rad,





RE:	SHILA GILBERT		DOB:	24/04/1999		UR:	2109925

							

														

														It was a pleasure to review Shila in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
She is a 23-year-old lady who was admitted here in January 2022 after an episode of blurred vision, palpitations, shortness of breath, twitching and headaches.
This occurred on the background of several episodes of loss of consciousness over the years, with the last one having been in December 2021.
It was unclear at the time if these were vasovagal syncope or seizures.
She was reviewed by the Neurology Team who thought they were unlikely to be epileptic and she  underwent an EEG which was normal.
She was to have an outpatient MRI brain.
She also underwent cardiac investigations including telemetry monitoring, ECG and echocardiogram which were unremarkable.
Shila had a further two episodes after her discharge, the last one at least 6 months ago, though she cannot recall the exact dates.
She identifies that they both occurred during periods of increased general stress.
The first episode occurred while she was doing an arm workout at the gym.
She felt nauseous and dizzy prior and developed pins and needles in her hands before having approximately 30 seconds of loss of consciousness which was witnessed by her friend.
She had no incontinence, tongue biting or post-ictal period and went back to training shortly afterwards.
The second episode occurred when she was laying down reading in bed.
She developed a sharp left sided chest pain and then became quite anxious and short of breath with this.
She had associated rapid palpitations.
She called her  husband to say she felt unwell and had an episode of loss of consciousness, which was unwitnessed.
She is unsure of the duration but again there was no incontinence or tongue biting and no post-ictal period.
I note she is seeing a psychologist to optimise her mental health currently.
In summary, Shila’s episodes are likely vasovagal, but I think it would be reasonable to consider a loop recorder given her recurrent episodes.
I will refer her for consideration of this.
We will also organise the MRI brain.
I have given her advice on avoiding vasovagal episodes such as avoiding dehydration and I will review her via phone in three months.
Please feel free to contact me with any issues or concerns in the interim.

Yours sincerely, 

														

														Electronically signed 12.01.23

														Dr Danielle Harrop

														Consultant Cardiologist

														William was referred to Dr Singbal’s cardiology clinic as a new patient for investigation of lower limb oedema.
This is in the context of chronic bilateral lower limb oedema, left worse than right.
He has evidence of venous insufficiency and also complicated left hip orthopaedic issues and osteoarthritis of his knees.
William has got quite fixed views about his medical problems and health care.
He is wheelchair bound due to his osteoarthritis and has a Bluecare nurse three times week to help with personal activities of daily living including showering, laundry and dressing.
His only other background is hypertension and OSA on CPAP.
Echocardiogram in December 2022 was completely normal, with normal filling pressures and satisfactory valvular function.
There’s no DVT on an ultrasound done in ED of that left leg.
I suspect his oedema is secondary to chronic venous insufficiency and post-operative orthopaedic changes.
Systolic blood pressure was 115, heart rate was 60bpm.
Given his normal echo and ECG, we will discharge him from our clinic.
He should have non-cardiac causes of lower limb oedema investigated.

														Dear Dr Sattari,

														

														

														RE:	FELICITY GLASSON		DOB:	13/04/1946		UR:	957175

																					

														

														

														Thank you very much for your referral.

Diagnoses:

														Chest discomfort and shortness of breath.
Nocturnal Wenckebach while on Isoptin (used for ventricular ectopics).
?ischaemia, ?
chronotropic incompetence.
Stop Isoptin.
For DSE.
Phrenic nerve palsy.

Under Dr Luke Garske

														Asthma.

Migraines,

														

														Current Medications:

														Isoptin 180mg slow release daily, Stemetil 5mg TDS, Ventolin inhaler, Seretide inhaler, Palexia, Nexium, Naramig PRN.
It was a pleasure to review Felicity in the Cardiology Arrhythmia Clinic.
She is a 76-year-old lady who tells me she has possible phrenic nerve palsy and is under Dr Garske.
She is not 100% sure about the diagnosis.
According to her, on last spirometry, her lung function had improved 10%.
In the last 6 months or so, she has noticed increasing shortness of breath, chest tightness, she feels like she is hitting a brick wall when she is walking.
This may be related to ischaemic or chronotropic incompetence.
In October she had an episode of presyncopal symptoms, when she felt nauseas.
She had a hot feeling throughout her body and felt dizzy.
She noticed her heart rate was low and her blood pressure was low as well on her blood pressure monitor.
Her heart rate went down to 40bpm.
This most likely is consistent with a vasovagal presyncope.
She mentioned she has had previous episodes very similar to that, but this was the worst one.
After that episode, I understand she has had a 3-day Holter monitor which had not shown any significant conduction disease, during the waking hours but has shown Wenckebach phenomena at nigh- time.
She tells me she has been on long term Isoptin for suppression of PVCs.
She had very minimal symptoms, when she had PVCs.
On examination today, she had no signs of heart failure.
She does have a history of ?pre-diabetes according to her.
She not on any oral hypoglycaemic agents.
She does not smoke.
Her ECG showed sinus rhythm.
I reviewed her Holter monitor that only shows nocturnal Wenckebach episodes.
In the first instance I have asked Felicity to stop Isoptin.
I do not see a strong indication for it.
It is possible that it might improve her breathing if she had chronotropic incompetence as a result.
I will organise for her to have a DSE to exclude ischaemia and also her baseline and LV and RV function.
She is not able to have an exercise stress echocardiogram due to her bad knees.
I will review her in a couple of months, once she has had the DSE performed.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Vu,





RE:	GLEN OWEN GRAY 		DOB:	31/01/1943	UR:	276638

								

	

														He has a past history of:

														Permanent pacemaker implanted at the Wesley Hospital, unfortunately, complicated by arterial lead placement of the ventricular lead.
Initial indication was tachy brady syndrome and the pacemaker was extracted at TPCH in January 2019.

The ventricular lead likely caused a left frontal lobe stroke, left occipital stroke and right cerebella hemisphere infarct and right hemiplegia with expressive aphasia and right homonymous hemianopia and left trochlear nerve palsy.
He has had multiple admissions with complications regarding these strokes.
He also has seizure disorder secondary the strokes and an occluded right vertebral artery.
Type 2 diabetes mellitus with moderate control.
Hypertension.
Chronic kidney disease.
Haematuria.
Permanent atrial fibrillation / atrial flutter, which is asymptomatic and for rate control.
Mr Glen Gray came along with his helpful and lovely wife to attend the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
His Holter monitor from 6 months ago showed well controlled ventricular rate.
He is not on any rate control, and he is on Warfarin and his INRs have been therapeutic past few weeks.
The rest of his history is as listed above.
He is very stable from cardiac symptoms point of view.
Today, he is euvolaemic, there is an ejection systolic murmur.
His carotid pulse is strong and normal.

This could be aortic sclerosis or may be mild aortic stenosis, and any intervention is not appropriate for this gentleman due to his extensive history of strokes and physical debilitation as a result.
There are no signs of severity on clinical examination today, regardless.

His wife reports that it has been difficult for him to get to appointments, as it requires an elaborate support system comprising of lengthy hoisting out of his bed into a chair and then drive in for appointments.
In summary, Mr Gray is stable and asymptomatic from his atrial flutter and the rate is well controlled.
He has no heart failure symptoms and is on appropriate medications.
He has a Renal Physician and a good therapeutic relationship with yourself.
As such, we are happy to discharge his care back to yourself.
If there are any concerns in the future with regard to his heart, we are more than happy to see him again with a new referral from yourself.

Yours sincerely,

														Current Background:
1.
ESRF.

- Now progressed to HD
Perma cath in situ
Awaiting maturation of AV fistula

2.

Type 2 diabetes 

3.
Severe visual impairment.
Hypertension.
Mildly raised pulmonary pressures.
- Likely post capillary pulmonary hypertension.

Current Medications:
Amlodipine 10mg daily, Bevacizumab intraocular, Frusemide 250 mg BD, Hydralazine 50mg twice daily, Irbesartan-Hydrochlorothiazide 300/25mg 1 tablet daily, Linagliptin 5mg daily, Sodium Bicarbonate 840mg 1 capsule twice daily.
Calcitriol .25 mcg three times a week, Calcium carbonate 600 mg nocte.

Epoetin 4000 U Twice a week, Gliclazide 80 mg 5 times a week, Insulin Protaphane 12 U OD, Linagliptin 5 mg OD , Moxonidine 200 mcg nocte, Multivitamin, Sevelamer, Ondansetron 

														I had the pleasure of meeting Ms Gold in cardiology clinic this afternoon.
She is a lovely 68 year old lady who was seen by Dr Wahi in May 2021, with the impression of likely cardiomyopathy with ongoing follow ups  and 12 month repeat echocardiogram.
In terms of the clinical progression Gaye is more or less much the same in the last 12 months.
She denies any decline in her exercise tolerance and there is no  history suggestive of orthopnoea or  PND.
She has been closely monitored in the renal clinic and now has progressed to haemodialysis with paermacath in situ while awaiting maturation of her av fistula.
She had a repeat echocardiogram on 24th January 2022, which reveals severe dilation of left ventricle (LVEDVi 81ml/m2) with LVEF 60%.
The right ventricle is dilated with normal systolic function, there is mild to moderate MR and moderate TR with mildly raised right ventricle and pulmonary artery pressure RVSP 38mmHg.
On examination her blood pressure was 140/70mmHg, heart sounds were dual, with no audible murmur.
There was no evidence of volume overload and chest examination was clear.
Although it seems that Ms Gold has been stable over the last 18 month period and there is no progression of pulmonary pressure on her echocardiogram finding.

She is stable symptomatically, at this stage I have discharged her from Cardiology clinic however, I would suggest that she should have a repeat echocardiogram in 2 years and review in Cardiology clinic if there are any concerns of worsening pulmonary pressure on the repeat echocardiogram.

Thank you for your ongoing care

														

														

														Yours sincerely,

														Dear Bruce,





RE:	MIGUEL GONZALEZ		DOB:	25/02/1955		UR:	106811

							



														

														I saw Miguel in my clinic for follow up today.
He has been complaining of exertional dyspnoea over the last few months.
However, he denied any orthopnoea, PND, or ankle swelling.
His recent exercise stress echocardiogram also showed  previous LAD scar but overall preserved LVEF (~50%), and no new inducible ischaemia.
Furthermore, his previous echocardiogram in 2021 at Logan Hospital showed elevated LV filling pressures with a pseudonormalised mitral inflow pattern.

His background is significant for ischaemic heart disease with previous CABG in 2009 (LIMA to LAD), NSTEMI in 2020 and subsequent PCI to distal LAD, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia and congenital solitary kidney (normal eGFR).
He is known to have moderate 50 to 60% proximal and mid LCX disease.
His current medications include Aspirin 100mg daily, Atenolol 25mg daily, Perindopril 10mg daily, Lercanidipine 20mg daily, Ezetimibe / Atorvastatin 10/40mg daily and Sertraline 150mg daily.
He has no allergies but is intolerant to Rosuvastatin.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 60bpm regular and his blood pressure was 120/70mmHg.
His chest was clear on auscultation and there was no peripheral oedema.

Today, I have informed Miguel that his ongoing exertional dyspnoea is likely due to the combination of elevated LV filling pressures documented on previous echocardiogram, as well as reduced cardiovascular fitness and increased BMI.
Therefore, I have asked him to reduce his oral fluid intake to 2L daily.
In addition, I have given him a pathology request form to check his fasting lipid profile again.
If the LDL cholesterol is >1.8mmol/L, can you please increase his Atorvastatin dosage to 80mg daily?
I will see him again in 3 months with another repeat fasting lipid profile.
If his LDL cholesterol is still >1.8mmol/L despite the maximal dose of Atorvastatin, he will qualify for Evolocumab.
Thank you for looking after Miguel.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Haq,





														RE:	DALE K. GOODRICH		DOB:	12/11/1990		UR:	8114584

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Dale in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know, she is a 32-year-old lady who was admitted to the PA Hospital on 11.12.2022 with an inferior STEMI.
She had prolonged chest pain prior to her presentation.
She underwent a coronary angiogram which revealed occlusion of the proximal RCA that was difficult to wire and thought possibly due to spontaneous coronary artery dissection.
She received a drug eluting stent to the proximal RCA.
Her left ventricular ejection fraction was 40-45% and her RV function was also impaired at the time.
Additionally, she had asymptomatic AV block for a number of days after her infarct, which did eventually resolve spontaneously though a pacemaker was being considered.

This occurs on a background of:

														Type II diabetes with previously suboptimal control.
Smoker.
Implanon in situ with no plans for further pregnancies.

Dale’s current medications are Aspirin 100mg, Clopidogrel 75mg, Atorvastatin 80mg, Ezetimibe 10mg, Ramipril 1.25mg, Bisoprolol 1.25mg nocte (commenced today), Empagliflozin 10mg, Metformin and Insulin.
Dale has recovered really well from her infarct.
She had one episode of chest pain for which she presented to Ipswich Hospital Emergency Department and had normal troponins and an unchanged ECG.
She has had no dizziness or presyncope.
She is starting Cardiac Rehabilitation soon.
Today, her pulse was 90bpm and regular and ECG showed her to be in sinus rhythm with a normal PR interval of 150ms and a narrow QRS.
Her blood pressure was 103/72mmHg.
A recent echocardiogram showed that her LVEF is about 45% and her RV function has normalised.
I have asked Dale to start a small dose of Bisoprolol today for up titration as tolerated.
She has multiple indications for beta-blocker therapy, including LV dysfunction and spontaneous coronary artery dissection.
Given her AV conduction on ECG has completely normalised, I expect her to tolerate this with close monitoring.
Given her EF is above 40%, Entresto is not indicated at this stage.
I have asked her to have some fasting lipids and I will review her in three months, but please feel free to contact me in the interim with any new issues or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Rehman,

														

														

														RE:	RICHARD BARRIE GOODWIN	DOB:	16/12/1953	UR:	524542

																					

														

														

														Richard Goodwin was reviewed in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
He has a past history of coronary artery bypass grafting (LIMA to LAD, with saphenous vein to intermediate with a skip to the posterolateral branch).
He had a coronary angiogram at RBWH in January 2019, that showed 3/3 patent grafts and an occluded left main.
An echocardiogram in 2019 showed normal LV size and LV systolic function with an ejection fraction of 55%.
His other history includes hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, atrial fibrillation and is an ex-smoker.

He did not have his medication list with him, but from the referral letter, it lists that he on Rivaroxaban 20mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Ramipril 5mg and Frusemide 20mg and GTN spray 20mg.
He has no known allergies.
He currently lives in a hostel and uses a Webster Pack for his medications which he tells me his medications get dispensed at the hostel.
Richard reports that he feels well.
He states since his surgery in 2018, he had episodes of chest pain and shortness of breath when he rushes to exert himself.
He states that he takes a breath, and his symptoms subside.
He reports that if he does exertional activities within his limits, he does not experience symptoms.
At most, his symptoms are of NYHA class II dyspnoea as class II angina.
He reports that I feel ok.
He states that he is currently tolerating his medications and feels unchanged in his symptoms in the past several years.
He had a presentation to at Logan Hospital in October 2022 with pneumonia as well as AF with rapid ventricular rate.
It appears upon discharge it was arranged for him to have outpatient investigations from a cardiology perspective.
I note that he has had an echocardiogram done at Logan Cardiology and Specialist Centre that he has severe LV enlargement and normal LV systolic function and severe LVH.
Of note, it also reports that he also has resting regional wall motion abnormalities.
The ejection fraction was 56%.
It also states that he has moderate aortic stenosis.
Richard does not report any symptoms of presyncope, or syncope and he is able to go about his daily activities.
On examination his heart rate was 80bpm and irregular and his blood pressure was 130/80mmHg.
His heart sounds were dual, with a soft ejection systolic murmur.
His chest was clear on auscultation.
His lower limb had mild pitting oedema bilaterally and it was noted the previous saphenous vein graft donor site in the right lower limb.
His ECG shows atrial fibrillation and is rate controlled.
Richard will need to continue on his current management.
He will be referred for a Holter monitor to assess his control of his atrial fibrillation as well as a transthoracic echocardiogram.
In the interim, he was advised that if he experiences symptoms that are concerning to seek medical review.
We plan to follow him up in clinic in approximately 4 months with the results.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear James,





RE:	ERROL GOSLEY		DOB:	24/06/1940		UR:	674918

							





														

														I saw Mr Gosley in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
I have got to say my overall impression is that he is breathless because he is so fat.
He is 118 kilograms now.
We know he has a degree of lung disease, based on his previous testing.
He has been diagnosed with heart failure reduced ejection fraction in the past, where his lowest ejection fraction was 40 to 45%.
His most recent ejection fraction was 45 to 50%.
There was no indication on his echocardiogram that he had elevated pulmonary pressures or diastolic filling parameters, but that is not an easy assessment.
Today, his blood pressure is 115/66mmHg, he tells me that it is normally lower than this.
His heart rate is 60bpm on Amiodarone 200mg a day and Bisoprolol 10mg a day.
He is no longer taking Entresto, I think because his kidney have gone off over the last 12 months.
I note that ceasing the Entresto did not make any difference to his renal function, from what I can tell.
I suppose my main comments are that he is taking too much heart rate slowing medication.
I have asked him to continue the Amiodarone (he does have paroxysmal atrial fibrillation) and to reduce the Bisoprolol to 5mg at night only.
I am uncertain about the need for him to continue the diuretic therapy.
I think if there is any worsening of his renal function, I would have a low threshold for at least halving the diuretics or ceasing it altogether as a trial.
As he is on Amiodarone would you please check his TSH, T3 and T4 every 6 months along with his ELFT’s and full blood count.
If you annotate the request form with the word Amiodarone, then Medicare will pay for the complex thyroid function testing.
We will see him towards the end of 2023.
I do not think there is anything else that we really have offer him.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr O’Brien, 

														

														

														RE:	JOHN W GRAINER		DOB:	23/04/1950		UR:	050666

																					

														

														

														John Grainer was reviewed in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
His wife was also present for the consultation.

His past history includes a coronary artery bypass grafting in November of 2015, at TPCH with grafts to LIMA – LAD, saphenous vein to ramus intermedius, saphenous vein to OM1 and saphenous vein graft to RPDA.
He previously also has a history of hypertension, dyslipidaemia and atrial fibrillation and glaucoma.
He had coronary angiography in February 2022, that showed 4/4 patent grafts with severe native vessel disease.
His current medications include Sotalol 40mg oral BD, Eliquis 5mg oral BD, Telmisartan 40mg oral daily, Rosuzet, Allopurinol, Xalatan and Azopt.
He reports that his main symptom is that of fatigue.
He does not experience any chest pain.
He states that over the past 6 months he is becoming more sleepy.
His wife notices him falling asleep during the day and he falls asleep at time sitting on the couch in the afternoon.
She reports that he had previous noticeable episodes of apnoea as well as previous snoring.
He has not had any previous sleep studies to his knowledge.
He has reported at times, that if he has reduced fluid intake that he may get transiently light headed.
He does not report any syncopal episodes.
He is not affected by palpitations.
On examination, his heart rate was 90bpm and his blood pressure was 120/80mmHg.
His heart sounds were dual, and his chest was clear and there was mild lower limb oedema.
His ECG showed atrial fibrillation that was rate controlled and heart rate was 93 and irregular.
His angiogram from February of 2022 showed severe 3 vessel disease with patent 4/4 grafts.
He had an ejection fraction that was 60% with an EDP of 20.
From a cardiac perspective, his fatigue appears to be multifactorial.
He is overweight, has a history of atrial fibrillation and he may have issues with sleep apnoea.
I have suggested that he continue on his current cardiac medications.
He reports that in his family history that his brother recently passed away from amyloidosis and he had a question whether his symptoms are related to that.
His previous cardiac investigations were not suggestive of that diagnosis.
He will be referred for a Holter monitor and reassessment of his LV function with a transthoracic echocardiogram.
If  you can please refer him for sleep study assessment, that will be appreciated.
He will have a plan for follow up in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic in approximately 6 months.
He was advised in the interim that if he feels unwell to seek medical review.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

RE:	MICHAEL GRIMSHAW	DOB:	10/11/1967	UR:	8077813

							





														

														I reviewed this 55-year-old gentleman in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.

Issues:
1.

PVCs; Intermittent shortening of PR interval + pre-excitation on PAH ECGs (Asymptomatic)
    a. Anaesthetic note 7.10.2021 + D/C summary 8.10.2021 – Frequent PVCs with runs of bigeminy under GA 10.2021 
    b. ECG 5.4.2022 – SR; Short PR 107msec with delta waves; ST depression + TWI I, II, III, aVF and v4-6 (Similar to ECG 4.9.2020; Different to ECG 3.8.2021)
    c. Holter 22.5.2022 – SR; 0.4% SVE; <0.1% VEs; Short salvos of atrial ectopic rhythm; Ventricular pre-excitation is intermittent but can be present at HR 155bpm
2.

TTE 29.6.2022 – Normal LV size with LVEF 50-55%; Basal inferoseptum/inferior and basal-mid inferolateral hypokinesis; Normal RV size and systolic function; No significant valvular abnormalities

Background:
1.

T2DM
2.

Obesity and metabolic syndrome; NAFLD
3.

Hypertension
4.

Hyperlipidaemia
5.

Perianal abscess I/D 09.2021; Trans-sphincteric fistula requiring seton insertion + bilateral pudendal nerve block 10.2021; Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract 21.10.2022
6.

LGI scope 22.11.2021 – Sigmoid polyp (Tubular adenoma)
7.

Non-smoker; No significant EtOH
8.

NKDA
9.

Owns dry cleaning shop; Lives at home with wife

Medications:
Diabex XR 1.5g od
Semaglutide 

														

														He has noticed some exertional dyspnoea but otherwise has had no chest pain, dizziness, palpitations or syncope.
On examination his blood pressure was 135/80mmHg, heart rate 72bpm and regular, JVP not elevated, and chest was clear.

RE:	MICHAEL GRIMSHAW	DOB:	10/11/1967	UR:	8077813

														

														Assessment:

														He does evidence of ventricular pre-excitation intermittent on his ECG and also his Holter monitor, even at heart rates of up to 155bpm.
He has reported hypokinesis in his basal inferoseptal, inferior and basal to mid lateral segments on the echocardiogram that is incidental.

Plan:

														I will obtain an opinion from my Electrophysiology colleagues regarding his pre-excitation.
I will organize a CT coronary angiogram to exclude any significant coronary artery disease, given the wall motion abnormalities.
We will decide on the need for Aspirin and or a statin based on the CT findings.
In the interim, I have started him on low dose Perindopril 2.5mg once a day.
I will catch up with him in 2 months.
Thank  you kindly for your continuing care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Winston,





RE:	JOHN GROENESTYN	DOB:	08/12/1952	UR:	875931

							



														

														It was a pleasure to catch up with John in the Cardiology Clinic today.
As you will recall, he has moderate 2 vessel coronary artery disease in the setting of breathlessness but no chest pain.
We think the more likely cause for his breathlessness is chronic aspiration due to his previous oesophageal surgery and gastric pull through with evidence of this on CT chest.
He also has iron deficiency which we are trying to sort out before we tackle any potential coronary artery disease.
In the meantime, I got him an exercise stress echocardiogram to assess his ischaemic burden.
This was actually a really good result.
There was no inducible ischaemia at a good workload at 8.5METs.
John recalls feeling pretty good doing most of the stress test, until stage 3 which he was able to push through.
This somewhat goes against the previous history had stated, which is that he feels completely wrecked doing any strenuous activities.
I was pleased to hear that he is having the endoscopy and colonoscopy tomorrow.
He is feeling stable.
I again discussed with  him the prognosis of asymptomatic coronary artery disease with no ischaemia on stress testing.
We discussed the concept of stable versus unstable plaque.
I think we have time to sort out his other medical issues first.
I would like to see him in 6 weeks to review the scope results and plan the next step.
There may be a case for challenging him with a dual antiplatelet regime for a month or two, ensuring that he tolerates it, before undertaking any invasive approach.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Garred,





RE:	MARIE ANN GUENETTE	DOB:	07/12/1969	UR:	8111425

							





														Thank you for referring Marie to my clinic for further assessment of chest pain.
She is a 53-year-old paramedic with a background of ADHD, ulcerative colitis (in remission), and anxiety.
Marie recently presented to hospital with severe headaches and chest discomfort.
At that time, her CT brain did not show any intracranial pathology.
As for her chest pain, she described it as a discomfort that only lasted for several minutes in duration.
It did not radiate, and self-resolved without any interventions.
Since then, she has had no further recurrence of the chest discomfort.
Marie is normally quite active and denied any exertional angina.
Her current medications include Dexamphetamine 10mg BD, Sertraline 50mg daily, Folic Acid, and Hydroxychloroquine 200mg daily.
She is allergic to Astrix branded Aspirin (rash), but not to other Aspirin brands.
On examination today, her pulse rate was 80bpm regular and her blood pressure was 115/80mmHg.
ECG today showed normal sinus rhythm (PR 115ms, QRS 93ms, QTc 446ms).
Today, I have reassured Marie that her chest pain was non-cardiac in origin.
I have discharged her from my clinic back  under your care.
Thank you for looking after Marie.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Ali,





														RE:	RAELLEN HACKETT		DOB:	29/12/1980		UR:	761078

																					

														

														

														I saw Raellen in my clinic for follow up today.

She is a 42-year-old lady with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction secondary to ischaemic cardiomyopathy, previous LV thrombus due to aneurysmal LV apex in 2022 (anticoagulation stopped at Redlands Hospital), previous PCI to LAD, and positive HCV infection.
Raellen is an active smoking.
Raellen is currently minimally symptomatic from the cardiac point of view and complains of minimal exertional angina or dyspnoea.
This was despite not taking medications for the last 2 weeks due to financial difficulties.

Her current medications should include Aspirin 100mg daily, Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Ramipril  2.5mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Isosorbide Mononitrate 30mg daily, Pantoprazole 40mg daily, and Quetiapine 100mg daily.
She has no allergies.
On examination today, her pulse rate was 90bpm regular, and her blood pressure was 145/90mmHg.
There was no peripheral oedema.
Today, I have encouraged Raellen to take her medications regularly.
To reduce the financial cost of her medications, I have given her scripts for Bisoprolol 5mg ½ tablet daily and Ramipril  5mg ½ tablet daily.
I have also stopped the Isosorbide Mononitrate as she is currently asymptomatic.
Finally, I will see her again in 3 months for follow up.
If she can demonstrate good compliance  to her medications, we should ideally change the Aspirin back to long term Warfarin as the substrate for the LV apical thrombus (i.e.
aneurysmal LV apex) is still present.
Thank you for looking after Raellen.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Horwood,

														

														

														RE:	ROSS HAGE		DOB:	25/05/1957		UR:	8068129

																					

														

														

														Background:

														Ischaemic heart disease.
Non-STEMI January 2020.
2 vessel disease, chronic occlusion of mid LAD and thrombotic occlusion of right coronary artery culprit.
Both vessels well collateralised.
Mild circumflex and marginal disease.
Normal LV function.
Type II diabetes mellitus.
Hypertension.
GORD.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg once a day, Isosorbide Mononitrate 60mg daily, Metoprolol 50mg BD, Candesartan 32mg once a day, Metformin 1g BD, Rosuvastatin 40mg once a day, Esomeprazole 20mg daily, Amlodipine 20mg daily, Dapagliflozin 10mg a day.
I had the pleasure of speaking to Mr Hage via telephone from the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
This was a scheduled phone review post ESE.
Mr Hage was reviewed by Dr Wahi in August 2022 and given his first ESE was done with 4METs, we wanted to clarify with a repeat stress echocardiogram.
Mr Hage is particularly fit and well gentleman and he does not have any ongoing anginal symptoms.
His repeat stress echocardiogram on 17.01.2023, did have some features of inducible ischaemia in LAD territory at peak stress.
However, he did not have any chest pain or ECG changes.
In his day-to-day life, there is no angina burden.
He normally does 30 minutes of brisk walking twice a day, goes to the gym and does aerobic for 40-minute sessions and has lost 10 kilograms in body weight in the last few months.

Given the angio findings of CTO of mid LAD and collateralised RCA lesion, Dr Wahi has suggested that there is probably no prognostic benefit of revascularisation and in the absence of any anginal burden, there is no role of further proceeding for another cardiac catheterisation.
At this stage, we will continue with medical management, however, if in future if there are any anginal symptoms, we will readdress this.
Please continue with your ongoing care and feel free to contact us if you have any concerns in the interim.
I have booked him for a phone review in 6 months.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Lin,





														RE:	MARGARET E. HALL	DOB:	16/10/1947	UR:	294943

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Margaret in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
She was actually cared for by my colleague, Dr Wang, during her recent hospital admission and seems was booked in my clinic in error.
Nonetheless, she is a 75-year-old lady who was admitted in October 2022 with a non-STEMI.
She had severe LAD and RCA disease and after further assessment was thought to be unsuitable for coronary artery bypass grafting due to her respiratory disease.
She underwent successful two vessel PCI.
Her LVEF was preserved at about 57%.

This occurs on a background of:

														Current smoker.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
PMR on steroids for many years.
Mildly dilating ascending aorta (42mm).

Her medications remain unchanged since discharge and include Aspirin 100mg, Clopidogrel 75mg, Metoprolol 12.5mg BD, Irbesartan 300mg, Rosuvastatin 40mg, Amlodipine 10mg, Hydralazine 75mg, Ezetimibe 10mg, Sitagliptin 50mg, Insulin Metformin, Prednisolone 5mg, Pantoprazole 40mg, Mirtazapine 45mg.
Margaret reports no chest pain or other cardiac symptoms since her discharge from hospital.
She has had no bleeding issues on dual antiplatelets.
She did report a number of longstanding issues today that predate her myocardial infarct.
She reports being very sleepy during the day for a number of years since commencing Prednisolone.
Her night-time sleep is interrupted, predominantly by nocturia.
She reports chronic nausea.
She has pain in her lower back and legs which she attributes to PMR.
She also reports significant anxiety.
Today, her blood pressure was 133/74mmHg, HbA1c was 8.0% and I note iron deficiency with a normal haemoglobin of 126.
In summary, Margaret is stable from a cardiac point of view.
She does have some longstanding non-cardiac symptoms which are causing her significant anxiety.
I wonder if iron supplementation may improve some of her symptoms.

I also note she has an appointment to see the Rheumatologists at the QEII Hospital in March and I think this would be useful, given her long term use of Prednisolone and its possible link to some of her symptoms.
I will review her in October 2023, but please feel free to contact me in the interim with any new issues or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor,





														RE:	WAYNE A. HALSTEAD	DOB:	02/07/1973	UR:	277355

																					

														

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Mr Halstead in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
He has been stable from his Brugada point of view, taking his Quinidine a bit more regularly now.
He is taking 200mg twice daily, because the 300mg strength is out of stock and I have confirmed this with our pharmacist as well.
The pharmacist confirms that this medication can be halved, therefore, I have asked Wayne to take 1 ½ tablets twice a day, making it 300mg BD, and I have given him a script with 5 repeats.
We will see him in about 6 months roughly when his scripts run out and renew his scripts.
He is aware of the importance of compliance with his medications, otherwise he is at risk of VT and device shocks.

Yours sincerely,

Dyslipidaemia.
Remote ex-smoker.

Edentulous.

RE:	PETER HANNAM		DOB:	29/10/1963		UR:	2305743

							



Peter returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
He feels well and continues to describe class I NYHA symptoms.
He denies any orthopnoea, PND, dizziness or light headedness.
I understand that he saw Dr Stowasser a few weeks ago, and the Candesartan was increased was to 32mg mane.
Peter told me that he tolerated this well.
Blood test on the 20th January show Na 139, K+ 4.2, Urea 6.7, Creat 89, and eGFR 81.
Peter told me that his blood pressure at home has been sitting around 150 systolic.

Medications

														Bisoprolol 10mg daily, Hydralazine 50mg bd, Spironolactone increased today to 37.5mg daily (as per Dr Stowasser), Candesartan 32mg daily.
On examination his blood pressure was 155/100mmHg sitting and 160/110mmHg standing, heart rate 60bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
I discussed ongoing management of Peter’s hypertension with Dr Stowasser today.
He advised to increase the Spironolactone to 37.5mg mane.
I have organised a blood test for Peter to have with QML in four weeks prior to review with me in this clinic.

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Coronary artery disease.
STEMI December 2021: Drug eluting stent to mid LAD.
Staged drug eluting stent to mid left circumflex artery January 2022.
Recent atypical chest pain – for exercise stress echocardiogram.
Mild LV dysfunction (LVEF 40 to 45%) December 2021.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Other Diagnoses:

														Obstructive sleep apnoea – CPAP.
Gastroesophageal reflux disease.
Previous retinal detachment.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Clopidogrel 75mg daily, Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Perindopril 8mg mane, Rosuvastatin 40mg daily, Ezetimibe 10mg daily.
I reviewed Stephen in the PA Hospital Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
He has been very well over the past year, exercising 5 times a week, walking briskly for ½ hour at a time, without any issue whatsoever.

He said he suffered a second episode in the days following.

														I reviewed Caroline via telehealth out of Roma today.

Dear Dr Dhital,





RE:	PETER HARTLEY		DOB:	09/01/1962		UR:	2234322

							



														It was a pleasure to meet Peter in the clinic today.
He has recently moved up from Victoria.
He was seeing a Cardiologist, but the name of Dr Dinesh Natarajan at Grampians Health in Victoria all last year for investigation of chest pain.
He has actually had chest pain for about 20 years, which has previously been attributed to reflux.
He is on Omeprazole, and it is not helping.
Interestingly, the pain is classically exertional in nature and is a central dull ache.
After discarding the theory of reflux, he thought it was cold air, whilst exercising in Victoria.
However, now he exercises inside on a treadmill and still gets the pain.
He is fine when he is walking, but only gets it when he pushes himself harder, for example, going up hills or running.
It is relieved by slowing down or resting.

He had an exercise stress echocardiogram in Victoria, earlier in 2020, in which he got the chest pain, but was able to exercise for 10.2METs with no evidence of inducible ischaemia on ECG or echocardiogram.
They had spoken about CT coronary angiogram, but it was at a time when he was relocating.
His risk factors for coronary disease include  dyslipidaemia on Atorvastatin with his cholesterol now at 4.3 and LDL at 2.5, and a family history in his father.
He is on Aspirin, Atorvastatin and Omeprazole.
Examination today revealed a blood pressure of 110/70mmHg, and a heart rate of 60bpm and regular.
Heart sounds were dual, the chest was clear and there was no peripheral oedema.
I agree with Dr Natarajan, that a CT coronary angiogram would be an excellent testing clarifying the issue one way or the other.
I do have some concerns about the pretty clear exertional nature of the pain, it is possible that the stress echocardiogram missed something.
We will get him a CTCA in the next few weeks and I will see him again with the results.

Yours sincerely, 

														

														Electronically signed 18.01.23

														Dr Gerard Connors

														Visiting Cardiologist

Dear Brian,





														RE:	MARKS JOSEPH HASKINS		DOB:	16/03/1960	UR:	811932

																					

														Our Pacemaker Clinic has detected on this man's remote monitor of his Boston Pacemaker, a 31-cycle episode of ventricular tachycardia in September last year.
The heart rate was 188bpm at that time.
Mark has been his usual self, except that he has some transient periods of dizziness and other transient periods of dyspnoea for which he takes sublingual nitro-glycerine.
His background is obesity complicated by ischaemic heart disease, obstructive sleep apnoea which is treated with CPAP, hypertension and hyperlipidaemia.
I implanted his pacemaker a couple of years ago in the setting of quite troublesome fainting.
At the time he was having some non-sustained atrial and ventricular tachy arrhythmias.
Mark also has polymyalgia rheumatica, gout and gastroesophageal reflux disease.
He underwent left nephrectomy 12 years ago for renal cell carcinoma and he had a carotid body tumour resected in 2019.
He has the SDHB mutation predisposing to paraganglioma, and prostate cancer was diagnosed in 2016.
He also has thyroid nodules and a left total hip replacement.
Today he weighed 155 kilograms.
His blood pressure was 140/70mmHg sitting, measuring on his left arm on a large cuff.
There were no abnormal cardiac signs.
His recent echocardiography at Redland Hospital, indicates normal left ventricular systolic function.
Today, I have substituted Sotalol at 80mg bd, to be taken on an empty stomach, for his Metoprolol.
I have enabled the rate response characteristic of his pacemaker, very gently in the face of his ischaemic heart disease.
Mark has an appointment for review in this clinic in about 1 month.

Yours sincerely,

														Thank you for referring Itsara to my clinic for further assessment of chest pain.

I have asked her to stop taking her Amiodarone, instead she can go on 25mg of Metoprolol bd.
She has also been taking 15mg Ramipril, the maximum dose on his drug is 10mg, I am not sure if it is affective above this.
If there are problems with her blood pressure, can you please consider increasing her Spironolactone to 50mg, or you could add Amlodipine.
To replace Amiodarone because of side effect toxicity and the fact that she remains in sinus rhythm, I have replacement it with Metoprolol 25mg bd.
I have mentioned to her that the success rate with first PVI’s is 70%.

There is still a 30% chance that she might get AF recurrence, especially without Amiodarone on board, but on balance in terms of side effect profile of Amiodarone we have decided mutually that she will go off it.
She is to continue all other medications, especially her Rivaroxaban and I have discussed the rationale for this.
Her next appointment will be in Dr Gould’s Private Practice Clinic as per his request in 6 months, with a repeat ECG on the day.
She can contact our EP CNC, if she believes she has gone back into AF.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Gange,

														

														

														RE:	JAKE TRAVIS HAWES	DOB:	10/05/1988	UR:	2222127

																						TWH:	196520

																					

														

														

														Problem List:

														Right middle cerebral artery stroke in July 2022.
Present to his right sided hemiplegia, dysarthria.
MRI brain showing a sub-cortical, sub -acute infarct in the frontal lobes.
Symptomatically improved with minimal dysarthria present.
Patent foramen ovale.
Positive bubble on transthoracic and transoesophageal echocardiogram.
Defect suitable for percutaneous closure.

Current Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Atorvastatin 40mg daily.
Thank you for referring Jake to the Cardiology Service at the PA Hospital.
He is a pleasant 34-year-old who works as motorcycle mechanic.

He presented with a  right frontal lobe ischaemic infarct with hemiplegia, dysarthria and during his inpatient stay was investigated which confirmed an underling patent foramen ovale with a positive bubble study on transthoracic and transoesophageal echocardiogram.
Most of his other vasculitic screen was negative.
There was no other secondary aetiology identified.
There was no definite evidence of venous thrombosis.
However, a strongly positive bubble study with a patent foramen ovale would certainly be a concerning finding for a young patient with a recent stroke.
From a cardiac standpoint otherwise, he is asymptomatic.
He has no shortness of breath, no symptoms of chest pain.
There is no history of palpitations.
His vasculitic screen, thrombophilia screen and a 48-hour Holter monitor have not shown anything that could be responsible for his acute presentation.
In the past he has been a smoker, which he is trying his best to reform.
His clinic examination was unremarkable.
His blood pressure was normal with a normal sinus rhythm.
His ECG today shows sinus rhythm with a rate of 90bpm.
His PR interval is within normal limits.
His QRS duration is normal, his QT interval is within normal limits.
His transthoracic echocardiogram does show normal left ventricular size and function with an ejection fraction of 65% on Simpson’s biplane method.
His left atrial size is normal.
His right side of the heart is within normal limits.
He did have a strongly positive bubble study with Valsalva and has no underlying valvular heart disease.
A transesophageal echocardiogram was subsequently undertaken on 26.07.2022, which once again confirmed the essential finding of patent foramen ovale, which appears quite suitable for device closure.

In summary, Mr Jake Hawes is a 34-year-old gentleman who had a recent presentation with a MCS stroke which was confirmed on the MRI scan and the possible aetiology for this presentation seems to be the patent foramen ovale, although no definite documentation of a venous thrombosis was confirmed.
I had a detailed discussion with Jake and his mother regarding the suitability of closing this with a percutaneous approach.
The defect is quite suitable for a percutaneous closure, and I will make arrangements for this to take place at the PA Hospital in the next few months.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Chhabra,





														RE:	TREVOUR G HAYES	DOB:	02/09/1968	UR:	8037101

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Trevor in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
He is a 54-year-old gentleman who was admitted here in July last year with troponin negative chest pain.
He underwent an echocardiogram which showed his ejection fraction to be 45-50% with some non-LAD territory wall motion abnormalities.

This occurred on a background of:

														

														Known coronary artery disease.
Non-STEMI 2018.
Angio 2018 revealed CT) of the proximal RCA, OM1 and OM2 with collaterals.
90% distal LAD stenosis.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
Type II diabetes (HbA1c 9.5%).
Peripheral vascular disease.
Current smoker.
The only medications Trevor is taking currently are Aspirin 100mg, Metformin, Jardiance and Pristiq.
Trevor reports disabling nausea when he takes all prescribed medications, ever since his MI in 2018.
He states he took them for a couple of years before ceasing.
He still gets some nausea with Pristiq and his diabetes medications and intermittently stops the diabetes medications and reports feeling better.
He reports having tried stopping single medications or taking single medications without any improvement in symptoms and strongly believes it is the combination of tablets that make him feel unwell.
He has also had nausea with Champix, and although he understands it would be best for his cardiovascular health if he ceased smoking, he has not been able to do this in the past.
He feels nicotine replacement patches do not work.
Today, we discussed the very severe nature of Trevor’s coronary artery disease and indeed his atherosclerotic disease generally.
There is a high likelihood he will suffer further myocardial infarction with real possibilities of heart failure and death.
Smoking cessation was strongly encouraged and probably be most likely action to improve his prognosis.
The other medication I have suggested would be most likely to improve his prognosis is a statin and he has agreed to trial this.
He is going to try taking Atorvastatin 80mg and check his lipids in about four to six weeks' time.
I will phone him in six to eigh weeks to see how he is tolerating it.
If does not tolerate the statin, then we should trial Ezetimibe and if this is not tolerated or does not adequately control his lipid profile, then he may be a candidate for Repatha.
Please feel free to contact me with any issues or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Chowdhury,





														RE:	GLEN MARK HEREWINI	DOB:	04/05/1975	UR:	892356

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Glen, a 47-year-old gentleman well known to the PA Hospital Respiratory and Cardiothoracic Service, who we met for the first time in Dr Hill’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.

His medical issues include:

														Severe centrilobular emphysema secondary to alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency.
Ongoing regular cannabis use.
Ascending aortic aneurysm followed up by Dr Ura (Cardiothoracic Surgeon).
Congenital heart disease.
Previous stenotomy for hole in the heart at age 6 months, patient unsure what.
Gastroesophageal symptoms currently being investigated by the General Medical Team.
His current medications include inhalers, Irbesartan 37.5mg, Docusate, and as required Ondansetron.
His medication list previously mentioned Metoprolol 25mg BD, but on clarifying with the patient today, he appears to have never physically taken this medication.
Glen was referred to our service for assessment of some atypical chest pain he has been experiencing for the last 18 months without increasing severity or frequency.
These last for a few seconds to a couple of minutes and 1 episode lasted a maximum duration of 10 minutes.
These usually occur after gentle exertion and are exacerbated by movement and breathing.
He has associated shortness of breath, but this pain is localised to the centre with no radiation.
He has no diaphoresis, presyncope or syncope associated with this pain.
In terms of his risk factors for coronary artery disease, I note that he continues to use tobacco and has a family history of myocardial infarctions in the late 60s.
On examination today, his blood pressure is 100/76mmHg, his chest was clear on auscultation and his heart sounds were dual with no murmurs.
Glen's echocardiogram done late last year, but although not formally reported, visually appears to have a low normal ejection fraction with no obvious regional wall motion abnormalities.
His CTCA performed in July 2022 at the Logan Hospital showed non-obstructive calcification in the LAD and RCA which requires medical management.
His ECG today shows sinus rhythm and an old right bundle branch block.
Our impression today, is that Glen has atypical chest pain with known mild coronary artery disease for medical management.

Our recommendations are:

														Commence Aspirin 100mg and Rosuvastatin 20mg.

We have not started him on Beta blockers  yet given his severe emphysema, however, if the respiratory team have no contraindications, low dose Metoprolol can be added to regimen in the future (this will help with his aortopathy as well).
Please ensure he has aggressive risk factor modification indefinitely and keep an eye on his lipid profile, aiming for an LDL <1.4.
We have strongly advised Glen regarding smoking cessation, and he seems motivated currently to make some reforms.
Given that the Cardiothoracic Team are following up his dilated aorta, there is not too much for us to add at this stage.
We have discharged Glen from our clinic.
Please do not hesitate in re-referring him if you  have any clinical concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Medications:

														Apixaban 5mg BD, Metoprolol XL 47.5mg daily, Flecainide 50mg BD (increased to 100mg BD).
Thank you for referring Mr Hernandez for further assessment and management.
Mark is a 43 year old man with recurrent persistent atrial fibrillation.
This has been diagnosed over the last several years, though he was most recently in hospital  in December, having a lipoma excision.
He was seen by Dr Eugene Yoong and commenced on anticoagulation,  and ultimate Flecainide.
He had a cardioversion around 2 weeks ago and had recurrence of his palpitations around 3 or 4 days ago.
He is feeling more tired and fatigued subsequently.
He has had no syncope or presyncope.
There is no history of hypertension or diabetes for Mark.
He had coronary angiography in 2021 with no obstruction coronary disease and an echocardiogram in November of 2022 showed normal LV function and no valvular abnormalities.
On examination his heart rate was 90bpm in AF.
An ECG confirmed atrial fibrillation.
Mark has recurrent persistent atrial fibrillation following his cardioversion, though he was only on a modest of Flecainide.
I have increased this to 100mg BD and spoken with him regarding going on to a repeat cardioversion on this higher dose.
I had an initial discussion with him regarding the option of further antiarrhythmic therapy or going on to an AF ablation depending on his symptom response.
I will update you following his cardioversion.

Yours sincerely,

Non-obstructive coronary artery disease.

Cardiac conduction disease.

Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Other Conditions:

Medications:

I reviewed Steven Heslip today at the PA Hospital.

He has had no angina, no prolonged or pathological palpitations and no syncope.

Dear Dr Horwood,





														RE:	TREVOR MICHAEL HIMSTEDT	DOB:	21/10/1961	UR:	1039450

																					

														

														

														Issues:

														Severe aortic stenosis.
AV velocity 4.4m/s, mean gradient 59mmHg, DSI 0.19.
Moderate systolic dysfunction, with severely dilated left ventricle.

Background:

														Left above knee amputation 2013, for non-healing ulcer / sepsis.
Significant obesity, current weight around 140 kilograms.
Reduced mobility in the setting of the above, uses wheelchair for mobility.
Agoraphobia.
Anxiety.
Penile cancer 2022.
Penectomy RBWH 2022.
No convincing FDG metastatic disease on recent PET scan 20.01.2023, awaiting formal follow up in the Urology Clinic next week.

Current Medications:

														Ramipril 1.25mg.
I had the pleasure of meeting Trevor alongside Dr Camuglia in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
He usually sees Dr Harrop who has referred him for an assessment for consideration of valve intervention.
Symptom wise, it is difficult to ascertain much as his mobility is quite limited.
He is wheelchair bound but within this, does not report any chest pain, shortness of breath and has never had any syncope or dizzy spells.
His main background is as above.
I understand he has follow up with the Urology Team next week, but his recent PET scan looks fairly reassuring.
Socially he does not smoke, does not drink and lives alone.
He does have a brother and sister who live not too far away and would be able to assist in appointment clinics and recuperation.
On examination, his blood pressure was 160/80mmHg, heart sounds with an ejection systolic murmur consistent with severe aortic stenosis.
He was euvolaemic with a clear chest.
His ECG shows sinus rhythm with ventricular bigeminy.
He has had a CT TAVR performed which we have reviewed.
This has not yet been formally reported.
We also reviewed his echocardiogram images today.
Our impression is that Trevor would be a high-risk candidate for a surgical aortic valve.

Given his severe aortic stenosis and now reduced ejection fraction, although it is difficult to gauge his symptoms, we should consider proceeding with an intervention in the form of a transcatheter aortic valve.
We will discuss this at our Heart Team Meeting.

Otherwise, we discussed the nature of the valve interventions with him including the risk up to around 1 in 20 of significant consequences such as stroke, blindness, major bleeding requiring urgent surgery, loss of his right limb, infection and death.
We also discussed with him the possibility of requiring a pacemaker up to 1 in 20 and a 1 to 2% infection risk.
He has been provided written paperwork for his consideration.

The plan is as follows:

														He will have further assessment with one of our surgical colleagues, to see if they are in agreeance.

We will discuss his case at our Heart Team Meeting regarding potential procedure

														I have given him a script for Miconazole 2% cream to use 3 times a day to bilateral groin.
He should do this continuously until he is seen for his valve.
I have increased his Ramipril to 2.5mg today and provided him a script for this.
He will have follow up with Dr Harrop in the intervening time.

Yours sincerely,

Penile cancer with penectomy April 2022.
Obesity (current weight 143kg).
Left leg amputation due to non-healing ulcer.
Mobilises with wheelchair, independent with ADL’s.
Trevor’s only current medication is Ramipril  2.5mg (dose increased today).
Trevor has tolerated the Ramipril  well.

I have increased his Ramipril  to 2.5mg.

Trevor was also reviewed by the High Risk Valve Team today and will be discussed at the Heart Team Meeting for consideration of transcatheter aortic valve replacement.

Dear Danielle,





														RE:	TREVOR  HIMSTEDT	DOB:	21/10/1961	UR:	1039450

																					

														

														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Severe aortic stenosis with evolving left ventricular systolic dysfunction.
Non-obstructive coronary artery disease.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Severe obesity.

Other Conditions:

														Previous left above knee amputation, subsequent wheelchair for mobility.
Previous penectomy for penile carcinoma.
Agoraphobia.
Social isolation.
Has living siblings but no children or partner.

Medications:

														Ramipril 2.5mg once daily.
I reviewed Trevor Himstedt today.
He has severe aortic stenosis and evolving left ventricular systolic dysfunction.
He has had no angina, no palpitations, and no syncope.
His chance of heart failure or death within the next 6 to 12 months is more than 50%, given the significance of his aortic stenosis and the evolution of left ventricular dysfunction.
I explained this to him today.
We discussed the natural history of the aortic valve disease including a 50% risk of heart failure or death within the next year or two without procedural intervention.

In relation to transcatheter aortic valve replacement we discussed the potential risks including a risk of 5% - 10% major complications that could include: stroke resulting in permanent disability, inability to walk or talk, blindness, death or permanent nursing home placement; major vascular or cardiac complications including dissection, rupture, the need for major reparative surgery, death or limb loss; kidney failure requiring permanent use of a dialysis machine; infection resulting in the need for major open heart surgery and or death.
We also discussed a 20 - 30% risk of requiring a permanent pacemaker as a result of the procedure.
The relevant written educational material outlining these issues was also provided (UQ Version 2021).

Despite Trevor’s relatively young age, his comorbidities including his mobility issues would likely make him a high risk candidate to have a traditional open surgical approach and for this reason, transcatheter aortic valve replacement is being contemplated as a more efficacious method for managing Trevor’s aortic valve disease.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Review at the PA Hospital Heart Team Meeting with regard to transfemoral TAVR, via the left femoral artery approach using a balloon expandable device.

I have asked Trevor to use 3 times a day antifungal cream to his bilateral groin creases in the setting of previous fungal groin infection to minimise his risk of periprocedural infection, when planning for his transcatheter aortic valve replacement procedure.

Yours sincerely,

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Norman Hinton in our Cardiology Research Clinic, accompanied by his wife.
This is a routine in-person clinic review after being on the Open Label extension of the EIDOS clinical trial for 1 month.
I am pleased to report that Norman has felt remarkably better after starting the medication approximately 1 months ago.
Objectively, he tells me that he has been able to climb all 13 steps in his house, without stopping, whereas previously he would have had to stop at least once during his climb.
He is feeling much more energetic as well and has been increasing the amount that he does in the yard.
However, he still fatigues relatively easily.
He does not have any chest discomfort with or without exertion.
He reports no orthopnoea, or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea.
On examination today, Norman appeared well and in good spirits.
His chest was clear, and his heart sounds were dual with no murmur.
His jugular venous pressure was not elevated.
He had no peripheral oedema.
Review of his neurological system was grossly intact.
He has not had any new symptoms in any of the systems that were assessed today.
The next in person review for Norman will be in approximately 5 months, which will be the 6th month post initiation of the Open Label extension review.
Further correspondence will be forthcoming at that time.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Hinton.

Yours sincerely,
