Dear Dr Chao,



RE:	BARBARA SUSAN HODGENS	DOB:	29/07/1951	UR:  1008918

							

														I had a phone review with Barbara today.
Overall, she has been feeling well.
She continues to report NYHA class I-II symptoms.
Although she had a break from Zumba over the Christmas period, she plans to restart next week.
She has not had any chest pain, dizziness, PND or orthopnoea, sleeping on 1 pillow.

Medications

														Zoloft 100mg mane, Thyroxine 50mcg mane, Bisoprolol 1.25mg mane, Ramipril 0.625 nocte.
The intention of today’s phone call was to check that Barbara remained stable with her medications and to discharge her.
However, Barbara has been doing her blood pressure on her home monitor and these have been quite stable.
Today her blood pressure was 106/67mmHg sitting and 105/63mmHg standing.
Her heart rate fluctuated between 58 and 69bpm.
As Barbara is feeling so well and her blood pressure remains above the 100 systolic.
I have asked her to increase the Ramipril slightly to 1.25mg nocte.
I have instructed her that if she should feel any significant dizziness, she can reduce this back down to her normal ½ tablet.
She is going to Canada in two weeks for a family skiing holiday.
Barbara assures me that this is not altitude, and she will not be doing any high altitude sports this time around.
Reassuringly I note that she had a CTCA on the 3rd November 2022 and the conclusion was that her total coronary artery calcium score is four, placing the patient at the 25 - 50th percentile.
When allowing for motion artefact, there is no significant coronary artery stenosis.
I have asked Barbara to see you next week to get a blood test for a repeat Chem20 with the increase of her Ramipril and to have these done prior to her holiday.
After Barbara’s holiday she will house sit her sister’s home in Perth.
Therefore, I will review her face to face again in April.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														I had the pleasure of meeting Greg in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
He is a lovely 64-year-old gentleman, living locally and currently working part time as a casual worker with NDIS.
Greg has a prior history of repaired coarctation of aorta and a mechanical AVR which we have been following.
He has remained clinically quite well.
He is a fit and active gentleman and has no signs or symptoms of any ongoing cardiac issues.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 130/80mmHg, his heart sounds were dual with no murmur.
His ECG was in sinus rhythm with a PR prolongation, normal axis and infrequent PVC’s.

His last echocardiogram from June 2022 has reported LVEF 60% with mild dilatation of the left ventricle, normal RV size and systolic function, mechanical AVR appears well seated with satisfactory function and coarctation of thoracic descending aorta is still present with a peak gradient of 47mmHg.
There were no significant interval changes in the peak gradient of descending thoracic aorta coarctation.
At this stage, I have booked Greg for a 12-month phone review with an echocardiogram prior, for which I have sent a referral for today.
Please continue with your ongoing care and feel free to contact us if you have any concerns in the interim.

Dear Dr Gallage,





														RE:	OWEN SELWYN HOLMES		DOB:	30/09/1936	UR:	396872

																					

														Our pacemaker clinic detected an episode of atrial fibrillation, lasting about 10 days, and commencing about 4 days after his admission to hospital here following a fall.
This in turn was preceded by some drooling of the patient on the weekend prior to his admission.
I note his past history of stroke 13 years ago and current dysphagia.
He is very deaf.
It seems that over treatment of high blood pressure may have contributed to his fall.
There have been no further falls according to his daughter Karen, who attended today.
Owen walked into my office with a wheelie walker and was very slow and unsteady without the walker, over only about 3 steps.
Today, Owen’s blood pressure was 130/70mmHg sitting.
His cardiac signs were consistent with mild aortic valve regurgitation.
Echocardiography shows normal size and function of both ventricles.
Examination of his pacemaker system reveals normal function, with about 35% ventricular pacing.
There has been no documentation of atrial fibrillation since the episode in June by his pacemaker telemetry.
I think that escalating his anticoagulation to NOAC for stroke prophylaxis would potentially cause this man significantly more difficulty than benefit.
At the moment he does not require specific therapy for atrial fibrillation, which may have been precipitated by COVID infection which followed the fall in June.
I have advised Karen about symptoms of atrial fibrillation which might include dizziness, dyspnoea or chest discomfort.
None of these has occurred in recent times.
Owen’s follow up will proceed at our pacemaker clinic as routine.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	PHILIP HONAN		DOB:	18/04/1951		UR:	2033886

																					

														

														

														Background:

														Atrial fibrillation / flutter.
Permanent pacemaker 2022 for tachy brady syndrome.
Chronic pulmonary thromboembolism – on Apixaban 5mg bd.
COPD.
Peripheral vascular disease.
AAA repair.
I had the pleasure of following up Mr Honan via telephone consultation today.
He tells me that he has had intermittent palpitations and fluttering sensations.
However, of more concerns, he tells me that he has had oedema.
He tells me that he feels oedematous in his hands and his feet, mainly late in the day, but resolved the next morning when he wakes up.
I note that this oedema is a new issue.
He is not currently on a diuretic medication to my knowledge.
To further investigate Mr Honan, I will organise for him to have an echocardiogram and look forward to reviewing him again afterwards.
I note that he is due for a pacemaker check later this week, which will give us an understanding of the burden and the rate of his arrhythmias.
I look forward to reviewing him again after his echocardiogram.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Mitov,

														

														

														RE:	ALEKSANDER EMIL HONKISZ	DOB:	17/07/1955	UR:	755260

																					

														

														

														Problem List:

														Coronary artery disease.
Previous PCI to right coronary artery in 2005.
Repeat admission in 2016 with coronary angiography showing 3 vessel coronary artery disease with severe LV dysfunction (ejection fraction 15-20%).
Coronary artery bypass grafting in 2016.
Repeat echocardiogram post operatively showing recovery of cardiac function with mild systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction 45%).
Shortness of breath for further investigation.
Bilateral osteoarthritis of knees and hips.
Type II diabetes.
Hypertension.
Morbid obesity.

Current Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Bicor 5mg daily, Citalopram 40mg daily, Duodart 1 capsule daily, Metformin 1g twice daily, Sublingual GTN PRN, Ozempic 1mg weekly, Rosuvastatin 40mg daily, Spironolactone 12.5mg daily, Tritace 10mg daily.
Thank you for referring Aleksander Honkisz back to the Cardiology Service.
I had last seen him back in 2016, after his bypass surgery.
He had recovered well.
Had no symptoms of angina.
His cardiac function had recovered significantly from the pre-operative severe systolic dysfunction that he had to just mildly reduced systolic function post bypass surgery.
He had an ejection fraction of 45% with no underlying valvular abnormalities.
There was some evidence of scarring in the right coronary artery territory from a previous myocardial infarction nearly 20 years ago.
His currently symptoms of some shortness of breath, which he says is more noticeable in the last few months.
He has had no formal investigations for this.
He denies any symptoms angina, however, I note that his blood pressure control has been suboptimal and the HbA1c from February of last year was 11%.
He has had a host of medical problems related to some industrial accident and has been on follow up with Urology Service here as well.

RE:	ALEKSANDER EMIL HONKISZ	DOB:	17/07/1955	UR:	755260

														

														

														

														On examination today his blood pressure was 110/70mmHg, with a heart rate of 70bpm in sinus rhythm.
Systemic examination was unremarkable.
His ECG confirmed the sinus rhythm.
He does have a 1st degree AV block with a PR interval of 236ms which is a new finding and has been documented on a previous ECG at the hospital as well.
His QRS duration is mildly increased with a incomplete left bundle branch block morphology.
His QT interval is within normal limits.
In summary, Mr Honkisz is a 67-year-old gentleman with a known history of coronary artery disease and mild systolic dysfunction following coronary artery bypass surgery.

His current symptoms are shortness of breath which do merit some further investigation and I have suggested an echocardiogram to assess his left ventricular function and also decide if we need to modify his medical therapy further.

I am pleased to hear that the plasma treatment that you were planning for him for his osteoarthritis of the knee was successful and he seems to be very happy with the results with no further osteoarthritic pain in the knees improving his mobility.
Just to fast track his investigation I have arranged the echocardiogram for him in the rooms.
I would like to review that result and decide if any modification of his treatment is needed.
I will keep you updated as soon as the investigation results are available.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Londono,





														RE:	DOROTHY JEAN HORNE	DOB:	04/04/1931	UR:	2089613

																					

														Our pacemaker clinic has detected by remote monitoring of this lady’s pacemaker a period of 11 hours of continuous atrial fibrillation last year.
Apparently, this was asymptomatic for Dorothy.
Today, her blood pressure was 125/80mmHg sitting and standing.
There were no signs of cardiac decompensation.
Dorothy told me 2 interesting things.
The first: she gives a history consistent with nocturnal orthopnoea.

Her echocardiography today indicates near normal overall left ventricular systolic function with elevated left ventricular filling pressures from the enlarged left atrium which bows the interatrial septum to the right.
There is satisfactory left sided atrioventricular synchrony, and the right ventricle has normal size and function.
Moderate mitral regurgitation and mild aortic regurgitation co-exist.
Secondly, she is under the impression that she has blood in her stomach.
Perhaps this relates to the iron deficiency which I have looked up on the S & N pathology results site.
She led me to believe that she may receive an iron infusion in the near future.
For this reason, and at this time, I have no desire to possibly aggravate iron deficiency,by escalating her anticoagulation beyond Aspirin as stroke prophylaxis.
Dorothy has diastolic impairment of the left ventricle.
I have advised her to stop adding salt to her food and to remove the salt shaker from the table.
I have increased her Frusemide to 20mg in the morning, plus 20mg at about 4pm, and reduced her Irbesartan down to 150mg at night only.
Dorothy attended with her daughter today, who asked several questions about her mother, which did not relate to her heart primarily.
Dorothy’s follow up will continue via out pacemaker clinic.
Please let me know if I can be of assistance in the future.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr King,





RE:	CHRISTOPHER HOYES	DOB:	23/05/1969	UR:  1147081

							



														Christopher returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
He tolerated the increase in Entresto without any concerns.
Thank you for arranging a blood test with QML on the 6/12/22 showing a Na 138, K+ 4.7, urea 6.4, creat 66, and eGFR >90.
Chris is feeling well and has no PND or orthopnoea.
He reports NYHA I symptoms with no dizziness.
He has a good exercise tolerance walking 1 hr most day.

Medications

														Entresto 49/51mg BD (increased to 49/51mg mane and 97/103mg nocte today), Spironolactone 12.5mg mane, Digoxin 62.5mg mane, Rosuvastatin 20mg mane, Apixaban 5mg BD, Carvedilol 25mg BD, Metformin XR 1g BD, Vit D x 2 tabs mane, Garlic/horseradish/Vit C tabs x 1 mane, Fish oil tabs mane, Paracetamol 1g BD, Frusemide 20mg mane (withheld from today), 

														

														I understand that Chris is not able to use Semaglutide at the moment therefore you commenced Sitagliptin 100mg mane last week.
On examination his blood pressure was 90/60mmHg sitting and 110/70mmHg standing, heart rate 68bpm and regular.
He had no peripheral oedema.
His lungs were clear.
Today I have increased the Entresto to 97/103mg in the evening and left the mane dose at 49/51mg.
I have also trialled withholding the Frusemide 20mg mane as he is quite euvolemic today.
He can take the PRN as required.
I will see him back in this clinic in four to six weeks.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Jon,

														

														

														RE:	CHARLES HUDSON		DOB:	08/07/1964		UR:	2234918

																					

														

														

														Thank you very much for referral.

Diagnoses:

														Recurrent symptomatic atrial flutter.
For atrial flutter ablation.
For treatment with Amiodarone while awaiting ablation.
Moderate alcohol intake.

Current Medications:

														Metoprolol 25mg bd, Xarelto 20mg daily.

New Medication:

														Amiodarone 200mg TDS for 2 weeks and then 200mg daily.
It was a pleasure to review Charles, in the Cardiology Arrhythmia Clinic.
He was accompanied by his wife.
He is a 58-year-old gentleman who is retired from the Restaurant Business.
He lives on Russell Island.
He is a distant ex-smoker, having quite more than 20 years ago.
He does not have any symptoms suggestive of sleep apnoea.
He is not obese.
He is not diabetic, and he is not hypertensive.
He has moderate alcohol intake, up to 20 to 25 standard drinks in 1 week.
This may be one of his major risk factors for atrial flutter and I have asked him to moderate his alcohol intake, at least have a couple of nights off alcohol.
In terms of symptoms from atrial flutter, he gets palpitations and chest tightness.
Today in the clinic he was in atrial flutter with a heart rate of 160bpm.
Except for the palpitations and chest tightness, he was feeling fine and there were no signs and symptoms of heart failure.
His blood pressure was 110/70mmHg.
On examination today, there were no signs of heart failure.
ECG and previous ECGs are consistent with typical cavo tricuspid isthmus dependent right atrial flutter.
There are no previous ECG’s showing atrial fibrillation.
I have discussed with Charles the treatment options.
I have also discussed with antiarrhythmic medications for long term or cardiac catheter ablation.
The procedure was discussed in detail with him.
There is around a 2% risk of any major complication including vascular complications, pericardial effusion, heart attack, stroke, need for open heart surgery or permanent pacemaker were discussed.
He is quite keen to have this procedure and I will organise this for him at the PA Hospital.
There is a long waiting list for this procedure.
In the meanwhile, I have given him a script for Amiodarone 200mg TDS for 2 weeks followed by 200mg daily, whilst he is on the waiting list for the ablation.
I will ask Dr Coleman to keep an eye on his liver function and thyroid function on a periodic basis.
As he does get some chest tightness during tachycardia, I would suggest if you could organise a CTCA for him as an outpatient on a non-urgent basis, to exclude coronary artery disease.
As his CHA2DS2-VASc is 0, and if he had no atrial flutter 6 months after the atrial flutter ablation, we could stop his Xarelto.
I have also warned him that around 30% of the patients with atrial flutter have either undetected or develop atrial fibrillation down the track as both their arrhythmias share similar risk factors.
In this regard, moderating alcohol would be quite important as well.

Yours sincerely,

														Coronary artery calcium score = 1 – December 2022

														Metastatic melanoma.
Hepatitis with dual immunotherapy.
In remission on Nivolumab alone.
Tremors – on Keppra.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100 mg daily, Thyroxine 75 mcg daily, Candesartan 4 mg daily (increased to 8mg daily), Pantoprazole 40 mg daily, Prednisone 10 mg daily, Venlafaxine 75 mg daily, Diazepam 5 mg bd, Bisoprolol 2.5 mg daily (increased to 5mg daily), to commence statin.
I spoke with Shane via phone today.
Pleasingly, his CTCA did not show any coronary stenosis.
It did show a very small amount of proximal LAD plaque (giving him a calcium score of 1).
Given his young age and presence of plaque, I would recommend statin therapy, and I notice his most recent ALT /AST was normal.
Could you please commence either Atorvastatin or Rosuvastatin at low dose?
We have confirmed his mild global left ventricular dysfunction is non-ischaemic in nature.

His therapy needs to be up titrated – I have asked him to increase his Candesartan to 8mg daily and his Bisoprolol to 5mg daily, given that his blood pressure at most recent immunotherapy infusion was greater than 110mmHg systolic and pulse rate 70bpm.

I will see Shane mid-year with a repeat echocardiogram to reassess his left ventricular function.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Ho,





RE:	NHON  HUYNH-NGUYEN		DOB:	16/02/1994	UR:	225183

							





														

														I reviewed this 20-year-old gentleman with his mother in the clinic today.

Issues:
1.

Dilated cardiomyopathy secondary to Duchenne’s Muscular Dystrophy
    a. LVEF 45% 11.2012; 40-45% 07.2013; 20% 07.2014; 20% 02.2016; 20-25% 09.2017; 25-30% 03.2018
    b.
Last TTE (Mater) 5.3.2018 – Mild LV dilatation with LVEF 25-30%; Mildly dilated RV with low-normal systolic function; Mild TR.

c. Repeat TTE 6.1.2023 – Normal LV size with LVEF ~20%; Normal RV size with reduced systolic function; No significant valvular pathology

Background:
1.
Duchenne’s Muscular Dystrophy.

a. Quadriplegic; Wheelchair bound; Severe respiratory muscle weakness; OSA and hypoventilation; NIV dependent
    b. Palliative care review 8.9.2022
2.

Osteoporosis
3.

Previous spinal surgery 2008

Medications:
Carvedilol 15.625mg bd
Lisinopril 5mg nocte
Spironolactone 12.5mg mane
Ivabradine 5mg bd

														

														He had COVID back in about June 2022 and has noticed deterioration since then.
Certainly, he tells me that he has had repeated aspiration pneumonia in December and also more recently requiring antibiotic therapy.

I note that he was seen by the Neurology Team on 22.112022, who noted progressive lower limb oedema to his mid shins but were also concerned regarding his presyncopal symptoms and home blood pressure readings down to 70/40mmHg.
On questioning, he gets intermittent light headedness, but he also gets episodes where his legs become heavy and his head feels tight, which maybe sometimes associated with visual disturbances.
Fortunately, he has had no syncope.
Interestingly, he tells me that his blood pressures at home systolic are often about 70, but they tend to be closer to 100, when he gets light-headed, somewhat counter intuitive.
However, he has noticed progressive lower limb oedema, which prior was cyclical but now remains persistent.

RE:	NHON  HUYNH-NGUYEN		DOB:	16/02/1994	UR:	225183

														

														On examination his blood pressure was 85/50mmHg, heart rate is 96bm and regular, his JVP is not elevated, heart sounds dual, chest was clear, and he does have lower limb oedema to his shins.

Assessment:

														He does have what sounds like symptomatic hypotension.
His right ventricle now is reportedly also impaired on the recent transthoracic echocardiogram.
This obviously in all in the context of his Advanced Duchene’s Muscular Dystrophy that is also progressing.

Plan:

														We will need to cut back on his  heart failure therapy, which is not ideal, but given that the focus is on quality of life, it is the most appropriate thing to do.
I have reduced his Carvedilol back to 12.5mg bd, certainly this can be cut back further if necessary.
I have reduced his Lisinopril to 2.5mg once a day for his lower limb oedema and comfort.
I have given him a prescription for Lasix at a very low dose of 10mg once a day (given that he weighs <40 kilograms), and I have counselled him regarding further aggravation of hypotension.
Once his swelling improves, this can certainly be used as an as required basis.
I had a further lengthy discussion with him today regarding his severe LV systolic dysfunction and now with RV involvement.
This cardiomyopathy will continue to progress.
Having to reduce his heart failure medications to improve his blood pressure  is not ideal, but necessary in order to focus on quality of life.
There is no role for device therapy for his heart failure.
At his level of LV dysfunction, he would be at risk of a serious arrhythmia, including fatal ventricular arrhythmias.
I would not recommend an ICD given his advanced comorbidities and also the increased risk of procedural complications and inappropriate shocks.
Certainly, this will not alter his underlying severe cardiomyopathy or progression of his muscular dystrophy.
He is aware that cardiopulmonary resuscitation may be futile given  his limited cardiorespiratory reserve.
I have answered all his questions and he understands the issues discussed above.
I will catch up with him in 6 months to check on his progress.
Thank you kindly for your continuing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Shahzad,

														

														

														RE:	CLAUDINA  IBANEZ-FORMAS	DOB:	04/05/1944	UR:	421707

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Claudina, a 78-year-old female, well known to the PA Hospital for her multiple comorbidities.
Of note she underwent a right hemicolectomy on 21.12.2022, without any cardiac decompensation.
Claudina since discharge feels deconditioned, however, thinks that her breathing is better than we when we last saw her.
She does get some atypical chest pain lasting less than 5 minutes at rest, which is relieved by GTN spray.
Unfortunately, she cannot remember the type of chest pain she was having prior to her bypass surgery to be able to compare her current pains to her index issues.
Her exercise tolerance is approximately 50 metres and although frail she reports having a reasonable quality of life.
She attended her appointment with her son today.

Her current medications include, Aspirin 100mg, Esomeprazole 40mg, Ezetimibe 10mg, Fenofibrate, Frusemide 50mg, Metoprolol 50mg BD, Lyrica, Calcium, Insulin, Isosorbide Mononitrate 60mg, Colecalciferol, Vitamin B, Systane eye drops, as required GTN spray, Iron and Epoetin Alfa.
On examination today, she had no peripheral oedema, and her systolic blood pressure was 150mmHg.
Her chest was clear.
Claudina had an echocardiogram performed last year in December that showed new regional wall motion abnormalities in the apical septum and apical inferior regions.
Her overall LV ejection fraction was preserved at 50%.
In light of this, we have discussed the option of an elective angiogram plus graft study.

Claudina would like to recover more from her surgery and given that her breathing has improved since our last review it would be reasonable to continue managing her medically for now and reassessing her situation in 3 months.
I have also explained to her and her son that should her pain get worse in frequency or severity, she should seek urgent medical attention.
The chest pain pathway has been reiterated to her and she is to continue her current Isosorbide Mononitrate, Metoprolol and Aspirin.
If there are no contraindications from her up coming surgical review, then the Aspirin can be swapped back to her Clopidogrel 75mg that she was on preoperatively.
Thank you for your ongoing care and please do not hesitate in contacting us should you have any questions or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

														Stephen returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
He feels well.
He tolerated the introduction of Dapagliflozin 5mg mane from when he saw Dr Hill in December.
He continues to describe class I NYHA symptoms and denies any orthopnoea or PND.
On the whole he does not feel dizzy although about two hours after he takes his morning medications, he does feel somewhat lightheaded, it lasts for about one to two hours and then resolves.
He denies any chest pain.
I understand that he is awaiting sleep studies at Logan Hospital which is secondary to the sleep study assessment on the pacemaker check in December.
Blood test with QML in mid-January show Na 135, K+ 4.6, urea 8.2, Creat 93, and eGFR 76.
On examination his blood pressure was 88/60mmHg sitting and 98/70mmHg standing, heart rate 80bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
I have moved both the Dapagliflozin and the Eplerenone to evening doses, and I have increased the Dapagliflozin to 10mg.
I have asked him to have to a blood test to check his renal function.
I will see him back in this clinic in four weeks, at that time I will look at increasing the Entresto to the final morning dose.

Dear Susan,





														RE:	GABRIELL IUTE		DOB:	24/03/2004		UR:	2234912

																					

														

														

														Diagnoses:

														Type 1 Brugada ECG.

Medications:

														Nil.
I saw Gabriell in the Electrophysiology Outpatient Clinic today.
He had been referred on following his previous care with the Queensland Paediatric Cardiac Service, under the direction of Dr Jason Wildschut.
Gabriell is an 18-year-old man who presented with a syncopal episode which was felt to be vasovagal syncope.
He had some non-specific ECG changes though over time this evolved to be a type 1 Brugada ECG on occasion.
Gabriell has been well subsequently with no recurrent syncope.
He has had a review at the Queensland Genetic Service and has a request form for genetic testing for Brugada syndrome, though to date has not had his bloods taken.
Gabriell remains well and active with no chest pain or shortness of breath on exertion.
He has no exertional symptoms.
An ECG today showed sinus rhythm with a normal axis.
There was 1 to 2mm of J point elevation, though it was not coved and not a typical type 1 Brugada ECG.
Gabriell has features of Brugada ECG and is waiting genetic testing.
Fortunately, he remains asymptomatic, and we will continue with observation.
I will review his progress in 12 months.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Altawil,





														RE:	CHRISTOPHER JAMES	DOB:	29/03/1961	UR:	233223

																					

														

														

														Diagnoses:

														Dilated aortic root.
Low normal LV systolic function.
Possible embolic CVA in context of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation identified on implantable loop recorder.
Mild aortic regurgitation.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
Moderate plaque and calcification on CTCA in July 2015.

Medications:

														Perindopril 2.5mg, Aspirin, Rosuvastatin.
Xarelto 20mg daily.
I caught up with Christopher James today.
He has been doing well since he was last in the clinic.
He gets occasionally dizziness.
He denied any classical exertional chest pain, denied any syncope or presyncope.
He is tolerating his Xarelto reasonably well.
He is concerned about progression of his coronary artery disease, given his atypical chest pains.
Keeping that in mind, I am organising a CT coronary angiogram.
Hopefully there is no significant progression of his coronary atherosclerosis.
We will also assess the size of his aortic root by CT.
He had an exercise stress echocardiogram in March 2022, which was negative for inducible ischaemia at 9.1METs of workload.
His heart rate was 70bpm regular, consistent with sinus rhythm.
His transthoracic echocardiogram showed low normal LV systolic function.
There is a possible suggestion of a PFO.
His aortic root by echocardiography was around 5cm.
Therefore, there is a discrepancy between the aortic root size and MRI and echocardiogram.
CT coronary angiogram will provide further clarification.
He is taking Crestor 40mg, we should aim for an LDL cholesterol of <1.5mmol/L.
If it above this range, then we should consider adding Ezetrol to his list of medications and I will leave this in your capable hands.
I will catch up with him again in 6 months to follow up the results of his CTCA.
I will keep you updated with his progress.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Brown, 

														

														

														RE:	MATTHEW M. JAMES	DOB:	07/02/1994	UR:	2020955

																					

														

														

														Issues:
1.

Genetically proven hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
    - cardiac MRI revealing 16mm intraventricular septal wall thickness with subtle

														      mid wall gadolinium enhancement in 2017.

Significant family history of HCM
    - Maternal great aunt with sudden cardiac death from HOCM.

- Mother with genotype positive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with ICD in situ for 

														      syncope episodes due to non-sustained VT.

Medication: atenolol 12.5mg daily

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Matthew James today in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
He was last seen in this clinic 1 year ago and has since seen Dr Gould several times for his genetically proven hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
Since his last review, he has noticed some palpitations and dizziness if he were to exert  himself.
He was previously a Carpenter by trade, but now he has changed to an administrative role due to an episode of presyncope while exerting himself during a session of jack hammering.
He said he felt dizzy and then fell onto his bottom at the time.
He diligently reported the episodes via the implantable loop recorder interface.

I reviewed this episode as well as other detected arrhythmias on the Medtronic system today, all of which were sinus rhythm and over sensed T-wave that were mistakenly identified as accelerated rhythms.
The loop recorder has since been reprogrammed to reduce the number of false detections.
No further automatic detection has been transferred, nor has Matthew experienced any further presyncope or syncopal episodes since mid-October.
Matthew was very clear that this episode was not associated with loss of consciousness.
Matthew has had a transthoracic echocardiogram today, which has not yet been reported.
On preliminary review of the images, there was a small increase in his LVOT gradient with Valsalva but confirmation of the extent of this, will require more thorough assessment.
Please await the formal report of the transthoracic echocardiogram for further information.
On examination, Matthew appeared well and in good spirits today.
His blood pressure was 120/80mmHg and his heart rate was 76bpm and regular, corresponding with sinus rhythm on ECG with unchanged morphology from previous.

I have encouraged Matthew to continue using the implantable loop recorder interface to report any arrhythmias that he might suspect, especially if they are associated with significant symptoms such as presyncope.
Should he experience any other symptoms, I have asked him to seek medical review promptly.
Given his symptoms with exertion and the potential increase in his LVOT gradient with Valsalva, I have asked Matthew to increase his Atenolol from 12.5mg daily to 25mg mane.
However, should this result in symptomatic bradycardia, he may need to reduce this dose back to 12.5mg daily.

In discussion with Dr Cox, as Matthew has ongoing follow up with Dr Gould from the genetic hypertrophic cardiomyopathy perspective, as well as monitoring of any potential arrhythmias, we will discharge Matthew from this clinic, pending ongoing review with Dr Gould later this year.
Should Dr Gould wish for Dr Cox to be involved once again, we would be happy for Matthew to be re-referred to us at that time.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr James.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dariusz, 





														RE:	MILAN JANKOVIC		DOB:	30/12/1959		UR:	8055492

																					

														Thank you for referring this gentleman who suffered an anterolateral myocardial infarct in April 2019.
At that time, he received a drug eluting stent to the mid LAD and the ostial segment of the 2nd diagonal branch.
Fortunately, left ventricular function was preserved thereafter.
I note that he has some dilation of the proximal aorta.
Unfortunately, Milan has resumed regular smoking over the last 6 months.
The issue for address today was supraventricular tachycardia, but our discussion about smoking included mention of the fact that smoking is a lethal problem, and SVT is not.
Today his blood pressure was 130/80mmHg sitting.
His pulse was 60bpm in sinus rhythm as confirmed by ECG which also shows PR 220ms, QRS 95ms and corrected QT interval 415ms.
There was clinical evidence of mild aortic valve regurgitation, but none of cardiac decompensation.
Milan has not had any symptoms of tachycardia over the years since he commenced Atenolol.

Therefore, at this point, I do not feel that there is any pressing need to proceed to an ablation procedure for his SVT, which is slow / fast atrioventricular re-entry tachycardia as you have diagnosed previously.
The priority for his heart is for him to stop smoking as soon as possible.

Yours sincerely,

RE:	IGNO JANSEN VAN RENSBURG	DOB:	21/12/1972	UR:	8039132

							



														

														I saw Igno in my clinic for follow up today.
He has been well and asymptomatic from the cardiac point of view over the last 6 months.
Specifically, he denied any exertional angina.
His repeat echocardiogram showed normal left ventricular size with mild segmental LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF 48%), and no significant valvular abnormalities.
His background is significant for ischaemic heart disease with previous anterior STEMI in 2018, and PCI to LAD, hypertension, untreated obstructive sleep apnoea and obesity.
His current medications include Aspirin 100mg daily, Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Ramipril 10mg daily, and Atorvastatin 40mg daily.
He has no allergies.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 55bpm, regular, and his blood pressure was 135/70mmHg.
Today, I have asked Igno to check his home blood pressure.
If it is consistently >130/80mmHg, he will start Amlodipine 2.5mg daily (script provided).
In the meantime, I have also asked him to see you again for consideration of a repeat sleep study for his sleep apnoea.
I will see Igno again in 1 year for follow up.
Thank you for looking after Igno.

														Thank you for joining Wayen today during our telehealth appointment.
Wayen suffered from a myocardial infarction without evidence of obstructive coronary artery disease on angiogram in November 2021.
He was treated with dual antiplatelet therapy for 6 months and underwent a CTPA to exclude alternative causes such as pulmonary embolus.
Since then, he has been doing very well from a cardiac perspective with no chest pain, heart failure symptoms, palpitations or syncope.
He has been compliant with his medications which include, Diabex, Lasix 40mg, Lipidil 80mg, Metoprolol 25mg mg BD, Micardis 40mg once daily, Nexium 20mg, along with Seebri and Ventolin puffers.
Wayen’s other medical issues includes, an ex-smoking history, obesity, type II diabetes and hypertension.
Thank you for sending his vital signs to us today, which showed a blood pressure of 127/65mmHg and a heart rate of 71bpm.
His ECG sent by you, showed sinus rhythm with a known right bundle branch block.
His recent blood tests showed a creatinine of 90 and LDL of 1.9.

Our impression today is that Wayen is stable from a cardiac perspective, however, given that his angiogram did not show any significant coronary artery disease, it might be worth while performing a cardiac MRI to exclude any structural cardiac conditions.

Our recommendations are:

														Cardiac MRI.
Review in 12 months once the MRI has been performed.
Add Ezetimibe 10mg, aiming for an LDL <1.4.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Wayen and please do not hesitate in contacting us should you have any questions or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Salman,





RE:	KEITH  JEFFERY	DOB:	21/08/1949	UR:	8020000

							







														

														It was a pleasure to review Keith today 11.01.2023.
He is a 73-year-old gentleman who has a 6-year history of SVT, for which you kindly sent an ECG demonstrating a narrow complex tachycardia.
He has since started Sotalol and has none since then.
His last episode was on 09.12.2022, with palpitations and SVT.
He was treated with Adenosine, no effect with Valsalva.
ECG today demonstrates normal sinus rhythm with a normal QTc and no evidence of pre-excitation.
He is medicated currently on Sotalol 120mg orally BD, Clopidogrel 75mg, Ezetrol 100mg, Pariet 20mg and Famotidine 20mg.
He has a past history of ischaemic heart disease with a stent to the mid LAD with 90% stenosis, statin induced hepatitis and gastroesophageal reflux and hyperlipidaemia.
He has had a recent echocardiogram and from your letter he has a normal ejection fraction, mild mitral regurgitation and dilated ascending aorta of 5cm.
He imbibes minimal alcohol; he partakes of no caffeine, and he is a non-smoker.
He has not relevant family history.
I note that his urea and electrolytes are normal.
I would be grateful if Dr Mitchell could perform a thyroid function test to exclude this as contributory.
I note he is allergic to statin, NSAIDs and paracetamol due to his liver condition which is preclusion for an allergy.
I have discussed the risks and benefits of an electrophysiological study with radiofrequency ablation.
If he has an ablatable arrhythmia induced, there is a 95% chance of success.
He may require left atrial access via trans-septal to achieve this.

There is a 5% recurrence rate, a 1 to 2% complication rate including permanent pacemaker, cardiac tamponade, venous access complications and pulmonary embolus, a less than 1% risk of a stroke, myocardial infarction and death.
He is happy to proceed and has private health insurance and would like to use this and I will facilitate this for him at St Andrew’s War Memorial Hospital Wickham Terrace.

RE:	KEITH  JEFFERY	DOB:	21/08/1949	UR:	8020000

If there are any problems, please do not hesitate to get in touch with me.

Dear Dr Marie Andrews,





RE:	AMANDA JESSOP		DOB:	28/10/1960		UR:	2209144

							



														Amanda returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
She tolerated the increase in the Entresto without any concerns.
She told me that she had a blood test with Australian Clinical Labs after the increase and these levels were fine.
However, on calling Australian Clinical Labs I could not find any documentation of these blood tests today.
Symptomatically she reports no orthopnoea, PND with NYHA class II symptoms.
She has no dizziness.

Medications

														Bisoprolol 10mg nocte, Frusemide 40mg PRN, Entresto 49/51mg mane + 97/103mg nocte, Spironolactone 25mg mane, Metformin 500mg nocte, Empagliflozin 10mg nocte, Aspirin 100mg mane.
On examination her blood pressure was 120/70mmHg sitting and 120/80mmHg standing, heart rate 76bpm and regular.
She had no peripheral oedema.
Amanda had left before I established that she most likely has not had a blood test since the last increase of her Entresto.
Therefore, I have asked her to see you next week for a blood request slip to repeat her renal functions to ensure that these have remained stable.
If these have remained stable, could you increase the Entresto 97/103mg BD and repeat her renal function two weeks after this increase.
Given that Amanda continues to report lethargy I would also appreciate if you would add iron studies to the blood test, as patients with heart failure can have iron deficiency.

If she does have ferritin levels of under 100 or between 100 and 300 with a trans ferritin less than 20, she would be eligible for an iron infusion which you are welcome to organise, or I can organise here.
I plan to see Amanda back in this clinic in April 2023.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dr Nick Sawyer

														Dear Dr Sawyer, 

														

														

														RE:	KARAN JESSOP		DOB:	26/10/1957		UR:	391890

																					

														

														

														Issues:
# Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
   - noted concentric hypertrophy in 2015 - no LVOT gradient
   - moderately thickened LV (2020) - peak gradient 45, IVS 1.6cm, PW 1.4cm
   - MPS (2020): negative for inducible ischaemia
# Renal transplant recipient
   - 2nd graft 2010
   - baseline eGFR 28, Cr 163 (14/12/22)
# T2DM
   - HbA1c 8.3% Sept 2022
# Hypertension (treated)
# Anaemia

Medications:
aspirin 100mg mane, irbesartan 75mg mane, nicotinamide 500mg BD, magnesium supplement, cotrimoxazole 300/500mg mane, tacrolimus 3.5mg mane, prednisolone 5mg mane, mycophenolate 500mg BD, allopurinol 100mg mane, Protaphane insulin 16 units mane, 4 units nocte, atorvastatin 20mg nocte, cefalexin 250mg mane (UTI prophylaxis), pantoprazole 40mg nocte

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Karan Jessop in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.

She was referred to us for review of thickened left ventricular wall and a positive gradient found on a transthoracic echocardiogram for consideration of differential diagnosis of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy or amyloidosis.
This is on a background of 2 previous renal transplant grafts, type II diabetes, and long term treated hypertension.
Discussing with Karan today about her symptoms, she tells me that she has had several years of progressive shortness of breath, especially with exertion.
She often finds that she needs to stop climbing the stairs halfway, especially if she were to be carrying groceries or a heavy load.
She has not had any syncopal episodes, nor does she have any regular presyncopal episodes.
She describes having occasional palpitations, which can occur at any time.
The occurrence of these palpitations is now approximately once a month.
They have not been associated with any syncope / presyncope or falls.
Reviewing her family history, Karan tells me that her mother has palpitations as well and is under investigation for possible ischaemia with Dr Singh.
There is no history in her family of sudden cardiac death or unexplained deaths.
However, she recalls that her grandfather died of heart trouble, but is unclear of the specific diagnosis.
Karan has had multiple echocardiograms over the last 14 years.
Thickening of the left ventricular wall was first noted in 2015, when concentric hypertrophy was described.
There was no LVOT gradient at that time.

In 2020, when she had her next echocardiogram, the left ventricular wall dimensions  had progressed – interventricular septum measuring ~1.6cm and posterior wall measuring ~1.4cm – and there was now a peak gradient of 45mmHg, that could be elicited.
Her most recent echocardiogram that was performed in July last year, showed a small LV cavity with normal overall LV systolic function.
An LV ejection fraction of 60% by visual estimation and mildly increased ventricular wall thickness was described at 1-point 3cm both at the interventricular septum and posterior wall.
There was a normal right ventricular size and systolic function.
Mild mitral regurgitation was seen.
Also, systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflets were noted.
Associated with this, an LVOT gradient was detected both at rest, with a significant increase with Valsalva.
Her peak gradient at rest was 21mmHg and her peak gradient was 58mmHg with Valsalva.
This was further investigated by Professor Hawley with the potential differential diagnosis of amyloidosis.
The Kappa / Lambda free light chain ratio was 0.82, urine Bence-Jones protein was negative, and her monoclonal IgG was negative.
Furthermore, the lack of further progression between 2015 and 2022 on echocardiogram is inconsistent with the diagnosis of amyloidosis.
On examination, Karan appeared well and in good spirits.
Her blood pressure today was 110/70mmHg and her heart rate was approximately 100bpm and regular.
This corresponded with an ECG in sinus rhythm with 1st degree heart block, left anterior fascicular block, and no R-wave progression anteriorly and normal QRS.
Her chest was clear, and her heart sounds were dual with a 2/6 intensity ejection systolic murmur that did not increase in intensity with Valsalva.
There was no peripheral oedema.

Karan was seen by Dr Korczyk today in clinic, and we discussed her condition to date and advised her that our impression of her thick heart walls is secondary to a combination of chronic hypertension, diabetes, and renal dysfunction.
In the setting of the significant LVOT gradient, we have started Karan on Metoprolol 25mg twice daily.
To assess her progress on this medication, we will review her in 6 months with a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram.
Furthermore, in the meantime, we will also ask Karan to have a blood test for alpha-galactosidase to explore the differential of Fabry disease.
Thank you for including us in the care of Ms Jessop.
We will write to you again at the time of her next clinic review.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Lasla,





														RE:	SPENCER JOHN		DOB:	19/07/1966		UR:	8105477

																					

														

														

														Issues:

														Presentation May 2022, with lysed inferior posterolateral STEMI complicated by significant cardiogenic shock, rhythmic instability with complete heart block and failure.
Rescue PCI to left main proximal LAD, mid LAD and ostial / proximal circumflex with balloon pump insertion.
Transferred to ICU post procedure.
Post procedure echocardiogram showed EF 15 to 20%, with LV apical thrombus.

Current Medications:

														Apixaban 5mg bd, Clopidogrel 75mg daily, Bicor 5mg BD, Valsartan 160mg, Eplerenone 25mg, Frusemide 20mg Rosuzet 40/10mg, Pantoprazole 40mg, GTN PRN.
I had the great pleasure in seeing Spencer alongside his wife today in Dr Hill’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
I saw him back in May when he presented in Resus, and I remember having a conversation with his wife about the likelihood of Spencer passing away.
It was remarkable to see him walk through the door telling me he is completely asymptomatic and doing very well.
He reports no chest pain, no palpitations, no shortness of breath and is back to working as a Diesel Fitter without any trouble.
He is NYHA class I.
He has adjusted his diet and has lost 8 kilograms and tells me he has been seeing you regularly for follow up.
I thank you for doing some recent blood tests and I note his LDL was 1.1.
He had a very stormy course, complicated by cardiogenic shock and LV thrombus.
In this setting he was on Apixaban and Clopidogrel as a combination.
He had an echocardiogram back in September, which again is remarkable in the improvement in his ejection fraction.
He does have some mild impairment, but his EF is 4o to 45% now and his apex seems to be working.
There is no evidence of any LV thrombus left.
On examination, his blood pressure was 120/70mmHg, heart sounds were dual, and he was euvolaemic.
His ECG shows sinus rhythm.
I discussed his case, most specifically the Apixaban and antiplatelet therapy with Dr Hill.
We feel that given the improvement in ejection fraction, the resolution of the thrombus and the return of normal function of his apex, it would be reasonable to cease his Apixaban.
Given the life-threatening event that he had,  he should however, be on dual antiplatelet therapy forever, unless there is a strong reason such as bleeding to remove one of the antiplatelet agents.
Otherwise, since he is doing well, I have made some small suggestions for medication changes only.
Given his life-threatening presentation last year, I've arranged for him to see us once more in 12 months time.

Plan is as follows:

														He can cease Apixaban.
He should continue on Clopidogrel 75mg daily.
He should replace his Apixaban with Aspirin 100mg daily.
Both Aspirin and Clopidogrel should be continued lifelong,  unless there is a significant bleed in which case one could be dropped.
I have asked him to change his Valsartan to Entresto at 49/51mg dose.
Could you please increase this to the maximum strength if his blood pressure and symptoms, ie: lack of dizziness allow.
Could you please continue to monitor his LDL with a target <1.4?
Could you please continue to monitor him for development of diabetes and err on the side of aggression in treatment?
He will see us in 12 months time with a repeat TTE.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Plint,





														RE:	DEBBIE ANN JOHNSON	DOB:	29/05/1959	UR:	499857

																					

														

														

														Issues:

														Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
Warfarin.
Sotalol 40mg BD.

Background:

														NSTEMI 2013 – Redland Hospital.
Angiogram 2013 – mild circumflex disease only.
OSA on CPAP.
Obesity.
Anxiety.

Other Background:

														Multiple prior CVA.
Has been on Warfarin since 2007.

Current Medications:

														Marevan 2.5mg, Atorvastatin 20mg, Sotalol 40mg BD, Escitalopram 10mg.
TTE 2020 – Normal LV size and function, normal RV size and function.
Thank you for your referring for Debbie Johnson.
I had the pleasure of meeting her in Dr Hill’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
I understand she has been referred for assistance in management of her paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and for consideration of ablation.
She previously saw Dr Dwivedi back in 2020 and there had been a referral to Dr Deen for consideration of ablation, but I understand she does not have any private insurance.
She was previously on Atenolol and after seeing Dr Dwivedi, he switched her to Sotalol 40mg BD.
Her symptom burden actually has improved quite significantly with the switch.
She does report palpitations and feeling like her heart races, but since the switch to Sotalol there has only been 1 episode around every 12 months.
Prior to this, she was getting episodes every couple of months.

She is anticoagulated on Warfarin for a long time, and although there does not seem to be any contraindication to a DOAC for her, given her stability on Warfarin, I have suggested she simply remain on this.
Otherwise, she has obstructive sleep apnoea, for which she usually  has a CPAP, although this has been broken for the last month.
She is obese at around 130 kilograms.
Her previous thyroid function test and renal function were normal.
On examination today her blood pressure was 120/70mmHg, heart sounds were dual and she was euvolaemic.
Her ECG shows sinus rhythm at a rate around 60bpm with a normal QT interval.

Our impression is that Debbie has paroxysmal atrial fibrillation for which her symptom burden is well controlled on Sotalol, there is therefore no urgency to pursuing an ablation at this point, as the risk benefits would not be in her favour.

Suggestions are as follows:

														She should remain on Sotalol 40mg BD.
Should she have an episode of palpitations, she could take an extra Sotalol 40mg.
If this does not settle after an hour, she should then seek medical attention.
She should remain on anticoagulation, and we are happy for Warfarin to continue.
She should be encouraged to have her sleep apnoea controlled, reduce alcohol intake and lose weight as this will also improve her symptom burden and success rate of any potential ablation.

We have not organised for her to have a regular appointment with us, but if her symptom burden increases significantly, please let us know and we would be happy to see her again either for adjustment of her medications or consideration of ablation at that point.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Farahmand,





														RE:	LEITH G. JOHNSON		DOB:	27/05/1958		UR:	2240055

																					

														

														

														Diagnoses:

														Likely recent anterior myocardial infarction (non-STEMI) in December last year in Melbourne.
Patient self-discharged prior to angiogram.
Works  as a Truck Driver.
Hypertension.
Current smoker.
Dyslipidaemia.

Medications:

														Lyrica 75mg, Palexia sustained released 50mg nocte, Olmesartan HCT 80/25mg, Aspirin 100mg and Clopidogrel 75mg.
Intolerance:  Lipitor and Crestor.
Thank you very much for referring Leith Johnson to my Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
He is a delightful 64-year-old gentleman who unfortunately sustained a myocardial infarction on 08.12.2022.
He presented to the Sunshine Hospital in Melbourne, as he is an interstate Truck Driver.
He had a sudden onset of central chest pain that radiated down to his right shoulder and down his left arm with numbness in the right hand.
Unfortunately, he self-discharged from the hospital prior to having an invasive coronary angiogram, as he had some concerns about driving a truck.
According to the discharge summary from Western Health in Melbourne, he was advised not to drive a truck, and his license was suspended.
His peak troponin during that time was at least 15000.
His ECG at that stage showed anterior Q-waves.
He was discharged on Aspirin, Clopidogrel and Atorvastatin 40mg.
Western Health tried to contact him a couple of days after discharge to advise him that he needed cardiology review as soon as possible in Queensland.
It appears that they had some difficulty getting their message across to him.
Leith informed them that he would like nature to take its own course and he was not concerned about dying from another heart attack.
Leith has been doing reasonably well since discharge from the hospital.
He has not been getting unstable symptoms.
He denied any chest pain or any symptoms suggestive of congestive cardiac failure.
He denied any syncope or presyncope.
He has not been experiencing any palpitations.
Leith has been compliant with his medications, except statin.
Unfortunately, he continues to smoke.
He informs me that Crestor and Lipitor have given him cramps.
On examination today, he was comfortable at rest, his chest was clear, heart sounds were dual, JVP was not elevated,  and there was no pedal oedema.
His blood pressure was 120/80mmHg.
His ECG showed normal sinus rhythm with anterior Q-waves.
I had a lengthy discussion with Leith.
He promises to quit smoking.
I plan to admit him to hospital today for an echocardiogram and an invasive coronary angiogram.
We will arrange follow up for him based on his investigation in hospital.

Yours sincerely,

I will review him progress in 12 months.

Dear Dr Huynh,





RE:	KEITH W. JOHNSTON	DOB:	23/11/1950	UR:	8056883

							



														Problem List:

														Coronary artery disease.
Previous PCI to mid LAD and OM1 in May 2019.
Negative stress echocardiogram in May 2022 for commercial driver’s license clearance.
Normal  left ventricular function.
Type II diabetes.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Current Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Telmisartan / Amlodipine 80/10mg daily, Bicor 5mg daily, Imdur 30mg daily, Atorvastatin 40mg daily, Metformin 2g daily.
It was a pleasure to catch with Mr Johnston in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
From a cardiac standpoint he has generally been well.
He noticed some swelling in his legs, but that is not a consistent pattern for him.
I am wondering whether some of this is related to the Amlodipine that he is receiving.
As you are aware he has a history of coronary artery disease and needs to have a functional study on a regular annual basis for his commercial driver’s licence clearance.
He did have the dobutamine stress echocardiogram which was done in May 2022, which shows normal left ventricular size and function at rest, with an ejection fraction more than 55%.
There was some apical septal hypokinesis.
The right heart function was normal.
With the increasing dose of dobutamine he did not get any chest pain.
The ECG did not show any ischaemic changes and there were no inducible wall motion abnormalities noted.
I have reassured him with these results.
There is no functional ischaemia and as such he is cleared from 12 months from that last test in May 2022, for his driver’s license.
I have arranged for a repeat study to be done in May this year and I will follow this up with a phone review, as I do not think he needs to travel up 4 hours just for a short review.
His blood pressure on examination today was slightly elevated with a reading of 160/80mmHg.

RE:	KEITH W. JOHNSTON	DOB:	23/11/1950	UR:	8056883

														

														Could I request you to monitor that on his return to your surgery and if required, the antihypertensive medication can be increased with the introduction of either Moxonidine or Hydralazine to his current combination of medications.
Thank you for the ongoing care of Mr Johnston.

Yours sincerely,

I reviewed Stephen today.

We again discussed the role for open heart surgery in order to prevent cardiac related morbidity and death.

Dear Cole,





														RE:	JENNIFER JONES		DOB:	16/03/1986		UR:	2053616

																					

														

														

														I had a telephone follow up with Jenny today from the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
As you know, on 26.06.2019, we placed a large 26mm Amplatzer device to close an atrial septal defect.
As you are aware she has had follow up bubble studies which have remained positive.
I would note that Jenny has been completely asymptomatic and well from the cardiac perspective and she is no longer taking Aspirin or any other medical therapy.
Her last transthoracic echocardiogram in August last year confirmed that her right heart size and function are normal as is the right atrium.
That excludes there being a significant shunt.
She underwent quite a diligent transoesophageal echocardiogram.
On very close review the device is very well seated, and, in some views, there is perhaps some flow in between the discs.
There is no uncovered defect.
I believe this probably means there has been a lack of complete endothelialisation of the device.
We know that, that may occur in approximately 20% of people and does not appear to cause any long term issues.
Given that the right heart is now normal and that there is no uncovered defect, I am happy to reassure Jenny that she has had a good result.

As I have told her, if I do have any cause for concern, then the only solution would be open heart surgery to remove the device and patch the septum and I am absolutely confident that that is not required.
I have wished her well.
She does not require any follow up or prophylaxis in the future.
Of course, we are always available if required.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Wong,





RE:	ROBERT OWEN JONES	DOB:	08/02/1935	UR:	495143

							

														

														I invited Mr Jones to attend today to discuss 2 issues.
He attended with his son Neil.
Firstly, Robert’s pacemaker generator is subject to a hazard alert issued by the manufacturer late last year.
This involves a 1/600 risk of sudden failure of the pulse generator.
This is relevant to Robert because he is completely dependent on pacemaker function.
We discussed the options for the way forward.
Robert could elect to have the pulse generator replaced electively for peace of mind, but this would entail risks of another procedure, including infection at up to 2%.
Robert would like to think about this more and discuss further with his family.

I have indicated to him that should he decide on elective replacement of the pulse generator, he should let me know by leaving a message in the Cardiology Office at this hospital, or by contacting yourself.
Should he develop dizziness or syncope he should proceed to hospital immediately.
The second issue is the detection of about 15 seconds of ventricular tachycardia on his pacemaker telemetry overnight by remote monitoring.
Robert does not have any cardiac symptoms and he is quite well in himself.
His blood pressure was 140/75mmHg.
There were no abnormal cardiac signs whatsoever.
He does not have angina or dyspnoea.
In the absence of associated features, I do not believe that specific therapy of the detected arrhythmia will be of benefit for Robert.
However, of course we will continue with remote monitoring of his pacemaker which is 2 years old and performing well to this point.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Dissanayake,





														RE:	SVEN KANGAS		DOB:	21/03/1972		UR:	8109795

																					

														

														

														Problems:

														Ischaemic heart disease.
Out of hospital cardiac arrest with transient ST elevation inferior leads.
3 vessel coronary artery disease on angiogram.
Drug eluting stent to proximal mid LAD September 2022.
Not a candidate for surgical revascularisation.
Initial LVEF 20 to 25%, current EF around 30% on echocardiogram with a reduced LV volume.
Current class II NYHA dyspnoea with significant postural symptoms.
Possible cognitive impairment following cardiac arrest.
Smoker.
Family history of premature coronary artery disease.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Clopidogrel 75mg daily for a total of 12 months, Thyroxine 100mcg daily, Bisoprolol 10mg daily, Entresto 49/51mg 1 tablet BD, Empagliflozin 10mg daily.
Intolerant to MRA.
I saw this unfortunate 50-year-old male in clinic today.
He had a very stormy time after his admission to the PA Hospital with an out of hospital VF arrest which required an ICU stay.
It appears that he has settled and has optimised medical therapy.
He struggles a little bit with predominant tiredness and postural symptoms.
His dyspnoea is probably not more than class II NYHA at present.
He has had no syncope, palpitations or chest pain.
On examination today, he was euvolaemic with a regular pulse at 70bpm and blood pressure of 90/55mmHg.
He had no clinical evidence of left or right ventricular failure.
His 12 Lead ECG confirms sinus rhythm with normal PR, QRS and QT intervals.
There was evidence of Q-wave in anterior leads.
QRS duration is 109ms.
His cardiac MRI which was performed before discharge from hospital confirmed extensive myocardial scarring consistent with extensive myocardial infarction.
His LV ejection fraction was 24%.
His recent echocardiogram shows overall LV volumes improving with LV ejection fraction around 30%.
He should continue with his current medical therapy.
He will be referred to our Electrophysiology Clinic for consideration of cardiac defibrillation.
I will organise a 24-hour Holter monitor prior.
With respect to his driving, he should be allowed to drive short distances.
He could also start low impact cardiac rehabilitation locally.
I will bring him back for review to my clinic within the next 3 months.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr App, 





														RE:	JODIE KAYROUZ		DOB:	20/09/1984		UR:	772620

																							MTR:	1065126							

														Thank you for your letter referring Jodie for review regarding the result of her exercise stress test.
This was performed presumably as a potentially diagnostic test for long QT syndrome.
Your referral related to arrhythmia did not contain any ECG documentation.
I would not refer a patient with a fracture to an Orthopaedic Surgeon without submitting an x-ray – the principle is the same.
So, we spent some time obtaining from your medical records department, copies of all of the ECG data obtained during the stress test.
There was concern that her corrected QT interval increased at peak exercise.
The problem with this is that that measurement was made by the ECG computer, which has included the subsequent P-wave in the QT measurement.
So, I spent some more time measuring manually the QT intervals from each recorded stage of your treadmill test.
Corrected QT interval was 430ms at the start of the test, with heart rate 87bpm.
The corrected QT reduced progressively to 335ms at peak exercise and return to resting levels without hysteresis.
Accordingly, the stress test does not indicate concern regarding long QT syndrome.
Furthermore, Jodie is currently taking (potentially QT-prolonging) Ondansetron every day for control of hyperemesis during her 7th pregnancy, and her corrected QT interval today remains at 430ms.
Jodie does not have any cardiac symptoms at all, in particular, none of syncope, seizure or dizziness which is not related to her pregnancy.
She does not have agonal nocturnal breathing.
You did send along the echocardiography report, which also shows no concern.
I note this lady’s family history including the sudden death of a cousin aged 13, while swimming.
It is possible that her mother has long QT syndrome, which contributed to cardiac arrest last year and subsequent ICD implantation.
You report that the patient has undergone genetic testing at RBWH, which was negative for detection of long QT syndrome related genes.
So, in summary, we have no substantial evidence of long QT syndrome in this lady, and I have informed her accordingly.

Yours sincerely,

														Thank you for asking us to see Mr Keenan.

He does not get angina and his echocardiogram is normal, including his diastolic function.
His blood pressure today is 160/60mmHg, he has woody oedema (probably lymphoedema) in both legs.

I certainly would not increase the dose of diuretic, as it is unlikely to have much effect.
Thank you for involving us in his care.

														Robert returned to heart failure titration clinic today.

It was manageable but quite noticeable for him.
Otherwise, he has been quite well with no PND, orthopnoea, or dizziness.
He reports NYHA class I symptoms.
Although Robert does not have PND, or orthopnoea he does report sleep disturbances and waking up feeling unrested.
It's difficult to get a good history of this from Robert, I feel this might be related to his breathing.
I do note that Robert has a history of OSA and does not have CPAP machine as he found it too difficult to tolerate.

We have begun discussions again about the importance of having treated OSA as well as the importance of other lifestyle factors including weight loss and exercise to assist all chronic conditions as well as aid in sleep.

Medications

														Entresto 24/26mg BD, Bisoprolol 7.5mg mane, Rabeprazole 20mg mane, Spironolactone 12.5mg mane.
On examination his blood pressure was 106/80mmHg with no postural drop, heart rate 62bpm and irregular.
ECG showed sinus rhythm at 62bpm with PVCs.
He had no peripheral oedema, and his lungs were clear.
Today I have asked Robert to increase the Bisoprolol to 8.75mg.
If he experiences any severe dizziness, he can reduce this back to the 7.5mg and call me.
I will see his back in this clinic in March.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

														It was a pleasure to catch up with Margaret in the clinic today.
She has been well from a cardiac perspective.
She has not had any symptoms of her tricuspid regurgitation.
She did have an admission her with a lower GI bleed associated with some hypertension and a mild acute kidney injury.
This was attributed to a Spigelian hernia and some diverticular disease.
I understand she had a colonoscopy a couple of weeks ago.
Examination today revealed a blood pressure of 145/60mmHg, JVP just visible at the base of the neck, a pan systolic murmur, a clear chest and interestingly, no peripheral oedema.
Despite having severe tricuspid regurgitation, she is functioning really well and does not have any major symptoms of right heart failure.
I think we should continue medical therapy and I will see  her again in 12 months with an echocardiogram.

														Dr Siobhan Tiernan

														Camp Hill Health Care

														585 / 577 Old Cleveland Road

														CAMP HILL QLD 4152

														

														

														Dear Dr Tiernan,

														

														

														

														RE:	MICHAEL P. KELLY		DOB:	13/03/1962		UR:	875490

																					

														

														

														Background:

														Atrial fibrillation.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
Severe obstructive sleep apnoea – not on CPAP treatment.
Diverticular disease.
Asthma.
Depression.
COPD.
Non-obstructive coronary artery disease on angiogram in 2019.

Medications:

														Metoprolol 100mg BD, Rivaroxaban 20mg once a day, Rosuvastatin 40mg once a day, Telmisartan 80mg once a day, Escitalopram 10mg once a day and inhalers.
I had the pleasure of meeting Michael in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
He was last seen by us in April 2022, for follow up of his atrial fibrillation.
Since discharge, he has been clinically overall feeling well, however, complaining of intermittent recurrent episodes of palpitations which is almost happening on a daily basis.
He feels frequently quite fatigued and tired which could be due to his underlying atrial fibrillation issues.
He currently appears euvolaemic and has no signs or symptoms suggestive of heart failure.
He does not indulge in excessive alcohol consumptions.
He has not smoked since his last cardiology clinic review.
His body weight is 115 kilograms, and he has untreated sleep apnoea which could be a possible trigger for his atrial fibrillation.
He was advocated about the importance of CPAP treatment at his last review, and I have further emphasised this.
The main issue for him to not start on CPAP treatment would be a financial reason.

I have gone through the sleep clinic letters and  have further discussed with our Sleep Fellow Colleague, Dr Webster, if Michael could rent for an initial 2 to 3 months a CPAP machine and uses it for more than 4 hours every night, then he would qualify for a CPAP machine under the Qld Health Sleep Disorder Program.
I have explained all this to Michael and have advised him to contact the CPAP Providers to rent this machine.
The therapy of underlying sleep apnoea would be vital for the control of his AF management.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 130/70mmHg, his heart sounds were dual, there was no murmur and he appeared euvolaemic.

I do not have a recent echocardiogram available in the system, however a 2019 echocardiogram has reported an LV function of 55%, normal RV size and function, and no significant functional valvular abnormalities.

In summary, Michael is a 60-year-old gentleman with atrial fibrillation and I have recommended the following plan:

														

														Start Amiodarone 200mg TDS for 1 week and then 200mg BD for the 2nd week and then to continue on 200mg once daily after that.
He should have 6 monthly liver function tests and 12 monthly lung function tests while he is on Amiodarone.
He should continue on NOAC, and I have planned an outpatient DC cardioversion after discussion with Dr Wahi.
He should get his CPAP treatment ongoing.

I have booked him for a review in the Cardiology Clinic in 6 months and depending on the clinic progress of his atrial fibrillation, we will discuss the role of Electrophysiology / AF ablation, if need be, in the future.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	DAVID KENRICK		DOB:	09/09/1948		UR:	765762

																					

														

														

														I reviewed this 74-year-old gentleman in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.

Issues: 
1.

Presumed previous silent MI + apical thrombus Dx on pre-op TTE 23.7.2009

														    (Treated with 12/12 of Clexane during cancer Rx); NO previous chest pain or 

														    revascularization
    a. TTE 23.7.2009 – Normal LV size with LVEF 47%; Apical thrombus; Normal RV.

No significant valvular dysfunction
    b. DSE 14.10.2009 – Normal LV size with LVEF 45%; LAD and RCA scar with no 

														        ischemia; No LV thrombus on pre-DSE resting TTE 
    c. TTE 14.4.2011 – Normal LV size with LVEF 45%; Akinetic apex; Basal 

														        inferoseptal and inferior hypokinesis; Normal RV size with hypokinesis of the 

														        apex: Mild MR
    d. Was seeing PA Cardiologist till 2011

Background:
1.

Esophagectomy 2009 for oesophageal Ca; Adjuvant CTx/XRT; Multiple dilatations

														    post (Last 2011); D/C UGI clinic 12.2021
2.

OA; ?Lumbar spinal stenosis 
3.

Haemorrhoids
4.

BCC; Intraepithelial carcinoma
5.

Non-smoker; Occasional wine
6.

Lives with wife; Retired purchasing manager in carton manufacturing plant
7.

NKDA
8.

No bleeding issues, planned surgery, active malignancy

Medications:
Lipitor 40mg od
Aspirin 100mg od
Bisoprolol 1.25mg od
Nexium 20mg od
Iron tablets


														He describes a long history of sharp pains on the back of his left hand.
They are fairly sporadic, sometimes they can shoot up to the upper arm.
They would last often for seconds.
He can go for months without symptoms.
There are no specific triggers.
He is an active bush walker.
He can walk 2 to 5 kilometres, including up steep terrains, with no chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, palpitations or syncope.
On examination, his blood pressure was 125/80mmHg, heart rate 60bpm and regular, JVP was not elevated, heart sounds dual, pan systolic murmur at the apex, and chest was clear.
ECG shows sinus bradycardia 55bpm, PR interval 210ms, anterior Q-waves.

Assessment:

														His hand pain does not sound cardiac.
He does not describe any angina.
He has obviously had previous myocardial infarction(s) involving the LAD and RCA territories with mild LV dysfunction, but unfortunately has not had any recent echocardiograms.
He is currently not on an ACE inhibitor for  heart failure.

Plan:

														I have started him on Ramipril 1.25mg in the morning, this can certainly be up titrated.
I will organise a transthoracic echocardiogram to decide if we do need to escalate his heart failure therapy.
He should stay on the rest of his medications.
He should have ongoing aggressive risk factor control.
I would be grateful if you could keep an eye on his BSL’s, as his last fasting sugar was mildly elevated.
I will see him in 4 months.
Thank you kindly for your continuing care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Taufik,





RE:	ALFRED KHAN		DOB:	05/10/1963		UR:	756698

							



														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Transcatheter aortic valve replacement for severe symptomatic aortic stenosis with impaired left ventricular systolic function.
Anatomically suitable for right femoral artery TAVR with self-expanding system (somewhat unfavourable for balloon expandable valve owing to nodular calcification extending into the annulus).
Previously documented as a bicuspid aortic valve, however, CT demonstrates a trileaflet native aortic valve.
TAVR at PA Hospital on 02.12.2022 with Abbott Navitor 27mm TAVR bioprosthesis.
Coronary artery disease with previous coronary artery bypass graft surgery.
LIMA – LAD, SVG – OM1 – OM2, SVG – RPDA.
Previous remote inferoposterior completed myocardial infarction.
Patent LIMA – LAD but other grafts occluded at coronary angiography with Dr T Fetahovic at PA Hospital on 21.02.2022.
Previous ischaemic occipital stroke.
No residual neurological definite.
Cardiac conduction disease.
Baseline right bundle branch block on 12 Lead ECG.
Dual chamber permanent pacemaker.
Advanced degree atrioventricular conduction block post TAVR procedure.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Type II diabetes mellitus.
Dyslipidaemia.
Hypertension.

Other Conditions: 

														Previous prostatectomy, with subsequent urinary incontinence.
Under assessment with a view to penile prosthesis at QE II Hospital Urology Unit.
Previous surgery for Pterygium.
Gastroesophageal reflux disease.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Clopidogrel 75mg daily, Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Ramipril  1.25mg daily, Rosuvastatin 40mg daily, Ezetimibe 10mg daily, Spironolactone 

														



RE:	ALFRED KHAN		DOB:	05/10/1963		UR:	756698

														

														12.5mg daily, Empagliflozin 10mg daily, Gliclazide MR 60mg daily, Metformin 1000mg daily.
Comment:  Further up titration of ACE inhibitor precluded by symptomatic postural hypotension.
I reviewed Mr Khan today.
He has made a good recovery from his transcatheter aortic valve replacement procedure.
NYHA class I.  CCS class 0.
No palpitations, no syncope and no episodes of cardiac decompensation.
On examination he is clinically euvolaemic.
He is tolerating his current medical therapy well.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Aspirin 100mg once daily ongoing and indefinitely.
Clopidogrel 75mg once daily ongoing and indefinitely (indefinite dual antiplatelet therapy in the setting of severe negatively remodelled diabetic coronary artery disease).
Cardiology follow up with referring and treating cardiologist, Dr Taufik Fetahovic.

With kind regards,

Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Other Conditions:

														Significant ambulation restriction requiring gait aids (4-wheel frame, wheelchair or single point stick) with previous recurrent falls and increased demands for mobility.
Epilepsy.
Previous diagnosis of asthma.

Medications:

														Clopidogrel 75mg, Aspirin 100mg, Empagliflozin – Linagliptin 25mg – 5mg, Gliclazide 60mg, Nicorandil 10mg, Pravastatin 20mg, Ezetimibe 10mg, Allopurinol 100mg, Dutasteride – Tamsulosin 500mcg – 400mcg, Gabapentin 400mg, Levetiracetam 500mg, Levetiracetam 1g, Mirtazapine 30mg,Pramipexole 0.125mg, Pantoprazole 40mg, Tapentadol 250mg, Magnesium Aspartate, Budesonide Formoterol, Colecalciferol 25mcg, Hydroxocobalamin injection, Movicol, Oxycodone 5mg, Salbutamol.

He has made a good recovery from his cardiac procedure.
He has had no episodes of angina or heart failure.
No definite syncope, although did have a fall a few weeks ago that his partner feels was likely due to a seizure.
His echocardiogram is satisfactory with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction and a well seated, well-functioning TAVR bioprosthesis.
