Dear Dr Altawil,



RE:	LYNDA KING		DOB:	8/03/1945		UR:	915350

							

														Lynda returned to heart failure titration clinic today with her husband Tony.
Unfortunately, over Christmas both Lynda and her husband caught COVID.
I understand that you provided Antiviral treatment to them.
Lynda’s symptoms were quite manageable, she had a cough, runny nose, sore throat, and an increase in shortness of breath.
She denies any fevers.
She is finding in recovering post COVID she feels shorter of breath when exerting herself.
This is slowly getting better.
Overall, she reports NYHA class II symptoms.
However, if she does housework quite vigorously, she does have to stop and rest.
She has no PND or orthopnoea.
She sleeps on one pillow.
She gets very occasional postural dizziness.
She has no bloating and continues to have a good appetite.
She has had no chest pain.

Medications

														Apixaban 5mg BD, Bisoprolol 2.5mg BD, Perindopril 2.5mg nocte, Spironolactone 12.5mg mane, Phenergan 25mg nocte, Magnesium 2 BD, Ventolin prn, Panadol prn, Fish oil, Flaxseed Oil daily.
On examination her blood pressure was 110/76mmHg sitting and 110/80mmHg standing, heart rate 76bpm and irregular.
She had no peripheral oedema.
As you know Lynda’s most recent echocardiogram showed an improvement.
She had a low normal left ventricular function, EF 50%.
Normal ventricular size with reduced systolic function.
Dilated aortic root and ascending aorta.
Mild tricuspid regurgitation.

Considering that her left ventricular ejection fraction has improved with her current treatment and her ongoing postural dizziness, in discussion with Lynda we have decided to cap medication titration here.
Therefore, I have discharged her from this clinic.
Lynda has our contact details and is more than welcome to contact us should she have any problems with escalating symptoms or fluid management concerns.
I have also encouraged her to see you should these problems arise.
Please feel free to contact me if needed in the future.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Lynda.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Abdulkader, 





														RE:	MICHAEL KING		DOB:	06/06/1963		UR:	8086670

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Michael today 25.01.2023, in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
He is a 59-year-old male, for assessment for a primary prevention ICD.

He has a past history of

														Non-ischaemic cardiomyopathy - ?secondary to sarcoid.

Most recent echocardiogram performed on 17.03.2022, demonstrated a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30% and he has had a cardiac MRI which showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30% and appearance suspicious of myocardial infiltration with FDG PET on 23.03.2022 with FDG uptake in the lateral and basal left ventricular myocardium, suggestive of cardiac sarcoidosis.
He had a cardiac biopsy performed in November 2022 which was negative.
Obesity.
Dyslipidaemia.
Hypertension.
Recurrent lower limb cellulitis.
?obstructive sleep apnoea.
His ECG today demonstrates normal sinus rhythm with interventricular conduction delay with a QRS of 108ms and no other conduction disturbances.
He has previously  had a borderline left bundle branch block with a QRS of 125ms.
He is NYHA functional class II, but his exercise is completely limited by problems with his ankle.

He is medicated currently on Atorvastatin 80mg nocte, Bicor 10mg orally daily,  Dapagliflozin 10mg, Duloxetine 60mg, Eplerenone 25mg, Lasix 40mg, Entresto 97/103mg ½ tablet mane and 1 full tablet nocte.
He has been on this current medical regimen for greater than 6 months.
He imbibes 2 to 3 rums per sitting, 1 to 2 times per week and I dissuaded him from doing this either abstain from alcohol or have 3 standard drinks per week on separate days.
He is a non-smoker; he does not partake of caffeine and does not partake of illicit drugs.
I have discussed at length with him the risks and benefits of primary prevention ICD.
There is a 1 to 2% risk of complications, including pneumothorax, cardiac tamponade, haemorrhage and infection.
The device can be subject to advisories and in up to 25% of patients require an appropriate shock.
He is happy to proceed, and I have listed him at the PA Hospital for this.

As it has been almost a year since his last echocardiogram or assessment of left ventricular function, I have organised a transthoracic echocardiogram and if his left ventricular ejection fraction is less than 35%, we will proceed.
He is listed current pending the results of this echocardiogram.

His electrocardiograph does not qualify him for a biventricular ICD, however, this can be reassessed, if he does have a developed left bundle branch block, we would like this to be at least greater than 130, but preferrable greater than 150ms to derive benefit.
At this stage he does not qualify.
Many thanks again for your kind referral.
If there are any problems, please do not hesitate to get in touch with me.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Tey,





RE:	KAREN ANNE KIRK		DOB:	03/12/1951	UR:	1083132

							



														Problem List:

														Severe COPD.
Markedly reduced lung function test with FEV1 0.46L (22% predicted).
Moderate pulmonary hypertension.
Secondary polycythaemia.
Currently on home oxygen 2L aiming for an oxygen saturation of 88 to 92%.
Cor pulmonale.
Anxiety.
Macular degeneration.
Thank you for referring Karen Kirk to the Cardiology Service at the PA Hospital.
She is a 71-year-old lady who has quite severe COPD with a markedly reduced pulmonary function as highlighted above.
This is secondary to a number of factors, including a previous history of smoking, but also some industrial and occupational exposure, including other environmental factors.

She has been on home oxygen following a recent acute exacerbation of her COPD for which she was treated with antibiotics at Hervey Bay Hospital and has now been on home oxygen therapy on a 24-hour basis.
She seems to be managing satisfactorily for personal needs but remains at risk for secondary infections given the severe COPD.
She certainly  has signs suggestive of right sided heart failure or cor pulmonale with moderate pulmonary hypertension, which has been documented on a previous echocardiogram from September.
Her left heart function on that scan in August was normal, with no underlying valvular abnormalities and normal left ventricular ejection fraction.
She has no known history of coronary artery disease or previous myocardial infarction.
Her cardiac troponins on the recent presentation to Hervey Bay Hospital were also unremarkable.
On examination today, she had no pedal oedema, her central pressure was not raised, her blood pressure was adequately controlled, and her chest was clear to auscultation.
She did have a loud pulmonary valve closure sound in keeping with her pulmonary hypertension as well as a right parasternal heave.
Her ECG shows sinus rhythm with evidence of right ventricular hypertrophy and a right axis deviation.

RE:	KAREN ANNE KIRK		DOB:	03/12/1951	UR:	1083132

														

														In summary, Karen Kirk is a 71-year-old lady with severe COPD on home oxygen therapy, with all the signs of right sided heart failure secondary to her lung disease with evidence of pulmonary hypertension.
She did not have any pulmonary oedema and her central venous pressure was not raised today.
I have suggested we repeat her echocardiogram to assess her progress to decide about the diuretic therapy that she will need on a regular basis.
Most of her problem is related to her underlying lung disease and she does not have any left heart dysfunction or known coronary artery disease.
I have recommended we do a phone review with her as soon as the echocardiogram has been done, to decide about the ongoing management of her cor pulmonale.
She more importantly needs a referral to a Respiratory Physician for regular monitoring of her airway’s disease and pulmonary hypertension.

Yours sincerely,

Peripheral vascular disease.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

Dyslipidaemia.
Hypertension.

Other Conditions:

Lower limb chronic venous insufficiency.
Previous diagnosis of asthma.
Peripheral neuropathy.
Gastroesophageal reflux disease.
Osteoarthritis.
Age related sarcopenia with reduced mobility and a degree of frailty.
4-wheel frame for mobility.

Medications:

														I reviewed Mr Klose today via telephone link by way of discussing things with his daughter Vicki, as his intermediary.

They have also considered the written information carefully by the sound of things.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Review at PA Hospital Heart Team Meeting regarding proceeding to transcatheter aortic valve replacement as a category 2 patient (transfemoral approach).

														Diagnoses:

														Infective endocarditis.
Stroke secondary to septic emboli.
MVR (27mm Perimount) and CABG (SVG to RCA) April 2016.
Boston Scientific Ingenio dual chamber pacemaker implanted 22.04.2016 (MRI compatible).
Hypertension.
Atrial flutter.
DC cardioversion September 2018.

Medications:

														Apixaban 5mg bd, Sotalol 80mg bd.
Fred came in for review today.
It has been 2 years since I saw him last, and he has been stable in that time.
His balance is still poor as an after result of his stroke.
There have been no recent changes.
He has no chest pain or shortness of breath of exertion.
He has had no palpitations.

Fred remains stable with appropriate anticoagulation and satisfactory pacemaker function.

I will review his progress in 12 months.

Dear Dr Boothroyd,





														RE:	ROSALIND  KRAHENBRING	DOB:	01/10/1949	UR:	391818

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Rosalind in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know she is a 73-year-old lady who had an episode of atypical chest pain at her brother’s funeral, which precipitated her investigations.
She underwent an exercise stress echocardiogram with Smart Care Diagnostics where she exercised for 2 minutes and 56 seconds.
The report states that the test was stopped due to target heart rate being achieved, but also reports reduced exercise tolerance.
Today Rosalind stats that she felt that she could have walked further if necessary and was a bit surprised that she was taken off the  treadmill.
She experienced no chest pain.
She had a resting left bundle branch block that limited interpretation of her ECG.
The echocardiogram images were said to demonstrate some inferior hypokinesis with stress, but this may have been due to her resting left bundle branch block.
Overall, the test seemed equivocal.

This occurs on a background of:

														Hypertension.
LDL 2.2mmol/L.
Non-smoker.
Father had a fatal MI at 69 years of age.
GORD.
Non-alcohol steatohepatitis.
Osteoarthritis.
Possible shrinking lung diagnosed some years ago.
Her current medications are Aspirin 100mg, Atorvastatin 20mg, Metoprolol 25mg BD, Felodipine 10mg, Prazosin 1mg and Allopurinol 100mg.
On examination today, ECG showed her to be in sinus rhythm at 67bpm with a left bundle branch block.
She brought a record of her home blood pressures, which were all well controlled.
Heart sounds were dual with no murmurs and her chest was clear.
She did have some pitting lower limb oedema which she reports has been the case since starting Felodipine.
In summary, I think Rosalind’s exercise stress echocardiogram is equivocal and difficult to interpret.
I have suggested that we perform a myocardial perfusion scan given this will not be affected by her left bundle branch block.
I will review her in 6 to 8 weeks via phone with those results.
I have also taken the liberty of ceasing Felodipine and starting Perindopril 5mg given her peripheral oedema.
This may need to be up titrated.
Many thanks for your ongoing care and I will keep you updated on her progress.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Glen,





RE:	SHIRELY JUDITH KRAUSE		DOB:	18/03/1936	UR:	364554

							



														Many thanks for asking me to see Shirley in the Cardiology Clinic at the PA Hospital.
I note that she sees my good colleague, Dr Naveen Dwivedi privately.
She also had an admission under the Logan Cardiology Unit back in 2019.
Shirley is a delightful 86-year-old woman who lives with her son and is independent in her activities of daily living.
She does not usually drive.
She mobilises with a wheelie walker.
Shirley had a recent stroke, when her Eliquis was ceased whilst she had melena.
She has had an excellent neurological recovery from the stroke and appeared as sharp as a tack to me today.
She is back on the Eliquis with no further bleeding issues.
Naveen has been watching her valvular heart disease for some years now.

Her most recent echocardiogram in October 2022, showed severe aortic stenosis with a mean gradient of 45, severe mitral annular calcification with moderate mitral stenosis with a mean gradient of 8 and an RVSP of 77.
She has permanent atrial fibrillation with a CHA2DS2-VASc of 4 and has mild coronary artery disease on a CTCA.
Shirley feels well on a day-to-day basis.
She can get around the shops on her wheelie walker.
She does not experience exertional chest pain.
She very rarely gets breathlessness.
She got some this morning as she was rushing to ger here on time.
Otherwise, her last episode of breathlessness back in September when she had the episode of melena.
She has never had syncope and the only type of dizziness she gets is if she stands up too quickly.
Examination today revealed a blood pressure of 140/70mmHg and a heart rate of 60bpm and regular.
Venous pressure was not elevated, and the carotid pulsations were severely reduced in volume and slow rising.
Her heart sounds were dual with a 3/6 ejection systolic murmur, which was not  particularly high pitched or late peaking, and there was no s4.
The chest revealed some coarse crackles which did not sound like pulmonary oedema and there was no peripheral oedema.
I do not think Shirley is a candidate for open aortic valve replacement.
If we did need to pursue it, she should have a TAVR.
She is currently relatively asymptomatic, so I think we can continue conservative management for now.
She is catching up with Dr Dwivedi in April.

RE:	SHIRELY JUDITH KRAUSE		DOB:	18/03/1936	UR:	364554

														

														I have suggested she could then alternate between he and I for us to both keep an eye on it.
This would keep her in the system here in case we do need to move on to doing a TAVR.
I will see her again in October.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Salehi,

														

														

														RE:	GERALD W. KRYNEN	DOB:	30/03/1937	UR:	2209614

																					

														

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Gerald Krynen today in our Cardiology Research Clinic.
He is enrolled in the EIDOS open label extension study and has presented for his routine 6 monthly safety clinic review.

Gerald has only recently returned from overseas, where, unfortunately, he suffered a stroke on his 3rd day which was complicated by a fall and associated para-prosthetic  hip fracture and pulmonary embolism.
He required multiple surgeries to repair the prosthetic hip and is now mobilising with a single point stick.
He tells me that he does not have limitation to his functional capacity as a result of shortness of breath, as it is often his hip that makes him stop.
He denies any paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea or orthopnoea and overall has an NYHA class of I.
On examination today, Gerald appeared well and in good spirits.
His blood pressure was 101/66mmHg and his heart rate was 76bpm and regular.
This corresponded with an ECG in sinus rhythm with 1st degree heart block that was previously known.
He had peripheral pitting oedema to the knees bilaterally, but his heart sounds were dual with no murmur and his jugular venous pressure was not elevated.
His chest was clear.
His abdominal and other systems on review were also unremarkable.
I have asked Gerald to  move the timing of his Frusemide dosage to the morning, as it has been causing him some sleep disturbance due to nocturia.
I have not advised him at this time to increase his Frusemide dose to manage the pitting oedema, advising him instead to trial compression stockings to manage this non-pharmacologically.
However, should he show signs of central congestions, most notably orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, I would ask that you titrate his Frusemide accordingly.
From the perspective of the EIDOS open label extension trial, he will be reviewed again in approximately 6 months.
We will also arrange for him to be reviewed by Dr Korczyk clinically in the meantime.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Krynen.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Alexander,





RE:	KARLEE KUMAR		DOB:	22/02/1990		UR:	2134981

							



														

														It was a pleasure to meet Karlee and her husband in the clinic today.
She is a very  pleasant 32-year-old woman who has 3 young children, twins aged 4 and a 3-year-old and has just set up her own hair salon.
She has no significant past medical history.
She does report fainting a few times over the years, a couple of time on school assembly and once whilst in the kitchen looking after her newborn twins.
Karlee’s first symptoms that she can recall started about 18 months ago.
She was laying down watching a movie, when she experienced some sharp central chest pain associated with a thumping sensation.
When her husband checked her pulse, it was not particularly fast.
This makes me wonder whether she was having some ectopic beats.
These symptoms happen here and there over the ensuing year, but they were not particularly pervasive, so she ignored them.
Late in October 2022, she was at work as a hairdresser, doing some foils with her arms and shoulders up.
She said that her fingers gave way, then cramped up.
They were in a fist like structure, and she could not open them.
They were blue, freezing cold and she really had to rip them open.
She actually had a video of these, and it looked a bit like and ulnar claw hand with the main spasm in the 4th and 5th fingers.
She had some mild acrocyanosis, but there was certainly not a triphasic discoloration of white – blue – red.
Two weeks later as she was cutting hair when a similar thing happened.
She thought she would get some fresh air and may be some food, so she was walking to the shop.
She sudden felt her heart racing and felt increasingly dizzy.
She felt the blood draining out of her head and fainted.
I understand she was then taken to your clinic where you thought she was hyperventilating.
She felt heavy in the chest.
Since then, she has had some intermittent chest tightness.
She had no symptoms at all while she was on her Christmas break for 2 weeks, but the symptoms started again within a day or two of going back to work.
Karlee had COVID in January 2022 and had 2 vaccines in 2021.
None of these symptoms seemed to have coincided with COIVD infection or COVID vaccines.
Examination today revealed a blood pressure of 11080mmHg both sitting and standing with a heart rate of 72bpm with no postural tachycardia.
Venous pressure was not elevated, heart sounds were dual, chest was clear and there was no peripheral oedema.
I could not elicit any clinic signs of thoracic outlet syndrome.

RE:	KARLEE KUMAR		DOB:	22/02/1990		UR:	2134981

														

														The Holter monitor with QML showed normal sinus rhythm with rare ventricular and supraventricular ectopics.
She had 11 patient events which all corresponded to sinus rhythm.
I think it is reasonable to get her an exercise stress echocardiogram to exclude structural heart disease, although I think the likelihood of this is very low.
She could have thoracic outlet syndrome to account for some of the studies and, given that I am a Vascular Physician here, I think we should get her for a thoracic outlet ultrasound study.
I will see her again with the results of these tests.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Fu,





														RE:	DANIJELA KUMBARIC	DOB:	24/10/1971	UR:	812926

																					

														

														

														Problem List:

														Chest pain – for further investigation.
Previous exercise stress echocardiogram in September 2020.
Symptomatically positive with no ECG changes of ischaemia and no inducible wall motion abnormalities.
Subsequent CT coronary angiogram and calcium score on 07.11.2020, at the PA Hospital showing 0 calcium and no obstructive coronary artery disease.
Repeat exercise stress echocardiogram at Logan Heart Centre on 21.12.2022.
Once again symptomatic positive (9/10 chest heaviness) with no ECG changes of ischaemia and no inducible wall motion abnormalities.
Chronic fatigue syndrome.
Temporalis muscle wasting.
Distant ex-smoker.
Family history of coronary artery disease.

Current Medications:

														Atacand 4mg daily, Endep 5mg nocte, Symbicort inhaler as advised.
Thank you for referring Danijela Kumbaric back the cardiology service.
She has previously been a patient of my colleague, Dr William Wang, who had seen her for the same symptom 2 years ago.
Inadvertently, she has been booked to my clinic as a new patient.
She is a 51-year-old lady who gives a long-standing history of chest pain ongoing for the last couple of years.
An exercise stress echocardiogram in September 2020, was essentially the same as the more recent scan done at Logan Heart Centre in December 2022.
She managed just over 3 minutes on the Bruce protocol with symptoms of chest pain, but no ischaemic ECG changes and no inducible wall motion abnormalities noted.
On the basis of that symptomatically positive stress test, Dr Wang had arranged for her to undergo a CT calcium and CT coronary angiogram which was done on 07.11.2020, which was essentially normal.
At that stage, she was reassured and discharged back in your care.
Her symptoms of chest pain have been ongoing and once again has presented with a lot of anxiety and stress about this stress test result.
I tried my best to reassure her that there has been no objective evidence of ischaemia demonstrated.
However, she was quite anxious and was keen to rule out any progression in her coronary artery disease, especially as she does have a family of early coronary artery disease.
On examination her blood pressure today was 120/80mmHg, with a heart rate of 74bpm in sinus rhythm.
Systemic examination was unremarkable.
Her ECG confirms a sinus rhythm with a rate of 76bpm and no acute changes.

In summary, Danijela is a 51-year-old lady who gives a history of chest pain which is most likely musculoskeletal in origin, especially as her previous investigations have failed to show any objective ischaemia and her CT coronary angiogram had shown  no obstructive coronary artery disease.
I tried my best to reassure her, however, she is quite anxious and stressed about this ongoing symptom, especially as she has family history.
I have offered her a repeat CT coronary angiogram just by way of reassurance.
I have explained to her the risk of as small radiation dose, particularly  in a lady , which she was willing to accept and keen to proceed.

I have arranged the CT coronary angiogram for her at the hospital and will follow this up with a phone consultation either in my clinic or with Dr Wang, which is mainly to reassure her if the test is negative.

If there is no obstructive coronary artery disease, which his very likely, I think it will be important to investigate for other causes of musculoskeletal pain but there is no cardiac ischaemic demonstrated.

Yours sincerely,

I saw John in my clinic for follow up today.
As you know he developed acute on chronic kidney injury after we introduced Empagliflozin.
It was primarily due to dehydration and his latest blood test last week showed that his eGFR has almost returned back to the baseline of  ~30ml/min.
In terms of his heart failure, although he was mildly fluid overloaded today with mild pitting oedema in the lower 2/3 of his shin, he denied any significant orthopnoea or PND.

His background is significant for ischemic cardiomyopathy, type II diabetes, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, chronic renal failure (baseline eGFR ~30ml/min), obesity with sleep apnoea, left above knee amputation in 2020, and osteoporosis.

Dear Dr Gooch,





RE:	HELEN T. LACE		DOB:	13/07/1947		UR:	735231

							



														Problem List:

														Aortic root dissection in February 2017.
CT angiogram showing type A dissection with intramural haematoma in the ascending aorta extending from the root to the coeliac artery.
Operated at the PA Hospital by Dr Chris Cole with aortic root replacement.
Post operative atrial flutter and fibrillation treated with Beta blockers.
Left internal jugular vein thrombus in the post operative course.
Embolic stroke with multiple small foci of acute infarction.
Multiple defects noted in the cerebral hemisphere.
Some background small vessel ischaemic changes with a possibility of amyloid angiopathy was raised.
Follow up MRI scan in June 2017 when she developed ataxia and headaches – at that stage a microhaemorrhage was noted raising the possibility of amyloid angiopathy but no evidence of acute infarct.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
Previous depression.
Right laminectomy at the L4-5 level.
Previous medullary thyroid carcinoma RET V804M gene mutation positive.
Total thyroidectomy with bilateral neck dissection in July 2012.
Repeat thyroid function test in November 2022 showing euthyroid state on replacement therapy.
No evidence of recurrence on the F-DOPA scan in March 2021.

Current Medications:

														Amlodipine 5mg daily, Nexium 20mg daily, Aspirin 100mg daily, Orex 300mg twice daily, Metoprolol 25mg twice daily Crestor 10mg daily, Thyroxine 100mcg daily.
Thank you for referring Helen Lace back to the Cardiology Service at the PA Hospital.
Her current symptoms are predominantly shortness of breath and easy fatigue, which she has been noticing more for the last 6 to 12 months.
There is no history of orthopnoea or PND and she certainly  has not got any evidence of pedal oedema or overt heart failure.
She denies any symptoms of chest pain.
There has been no previous  history of coronary artery disease or myocardial infarction.

RE:	HELEN T. LACE		DOB:	13/07/1947		UR:	735231

														

														On surveillance her thyroid function has been within  normal limits.
She is not diabetic; she does not smoke and her blood pressure has been adequately controlled on current medication therapy.
Examination revealed no evidence of oedema.
Her central venous pressure was not raised, her chest was clear to auscultation.
She does have a pan systolic murmur heard along the sternal edge related to her tricuspid regurgitation but has no evidence of pulmonary hypertension.
She denies any history of airways disease or bronchial asthma.
There has been no history of smoking and no family history of significant coronary artery disease previous known.
At the time of her acute presentation, of course, she did not undergo any formal cardiac investigations to rule out coronary artery disease.
Interestingly, her echocardiogram from 2019, shows normal thin tricuspid valve leaflets with just mild tricuspid regurgitation.
Her right heart size was normal.
She had normal right atrial size and the right atrial pressure was within normal limits.
She had normal pulmonary pressures on that occasion.
A more recent echocardiogram has been done in November 2022, which does show a significant change in the severity of the tricuspid regurgitation.
However, the right ventricular size and function once again are normal.
The right atrium in only mildly enlarged with the estimated mean right atrial pressure within normal limits.
There is no evidence of pulmonary hypertension.
Of note the tricuspid leaflets on the more recent scan were described as being minimally sclerosed but mobile with a lack of coaptation of the leaflets.
This is unusual with a normal size tricuspid annulus and would certainly raise the possibility of underlying neuroendocrine conditions which need to be excluded carefully.
Just for completion I have asked for a functional study to make sure we are not missing any form of coronary artery disease, although that appears unlikely.

She will undergo a myocardial perfusion scan and I have also asked for a repeat echocardiogram to be done here at the hospital as I do not have the images from the recent private echocardiogram for review.

A repeat scan would also give me some assessment of any interval change,  including doing some myocardial strain measurements given the background history of amyloid angiopathy and thyroid disease that has been described.
I have explained all of this to Helen and her husband.

I find it a little bit difficult to explain all her symptoms just on the tricuspid regurgitation when there is no clear haemodynamic correlate,  particularly the right atrial size in only mildly enlarged, right ventricular size and function is normal and the pulmonary haemodynamics are within normal limits.
I would like to review her back with these investigations as soon as they are completed.
I have also asked for a pulmonary function test to be done to rule out underlying airways disease.
I will keep you informed with the results as soon as these are available when she returns back for another follow up.

Yours sincerely, 

														

														Electronically signed 25.01.23

														A/Prof Sudhir Wahi

														Director of Cardiology

RE:	DUNG HOANG LAM		DOB:	20/04/1957		UR:	668348

							





														Problems:

														Asymmetrical septal hypertrophy with chordal SAM and dynamic LVOT obstruction.
No evidence of fibrosis or coronary artery disease on imaging.
No family history of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or sudden cardiac death.
No evidence of pathogenic gene variants.
?Possible new hypertrophic variant.
Well controlled arterial hypertension.
Type II diabetes mellitus.

Medications:

														Unchanged, including Diltiazem, Metformin, Perindopril, Atorvastatin, Pantoprazole.
Mr Lam continues to get periodic palpitations and breathlessness on exertion.
He admits that on some of the days, he is able to walk without major difficulties, but then struggles and requires several stops on his way.
On examination today, he was warm and well perfused with regular pulse at 78bpm and blood pressure of 122/82mmHg.
He had a loud ejection systolic murmur at the left sternal edge.
There was no evidence of left or right ventricular failure.
His exercise treadmill test shows no evidence of arrhythmia, but it was stopped relatively early due to tiredness.
His blood pressure augmentation was minimal.
I will arrange a repeat echocardiogram and a 24-hour Holter monitor within the next 6 to 8 weeks and review him in my clinic afterwards.
His symptoms are fairly unpredictable, and, in my mind, they did not represent a fixed LVOT obstruction, but I will collect further information before making a final judgement.
I will see him in my clinic in 3 months.

Dear Dr Vivekanandan,





														RE:	NOLLAN DEAN LANDICHO		DOB:	28/07/1985	UR:	099361

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Nollan, a 37-year-old gentleman I had the pleasure of performing a phone review on for Dr Ahmad Cardiology Outpatient Clinic for management of his newly diagnosed dilated cardiomyopathy.
As you are already aware, Nollan was admitted under the general medical team in April last year with a COVID infection, complicated by a troponin leak.

He subsequently self-discharged and an outpatient echocardiogram performed in September last year, revealed a severely dilated left ventricle with severely impaired systolic function (ejection fraction of 18%).
Given these findings he was referred to the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic for further work up.
Nollan’s other medical history is pertinent for previous methamphetamine and alcohol dependence.
He denies any hypertension, dyslipidaemia or diabetes.
On review today, he tells me that he is feeling very well with NYHA class I symptoms.
He has no postural dizziness or presyncope.
He has no syncope, leg swelling, orthopnoea or PND.
Although Nollan remains off methamphetamines he has taken to vaping and admits to doing so too frequently.
We have discussed the health implications of this, and he is keen to cut down and eventually stop.
He is back at work however, he does not drive at present.
His current medications include Mirtazapine, Panadol Osteo, Candesartan 80mg nocte, Bisoprolol 3.75mg nocte, Diazepam 2mg TDS, Panadeine Forte 2 tablets QID PRN and Pregabalin.
In terms of work up for his severe LV dysfunction, Nollan has undergone a CT coronary angiogram that has shown normal coronaries.
He is booked for a cardiac MRI in February after which we will perform a chart review to follow up these results.
I have congratulated him on his efforts with the lifestyles he has made and medication compliance and encouraged him to continue doing so.
To help him stop his vaping, I have also referred him to our Alcohol and Drugs Unit here at the PA Hospital.
Nollan has been engaging very well with her Heart Failure Titration Service since being released from prison and will be seeing Robyn, our nurse practitioner, in Feb.
Finally, we have advised Nollan that he cannot hold a commercial license unless his ejection fraction improves, in case he was wishing to pursue that for employment purposes.
We will update you of the results of his MRI in due course.
In the meantime, should he run into any troubles, please do not hesitate in contacting us.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Holmes,





RE:	PIETRO RICO LAURENZI	DOB:	09/09/1963	UR:	556058

							





														Diagnoses:
1.
Multifactorial dyspnoea , likely HFPEF, No significant CAD on CTCA in 2017.

Obesity with BMI of 47 with type II Diabetes Mellitus 
3.

Atrial fibrillation
4.

Colonic polyps
5.

NAFLD
6.

Hypertension
7.

Depression
8.

CKD stage III 
9.

Obstructive sleep apnoea with community-based sleep study demonstrating

														      positional obstructive sleep apnoea
10.

Episodes of haemoptysis on a background of mild bronchiectasis in January 

														      2021 with unremarkable endobronchial examination via bronchoscopy.

No 

														      bleeding source identified at the ENT assessment .

Medications:
· Atorvastatin 80 mg nocte
· Cholecalciferol 50 mcg OD
· Digoxin 250 mcg OD
· Fenofibrate 145 mg OD
· Furosemide 40 mg OD
· Irbesartan 300 mg OD
· Metformin 1000mg MR nocte
· Metoprolol 150 mg BD
· Pantoprazole 40mg OD
· Pregabalin 50 mg nocte
· Rivaroxaban 20 mg OD
· Optisulin 30 U nocte
· Humalog 10 U TDS
· Semaglutide subcutaneous once a week
.

Lercanidipine 10mg commenced today
.

Dapagliflozin 10mg commenced today

														

														Thank you very much for referring Pietro to my Cardiology Clinic.
As you are aware, he is a delightful 59-year-old gentleman with multifactorial dyspnoea.
He has moderate obesity and weighs around 132 kilogram and a BMI of approximately 47.
Unfortunately, he continues to smoke.
He experiences orthopnoea.

He also expressed concern that given his exertional dyspnoea he will not be able to lose 



RE:	PIETRO RICO LAURENZI	DOB:	09/09/1963	UR:	556058

														

														weight.
His LV ejection fraction on most recent echocardiogram was 62% and also had severely dilated left atrium.
However, his BNP was normal.
He is on Frusemide 40mg.
He has not been able to increase the dose of his Lasix because of his impaired renal function.
He is also under the care of the Renal Physicians and his spirometry has showed restrictive pictures.
His NT-proBNP was within normal limits.
His total cholesterol was 4.2, with LDL cholesterol of 2.5mmol/L.
His eGFR on 16.09.2022 was 53.
His HbA1c was 6.4% and haemoglobin  of 187g/L.
His serum ferritin level was within normal limits.
His last echocardiogram was on 23.09.2022 with  Qld Xray which showed an LV ejection fraction of 62%, his right ventricle was mildly dilated with low normal systolic function.
His pulmonary pressures were mildly elevated with an RVSP of 38mmHg.
Pietro has improved somewhat since he last saw you in October.
He has managed to lose some more weight and has increased his exercise capacity.
His orthopnoea also appears to have improved.
He denied any exertional chest pain, he denied any syncope or presyncope.
On examination today, he was comfortable at rest, his chest was clear, heart sounds were dual, JVP was not elevated and there was no pedal oedema.
His blood pressure is 140/80mmHg.
His ECG today showed atrial fibrillation with a resting heart rate of 64bpm.
His corrected QT was 374ms.

Impression:

														Pietro is a 59-year-old retired Wards Person from Logan Hospital, who has been experiencing multifactorial exertional dyspnoea on a background of morbid obesity, BMI of approximately 47, current weight of 132 kilograms, type II diabetes, chronic atrial fibrillation, hypertension and stage 3 kidney disease.
He likely  has obstructive sleep apnoea that appears to be untreated and is under the care of the  Respiratory Team.
He is previous known to the Cardiology Department at the Logan Hospital, however had missed a few appointments.
He had a CT coronary angiogram in 2017 which showed no significant obstructive coronary disease.
The most important thing for Pietro would be to indulge in a healthy lifestyle, attempt to lose weight and abstain from smoking.
I understand he is due to see the Respiratory Team in the near future and will undergo another sleep study to see if he will benefit from CPAP therapy.
With respect to his renal impairment and possibility of heart failure with a preserved ejection fraction, I have commenced him on Dapagliflozin 10mg daily.
He will also check with the Renal Physicians prior to commencing this mediation in the next couple of weeks.
I am reluctant to commence him on Spironolactone given his history of renal impairment.
I plan to catch up with him again in 4 months with another echocardiogram.
Once his sleep apnoea is appropriate treated and once he has abstained from smoking, I could consider cardioversion for his atrial fibrillation with Amiodarone therapy on board.
However, the chances of maintaining sinus rhythm, may be limited given that he has had atrial fibrillation for at least 5 years.
Although, if he continues to experience exertional dyspnoea, it may be worthwhile trying to maintain sinus rhythm.
Given his elevated blood pressure, I have given him a script for Lercanidipine 10mg and this could be up titrated as required.
I will catch up with him again in 4 to 5 months with a repeat echocardiogram and will keep you updated of his progress.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Past Medical History:
# Ischaemic cardiomyopathy
   - STEMI 2006
   - LVEF 45% (9/11/22)
   - LVEF 30% (2021)

# AF
# T2DM - on OHAs
# Hypercholesterolaemia

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Faitalia Lavea in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today, accompanied by his wife.
He is known to this clinic from the perspective of ischaemic cardiomyopathy and atrial fibrillation.
Since his last review, Faitalia has overall been well.

He describes chest discomfort, which after extensive discussion, seems consistent with a musculoskeletal origin in the setting of his frozen shoulder, as it is sharp in nature and tender to touch, as well as associated with motion.
Notably, he tells me it is different from the discomfort that he experienced during his previous acute coronary syndrome.
Faitalia tells me that he is able to walk for at least 30 minutes on flat ground at a strolling pace without any chest discomfort.
The reason he stops after 30 minutes is due to fatigue and not dyspnoea or chest discomfort.
With respect to signs and symptoms of potential decompensated heart failure, Faitalia denies any reduction in his exercise tolerance or any requirement for additional pillows to suggest orthopnoea.
However, he tells me that he has occasional paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, which upon further questioning is suspicious for obstructive sleep apnoea.
He snores at night and his wife tells me that she occasionally notices that he stops breathing during the night.
Furthermore, Faitalia tells me that he often does not feel rested after a full night sleep.
However, he does not report any significant daytime somnolence.
Nevertheless, I suspect obstructive sleep apnoea and ask that you please arrange an outpatient sleep study to investigate this further.

From the perspective of atrial fibrillation, Faitalia was clinically in sinus rhythm today and I have encouraged him to continue his regular Apixaban to minimise the risk of stroke from a paroxysmal event.
On examination today, Faitalia appeared well.
His blood pressure was 116/60mmHg and his heart rate was 64bpm and regular.
His chest was clear on auscultation and his heart sounds were dual with no murmurs.
His jugular venous pressure was not elevated.
There was no peripheral oedema.
From the perspective of his left ventricular dysfunction, I believe that Faitalia can have further optimisation of his heart failure medical therapy.
As such, I will refer him to our Heart Recovery Service for titration and consider additional agents such as Spironolactone if it is safe.

To facilitate the efforts of the Heart Recovery Service, I have arranged for Faitalia to have a routine pathology panel, including FBE, Chem 20, iron studies, HbA1c, and thyroid function tests today, prior to his departure from the hospital.
A copy of these results will be forwarded to you for your records.
I will arrange to have a clinic review in 12 months with a  repeat transthoracic echocardiogram to gauge his response to optimised medical therapy.
In the meantime, you will receive correspondence from our Heart Recovery Service, with respect to gradual changes as per our titration protocol.
If he remains stable at the next clinic review, on optimised medical therapy, we will consider discharging him from our clinic at that time.
As mentioned above, I would be grateful if you could include us in the recipients of a report for any sleep study and pathology that you may arrange in the community.
Thank for your ongoing care of Mr Lavea.

Yours sincerely,

RE:	FRED LECHNER		DOB:	11/10/1949		UR:	056303

							

														Fred returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
He feels well.
He tolerated the change to Candesartan and the introduction of Spironolactone.
He still says that his blood pressure can range between 140 and 150 systolic most of the time on his home monitor.
He decided against the iron infusion and declined the appointment as he feels that he does not need it.
We had a long discussion about this today and I will recheck his iron levels in one month and re-refer if appropriate.

Medications

														Rivaroxaban 15mg daily, Aspirin 100mg mane 3 times per week (not currently taking), Bisoprolol 7.5mg daily, Candesartan increased to 8mg daily, Frusemide 40mg mane, Escitalopram 10mg daily, Spironolactone 12.5mg mane.
Fred is not taking the Aspirin at present as he feels that he bleeds too much if he bumps or cuts himself.
He denies any evidence of serious bleeding from the bowel or bladder or episodes of epistaxis.
Fred describes class I NYHA symptoms and denies any orthopnoea or PND.
He is experiencing occasional postural light headedness.
Blood test with QML on the 5th January 2023 show Na 140, K+ 4.2, Urea 8.3, Creat 67, and eGFR >90.
On examination his blood pressure was 120/70mmHg sitting and 140/80mmHg standing, heart rate 64bpm and irregular.
There was moderate oedema present to his shin on his left leg and nil on the right.
Today I have increased the Candesartan to 8mg mane.
I have organised for him to have a blood test with QML in two to three weeks, prior to coming back to see me, to assess his renal function, potassium, iron levels and Hb.

Dear Martin,





														RE:	LEONARD LEPPER		DOB:	27/01/1949		UR:	841500

																							IPH:	115617							

														Examination of Leonard’s pacemaker telemetry here indicates periods of atrial fibrillation, to add to the known atrial flutter which has been documented on ECG at Ipswich Hospital.
Since restitution of Amiodarone at adequate dosage, Leonard has felt much better overall, with more energy and less disturbance to his life.

Despite he and his wife developing COVID infection last Christmas, his cough is actually better now than it was, and I understand that respiratory opinion from Ipswich Hospital is that there may be contribution to his cough from sinus problems.
There was no specific evidence on CT scan of his chest to suggest Amiodarone toxicity.
Today his blood pressure was 115/70mmHg sitting.
There were no signs of cardiac decompensation, nor any new cardiac signs.
ECG indicated sinus rhythm at 60bpm, with PR 200ms, QRS155ms due to right bundle branch block with indeterminate QRS axis and a satisfactory QT interval.
Given Leonard’s age and comorbidities, I think it would be best to continue prophylaxis of atrial tachyarrhythmia by medical means.
I have arranged for him a repeat thyroid and liver function test in June this year and copies of this test result will come to you.
I would be grateful if you would continue this surveillance each 6 months on continuing Amiodarone therapy.
Leonard has an appointment for review in Dr Franjic’s clinic at Ipswich Hospital later this year.
Should the patient encounter difficulty with Amiodarone interim, alternative antiarrhythmic therapy could be considered.

Yours sincerely,

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Brian Leschke in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic at the PA Hospital.
As you are aware he is a 56 year old man who is known to you from an inferior STEMI that occurred in February of 2022.

Cardiovascular Diagnosis:

														Ischaemic Heart Disease.
Inferior STEMI February 2022.
PCI to RCA with DES(s).
Preserved LVEF (55%).
Exercise stress echocardiogram April 2022.
Exercised for 10:30 minutes, achieved 12.4METs and 150bpm (91%MPHR).
No chest pains.
No inducible ischaemia by ECG or echocardiogram criteria.

Cardiac Risk Factors:

														Pre-diabetes.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg nocte, Clopidogrel 75mg nocte (until 23.02.2023), Atorvastatin 80mg nocte.
In brief summary, Brian presented to the PA Hospital with an inferior STEMI in 2022.
He subsequently went on to have a coronary angiogram with percutaneous intervention to his right coronary artery with drug eluting stents.
His left ventricular ejection fraction as preserved.
Brian is a commercial driver, although he does not drive commercially regularly.

He underwent an exercise stress echocardiogram in April of 2022, where he achieved 10 minutes and 30 seconds for a total of 12.4METs, with no chest pain and no inducible ischaemia on ECG or echocardiogram.
On examination today, Brian was euvolaemic with a heart rate of 64bpm and a blood pressure of 140/80mmHg.
He had no evidence of fluid overload.
Brian is not trouble by any chest pain or angina, nor does he report any breathlessness.
The only thing troubling him, is he does get some dizziness while he mows the lawn, that he feels might be related to his vestibular system.
He has been reviewed by the vestibular physiotherapist and was subsequently discharged from his clinic after finding no significant findings.
His GP has started him on Stemetil, and he feels this has made a significant improvement to his symptoms.
Given Brian lives quite a distance from Brisbane, I will arrange for him to have ongoing follow up at the Ipswich Cardiac Centre under the care of yourself.
He will require an exercise stress echocardiogram for commercial driving clearance, which will hopefully occur in April 2023.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Suleman, 

														

														

														RE:	TYRESE LETALU		DOB:	31/05/2005		UR:	2225712

																					

														

														

														Issues
1.

Lateral medullary stroke 

															- 	Several investigations to date with no clear aetiology aside from TTE which shows a PFO.

- 	Negative thrombophilia screen
	- 	TOE done 24/11/2022 – PFO noted (colour flow+ early positive bubble study at rest)

															-	Normal pulmonary vein connections
	- 	Seen at QEII cardiology Dr Reza Reyaldeen – referred for consideration of PFO closure

Medicines
Aspirin 100mg daily 

														

														Review:

														I reviewed Tyrese along with his mother, Kimberlie, in Dr Singbal’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today at the PA Hospital.
He had a lateral medullary stroke which was worked up with the Stroke Team.
He was found to have a PFO confirmed on transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiogram.
This appears amenable to percutaneous closure.
We discussed the pathology, mechanism of stroke and rationale of closure with Tyrese and his mother.

We discussed procedural risks including 1% risk of major complication (VTE, perforation, device migration, air embolism causing MI, emergency surgery, long term risk of arrhythmia); requirement for aspirin 300mg daily initially followed by 100mg daily for a period of time and also avoidance of contact sports/strenuous activity for a few months (until device endothelialisation).

Plan
- Information pack + consent form given for perusal 
- Consent form signed – by patient (Tyrese) and co-signed by mother (Kimberlie)
- Book for PFO closure as an outpatient

														

														

														Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Gunasena,





														RE:	MIKAELA LEYDEN		DOB:	22/09/2006	UR:	2235564

																					

														

														

														Problem List:

														Atypical chest pain for further investigation.
Thank you for referring Mikaela, a very pleasant 16-year-old who learning the trade of being a Boiler Maker.
She gives a history of chest pain which she has had for the last 12 or 18 months now.
The symptoms are quite random according to her.
These could last anywhere from 30 seconds up to 3 hours.
She could have periods of no chest pain for 2 to 3 weeks and then have some days of chest pain recurring 2 or 3 times a day.
There is no particularly trigger or precipitating event and no aggravating or relieving factors that she could elaborate.
She can play sport, and plays basketball for a club, but occasionally has noticed that she is getting a bit short of breath.
She has had no symptoms of palpitations, has no history or symptoms of presyncope or syncope.
There is a family history of atrial fibrillation.
She tells me her father has had atrial fibrillation in the past, but that is no longer an active problem.
She is current using Zoloft for symptoms of anxiety and depression, but is on no other medication.
She was vaping between March and December last year but has discontinued the habit completely.
Her blood biochemistry that you sent along was within normal limits.
Her total cholesterol is marginally elevated, but for a 16-year-old I think that would not require any intervention at present.
Her ECG that you sent along is within normal limits.
I understand she has had an echocardiogram at one of the radiology practices, although the report is not available, but I am told that that was also reported to be normal.
Her blood pressure on examination today was satisfactory with a reading of 110/70mmHg, with a heart rate of 90bpm in sinus, systemic examination was unremarkable.
Her 12 Lead ECG shows sinus rhythm with no acute changes.
Her PR interval is normal, there is no evidence of pre-excitation on that ECG.
Her transthoracic echocardiogram that was done recent at the hospital shows normal left ventricular size and function (ejection fraction 60%).
Her right heart function is normal.
There is no underlying valvular abnormalities.
In summary, Mikaela Leyden is a 16-year-old girl, who has some atypical symptoms of chest pain, most likely from the descriptions, these are musculoskeletal in origin.
There has been no evidence of any cardiac arrhythmias or any other cardiac aetiology to explain these symptoms.
Her investigations on2 separate occasions with echocardiograms, are within normal limits.
Her ECG has shown no significant abnormal findings.

I have offered her an exercise stress echocardiogram more by way of reassurance that there is no  underlying heart rhythm abnormalities or ischaemia, although that is very unlikely from the description.
This is a relatively safe test for her with no exposure to radiation and I would be comfortable if the exercise stress echocardiogram is normal, to have no further investigations done.

The only very rare possibility of cardiac aetiology for chest pain in someone this age would be a anomalous coronary artery, but that itself is very uncommon and we have no clinical evidence to suggest that is the case.
At this stage, I would not be keen to subject her to any unnecessary thoracic radiation and I would like to review her back with the stress echocardiogram by way of a phone consultation.
If that is negative, I do not think that further investigations would be warranted at this stage.

Yours sincerely,

RE:	GEOFFREY LINLEY		DOB:	28/12/1948		UR:	1011267

							





I saw Geoffrey in my clinic for follow up today.
Lately, he has been complaining of increased exertional dyspnoea after starting Gabapentin for neuropathic pain.
So far he denied any orthopnoea or PND.

His background includes ischaemic heart disease with previous CABG x 4 in April 2017, heart failure with mildly reduced ejection fraction (LVEF 40 to 45%) recurrent PE on long term Rivaroxaban, hypertension, dyslipidaemia and adenocarcinoma of the posterolateral tongue in remission under the ENT team.
His current medications include Rivaroxaban 20mg, Perindopril 2.5mg daily, Nebivolol 2.5mg daily, Rosuvastatin 40mg daily and Esomeprazole 20mg daily, Gabapentin 600mg TDS.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 60bpm regular, his blood pressure was 100/60mmHg.
There was mild to moderate bilateral pitting oedema to his mid shins.
ECG today showed sinus rhythm with LBBB (PR 192ms, QRS 156mg, QTc 463ms).
Today, I have started Geoffrey on Empagliflozin 10mg daily for his heart failure.
I will see him again in 1 to 2 months with the intention of changing his Perindopril to Entresto if possible.
Thank you for looking after Geoffrey.

Yours sincerely,

														It appears that he has completed his chemotherapy and has now achieved remission.
From the cardiac perspective he denies any chest pain, shortness of breath, syncope or palpitations.
He still feels a little weak post his chemotherapy but manages to walk 30 to 60 minutes at a time.

On examination his blood pressure was 130/80mmHg, his heart rate was 60bpm and regular, JVP is not elevated, heart sounds dual with a soft ejection systolic murmur at the base and pan systolic murmur at the apex.
His chest was clear.

Assessment:

														He has multivessel coronary artery disease that was previously considered for surgical revascularisation.
However, his lymphoma management took precedence, and he has now thankfully achieved remission.
At the present time he has no angina on medical therapy.

Plan:

														I will get an updated transthoracic echocardiogram.
The patient and his wife would like to get a cardiothoracic surgical opinion regarding CABG, and I will make a referral for this.
Certainly, a repeat coronary angiogram can be organised if he were to proceed with surgery and the cardiac surgical team would like it done.
I will check on him in about 4 months to assess his progress.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Grigoreva,





														RE:	DMITRY LITVINOV		DOB:	20/05/1962		UR:	1006666

																					

														

														

														Background:

														Mechanical aortic valve replacement in 1998.
Known mild to moderate paravalvular aortic regurgitation.

LV dilatation , as per last echocardiogram in 2021, LVEDV 202ml, preserved function with EF 55%, dilated right ventricle with preserved systolic function, dilated aortic root 40mm and ascending aorta 44mm.
I had the pleasure of meeting Dmitry in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
He has the above-mentioned cardiac background and has been booked for a review to follow up on the paravalvular leak of aortic valve prosthesis.
He has an echocardiogram done out of hospital where there was no comments about the paravalvular leak.
I don't have the access of those images.
Clinically he remains asymptomatic and  continues to work as a commercial bus driver.
He denies any shortness of breath or anginal symptoms.
He is currently on Warfarin and has been adherent with his regular doses.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 120/60mmHg, heart sounds were dual with a prosthetic mechanical sound.
There was no evidence of volume overload.

For the continuity of care purposes, I have organised an echocardiogram here at the PA Hospital, which should happen in the next few weeks and afterwards will do a phone review to further assess any possible interval changes on his paravalvular leak.
I have also organised blood tests including LDH which will happen this afternoon and we will review that on the day of his phone review.
Please continue with your ongoing care and feel free to contact us if you have any other concerns in the interim.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Nicolae,





RE:	TONY LONDY		DOB:	10/12/1958		UR:	492984

							



														Tony attended the heart failure titration clinic today following his recent admission, under Dr Ross here at the Princess Alexandra Hospital, with a bioprosthetic AVR + AscAo replacement on the 1st December 2022 under.
He was readmitted post procedure on the 13th December with AF+RVR and mild-moderate pericardial effusion.
I understand that his ejection fraction pre-surgery was 40% which had improved to 55% post-surgery.
He was referred to this clinic for heart failure medication titration.
Tony is back at work as a painter, and he told me that he is managing this well.
I note that during his readmission his Hb was in the 70’s and he underwent an iron infusion.
He told me that this helped him to feel a lot better.
He describes class I NYHA symptoms.
He is able to manage 30 stairs to his apartment with no concerns.
He denies any orthopnoea or PND.
He is experiencing occasional postural light headedness.

Medications

														Frusemide 40mg mane, Bisoprolol 5mg mane, Rivaroxaban 20mg mane, Aspirin 100mg mane, Amiodarone 200mg mane, Ramipril 1.25mg mane (increased today to 2.5mg mane), Rosuvastatin 40mg mane, Spironolactone 12.5mg mane.
On examination his blood pressure was 130/90mmHg sitting and 140/100mmHg standing, heart rate 80bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
His heart sounds were dual, and chest was clear.
Blood test at the Princess Alexandra Hospital on the 19th December showed Na 137, K+ 4.7, Urea 6.4, Creat 87 and eGFR 80.
His FBC Hb was 79.
Today I have organised an ECG to check his rhythm and a repeat blood test to check his renal function given the ongoing Frusemide.
These are attached for your information.
I have also asked him to have a blood test in one week given the increased in Ramipril.
These will have these prior to attending Dr Ross’ clinic on the 30th January.
I wonder if I can ask for guidance with regard ongoing titration of heart failure medications given that Tony’s ejection fraction has normalised.
I have tentatively made him an appointment for one month for ongoing titration, given that his blood pressure was slightly elevated today.
I would be very grateful for any guidance that you could provide.

Yours sincerely, 





Robyn Peters

Nurse Practitioner Heart Failure

Princess Alexandra Hospital Heart Failure Service

Dear Dr Weerasinghe,





RE:	ANNIKA KATE LOUIE	DOB:	12/10/2005	UR:	2234291

							



														

														It was a pleasure to review Annika today 18.01.2023.
She is a 17-year-old female who has syncope for investigation.
She has a past history of depression / anxiety.
She is medicated currently on Escitalopram 20mg, Femme-Tab ED 20/100, Ferro-Tab Ostium, Calcium, Vitamin D.  She is allergic to dairy, eggs, peanuts and sesame, which cause anaphylaxis.
Six months ago, she had 5 episodes of seated syncope within 1 hour associated with stress.
She had a presyncope episode, no diaphoresis, no nausea, loss of consciousness for seconds, no epileptiform movements.
She had palpitations prior with a gradual start and offset.
She denied dehydration at the time, and she suffered no trauma.
She has had 4 syncopal episodes subsequent to this, one per month, each query associated with stress but sometime not and associated palpitations.
Four years ago, she has had what sounds like vasovagal syncope, associated with dehydration and what she describes as heat stroke.
She is a non-smoker, imbibes alcohol socially, partakes in caffeine on a weekly basis and does not partake in illicit drugs.
There is no family history of sudden cardiac death.
She has had a Holter monitor performed by yourself on 05.09.2022, which you kindly sent along.
The symptoms correlated with sinus rhythm with sinus rhythm with dizziness, but there was no syncope.

She had an echocardiogram performed at the PA Hospital on 01.12.2022, which demonstrated normal left ventricular size and systolic function, left ventricular ejection fraction 55% by visual estimation, normal right ventricular size and systolic function and no significant valvular abnormalities.
She has normal thyroid function, normal urea and electrolytes.
Of note her triglycerides are elevated 2.6mmol/L.
I have counselled her on dietary modifications, and I would be grateful if you could reassess these in 3 to 4 months.
We would like her triglycerides to be < 2.0mmol/L.
She is not drive currently, as she has had seated syncope and ECG demonstrates normal sinus rhythm.
She has syncope at rest of unclear cause.

We would like to exclude a cardiac cause and as such I have organised for her to have an external loop recorder to re-establish a symptom correlation with a syncope episode in 2 weeks and review her again in 3 months.

If she is getting ongoing syncope and we are not able to establish a rhythm symptom correlation, I believe an 



RE:	ANNIKA KATE LOUIE	DOB:	12/10/2005	UR:	2234291

														

														electrophysiological study with a  consideration for an internal loop recorder placement would establish a rhythm symptom correlation.
I have organised to review her in 3 to  month in my Private Practice Clinic.
Her cardiac investigations are normal, which decreases the concerns for any significant cardiac abnormality contributing to the episodes.
Many thanks for your ongoing care of the patient.
If there are any problems, please do not hesitate to get in touch with me.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Capulong,







														RE:	COLIN LOVEJOY		DOB:	22/01/1953		UR:	2068772

																					

														

														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR in SAVR) for severe aortic stenosis.
TAVR with Abbott Navitor 29mm TAVR bioprosthesis at PA Hospital on 19.11.2021.
Ischaemic heart disease.
Previous coronary artery bypass graft surgery.
Episode of syncope under assessment.
Under assessment via Bundaberg Hospital and with Dr H Wittmer at Genesis Care Cardiology.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Obesity.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Other Conditions:

														Crohn’s disease with previous bowel resection.
Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis with portal hypertension and varices with chronic portal vein thrombosis.
Previous sarcoidosis.
Previous depression.
Previous multifocal non-melanoma skin cancer with skin graft.

Medications:

														Adalimumab 40mg/0.4mL, Loperamide 2mg, Ferric Carboxymaltose 500mg/10mL injection, Apixaban 5mg, Atorvastatin 80mg, Ramipril 1.25mg, Propranolol 40mg, Spironolactone 25mg, Frusemide 40mg, Escitalopram 10mg, Esomeprazole 20mg, Pramipexole 0.25mg, Pregabalin 75mg, Colecalciferol 25mg, Magnesium Aspartate 500mg, Quinine Sulfate 300mg, Hydroxocobalamin.
I reviewed Colin Lovejoy via telehealth link.
His cardiac status is stable.
NYHA class I – II.
No angina, no prolonged or pathological palpitations.

Around Christmas time he had an episode of presumed syncope, for which he eventually attended the local hospital and he is still having assessments for this, including a HeartBug and follow up with Dr Wittmer.
I understand he has also had a head scan.

He had a transthoracic echocardiogram performed at Bundaberg Radiology on 04.01.2023 and the results of this demonstrated well seated TAVR bioprosthesis with good haemodynamics and no significant paravalvular regurgitation (trivial regurgitation only).
LVEF 55 – 60%, estimated RVSP 38mmHg.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Continue DOAC ongoing and indefinitely at appropriate dose for age, weight and renal function (currently on Apixaban 5mg oral twice daily).
Repeat review in the structural heart disease clinic in 12 months.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Thein,





														RE:	ALFRED LOWE		DOB:	8/03/1974		UR:	753229

																					

														

														

														Past Medical History:
# IHD (NSTEMI)
- August 2021
- Risk factors: ex-smoker, strong family history
- two stents were placed to the LAD, two stents to the right coronary
- cholesterol target <1.6
- LVEF 57%
# GORD

Medications:
Aspirin 100mg daily, Ticagrelor 90 mg for 12 months only (stopped today), Atorvastatin 80 mg (change to atorvastatin/ezetimibe 80/10mg daily)


														I had the pleasure of reviewing Alfred Lowe in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
This is a routine post myocardial infarction clinic review, to assess his progress since discharge from hospital.
As you know, Alfred had an NSTEMI in August 2021.
He had 2 stents placed in the LAD, as well as 2 stents in the right coronary artery.
He has continued on dual antiplatelet therapy with both Aspirin and Ticagrelor since the event, now completing 18 months.

Therefore, given that Alfred tells me that he experiences no chest discomfort with or without exertion, as well as denying any signs of symptoms of decompensated heart failure, and no limitation to his physical exercise, I have asked him to discontinue his Ticagrelor today.
However, he needs to continue Aspirin indefinitely.
On examination today, Alfred appeared well and in good spirits.
His blood pressure was 115/75mmHg and his heart rate was 72bpm and regular.
Thank you for providing Alfred with a copy of his most recent pathology panel, performed earlier this month.
This showed a total cholesterol 3.5, LDL of 1.92, HDL of 1.08.
His renal function was stable with a creatinine of 90 and eGFR of 87ml/min.
His ferritin was 208 with a transferrin saturation of 34%.
His HbA1c was 5.0%.
As his LDL remains above target (<1.6mmol/L), I have taken the liberty of changing his Atorvastatin to a combination of Atorvastatin / Ezetimibe 80/10mg daily.
I ask that you please consider repeating his lipid profile in approximately 3 months to assess the effect of the addition agent.
In the future, should Alfred experience chest discomfort with elevated lipid markers, he may qualify for other agents such as a PCSK9 inhibitor.
The PBS indications are regularly revised, and I would suggest considering referring him to a lipidologist for further consideration should Alfred’s condition change.
I have encouraged Alfred to have regular check ups to screen for risk factors that may arise, such as diabetes and hypertension.
I have emphasised the importance of addressing these issues early, should they occur.
As Alfred has been stable since discharge from hospital, I have not made another appointment to review him in this clinic at this time.
I have emphasised the importance of being mindful of any recurrence in chest discomfort and to seek prompt medical review should they recur.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Lowe.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Trinh





														RE:	JADE YU-PAO LU		DOB:	12/02/1957		UR:	1123948

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Jade, a lovely 65 year old female, I reviewed on behalf of Dr Hill today in the presence of her daughter and an interpreter.
This is roughly a month after Dr Hill saw her due to some atrial lead under and over sensing.
Despite these issues, she is largely asymptomatic from a rhythm perspective and only suffers from occasional postural dizziness in the context of very poor water intake.
She also has dyslipidaemia and hepatitis B.
She has recently stopped her statin therapy with the aim to manage her cholesterol with dietary changes.
Mrs Lu plays tennis every day and denies any worsening shortness of breath of exertion, fatigue, presyncope or syncope.
She has had 2 episodes of sharp left sided chest pain that lasted less than 2 seconds and this is unlikely to be ischaemic nor as a consequence of her pacemaker.
On examination today, her chest was clear, heart sounds were dual with no murmurs and her blood pressure was 120/60mmHg without a postural drop.
Her ECG today showed ventricular pacing with an underlying sinus rhythm and a first-degree heart block.
Given that Mrs Lu is largely stable from a cardiac perspective, we have discharged her from Dr Hill’s clinic.
We will continue to follow her up in the device clinic and should she run into any troubles, be linked back in with our clinic.
If she develops any symptoms of presyncope or syncope, that are not postural in nature, please do not hesitate in sending Mrs Lu back to our clinic.
She had approximately 2 years of battery life remaining on pacemaker at the last check.
We will keep an eye on this.
Thank you for your ongoing care and please do not hesitate in contacting us should you have any questions or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Moussa,





RE:	JOHN LUKE		DOB:	10/10/1978		UR:	1033284

							



John returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
He feels well.
He had a recent Gout flair.
I understand that he was prescribed Colchicine and his Gout has now resolved.
We have given him a plan today to return the Allopurinol to 300mg to prevent further flairs.

Medications

														Frusemide decreased today to 20mg mane, Bisoprolol 10mg mane, Entresto increased today to 24/26mg mane and 49/51mg nocte, Spironolactone 12.5mg nocte, Rosuvastatin 20mg mane, Metformin 500mg XR nocte, Symbicort 1 puff BD, Ventolin prn, Multivitamin 1 daily, Allopurinol 100mg mane.
John continues to describe class II NYHA symptoms, and denies any orthopnoea, PND, dizziness or light headedness.
One week ago, John had forgotten to drink water during the day which resulted in him being dehydrated however this resolved by the next day.
He told me that he feels a little more energized and he has been more active.
He has a goal of riding a push bike around the neighbourhood and is gradually increasing his exercise tolerance.
On examination his blood pressure was 125/90mmHg sitting and 130/90mmHg standing, heart rate 76bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
Today I have increased the Entresto to 24/26mg mane and 49/51mg nocte.
I have decreased the Frusemide to 20mg mane.
I have asked him to have a blood test prior to coming back to see me.
I will see him back in this clinic in four weeks.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr McCarthy,

														

														

														RE:	COLLEEN LYNNE		DOB:	01/12/1943		UR:	805514

																					

														

														

														Colleen was booked for an exercise stress test today.
Unfortunately, I have cancelled this today, as she is not suitable.
The referral came after an episode towards the end of last year in which she had a troponin leak.
However, this was in the setting of a pulmonary embolus.
She was put on anticoagulation and seems to have variable compliance with this.
The troponin leak was only minor.
She did have an echocardiogram, which showed a low normal ejection fraction and some minor regionals.
She is completely asymptomatic as far as I can and reports no chest pain at all.
Furthermore, her cognitive state and degree of frailty are not amenable to putting her on an exercise stress test.

I suspect the troponin leak is simply from the PE and it is likely she has a degree of coronary artery disease but given she is asymptomatic, there is no current need to further pursue anything more than medical management.
I would suggest she continue anticoagulation as per the guidelines.
Once she has ceased anticoagulation, if this is the decision made,  Aspirin could be substituted.
In addition, a statin may be reasonable for her.
We have not organised any further follow up with her and have not boked her for a repeat attempt at EST.
Please let us know if you wish for her to be seen in clinic.

Yours sincerely, 

														

	HILL, JOHN NEVILLE SMO on 16 February 2023 17:34 AEST

Dear Dr Connor,



RE:	 IAN DAVID MACKENZIE	DOB:	8/09/1954	UR:	649593

								

	Issues:

														ATTR wild type cardiac amyloidosis.
Increase in LV wall thickness with a drop in global LV strain but preserved LV ejection fraction on recent echocardiogram.

NTproBNP 1860pg/l

														Normal renal function.
on AG10 study drug.
Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with a history of AF ablation.
Prolonged PR interval – on Sotalol.
Haemochromatosis carrier.

Medications:

														Sotalol 40mg bd, Rivaroxaban 20mg daily, Perindopril 2.5mg daily, Frusemide 120mg mane, 80mg at lunchtime; AG10 study medication, Span-K i bd.
I had the pleasure of reviewing Ian Mackenzie in the Cardiology Research Clinic today as part of the routine EIDOS study follow up appointments.
Ian tells me that he has been stable since the last review with Dr Korczyk in November.
He has had a pleasant holiday period and has admitted to having a hearty dietary intake during this time.
As a result, his weight has increased from his baseline approximately 100kg to 101.7kg today.
Clinically, Ian denies any paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea or orthopnoea.
He has stable, but significant reduction in his exercise tolerance.
He does quite well on flat surfaces, but struggles on inclines.
Today, he did not park across the road as the hill climb from the carpark causeway would have caused him significant difficulty.
On examination today, he appeared well.
His jugular venous pressure measured approximately 4-5cm with hepatojugular reflux.
His heart sounds were dual with no significant murmurs.
He had bibasal crepitations, more so on the right than on the left.
There was mild pitting oedema peripherally to the knees bilaterally.
His blood pressure today was 108/74mmHg and his heart rate was 72 beats per minute and regular.
This corresponded with sinus rhythm on his ECG.
I note that his QTC is 497ms, and his PR interval is 248ms.
These intervals are largely within his normal range of fluctuation through his time on the trial medication.
Ian has also had a Holter monitor performed in the community, which has shown sinus rhythm with a small burden of ectopic beats.
Ian tells me that he has not had any significant presyncope with his only syncopal episode approximately 8-10 months ago, which he attributes to rapid postural change.
After this event, he has ensured that he stands up more slowly and has not had a repeat incident.

With respect to managing Ian’s current fluid status, I have asked him to increase his usual Frusemide from 120mg mane and 80mg midday to 120mg twice daily until his weight returns to his baseline 100kg.
At that time, I have asked him to resume his usual 120mg mane and 80mg midday dose of Frusemide on an ongoing basis.
He will continue his morning routine of wake, wee, weigh.
I have also advised him to seek prompt medical review should he experience any orthopnoea, paroxysmal dyspnoea, or distressing dyspnoea.
His next appointment with the clinical trial will be in approximately 3 months, which will be the last clinic appointment from the perspective of the EIDOS trial.
Should the trial findings be positive, he will be put on open label Acoramidis thereafter.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Mackenzie.

Yours sincerely,

														Background:

														Bioprosthetic aortic valve replacement for severe aortic stenosis.
Single vessel CABG (SVG to D1) at time of AVR.
Post operative atrial fibrillation.
Type II diabetes mellitus.
Hypertension.
Gout.

Medications:
Atorvastatin 40mg a day, Bisoprolol 2.5mg a day, Candesartan 8mg a day, Amlodipine 10mg a day, Frusemide 40mg BD, Allopurinol, Lantus, Thyroxine and Esomeprazole.

Mitral annular calcification with increased forward flow gradient.

I am pleased to see that Keith has been stable from the cardiac perspective.
He can now mow his garden which is roughly 1200 squared metres without any anginal symptoms.
He denies any symptoms of orthopnoea or PND.
His main issues currently would be recurrent venous ulcer, which has been actively managed with the help of the Vascular Surgery Department at the PA Hospital.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 140/90mmHg, heart rate was 72bpm, and heart sounds were dual with no murmur.
At this stage, I have not made any changes to his medications, and I have discharged him from the Cardiology Clinic.
He should continue with his heart failure medications.
Please feel free to refer him back to our service if any other cardiac concerns arise in the future.

														Willim with his wife and daughter returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
He has been quite well with no dizziness, PND or orthopnoea.
He reports NHYA class I symptoms.
His daughter told me that Willim gets quite lethargic, however Willim believes it is at baseline for him without any recent worsening.

Medications

														Carvedilol 12.5mg BD, Rivaroxaban 20mg mane, Entresto 49/51mg BD, Simvastatin 40mg nocte, Thiamine 100mg mane, Sertraline 100mg mane, Spironolactone 12.5mg mane.
On examination his blood pressure was 90/60mmHg with no postural drop, heart rate 57bpm and irregular.
He had no peripheral oedema.
His lungs were clear.
Today Willim is on maximum tolerated doses of heart failure medications.
Given his blood pressure and heart rate there is no further room for me to put these up any higher.
I have organised for him to have an echocardiogram and a review with his cardiologist Dr Wahi in the next three months for ongoing management decisions.
I have discharged him from this clinic.
Thank you for your ongoing care.
