Dear Doctors,





														RE:	RHIANNON DIONYSIUS	DOB:	31/10/1994	UR:	342597

																					

														

														

														Past Medical History:
# ?POTS
   - does not meet criteria for POTS
   - previously recommended minimum fluid intake of 2L per day aiming for 3L daily 

														     and also to consider adding salt to her food to assist with elevating her blood 

														     pressure slightly
# Fibromyalgia
# Anxiety/Depression
# CVID
   - known to immunology PAH
# Iron deficiency
# Chronic fatigue syndrome
# Dry eyes
# Corneal hyperalgesia
# Possible hypermobility syndrome 
# Non-allergic rhinosinusitis
# IBS
# central pain sensitization (under care rheumatologist)

Medications:
Lovan 40mg, supplements, CyA eye drops, lubricating drops, naltrexone, PRN diazepam

														

														I had the pleasure of speaking with Rhiannon Dionysius in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
This appointment was performed as a telephone consultation.
She is known to this clinic after being referred initially for investigation and management of possible postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS).

As  you know, during our last clinic appointment in May 2022, Rhiannon’s condition was discussed with Dr Cox, and it was his opinion that Rhiannon’s symptoms do not satisfy the strict definition of postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome.
Nevertheless, it was recommended that Rhiannon increase her fluid intake to approximately 2 to 3 litres per day with addition salt to her food in an attempt to increase her blood pressure.

In this regard, Rhiannon has not been able to quite reach the recommended levels of fluid intake, drinking approximately 1 to 2 litres of fluid a day, but she is adding salt to her food as recommended.
She tells me that she has been having ongoing mild symptoms of dizziness, most notable during postural change.
Fortunately, she has not had a syncopal episode.

At our last clinic appointment, to be comprehensive, we arranged for Rhiannon to have an outpatient transthoracic echocardiogram to exclude structural heart disease as a potential contributor to her symptoms.
Unfortunately, Rhiannon was not aware of the appointment that was made for her today and missed her booking.
She has been quite occupied with her other medical conditions, which is completely reasonable.
During our consultation today, I reiterated the recommendation of increasing her fluid intake to at least 2 litres per day with ongoing additional salt to her food.
Furthermore, I have suggested that she consider a regular exercise program that may include activities, such as rowing – whether this be on a body of water or on a rowing machine.
Both are potentially beneficial.

With respect to excluding structural heart disease, I have asked that she speak with you at her next consultation to arrange a transthoracic echocardiogram at a more local facility as the PA Hospital is now not very convenient for her to travel to after her recent move.
At this time, I will not make another appointment to see Rhiannon.

However, should the transthoracic echocardiogram reveal unexpected structural abnormality, we would be happy to receive a new referral from you to address any issues uncovered by the transthoracic echocardiogram.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Ms Dionysius.

Yours sincerely,

														It was a pleasure to review Claude in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know he is a 73-year-old gentleman who was admitted here in December with an inferior STEMI.
He underwent PCI with drug eluting stents to the proximal RCA and moderate left main and LAD stenosis were also noted.
His left ventricular ejection fraction was about 40% and his RV function was preserved.

This occurred on a background of:

														Recently diagnosed lung cancer, awaiting further workup.
Hypertension.
Osteoarthritis with significant mobility impairment.
PR bleeding now settled.
Ex-smoker.
Rheumatoid arthritis.
Psoriasis.

Claude’s medications on discharge were Aspirin 100mg, Ticagrelor 90mg BD, Atorvastatin 80mg, Bisoprolol 2.5mg, Spironolactone 12.5mg, Amlodipine 10mg, Colchicine 0.5mg nocte, Domperidone 10mg TDS, Nizatidine 300mg nocte, Perindopril 8mg, Ostelin Vitamin D, Sulfasalazine 1g BD, Thiamine 100mg, Ixekizumab injection every 3 weeks, Spiriva.
Claude has recovered quite well from his infarct.
He reports no chest pain.
I understand he is awaiting bronchoscopy / biopsy of his lung lesion with Dr Edwards.
I spoke to him on the phone the other day and we have recommended a minimum of six weeks uninterrupted dual antiplatelet therapy.
The procedure could be performed on Aspirin alone after that time.
Today, Claude’s blood pressure was 185/92mmHg and he reports it does fluctuate quite a lot.
His pulse was 72bpm and regular.
In regard to Claude’s heart failure therapy, I have increased his Bisoprolol to 3.75mg and given him a script for this.
He is seeing the Heart Failure Team later this week and I would appreciate if they could facilitate a switch from ACE inhibitor to Entresto in his Webster Pack and ongoing titration with thanks.
I have not started an SGLT2 inhibitor as Claude and his son describe a history of recurrent urinary tract infections with a procedure possibly required at Greenslopes Hospital last year.
I will review Claude in 6 months with an echocardiogram and he will see the Heart Failure Titration Team here in the meantime.
Please feel free to contact me with any issues or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Kyranis,





														RE:	NORMAN MANAENA	DOB:	28/04/1957	UR:	2234937

																					

														

														

														Issues:

														Dilated cardiomyopathy.
EF has improved from 10 to 40%.
Thymus squamous cell carcinoma.
Completed chemotherapy and radiotherapy at RBWH.
Atrial flutter.
Previous DC cardioversion with sinus bradycardia until last year.
Atrial flutter on ECG since.
Holter monitor July 2022 – sinus rhythm with average rate of 56, 14.8% supraventricular ectopy, 8.6% ventricular ectopy, periods of junctional escape with ventricular rate of 40.
Asymptomatic with this.

Medications:

														Bisoprolol 3.75mg mane, Eliquis 5mg BD, Rosuvastatin 20mg daily, Spiractin 25mg daily, Ramipril 5mg daily, Frusemide PRN.
Thank you for your referral for Norman and consideration of left bundle branch pacing.
Norman, as you mentioned, has a dilated cardiomyopathy with an improvement in his ejection fraction.
I note he had a CTCA showing no coronary disease  a few years a back.
Symptoms wise he is fairly good, and reports may be some very mild breathlessness with heavy weight sessions and is otherwise NYHA class I.
There is no dizziness, no blackouts and he has never had any other concerning symptoms.
His blood pressure today was 105/90mmHg, heart sounds were dual, and he was euvolaemic.
His current ECG shows 3:1 atrial flutter, however, I note last year he was in a sinus bradycardia.
There is some occasional ventricular ectopy on his ECGs.
The Holter monitor in July of last year, I have summarised above, but was the main cause for concern and reason for referral given the periods of junctional escape.
Norman appears to have actually been asymptomatic with these.

His most recent echocardiogram late last shows a mildly dilated LV with an EF of 44%, a mildly dilated RV with normal systolic function, mild MR and mild TR as well as a dilated aortic root and ascending aorta.
I saw him alongside Dr Ahmad today.
He clearly  has both an indication for a Beta blocker, given the reduced ejection fraction as well as the ectopy and although asymptomatic, a concerning bradyarrhythmia.
We therefore agree that a pacemaker would be advised for him and that a left bundle branch pacing may be the optimal strategy.

The plan is as follows:

														We have booked him in for a left bundle branch pacemaker.
He should continue his current dose of Bicor with no up titration or down titration unless he is particularly symptomatic.
If he has syncope, he needs to present to hospital via QAS.
We will also consider him for a flutter ablation once he has a pacemaker in situ.
He will have routine follow up at the Redland Cardiology Unit as well.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Amoli,





														RE:	CARA-MIA MARTIN		DOB:	03/10/1954		UR:	504826

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Cara-Mia in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
She is a 68-year-old lady who was referred by her private Cardiologist for consideration of angiogram and to take over her care.
The referral states she was sent for a cardiac workup prior to a hernia operation but Cara-Mia believes that her lower limb swelling post fem-pop bypass precipitated the referral.
She denies any cardiac symptoms such as chest pain, palpitations or undue dyspnoea.
She underwent a resting echocardiogram which reported apical akinesis.
She then proceeded to an exercise stress echocardiogram where she was able to walk for 6 minutes and 20 seconds on the Bruce protocol with no chest pain and was limited by dyspnoea.
She had less than a millimetre of ST segment shift, but apical regionals were reported on the post-exercise echocardiogram.
It is unclear if these were new or more extensive compared to her baseline regional wall motion abnormalities.
This occurs on a background of significant co-morbidities.
COPD (quit smoking August 2022).
Peripheral vascular disease.
Right fem-pop bypass 2002.
Aortobifem bypass 2020.
Left graft thrombosis July 2022, managed with profundoplasty and patch.
Infected left groin seroma November 2022 on lifelong suppressive antibiotics.
LDL 1.9mmol/L.
Low grade lymphoma under surveillance.
OSA not on CPAP due to difficulties obtaining rental equipment.
Anxiety.
Chronic back pain.
Her current medications include Aspirin 100mg, Atorvastatin 80mg, Ezetimibe 10mg, Nebivolol 1.25mg, Frusemide 40mg, Sertraline and Cephalexin.
Today  her blood pressure was 116/64mmHg.
ECG showed her to be in sinus rhythm at 71bpm with poor anterior R-wave forces.
She has bilateral pitting leg oedema.
In summary, Cara-Mia likely has coronary artery disease with a previous apical infarct.
She is asymptomatic currently with a reasonable exercise tolerance and it is unclear if there is any inducible ischaemia.
I have offered Cara-Mia a dobutamine stress echocardiogram for further risk stratification.
She is already on good medical therapy with reasonable risk factor control.
I will review her via phone in three months, but please feel free to contact me in the interim with any new issues or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Jaishankar,





														RE:	DANE MARTIN		DOB:	31/10/1964		UR:	2082912

																					

														

														

														My Outpatient Nurses received a call from Dane, saying that he and you were concerned about his recent CT scan.
He had a coronary artery calcium score of 832 on the scan and they did not proceed to the CTCA.
I note that his previous coronary artery calcium score in 2018, was 471.

To be honest it is not awfully surprising that a coronary artery calcium score increases from 400 to 800 over the course of 5 years, in a patient with established atherosclerosis, and ongoing smoking.
His exercise stress echocardiogram less than a year ago did not show any ischaemia at a good workload of 10METs.
When I saw him about 6 months ago, he did not have any anginal type chest pain.
The single most important thing to improve his prognosis would be for him to give up smoking.
There is no indication to pursue an invasive strategy at present.
I will see him for routine follow up.

Yours sincerely,

														Dr Jennifer An

														Dear Dr An,

														

														

														RE:	WARREN MARTIN		DOB:	23/11/1947		UR:	916464

																					

														

														

														Warren Martin was reviewed in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
His past history incudes ischaemic heart disease.
He had previous PCI in New Zealand more than 10 years ago.
He underwent repeat coronary catheterisation in March 2020 at PA Hospital and had PCI to the right coronary artery with 2 overlapped drug eluting stents.
His other past history includes type II diabetes, depression, generalised anxiety disorder, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and he reports that he stopped smoking.
His current medications include Aspirin, Atorvastatin, Dutasteride, Empagliflozin, Metformin, Mirtazapine, Perindopril and Ticagrelor.
He has no known allergies.
He lives at home with this wife, and he uses a single point stick to help mobilise.
He did not have it present with him during  today's consultation.
Warren reports that his main symptom is that of dizziness.
He reports that it is persistent.
He reports that it is exacerbated when he is trying to mobilise.
He feels like he drunk with regard to his mobility and disequilibrium.
He also feels like the room is spinning.
He has taken up using a single point stick to help gait aid his mobility.
He is not affected by any chest pain.
He reports that he walks approximately 1 kilometre twice a day with the walking stick.
He does not report any falls.
His other symptoms he reports, he gets intermittent shortness of breath, especially noticeable when he lays down.
He reports that he takes several minutes to take deep breathing exercises and then the feeling subsides.
He does not appear to be affected in his daily exercise activities by dyspnoea.
On examination his heart rate was 72bpm.
His blood pressure was 160/90mmHg when he was laying flat and when he was sitting up it was 155/90mmHg.
There was no postural drop.
His heart sounds were dual, and his chest was clear on auscultation.
His ECG showed sinus rhythm with Q-wave in inferior leads and T-wave inversion in the lateral leads.
This is similar to prior ECGs.
During his examination he was experiencing dizziness.
His pulse rate was regular.
With regards to Warren’s episodes of dizziness, it is unlikely to be cardiac in origin.
He has no postural drop with his blood pressure and during the examination when he was experiencing dizziness, his heart rate was regular.
With regards to his symptoms of dyspnoea, in view that he has been able to walk several kilometres a day, it is unlikely to be secondary to a cardiac component.
I  note that he is currently on Ticagrelor.
In view that it has been more than 12 months since he had PCI, he was advised to cease his Ticagrelor.
With regard to his dizziness, he was prescribed Stemetil 5mg oral BD PRN.
If you can please follow up the response to this, that will be appreciated.
He has been advised that if he experiences any side effects from this, to cease the medication.
In view of his symptoms that vertiginous in description, if you can please consider a neurology opinion that would be very much appreciated.
From a cardiac perspective, he will be referred for a Holter monitor to assess his rhythm over a 24-hour period and an assessment of his LV function.
He has been advised to seek medical review in the interim if he feels unwell.
He has been advised to continue on his other medications.
We plan to follow him up in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic in approximately 6 months.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Sal,

														

														

														RE:	BRIAN MARTINI		DOB:	21/02/1934		UR:	225526

																					

														

														

														Thank you for asking me to review Mr Martini.
He is 89 years old in a few weeks.
He had angioplasty performed by Dr Paul Garrahy a few years ago and coronary angiography in 2020 showed that he did not have prognostically significant coronary disease.
He tells me he is no longer getting angina, but I do note that he has been increasingly breathless over the last few years.
He saw the Respiratory people at Redland Hospital, and I note his respiratory function testing is satisfactory, apart from his low DLCO at 60%.
I would note that clinically he has bilateral fibrotic lung crackles on the left base greater than right.
Thank you for performing the stress test which shows that he has at least moderately severe aortic stenosis and a similar degree of mitral regurgitation.
There was concern that perhaps he had an anterior wall motion abnormality, but he is known to have residual distal LAD disease.
Mr Martini is adamant that he no longer gets angina.
He does not have resting heart failure symptoms, syncope or palpitations.
Today, his 12 Lead ECG shows sinus bradycardia at 58bpm without left ventricular hypertrophy or strain.
Clinically he has at least moderate aortic stenosis with a 2-3/6 mitral regurgitant murmur.
His blood pressure was approximately 150 to 160 systolic, diastolic of 70 to 75mmHg.
His oxygen saturation was 97%.
There is no easy fix for Mr Martini.
As he does not have angina, it is unlikely that intervention would help him and without prognostically important disease he would be a category 3 (low priority case given our workload).
He does however have significant valvular heart disease.
I am not sure that there is a downstream option for him, but we will see him in 4 months with a repeat echocardiogram.
In the interim, I have elected to reduce his Beta blocker from Atenolol 25mg a day to Bisoprolol 2.5mg at night.
I would be happy if that was up titrated if he developed recurrent angina, but I think if we make him less bradycardic, that might be helpful.
I think it is a useful test.
In summary, he has polyfactorial breathlessness without a simple solution.
We would be happy to see him with the above plan in place.

Yours sincerely, 

														

	COX, STEPHEN VINCENT SMO on 08 February 2023 16:31 AEST

Dear Danielle,





RE:	ANTONIO MARTINS		DOB:	01/11/1954		UR:	8090989

							





														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Transcatheter valve replacement for bicuspid aortic valve disease with severe stenosis and concomitant severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction.
TAVR at Princess Alexandra Hospital with Edwards Sapien 3 Ultra 26mm bioprosthesis on 25.11.2022.
Non-obstructive coronary artery disease.
Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Ex-smoker.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
Type II diabetes mellitus.

Other Conditions:

														Traumatic injury with impaired vision to left eye.
Lower limb chronic venous disease with varicosity.
Medications: (List following review on 12.01.2023).

Apixaban 5mg twice daily, Rosuvastatin 40mg daily, Sacubitril – Valsartan 24/26mg  1 tablet twice daily, Spironolactone 125mg daily, Bisoprolol 5mg daily, Amiodarone 200mg daily, Metformin 2000mg daily, Ezetimibe 10mg daily, Colecalciferol as directed, Empagliflozin 25mg daily, Linagliptin 5mg daily, Frusemide 40g daily, Gliclazide MR 60mg daily.
I reviewed Antonio Martins today.
He has made a good recovery in terms of his cardiac situation.
He has had no episodes of cardiac decompensation.
His functional class has improved to NYHA class II.
He has had no angina, no prolonged or pathological palpitations and no syncope.
He is having intermittent issues with atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter.
I discussed these with him today.
I discussed the role for introducing Amiodarone and the potential toxicities of Amiodarone including pulmonary fibrosis, hepatic toxicity, skin toxicity as well as visual toxicity.
We also discussed the potential for hypo and hyperthyroidism.
On clinical examination he is euvolaemic.
Heart rate 105bpm and blood pressure is 10176mmHg.
Heart sounds were dual nil added, his JVP is not elevated, lung fields are clear and there is no pitting peripheral oedema.
Home blood pressure diary reviewed.

RE:	ANTONIO MARTINS		DOB:	01/11/1954		UR:	8090989

														

														Plan and Recommendations to LMO:

														Commence amiodarone 200mg once daily.
Increase bisoprolol to 5mg daily.
Repeat  cardiology review in 4 weeks, with a 12 Lead ECG on the same day.
Consideration will be had to proceed to cardioversion, depending on repeat assessment in 4 weeks' time.
Antibiotic prophylaxis for any invasive procedures including dental procedures as a lifelong recommendation.
Please check TSH/T4, ELFT and FBC every 12 weeks while on amiodarone and have patient undergo a chest xray every 12 months while on amiodarone.

With kind regards,

														

														Yours sincerely,

														Mr Matthews presented to the PA Hospital with complete heart block in September 2021.

														Just a note to let you know that Keith Mawn attended the PA Hospital today 06.02.2023, for a direct current cardioversion for his atrial flutter.
We confirmed compliance with his Dabigatran with no missed doses.
Keith was anaesthetised by our Anaesthetics Team and then proceeded on to 1 synchronised shock at 200 joules with reversion to sinus rhythm.
He remained well and was discharged 2 hours post procedure.
We have made no changes to his medications.

He continues on Dabigatran 150mg twice a day, Metoprolol 100mg twice day, Amlodipine 10mg once a day, Lisinopril 5mg bd, Lamotrigine 200mg twice a day, Carbamazepine 300m twice a day and Atorvastatin 20mg once a day.
Keith has been on quite a high dose of Metoprolol for rate control of his flutter.
Post cardioversion, his heart rate at rest was low 60's in sinus rhythm.
I have asked him to visit you at the end of the week or early next week for review of his ECG and heart rate.
If Keith is bradycardic, please alter his Metoprolol dose accordingly.
Keith will have ongoing follow up through the Roma Hospital Outreach Clinic with one of the Electrophysiology Cardiologists.
Thank you for your care of Keith.

Dear Dr Grout,





														RE:	PATRICIA M. MCCLARNON		DOB:	28/04/1944	UR:	2196218

																					

														

														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:
1.
Mitral regurgitation.
a. Functional mitral regurgitation in the setting of permanent atrial fibrillation.

b. Anatomically unsuitable for transcatheter mitral valve replacement (screen fail

														        for HiLife/HiFlo study)
    c. Mitraclip on 12/10/2022 – satisfactory post procedure echocardiogram at 

														        Bundaberg 10/11/22 (mean gradient 3mmHg, with mild residual MR, RVSP 

														        34mmHg with normal RV function.
Idiopathic cardiomyopathy.
Non-obstructive coronary artery disease.
Permanent atrial fibrillation.
Cardiac conduction disease.
a. Dual chamber Medtronic permanent pacemaker implanted on 21.02.2018.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:
1.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Other Conditions:
1.
Previous depression.

Mild naso-oropharyngeal bleeding (under assessment with LMO)

Medications:
Apixaban 5mg BD
Aspirin now ceased
Bisoprolol 10mg daily 
Ramipril 2.5mg daily 
Digoxin 125mcg daily 
Frusemide – to stop today
Rosuvastatin 5mg daily 
Desvenlafaxine

														

														Review:

														I reviewed Patricia McClarnon via telehealth in Dr Singbal’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today at the PA Hospital.
She dialled in via telehealth from Bundaberg Hospital.
Patricia underwent a successful MitraClip procedure in October 2022 for severe functional mitral regurgitation.
Since that time, she feels her breathlessness has improved to NYHA class II, but now is getting significant dizziness with documented postural blood pressure drops in the clinic today.
She feels she does not have any fluid overload.

Pleasingly, her echocardiogram post procedure in November 2022, showed a now a normal ejection fraction and a satisfactory MitraClip with only mild residual MR and a mean gradient across the mitral valve of 3mmHg.
Her RV function was normal and her RVSP was 34mmHg.
Overall, this is a pleasing post procedure echo.
Her blood pressure today was 100mmHg systolic, with documented blood pressure drop to 80 on standing.
Her ECG showed atrial fibrillation with a V paced rhythm.
Overall, Patricia has had a successful MitraClip procedure with satisfactory post-procedural device, echo and mitral valve haemodynamics.
I have suggested she stop her Frusemide and see if the blood pressures and symptoms improve.

Plan
- Stop frusemide – suggest BP machine at home to measure blood pressures/postural to see if 

														  medications can be down titrated a bit given significant dizziness getting in way of lifestyle
- Continue rest of medications
- Ongoing follow up with Dr Grout in Bundaberg (has appointment in March), and GP
- Discharge from structural clinic PA Hospital

														

														Yours sincerely,

Dear Karen,





														RE:	LILLIARNA MCDONALD	DOB:	24/10/2002	UR:	2234917

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Lilliarna today 25.01.2023.
She is a 20-year-old female with a young daughter who suffered SVT for 3 years.
She gets it every second week currently, on the current medical regimen.
She last presented to hospital in September 2022 with an SVT.

You kindly sent along ECG’s, they are quite faded unfortunately, but it does appear that she has narrow complex tachycardia which may well be a long RP tachycardia which has a differential diagnosis of atypical AVNRT with a decremental postero septal accessory pathway or AT.
She underwent cardioversion at the time due to adenosine not being helpful and she had 48 hours of SVT which started suddenly and stopped spontaneously.
She has had 5 previous cardioversion and adenosine does not work for her.
She medicated currently on Metoprolol 100mg orally BD and Flecainide 50mg orally BD.

She had an echocardiogram in September 2022 with normal left ventricular size and systolic function with an ejection fraction of 60% and normal right ventricular size and systolic function, normal atrial size and no significant valvular abnormalities.

I was not able to find any blood results today, but I believe she has had normal urea and electrolytes and possibly normal thyroid function, and I would be grateful if the results of these could be sent to me or if these have not been performed, if the attending doctor at Toowoomba Medical & Dental could performed urea, electrolytes and thyroid function and forward the results to me.
She does not imbibe alcohol, she does not partake of caffeine, is a non-smoker and does not partake of illicit drugs.
She has no known allergies.
She has a family history of sudden cardiac death in mother at 45 years of age, but there were multiple other comorbidities, such as septic arthritis possible contributory.
ECG demonstrates normal sinus rhythm and no evidence of pre-excitation.
I have had a long discussion with Lilliarna with regards to the benefits of electrophysiological study with a view to radiofrequency ablation, the need for an ablatable arrhythmia.
She has a 95% chance of success, may require a left atrial access via trans septal to achieve this.
There is a 5% recurrence rate and 1 to 2% complication rate, including permanent pacemaker, cardiac tamponade, venous access complications and pulmonary embolus.
Less than 1% risk of stroke, myocardial infarction and death.
I believe she needs this, and she is happy to proceed, and I will list her for this at the PA Hospital.
She states that Metoprolol 100mg orally BD is causing nightmares.
I have prescribed her Atenolol 50mg orally daily instead.
I have not organised to see her formally, as she is listed, but would be happy to see her at any stage to help with medications.
She is considering going privately, otherwise she is listed at the PA Hospital, and we will perform this in due course.
If there are any issues, please do not hesitate to get in touch with me.
Many thanks for your kind referral.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Lau,





														RE:	TREVOR MCELLIGOTT	DOB:	06/06/1966	UR:	490456

																					

														

														

														Problem List:

														Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
Mild aortic regurgitation.
Mildly dilated aortic root and ascending aorta.
Obstructive sleep apnoea.
Thank you for referring Trevor to the Cardiology Service at the PA Hospital.
He is a pleasance 56-year-old gentleman who works as a Disability Support Worker.
He is essentially asymptomatic from a cardiac standpoint.
He has had regular follow up and investigations with Dr Syed who has been watching his aortic regurgitation and aortic dimensions carefully on an annual basis.
There is no history of diabetes or coronary artery disease.
He does have hypertension, which has been known for the last 5 years for which he has been on regular treatment with good blood pressure control.
He also admits to a history of dyslipidaemia for which he is lipid lowering treatment.
He does not smoke.
His brother has had a pacemaker at the age of 40, but no further details are known about his brother’s cardiac condition.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 110/80mmHg with a heart rate of 50bpm in sinus rhythm.
Systemic examination was unremarkable.
His ECG in the clinic confirms sinus rhythm with a rate of 48bpm with normal PR interval and normal QRS duration.
A transthoracic echocardiogram that was undertaken for him recently here at the hospital, confirms normal left and right ventricular size and function.
The aortic root and ascending aorta are marginally dilated with a measurement between 39 and 40mm.
The aortic regurgitation is only mild and is not haemodynamically significant.
In summary, Trevor is a 56-year-old gentleman who has a mildly dilated ascending aorta and aortic root, which seems to be fairly stable on serial measurements.
His blood pressure is adequately controlled on current medical therapy and the aortic regurgitation is only mild which is not haemodynamically significant.
He does have sinus bradycardia, which is the consequence of Metoprolol 25mg bd, that he is receiving.

I could not be sure  what his nocturnal heart rate might be, and it is possible that a Holter monitor might help us make a decision and further reduce the Beta blocker to either 12.5mg twice daily or perhaps just continue the night-time dose.
I will leave this in the hands of Dr Syed, who has been regularly following him up.
I have made no changes to his medical therapy.
He does not require any other follow up besides a regular echocardiogram once every 18 or 24 months and I will leave that decision with Dr Syed to follow him up on a regular basis.

Yours sincerely,

RE:	FYNLAY MCGAVIN		DOB:	12/10/1999		UR:	2134341

							





														This is a short note to inform you that I reviewed Finlay McGavin via telephone today.
He is a delightful 23-year-old, who has a haemodynamically insignificant small secundum ASD which is under surveillance.
He underwent liver transplant on 20.10.2021.
He is under regular follow up of the transplant team.
He had a fall on 18.11.2022,resulting infracture of the left tibial plateau which required ORIF.
He said this was complicated by DVT and he was therefore given Clexane for anticoagulation.
Finlay has been doing reasonably well and has not had any unstable cardiac symptoms.
He is recovering from his leg fracture.
He is on Clexane 100mg twice a day for a total duration of 3 months.
He will have an ultrasound of his leg to ensure resolution of his DVT prior to ceasing Clexane.
He underwent an echocardiogram at the PA Hospital.
His RV was commented to be mildly dilated.
However, overall appearance appears to be unchanged when compared to MRI.
As you are aware the MRI calculation suggested the right ventricular size and systolic function was normal.
As part of his follow up, I am organising a cardiac MRI which will be performed over the next 12 months, and I will catch up with him again in 12 months.
I will keep you updated of his progress.

Yours sincerely,

Chronic atrial fibrillation with conduction delay requiring insertion of permanent pacing.
Amyloid on tongue biopsy.
Severe carpal tunnel syndrome on right.
I saw this 95-year-old pleasant lady in the Amyloid Clinic.
She had positive tissue diagnosis of undifferentiated amyloid from her tongue biopsy.
However, she gives a fairly consistent history of possible cardiac and peripheral TTR deposition.
Her echocardiogram is fairly suspicious of ATTR cardiac amyloidosis and as I understand the AL amyloidosis has been excluded with no monoclonal gammopathy and normal free light chains ratio.
Her troponins are mildly elevated 20ng/L and NT-proBNP raised to 1350ng/L.
She will require a PYP nuclear scan for confirmation of the diagnosis.
I would be grateful if you could organise this locally as this is her preference.
I will book a phone review following the scan to discuss the available therapies.
She is still to undergo a further immunohistochemistry typing of her amyloid tissue.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Chris,





														RE:	GLORIA MCGUIRE		DOB:	13/05/1945		UR:	1126009

																					

														

														

														Problem List:

														Hypothyroidism.
Type II diabetes.
Dyslipidaemia.
Previous carcinoma of breast.
Hypertension.
Previous dilated cardiomyopathy with moderate LV dysfunction.
Coronary angiography in July 2017, showing moderate 2 vessel coronary artery disease.
LV dysfunction out of proportion with the underlying coronary artery disease.
Recovery of LV function on medical therapy.
Repeat echocardiogram in June 2018 showing normal LV function.
Coronary artery disease.
Recent presentation with chest discomfort with jaw pain.
Exercise stress echocardiogram strongly positive at a low workload.
Repaet coronary angiography on 19.01.2023, showing progression in coronary artery disease with severe 2 vessel disease.
Tight stenosis in proximal LAD.
Tight stenosis in left circumflex and marginal branch.
Occluded right coronary arteries with inter coronary collaterals to distal right coronary artery.
Intra renal AAA.
Right renal artery stenosis.

Mild stenosis in the coeliac artery 

														

														Current Medications:

														Amlodipine 10mg daily, Aspirin 100mg daily, Clopidogrel 75mg daily, Atorvastatin 40m daily, Bicor 5mg daily, Prolia 60mg/ml injected every 6 months, Jardiance 10mg daily, Sublingual GTN PRN, Thyroxine as advised, Pantoprazole 1 tablet daily, Coversyl 2.5mg daily, Janumet 1 tablet twice daily.
It was a pleasure to catch up with Gloria and her daughter in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
I had last seen her back in 2018, at that stage, she was doing very well with good recovery in her cardiac function and no symptoms of angina.
Her blood pressure at that stage, was also well controlled.
In November last year she had presented with some upper chest discomfort with radiation of some symptoms to her jaw, which she described as jaw pain on exertion.
This would be fairly suggestive of underlying ischemic heart disease.
She did not have any acute ischemic ECG changes or troponin rise during her admission in November and an exercise stress echocardiogram was booked to investigate her symptoms further.
She underwent her stress echocardiogram in January this year, which was strongly positive at a low workload with her index symptoms being reproduced.
There were ECG changes of ischaemia and inducible wall motion abnormalities, within a minute and a half on stage 1 of the Bruce protocol.
She was admitted to hospital and underwent a repeat coronary angiogram as part of the workup.
This clearly shows progression in her coronary artery disease.
As highlighted above, her LAD lesion has progressed significant compared to July 2017 and her right coronary artery is now completely occluded.
Given her background history of diabetes and multiple other comorbidities, I would favour a surgical opinion regarding suitability for coronary artery bypass surgery in her case.

To facilitate that decision, I have also arranged for a CT scan to be done to assess for atheroma or calcification in her ascending aorta and arch, which will be very important in the decision making for her bypass surgery.
I have also made arrangement for her to be seen by the Surgical Outpatient Clinic here for further evaluation and she will return back for another consultation with me in 3 months.
I have reminded her to use the sublingual GTN should she get symptoms of chest discomfort similar to the ones she presented with in November.

Yours sincerely,

														Judith returned to heart failure titration clinic today.

Her magnesium level was improved ar 1.0.
I note that you repeated her iron levels, and these are normal with Iron 13, Ferritin 149, Sats 26%.
Her HbA1c was well managed at 6.3%.
Judith told me that since our last review she has tolerated the decrease in her Frusemide to 20mg mane well.
She has occasionally taken 40mg if has noticed a cough on waking in the mornings.
This has occurred every one to two weeks.
She has no PND however she does sleep elevated at about 45 degrees which she has done since she was a teenager due to childhood asthma.
She does not feel shorter of breath when she is sleeping.
She reports an improvement in her NYHA class to class II.
She can walk up a few stairs without being short of breath.
Her weight is stable at 87kg.
Her appetite has improved.
She finds when she takes the 40mg Frusemide she has some daytime light headedness however this is quite mild.
She has no other dizziness.

Medications

														Apixaban 5mg BD, Amiodarone 200mg nocte, Frusemide 20mg mane, Bisoprolol 5mg nocte, Entresto 24/26mg nocte, Spironolactone 25mg nocte (decreased to 12.5mg nocte), Empagliflozin 10mg - Linagliptin 5mg mane, Rosuvastatin 20mg nocte, Thyroxine 50mcg mane, Pantoprazole 40mg nocte, Panadol Osteo 2 tabs BD, Magnesium 2 tabs TDS, Span K 1 tab BD (reduced to 1 tab mane), Seretide 1 puff BD.
On examination her blood pressure was 106/70mmHg sitting and 104/80mmHg standing, heart rate 72bpm and regular.
She had no peripheral oedema.
She had soft inspiratory bilaterally in her mid zones, however she did have clear entry at her bases.

														Thank you very much for your referral.

														Recurrent SVT.
For EP study and SVT ablation at PA Hospital.

It was a pleasure to review Jaclynne in the Cardiology Arrhythmia Clinic.
She is a 41-year-old lady who has had palpitations for more than 20 years.
She was admitted to the QE II Hospital for Gynaecological Surgery and had an episode of SVT.
The ECG showed narrow complex tachycardia with a short RP interval consistent most likely with AVNRT or atrial tachycardia.
Since discharge she has had multiple episodes, but she has not had to present to the hospital.
She started Metoprolol on your advice and it has reduced the frequency of palpitations.
She described the palpitations as sudden onset, but they have a gradual onset most of the time, although there have been occasions, where they have had a sudden offset as well.
I must say there is also a description of some palpitations, which most likely are not consistent with AVNRT and may be related to anxiety, which she has had for a long time as well.
Her ECG performed today had shown sinus rhythm.
There is no evidence of pre-excitation.
I have discussed with her the treatment options.
I discussed medications versus cardiac catheter ablation, pros and cons of both approaches were discussed.
The procedure of EP study and cardiac catheter ablation was discussed in detail.
Written information has been provided.
A <2% risk of any major complication including need for a permanent pacemaker were discussed.
She is quite keen to have this, and I will organise this for her at the PA Hospital.
I have warned her about our long waiting list.
She will continue on Metoprolol for now, but if she has frequent symptoms, then you could either increase the dose of Metoprolol or add Flecainide 50mg bd to her treatment regimen.

Yours sincerely,

Class II – III NYHA dyspnoea.
Echocardiogram consistent with TTR cardiac deposition with moderate increase in LV wall thickness, IVSd 1.5cm, reduction in global LV strain -8.65% with apical sparing.
Overall LV ejection fraction 45%.
No evidence of monoclonal gammopathy on testing.
Elevated cardiac biomarkers with NT-proBNP 9680ng/L, troponin 39ng/L, eGFR 60ml/min/m².

Bilateral should reconstruction.
Type II diabetes mellitus.
Embolic stroke 2016.

Medications:

														Frusemide, Aldactone, Bisoprolol 5mg daily, Eliquis 2.5mg bd, Empagliflozin 10mg daily, Imdur 60mg daily, Candesartan 8mg daily, Somac 40mg daily, Diabex 1g daily.
I saw this pleasant 79-year-old patient with Iris origin.
His 63-year-old brother passed away recently with T60A variant of ATTR cardiac amyloidosis.
His other brother with confirmed mutation is still alive.
His 2 sisters are healthy.
James has symptoms and signs of heart failure with class II – III NYHA dyspnoea.
He remains in permanent atrial fibrillation.
He has had previous bilateral shoulder reconstructions but no carpal tunnel syndrome, spinal stenosis or biceps rupture in the past.
He remains on diuretics, in compensated heart failure.
He had no macroglossia or organomegaly.
His ECG confirms atrial fibrillation with pseudo infarct pattern in the anteroseptal leads and reduced voltages throughout both limb and precordial leads.
His echocardiogram features are consistent with advanced cardiac amyloidosis.
Cardiac biomarkers including NT-proBNP are elevated.
As far as I understand his PYP scan was positive for TTR deposition, however, I was unable to review that today.
He will require genetic testing to confirm the TTR mutation.
This is important for his daughter and his grandchildren as they may require cascade testing.
I will bring him back to my clinic following the genetic testing for further discussion about possible therapies available to him.
Thank you again for your referral.

Dear Dr Smith,





														RE:	CHARLOTTE MCLEAN	DOB:	6/09/1990	UR:	8096022

																					

														

														

														Past Medical History:
# Myocarditis
   - November 2021 (with 2nd Pfizer COVID vaccine)
   - secondary to COVID vaccination (Pfizer)
   - saw private cardiologist, Dr. Mahala Huderverdi
     -- unable to afford ongoing private reviews
   - verified on cMRI
# Palpitations for investigation
# Obstructive sleep apnoea
   - on CPAP
# Graves’ disease
   - known to Dr. Cracknell
   - on carbimazole 5mg daily
# Anxiety/Depression
   - known to psychologist

Medications:
atenolol 6.25mg daily (higher doses cause postural hypotension), sertraline 100mg mane, carbimazole 5mg mane, Amitriptyline 10mg nocte

														Note:  anaphylactic to diltiazem

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Charlotte McLean in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
Thank you for referring her to us for review of her palpitations on the background of his previous post COVID vaccination myocarditis.
As you know, Charlotte is an independent 32-year-old lady who is a University Lecturer in the field of music.
She lives at home with her partner and is independent of her activities of daily living.
She has never smoked and drinks alcohol only twice per year.

With respect to Charlotte’s symptoms of palpitations, she tells me that they started in late November 2021, shortly after suffering myocarditis, which was a presumed complication of her second Pfizer COVID vaccine.
She feels that these usually occur at night when resting, as well as in the morning upon waking.
She describes the symptoms of palpitations as her heart beating quickly and harder.
Her symptoms seem to be exacerbated by caffeine and exercise.
Notably, she only drinks 2 expresso shots (by way of lattes), in separate sittings in 1 day at most.
Her symptoms seem to have progressed with time and now are consistently exacerbated with more strenuous exertion.
Separately, Charlotte describes a flutter sensation which feels like and sort of ‘quivering’ upper chest wall.
She is unclear whether this is associated with muscular activation.
Charlotte has purchased an AliveCor event monitor and has used it to capture a few episodes of her palpitations.
I reviewed the recordings today on her phone, which were predominantly sinus rhythm with a rate <100bpm.
There were 2 episodes that could not be classified with certainty and may be associated with electrical noise.
I understand that Charlotte was initially seeing a private cardiologist, Dr Mahala Huderverdi, but is unable to continue seeing her, due to the significant cost burden.
Charlotte tells me that she has undergone a cardiac MRI as well as a Holter monitor as part of this consultation process.
Unfortunately, the results of these reports were not available for review during her clinic appointment today.

I would ask that you please forward any cardiac investigations (including transthoracic echocardiogram, cardiac MRI, Holter monitors, etc) and specialist letters to us for review at Charlotte’s next clinic appointment.
On examination today, Charlotte appeared well in and in good spirits.

Dear Dr Smith,





RE:	CHARLOTTE MCLEAN	DOB:	6/09/1990	UR:	8096022

							





Past Medical History:
# Myocarditis
   - November 2021 (with 2nd Pfizer COVID vaccine)
   - secondary to COVID vaccination (Pfizer)
   - saw private cardiologist, Dr. Mahala Huderverdi
     -- unable to afford ongoing private reviews
   - verified on cMRI
# Palpitations for investigation
# Obstructive sleep apnoea
   - on CPAP
# Graves’ disease
   - known to Dr. Cracknell
   - on carbimazole 5mg daily
# Anxiety/Depression
   - known to psychologist

Medications:
atenolol 6.25mg daily (higher doses cause postural hypotension)
sertraline 100mg mane
carbimazole 5mg mane
Amitriptyline 10mg nocte
anaphylactic to diltiazem



I had the pleasure of reviewing Charlotte McLean in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
Thank you for referring her to us for review of her palpitations on the background of his previous post COVID vaccination myocarditis.
As you know, Charlotte is an independent 32-year-old lady who is a University Lecturer in the field of music.
She lives at home with her partner and is independent of her activities of daily living.
She has never smoked and drink alcohol only twice per year.

With respect to Charlotte’s symptoms of “palpitations”, she tells me that they started in late November 2021, shortly after suffering myocarditis, which was a presumed complication of her second Pfizer COVID vaccine.
She feels that these usually occur at night when resting, as well as in the morning upon waking.
She describes the symptoms of palpitations as her heart beating quickly and harder.
Her symptoms seem to be exacerbated by caffeine and exercise.
Notably, she only drinks 2 expresso shots (by way of lattes), in separate sittings in 1 day at most.
Her symptoms seem to have progressed with time and now are consistently exacerbated with more strenuous exertion.
Separately, Charlotte describes a “flutter” sensation which feels like and sort of ‘quivering’ upper chest wall.
She is unclear whether this is associated with muscular activation.
Charlotte has purchased an AliceCor event monitor and has used it to capture a few episodes of her palpitations.
I reviewed the recordings today on her phone, which were predominantly sinus rhythm with a rate <100bpm.
There were 2 episodes that could not be classified with certainty and may be associated with electrical noise.
I understand that Charlotte was initially seeing a private cardiologist, Dr Mahala Huderverdi, but is unable to continue seeing her, due to the significant cost burden.
Charlotte tells me that she has undergone a cardiac MRI as well as a Holter monitor as part of this consultation process.
Unfortunately, the results of these reports were not available for review during her clinic appointment today.

I would ask that you please forward any cardiac investigations (including transthoracic echocardiogram, cardiac MRI, Holter monitors, etc) and specialist letters to us for review at Charlotte’s next clinic appointment.
On examination today, Charlotte appeared well in and in good spirits.
Her blood pressure was 130/80mmHg and her heart rate was approximately 68bpm and regular.
This corresponded with an ECG in sinus rhythm.
Her chest was clear, and her heart sounds were dual with no murmurs.
She did not have peripheral oedema.
Charlotte was seen by Dr Korczyk in clinic today.
After reviewing the above history with Charlotte, we will arrange a repeat 24-hour Holter monitor and transthoracic echocardiogram.
As mentioned above, we would be grateful if previous investigations could be forwarded to us for review and comparison with her repeat investigations.
In the meantime, we have asked Charlotte to stop her Atenolol, as the dose she is taking is ineffective for an adult.
We have also asked her to try decaffeinated beverages.
We will arrange for a chart review in approximately 4 to 5 months to assess the findings of her repeat investigations in comparison with those done previously in the community.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Miss McLean.

Yours sincerely,

														FS1 Riverlink Shopping Centre

														NORTH IPSWICH QLD 4305

														

														

														

														Dear Dr Byrnes

														

														

														RE:	KAREN MCNAUGHTON	DOB:	23/09/1958	UR:	395225

																					

														

														

														Karen was reviewed in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
Her friend was also present for the consultation.
She has a history with degenerative disc disease.
Her other history includes osteoarthritis, C3-C4 laminectomy, migraine, diverticulitis, and she is an ex-smoker stopping 10 years ago with approximately 30 pack years of smoking.
Her medications include Oxycontin, Olmetec 40mg, Motilium, Pramin, Somac, Tazac and Pethidine previously.
She has a listed allergies to Panadol.
She lives at home alone and she has support from her friends.
She does not drink, and she is currently on New Start Allowance.
She reports for mobility she uses a 4-wheel frame to mobilise when she feels like using it.
In addition, she reports a history of PTSD and she has follow up with a Psychiatrist in the community.
Karen reports that she has been experiencing symptoms of progressive dyspnoea that is more noticeable over the past 6 months.
With regards to her exercise tolerance, even approximately 12 months ago, she reports that her exercise tolerance was approximately limited to 50 metres.
Approximately in the past 6 months, she reports that her exercise tolerance has reduced to approximately 25 metres.
This is in keeping with NYHA class III dyspnoea.
She reports that when she reaches her limits, she starts to get very short of breath and she experiences palpitations and then once she takes a break the symptoms subside.
Additionally, she experiences left sided reproducible atypical chest wall pain which is not exacerbated by exertion.
She informs me that she stopped smoking 10 years ago.
She does not recall having previous investigations from a lung perspective.
Regards to her family history, she reports that her birth mother had ischaemic heart disease aged in her 80s.

Of note, she reports episodes approximately 3 months ago when she was at the shops where she felt light headed and short of breath and she cannot recall if she had a presyncopal episode or lost consciousness.
She reports this happened a couple of times, but she did not seek medical review at the time.
She reports having a similar episode approximately 1 month ago.
She currently does not drive, as she was advised not to drive in the setting of these episodes.
On examination her heart rate was 59bpm and her blood pressure was 150/90mmHg.
Her heart sounds were dual, and her chest had mild crepitations at the left base on auscultation.
On the left chest wall, approximately the anterior axillary line at the level of the 9th and 10th ribs, there is a focal area of reproducible chest pain on palpation.
She reports that this pain is similar to the chest pain that she had experienced.
Her ECG shows sinus bradycardia with a heart rate of 59bpm.
She had an echocardiogram via Lumas Imaging in Oxley in June 2022, which concluded that she had normal left ventricular size and systolic function with an ejection fraction of approximately 63%.
There was normal diastolic function for her age.
Normal right ventricular size and systolic function.
She had a severely dilated left atrium.
She had mildly thickened mitral valve leaflets with mild mitral regurgitation.
There was aortic valve sclerosis and mild tricuspid regurgitation.
With regards to Karen’s history of dyspnoea, the current investigations from a cardiac perspective is not in keeping with the severity of the symptoms that she is experiences.
There may be a contribution of multifactorial causes to her dyspnoea.
She has a previous history of smoking and if you can please consider referring her for a respiratory opinion in order to further assess it.

From a cardiac perspective, she will be referred to have a Holter monitor in the setting of her history of reported palpitations and she will be referred for a repeat echocardiogram to reassess her cardiac function.
If you can please monitor her blood pressure and cholesterol levels that will be appreciated.
If her cholesterol levels are elevated, please consider commencing her on a statin agent.
Also, in regard to her blood pressure, if her blood pressure remains elevated can you please consider addition of a further antihypertensive agent such as Amlodipine to her current therapy.
She was advised in the interim, that if she experiences symptoms that are concerning to please seek medical review.
She is planned for follow up in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic in approximately 6 months.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Chow,





RE:	KERRY JAMES MENZ	DOB:	30/04/1948	UR:	662496

							



														Background:

														1.
Indolent B cell non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma in remission, on maintenance Rituximab.

Anthracycline induced cardiomyopathy – repeat echocardiogram in September

														    2021 showing moderately dilated left ventricle with moderate systolic dysfunction

														    (Ejection fraction 35%)., AICD in situ
3.

Dilated aortic root and ascending aorta
4.
Atrial fibrillation , Digoxin 125mcg daily, and Bicor 5mg twice daily.
Hypertension.
Previous history of haemoptysis.
Type II diabetes.

Bicuspid aortic valve with mild-moderate aortic regurgitation and moderate aortic 

														    stenosis.

Current Medications:
Allopurinol 100mg daily
Bicor 5mg bd
Rosuvastatin 20mg nocte
Digoxin 125 mcg daily.

Entresto 24/26 mg twice daily, 
Frusemide 40mg daily.

Gliclazide 30mg daily
Janumet 1 tablet daily
Pantoprazole 20mg daily
Spironolactone 25mg daily

														

														I had the pleasure of meeting Mr Menz in the Cardiology  Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
He has a fairly complex medical / haematological background which has resulted in anthracycline induced LV dysfunction.
He is currently being managed with heart failure medications which I have mentioned above.
He also has a history of bicuspid aortic valve and had an echocardiogram performed this afternoon, showing an ejection fraction of 35% which is unchanged from his previous echocardiogram.
There is moderate stenosis across Bicuspid aortic valve with mild to moderate regurgitation.
Fortunately, he remains clinically asymptomatic and denies any history of shortness of breath, orthopnoea or PND.
He has no history of chest tightness or syncope.

His recent clinical progresses have been complicated with pancytopaenia and ITP which has been actively managed under the Haematological Team and due to the low platelet count he has been switched off from Rivaroxaban.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 110/70mmHg, with dual heart sounds and an ejection systolic murmur, though no evidence of volume overload.
There was reduced breath sounds on chest examination.
Overall, it seems that Kerry has a persistent LV dysfunction with no changes in the last 2 years.
He has an AICD in situ for the prevention of any malignant arrhythmia.
He needs ongoing medical management.
I have not made any changes to his heart failure medications today.
We will review him in 12 months with an echocardiogram prior which I have organised.
He should resume his NOAC when it is safe from ITP / haematological side, and I believe this is being driven by our Haematological  Colleagues.
Please continue with your ongoing care and feel free to contact us if you have any concerns in the interim.

Yours sincerely,

														Joshua returned to heart failure titration clinic today.

He did not notice any other skin, movement or sensation changes.
This did occur whilst he was taking Sudafed for a light cold.
After ceasing the Sudafed, the tingling resolved for 24 hours.
He then had another 24 hours of tingling which self-resolved and has not returned.
Joshua told me that he saw his podiatrist recently who gave him a full review of his feet and legs, and they did not have any concerns.
He continues to play Powerchair football.
He has had no PND, orthopnoea, dizziness or shortness of breath.

														Local Medical Officer

														Carina Medical Centre

														396-398 Stanley Road

														CARINA QLD 4152

														

														

														Dear Doctor,

														

														

														RE:	BOSKO MILIKIC		DOB:	07/02/1945		UR:	473929

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Bosko, a 77-year-old gentleman who I had the pleasure of reviewing on behalf of Dr Ng as a post discharge appointment.

As you are already aware, Bosko was admitted under the PA Hospital Cardiology Department from 2nd to the 6th of December following an aborted STEMI on the background of known ischaemic cardiomyopathy.

He underwent an angiogram that showed severe in stent restenosis of his mid LAD stents and subsequently underwent bifurcational PCI to LAD / D2, with 1 drug eluting stent in his second diagonal and 2 drug eluting stents in his LAD.
Since discharge, Bosko has not had any chest pain or any significant breathing difficulties.
He has taken back to gardening; however, his wife does most of the chores around the house.
He has some mild ankle oedema, but otherwise no orthopnoea or PND.
He has had no bleeding complications from his dual antiplatelet therapy either.
Bosko is a never smoker, who drinks approximately 1 standard drink per day.
He was discharged with a Webster Pack.
However, since then he reports that he finds it easier to self-medicate through the usual boxes.
I am pleased to report that since he has been home, he has been well compliant with his medications.
These include Amlodipine 10mg, Aspirin 100mg, Clopidogrel 75mg, Crestor 40mg, Ezetimibe 10mg, Bisoprolol 5mg, Perindopril 4mg, Metformin Extended Release 500mg.
He was also prescribed 30mg of Isosorbide Mononitrate,  however, he has not taken them in the last week since he ran of his prescriptions.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 128/60mmHg with a regularly regular heart rate of 60bpm.
His heart sounds were dual with no murmurs and his chest was clear on auscultation.
He had trace ankle oedema (pitting).
Bosko has not had any blood tests since discharge and I note that his LDL was 2.3 while he was hospitalised with us.
Our impression today is that Bosko has stable ischaemic cardiomyopathy with good medication compliance and minimal symptoms.

His LVEF in December was 40-45%/ 

														

														Our plan is:

														Can stop Isosorbide Mononitrate given he has had percutaneous intervention to his single vessel coronary artery disease.
Continue dual antiplatelet therapy for 12 months.
Can stop Clopidogrel 12 months after PCI (stop on 05.12.2023).
Aspirin to continue indefinitely.
Add Empagliflozin 10mg.
Once he is established on Empagliflozin and his blood pressure allows, please up titrate his Perindopril to assist with heart failure management.
We will review him in 6 months and would appreciate if you could organise some routine blood tests as well as a lipid profile test for him prior to this clinic review.
The chest pain pathway has been reiterated to Bosko, and I have advised him to seek urgent medical attention should he have chest pain lasting more than 15 to 20 minutes.
Thank you for your ongoing care and please do not hesitate in contacting us should you have any questions or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Wong,





														RE:	DAVID MILLER		DOB:	15/01/1941		UR:	014646

																					

														

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Mr Miller in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
We have been monitoring him for a mobile echodensity on his mechanical aortic valve from he had a stroke unfortunately in August of 2022.
This is favored to represent to represent a thrombus in setting of subtherapeutic INRs on warfarin.

He has had serial echocardiograms which show reducing size of thrombus over time but still not fully resolved on the latest echocardiogram performed at the QEII Hospital in December 2022 - the pictures are not available to me today for review.
He has been well with therapeutic INR’s via QML, the last one being 2.8 on 06.01.2023.
He has a normal second mechanical heart sound and there is a soft pain systolic murmur.
He is euvolaemic today.
I have revised his notes from our Urology Colleagues from the QEII Hospital who are planning to do a TURP for his prostate and urological issues.
From urology perspective, the preference is that they perform TURP without anticoagulation on board if feasible and safe.

Our recommendation however is that it really never is safe for this gentleman to come off anticoagulation completely firstly n view of having a mechanical valve, secondly mechanical valve thrombus from which he has already had a complication of a stroke and thirdly the fact that there is still thrombus present on his mechanical aortic valve.
We recommend that he undergoes inpatient bridging with either unfractionated Heparin preferably or low molecular weight heparin.
His APTT ideally should be therapeutic all the time as much as feasible and if LMWH is used, anti-Xa level could be checked- we recommend Haematology advice.
Our advice is that interruption of anticoagulation is kept to minimum and post procedure he should be bridged back onto warfarin when the surgical team is happy.
This ideally should be done as an inpatient, rather than in the community as he is at high risk of complications from his mechanical valve.
I have organised another echocardiogram for him in the next 4 weeks at the PA Hospital, so we can compare the images, as we do not have access to the  QEII echocardiogram images from December 2022.
I have requested a review in 6 weeks.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Toe,





RE:	CARL MINNS		DOB:	25/04/1962		UR:	965592

							



														Mr Minns was referred from Dr Fetahovic’s cardiology clinic for medication titration.
As you know this gentleman has non-ischaemic cardiomyopathy with a most recent EF 36% in November 2022 this had declined from 45% December 2020.
He has a past history of Hyperlipidaemia, HIV on treatment, treated HCV, and depression.

Medications

														Perindopril 8mg mane.
He self-ceased the Spironolactone 4 days ago due his concern around the effects and sides effects of this medication.
He is not on B-Blocker due to previous lethargy.
He has nil known allergies.
Mr Minns is currently not working, and he is on Centrelink benefits.
He told me that he attends the gym 6 times per week doing about 90 minutes cardio sessions.
He had reduced his alcohol significantly since his appointment with Dr Fetahovic late last year.
However, he has had a few bottles of wine periodically to help him sleep in the last little while.
He is a non-smoker.
The most important issue, I believe for Carl at the present time is depression.
This is a long-standing condition which has been acutely exacerbated since Christmas after his dog died.
He was teary and upset during the consultation.
He has had previous suicidal ideation.
He is not currently on any anti-depressants.
He denies any current thoughts of self-harm.
Carl has two sons with whom he is estranged and there are issues with domestic violence orders with his ex-wife and sons.
Carl is at a loss to explain this.
I understand that he been to see you recently about not being able to sleep.
He feels that the sleeping tablets prescribed are not effective.
He describes class II NYHA symptoms.
He became breathless walking up the hill to the hospital this morning.
He denies any orthopnoea, PND, dizziness, light headedness, or chest pain.

RE:	CARL MINNS		DOB:	25/04/1962		UR:	965592

														

														

														

														On examination his blood pressure was 120/80mmHg sitting and 110/80mmHg standing, heart rate 88bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
Heart sounds were dual, and chest was clear.
Today I have organised a blood test to assess his renal function, full blood count and iron studies.
These are attached for your information.
I have asked him to restart the Spironolactone at 12.5mg mane.
I have explained the rational for all heart failure medications.
Carl was able to confirm with me that he understood.
I will see him back in this clinic in four weeks.
I have also asked our Social Worker to see him today to offer support and encouragement given his emotional state.
I also offered access to our heart failure gym program here at the hospital, but Carl declined.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Kostner,





														RE:	DENISE ANN MITCHELL	DOB:	06/10/1957	UR:	012927

																					

														

														

														Thank you very much for your referral.

Diagnoses:

														Non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy.
Likely post chemotherapy (Doxorubicin, Cyclophosphamide, Paclitaxel and Herceptin).
Wide left bundle branch block.
For CRT-D implant.
Left sided breast cancer.
Stopped adjuvant chemotherapy with Letrozole.
Previous lumpectomy and lymph node dissection.

Current Medications:

														Entresto 97mg, Crestor, Bisoprolol 7.5mg daily, Dapagliflozin.
It was a pleasure to review Denise in the Cardiology Arrhythmia Clinic.

She is a 65-year-old lady who has a history of left breast cancer, which was treated with a lumpectomy and lymph node dissection, followed by chemotherapy as described above, along with radiotherapy as well.
In 2017 she was found to have mild LV systolic dysfunction, which over a period of time, despite medical treatment has deteriorated with a recent ejection fraction of 15%.
She is on maximum medical therapy.
She has NYHA class II symptoms.
There is no recent history of syncope, but she does get quite frequent presyncopal episodes, which are mostly postural in nature.
Further treatment with heart failure therapies, is limited due to symptomatic low blood pressure.
Her ECG shows sinus rhythm with a wide left bundle branch block (QRS 170ms), with notching in the inferior leads.
In view of NYHA class II symptoms, left bundle branch block and an ejection fraction of 15%, I have recommended a CRT-D device.
The rational for this was discussed (prevention of sudden cardiac death from ventricular tachyarrhythmias and left bundle branch block).
The procedure and after care were discussed with her.
There is around a 2% risk of any major complication including infection, bleeding, pneumothorax, pericardial effusion, and lead dislodgement.
This was discussed with her.
It was also discussed that the LV lead implant depends on the anatomy of the coronary size.
There is also a question of whether she should have a right sided device or left sided device.
Ideally a left sided device is technically more feasible and also, she is right-handed.
Although I am a bit concerned about her lymph node dissection and future risk of lymph-oedema.
I guess there is a theoretical risk of breast cancer recurrence & thereby future need of Radiotherapy requirement & the need to move the device.
If things are unclear, we will try a right sided implant which is usually quite challenging for the CS lead implant, but we will try our best.
She is due to have a repeat mammogram done in the next couple of weeks and I will organise this for her post the scan.
She will continue to have regular follow up with yourself.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Jaramillo,





														RE:	JOHN E. MITCHELL		DOB:	16/02/1942	UR:	409786

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of John, an 80-year-old gentleman known to Dr Hill for work up of his unexplained syncope.
This is on the background of diabetes, hypertension, vasculopathy and a stroke 17 years ago, along with benign prostatic hypertrophy.
John tells me that he has been having syncopal episodes for over a decade now and all these occur whilst upright without any warning signs.
He tells me his episodes are more frequent now with his last one being 2 weeks ago.
This occurred while he was sitting at a café, about to drink coffee.
He had no warning, woke up after a syncopal episode feeling absolutely fine.
This is a second episode of syncope in the last 6 months and both of them have occurred on days where he has had nothing to eat or drink.
He still continues to drive short distances and mobilises with a 4-wheelie walker.
John has had frequent dizziness since his stroke, and this is not particularly worse at present.
John lives alone and does not have an ACAT assessment.
He finds the months of December and January particularly difficult, because a lot of family members including his wife have passed away around this time.
John and I discussed why he does not drink any water, and he became very teary about the fact that he has significant urinary frequency and urge incontinence.
He is very bothered by this, despite being on Duodart.
He has not seen Urology in many years.
His current medications include Duodart, Sitagliptin, Crestor, Jardiamet, Verapamil 180mg, Trandolapril 4mg and Eye drops.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 160/80mmHg, without a postural drop, his heart sounds were dual with no murmurs and his chest was clear on auscultation.
He had no peripheral oedema, and his jugular venous pressure was not elevated.
His ECG today was in 1st degree heart block at a rate of 96bpm.

His echocardiogram performed a couple of weeks ago showed a normal left ventricular size with a low normal ejection fraction and no significant valvular abnormalities

														

														Our impression today is that John has long-standing unexplained syncope without warning which requires further assessment.

Our recommendations are:

														Needs to stay well hydrated and eat regularly.
We have stopped his Empagliflozin in light of his bothersome urinary symptoms.
Please keep an eye on his glycaemic control in the context of this.
Please refer John to the Urology Outpatient Service for consideration of TURP.
Please also refer him to Neurology to exclude a neurogenic component to his syncope (although story is atypical, given his stroke, seizures may need to be excluded).
We will review him in 3 months with an ECG.
Dr Hill is happy for him to continue driving short distances as long as he is eating and drinking and does not have another syncopal episode.
John should seek urgent medical attention should he have further syncope.
Please contact us should you have any questions or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

														Neville returned to heart failure titration clinic today.

He is currently finding it difficult to adjust to the device as he feels that it is quite prominent on his chest wall.
He continues to describe class I NYHA symptoms.
He denies any orthopnoea, PND, or chest pain.

RE:	PERRY MITCHELL		DOB:	28/05/1959		UR:	674681

							

														Perry presented to this hospital with exertional angina in August last year.
In addition, he had moderate aortic valve stenosis and a symptomatic cardiac conduction disease with 1st degree atrioventricular block and alternating left and right bundle branch blocks.
He proceeded to coronary artery bypass grafting utilising LITA and 2 radial artery grafts.
This was complicated by a shock state post operatively for which he required an intra-aortic balloon pump and catecholamine support.
Atrial fibrillation then supervened with significant reversion pauses, prompting urgent permanent pacemaker implantation.
He returned to theatre for drainage and washout of an haematoma at the left radial harvest site.
Left ventricular ejection fraction was 40% preoperatively, however, he required careful titration of heart failure medications, which was ongoing after discharge.
At the moment, Perry is generally feeling well.
His walking distance is about 200 metres before he develops dyspnoea, and then he can develop some dizziness if he persists with walking.
This suggests some chronotropic incompetence, so I have increased the upper sensor rate of his pacemaker from 130 to 150bpm and increased the exertion response by 1 step.
The function of his pacemaker was satisfactory otherwise today.
His blood pressure today was 95/60mmHg sitting, so I have asked him to reduce his Spironolactone now down to 12.5mg in the morning.
His wounds have healed well and there were no other abnormal cardiac signs, in particular none of cardiac decompensation.
The last measurement of left ventricular ejection fraction was 42%.
He has resumed driving and is looking forward to returning to work next month.
I have made him an appointment in our Device Timing Clinic for echocardiographic optimisation of pacemaker timing cycles and will report further thereafter.

Yours sincerely, 

														

														Electronically signed 13.01.23

Dear Dr Sattri,





														RE:	RAFIQUE MOHAMMED	DOB:	1/10/1957	UR:	8087433

																					

														

														Issues:
# Ischaemic cardiomyopathy.
· CABG X 2 1998 – LIMA to LAD, SVG to circumflex, SVG to right coronary.
· Angiogram 2011 – occluded vein grafts.
· Redo CABG graft to PDA, unable to graft circumflex.

· Angiogram 2020, due to chest pain, PCI to distal LAD and LIMA (LIMA

														     dissection).

· TTE August 2022 PA Hospital EF 25 to 30% with mildly dilated LV size, normal

														     RV size with impaired systolic function, mild MR.
   - ACEi/ARB/ARNI: sacubitril/valsartan 49/51mg BD
   - Beta-blocker: bisoprolol 1.25mg mane
   - MRA: spironolactone 12.5mg mane
   - Diuretics: frusemide 20mg PRN
   - SGLT2i/GLP-1: dapagliflozin 10mg mane
   - Iron studies: Ferritin 51 (Sept 2022)
     -- Last iron infusion: 500mg Oct 2022
# Atrial fibrillation.

- anticoagulated with apixaban
# Diabetes type II.
# BPH.

Medications:
Frusemide 20mg PRN (last taken one month ago), Apixaban 5mg BD, Entresto 49/52mg BD, Bisoprolol 1.25mg mane, Spironolactone 12.5mg mane, Rosuvastatin 40mg nocte, Metformin 500mg MR 1 tab BD, Esomeprazole 20mg nocte, Magmin 500mg mane, Dapagliflozin 10mg mane.
I had the pleasure of reviewing Rafique Mohammed in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today, accompanied by his wife, daughter, and granddaughter.
This was a routine review with respect to his ischaemic cardiomyopathy and atrial fibrillation.
Since his last review, Rafique has been regularly seeing Robyn Peters, our Nurse Practitioner in the Heart Recovery Service, to optimise his heart failure therapy.
The regimen that you see listed above is possibly his maximum tolerated doses, as any higher doses reportedly cause lightheadedness.
From a clinical perspective, Rafique tells me that he has been feeling tired on a regular basis but does not experience any exertional chest discomfort.
His exercise tolerance remains stable at being able to walk around the block without stopping.
However, he reports occasional paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea and orthopnoea.
It is unclear though, whether this is due to fluid overload or to other concerns, as his weight has remained stable, and he was euvolaemic today.
Importantly, Rafique has a fluid management plan and continues to weight himself daily to manage his diuretic doses.
On examination today, Rafique weighed 73 kilograms fully clothed.
His blood pressure was 115/65mmHg sitting and increased to 125/80mmHg when standing.
His heart rate was approximately 55 to 60bpm and irregularly irregular consistent with his known diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.
His chest was clear, and his heart sounds were dual with no murmur and his jugular venous pressure was not elevated.
Rafique had a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram on 18th of this month.
This has not yet been formally reported, but the preliminary report shows a largely unchanged cardiac circumstance with an LVEF of approximately 25% and a reduced right ventricular systolic function.
A formal report will follow, when finalised by the reporting consultant.
I understand that Rafique has another appointment with our heart failure nurse practitioner next week for consideration of further possibility of up titration if possible.
Therefore, I have arranged for him to have a repeat pathology panel today, which includes FBE, Chem 20, TFTs, Iron studies, and a HbA1c.
A copy of these results should be forwarded to you for your records.

Based on these results, there may be further gradual refinements to his heart failure therapy regimen, but I have advised Rafique and his family today, that it is possible that at this time we are unable to further increase his medications, which would improve his long-term prognosis.
Prior to leaving today, I have emphasised the signs and symptoms of decompensated heart failure with him today, and also emphasised the importance of addressing any chest discomfort that may arise.
Should either occur and not resolve, I have asked him to seek medical review promptly.
I will arrange to review Rafique again in approximately 1 year.
Should he be stable at that time, we may discharge him to your ongoing care.
However, should his condition deteriorate before then, please write to us and we will move his appointment forward accordingly.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Mohammed.

Yours sincerely,

														Ron came for an elective cardioversion today for atrial fibrillation associated with severe LV dysfunction.
