														RE:	DARRYL MORRISON	DOB:	30/11/1943	UR:	1171144

																					

														

														

														I caught up with this 79-year-old gentleman in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.

Issues:
1.

CAD
    a. CAC 1508.3 (QXR) 6.10.2021; 82nd centile; Calcified left-sided pleural plaque
    b. TTE 13.12.2021 – Normal LV size with LVEF 55%; Normal RV size and systolic

														        function; Aortic sclerosis
    c. DSE 23.8.2022 – No CP or ECG changes; Negative for inducible ischemia

Background:
1.

T2DM
2.

Hyperlipidaemia; Hypertension
3.

Asthma
4.

Depression; Polymyalgia rheumatica 
5.

Diverticular disease; Colonic polyps
6.

Prostatomegaly
7.

Previous right knee reconstruction, traumatic bladder and rectal injury (Required 

														    primary bladder repair and Hartmann’s (reversed)), bilateral hydroceles, left 

														    epididymo-orchitis
8.

Ex-smoker (Ceased 2011); EtOH - 3 stubbies/night 
9.

Lives with wife; Retired gas fitter; Plays bowls 3-5 x week; Independent ADLs
10.

NKDA
11.

No bleeding issues, malignancy, planned elective surgery 

Medications:
Caduet 10/20mg od
Coversyl 10mg od
Diabex XR 2g mane
Aspirin 100mg od

														

														From the cardiac perspective, he remains asymptomatic with no chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, palpitations or syncope.
He is still active mowing lawns and playing bowls.
He works at the Bowls Club.
On examination his blood pressure 145/90mmHg.
He tells me that his blood pressure with yourself systolic normally sits around 150mmHg.
I also not that he was quite hypertensive during the DSE as well.
His heart rate was 72bpm and regular, JVP not elevated, heart sounds dual with a 2/6 ejection systolic murmur at the base.
His chest was clear.

Assessment:

														He has stable coronary artery disease.
He has no angina.
His dobutamine stress echocardiogram was negative for inducible ischaemia.
However, his  hypertension requires further optimisation.

Plan:

														I have started him on Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg once a day.
I would be grateful if you could review him, monitor his renal function and escalate his antihypertensive treatment as required.

Given he does have coronary artery disease present on the basis of coronary artery calcification, we should be aiming for aggressive risk factor modification with secondary prevention targets for his blood pressure and lipids.
I will leave that in your hands.
I have not made any further appointments to see him at this stage but would be happy to review him again if there are any other concerns, or certainly if he develops angina.
Thank you kindly for your continuing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Chester,

														

														

														RE:	DENIS JAMES MUNDAY	DOB:	18/07/1950	UR:	2141677

																					

														

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Denis Munday in our Cardiology Research Clinic today;  he was accompanied by his wife.
This was a routine visit for the Ionis Clinical Trial.
Denis tells me today that he has been doing relatively well recently with his physical condition remaining at his usual baseline.
He tells me that this includes approximately 500 metres mobilisation or up to 17 stairs without stopping.
However, he occasionally requires the use of home oxygen which he has available to him.
He has needed an increasing amount of time on the supplement of oxygen in recent memory.
It is unclear exactly the underling aetiology as to why this is so.
He denies any significant orthopnoea, or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, and today, on examination he was euvolaemic.
Specifically, on examination, his heart sounds were dual with no murmurs.
His chest was clear, JVP was not elevated, and he had no peripheral oedema.
His primary concern today was the significant paraesthesia that he experiences in his hands that he describes as tingling.
This is particularly bothersome when he is trying to sleep at night.
This is in the context of previous bilateral carpal tunnel release, though today he had positive Tinel sign and reverse Phalen’s.
He had similar sensations on examination of his lower limbs as well, predominantly around his feet.
These symptoms, however, are not new and have been ongoing for at least 12 months.
The interpretation of these symptoms is complicated by his history of spinal stenosis and multiple surgeries.
I ask that you continue to monitor these symptoms and consider further investigations and or treatment.
At this time, I do not believe these symptoms to be secondary to the trial drug.
As part of routine testing for the clinical trial, Denis’ renal function is regularly measured.
His baseline eGFR was 39ml/min, which significantly deteriorated by week 55 to only 28ml/min.
This is a 28% decrease in renal function from baseline.
By week 59, his eGFR had decreased further to 22ml/min, which is a 43.6% decrease from his baseline.
As per protocol, dosing of the trial drug will be interrupted.
His renal function will be repeated, the results of which will be forwarded to you for your review.
His next blood test will be in early February and if the renal function improves sufficiently, restarting the trial drug will be considered.
His next clinic review as part of the clinical trial will be in April this year.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Munday.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Browne,





RE:	HELEN MURPHY		DOB:	20/02/1959		UR:	8111330

							



														Helen attended the heart failure titration clinic today with her daughter Louise.
As you know this is on the background of a long and complicated admission from the 1st October to the 8th December 2022.
Initially Helen presented with a late presentation STEMI, complicated by complete heart block and cardiogenic shock.
An angiogram at that time showed an occluded proximal LAD.
Her mid LAD and distal LAD were not visualised as there was no collaterals.
Her right coronary artery showed mild diffuse disease.
Echocardiogram showed, left ventricular EF 20% with extensive LAD territory regional wall motion abnormalities.

She was admitted to ICU with an intra-aortic balloon pump along with temporary pacing wires, which were weaned and removed, however, on weaning of the inotropic support she relapsed into cardiogenic shock, that possibly had a septic cause and was readmitted into ICU with intra-aortic balloon pump.
During this time Helen had a severe acute kidney injury, atrial fibrillation and a LV thrombus noted on TTE.
During treatment with Heparin she developed HITTS.
The balloon pump was once again removed, and she was stepped back down to CCU on the 26th October where she eventually had the dobutamine weaned.

Helen did attend rehabilitation at the Princess Alexandra Hospital and during this admission Helen complained of an ongoing headache, a CT on the 14th November which showed a new right occipital lobe cerebral infarct.
As a result of this Helen has going left sided vision disturbance and she is having follow up with ophthalmology.
Additionally Helen received an iron infusion for deficiency during the admission.
Her other past medical history includes T2DM, HTN, Hyperlipidaemia, right proximal radius ulna facture requiring ORIF in 2017.
Today Helen mobilised into my clinic room with a four wheeled walker.
I understand she uses this for long walking journeys.
Helen told me that overall, she is recovering very well from her long hospital stay.
She is currently living with her daughter at Wishart.
Prior to Helen’s admission she lived alone in her own home in Salisbury.
She was on Job Seeker and did 15 hours of volunteer work per week.
Currently she is unsure if she will return to her home, and she is considering her options regarding a retirement village.

RE:	HELEN MURPHY		DOB:	20/02/1959		UR:	8111330

														

														

														

														Symptomatically Helen's main symptom is ongoing lethargy needing frequent rests throughout the day.
She does complain of postural dizziness when she stands quickly which occurs a few times per week.
She has no PND or orthopnoea.
She sleeps on two pillows.
She's had no chest pain, or symptoms similar to her initial admission.
She reports NYHA class II symptoms.
Her appetite is good however is less than prior to her myocardial infarction.
She has been checking her blood glucose levels regularly which are averaging between 5 and 7.
Her weight has been stable on her home scales at 87.9k, which is about 4kg lighter than when she left hospital.
Helen has had a physiotherapy review from the Chronic Diseases home visiting team, and they have provided her with regular home exercises.
Helen has been doing these for about 10 minutes per day most days of the week and she has been managing these quite well.
Her most recent echocardiogram on the 11th January 2023 showed moderately dilated LV with severe segmental systolic dysfunction.
RWMA, mildly dilated RV with low-normal systolic function.
Mild MR and raised pulmonary pressures, RVSP 55 mmHg.

Medications

														Warfarin (QML program) currently 2mg daily, next INR 27/1/23, Aspirin 100mg mane, Cholecalciferol 25mcg mane, Pantoprazole 40mg mane, Paroxetine 20mg x 3 tabs mane, Sitagliptin 25mg mane, Gliclazide 120mg mane, Dapagliflozin 10mg mane, Spironolactone 25mg mane, Frusemide 80mg mane + 40mg lunch, Ramipril 1.25mg BD, Bisoprolol 5mg nocte, Atorvastatin 80mg nocte, Coloxyl and sena 2 tabs BD, Miconazole cream daily, FEES nasal spray PRN.
Blood test completed today 20th January 2023 show Na 143, K+ 3.5, urea 7.6, creat 104, eGFR 49.
These are attached for your records.
On examination her blood pressure was 96/60mmHg sitting and 98/60mmHg standing, heart rate 68bpm and regular.
She had no peripheral oedema.
Heart sounds were dual, and her JVP was negative at 3cm.
Her lungs were clear.
Today Helen is euvolaemic, given her potassium levels remain low despite being on Spironolactone I have commenced her on Span K 600mg tablets one tablet BD.
I have also asked her to reduce her Frusemide to 80mg mane.
Helen can restart the lunchtime Frusemide 40mg if she notices any increase in weight, oedema or symptoms of heart failure.
I have asked her to see you in one weeks time for a fluid status review and repeat her renal function and potassium levels.
The aim for her potassium level is above 4.0, please titrate the dose accordingly.
I will see her back in this clinic in mid-February to continue to titrate her heart failure therapy.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Pleml,





RE:	JOHN H. MURRAY		DOB:	06/08/1940	UR:	158930

							



														I invited John for review today because the manufacturer of his pacemaker generator has issued a hazard alert.
This involves a 1 out of 600 risk of sudden failure of the device.
Since John is dependent on his pacemaker, this is a very relevant issue for him.
We discussed elective replacement of the pacemaker pulse generator for peace of mind, but with risks of a further procedure, including up to 2% risk of infection and significant risk of bleeding.
I remember John well from his last pacemaker procedure here.
At the time of generator replacement, lead fracture occurred at the junction with the pacemaker header requiring immediate insertion of a new lead.
For several days afterwards he had significant ongoing blood ooze from the superficial part of his wound, requiring him to be hospitalised for that time.
Subsequent surveillance was satisfactory over a period of a couple of months.
I understand that he is participating in the FINEARTS trial at the RBWH.
He has had significant shortness of breath on exertion associated with diastolic left ventricular impairment to which atrial fibrillation may have contributed.
Fortunately, his atrial fibrillation has remitted, since persistent left atrial appendage thrombus has prevented safe cardioversion attempts.
John has anginal discomfort at his upper sternum and throat, which is rather unpredictable and usually occurs at rest these days.
His described pattern of exertional dyspnoea suggests that there is an element of chronotropic incompetence.
Accordingly, I have increased very slightly the rate response of his pacemaker system today.
I have invited him to our Device Timing Clinic for echocardiographic optimisation of pacemaker timing cycles in order to optimise left ventricular filling.
I will report further thereafter.
Today his blood pressure was 120/75mmHg sitting, with no abnormal cardiac signs.
He does report postural dizziness.
Amiodarone may be contributing to this as well as to his vivid dreams.
In frequently he can develop orthopnoea.

I have suggested that he should take his 20mg of Telmisartan at night instead of in the morning and to split his dosage of Frusemide to 20mg in the morning plus a further 20mg at about 4pm in the afternoon.
John is not sure whether he has had a recent thyroid function test.
Thyroid and liver function tests should be performed each 6 months with continuing Amiodarone therapy.
I would be grateful if you would ensure that this will occur.
John will bring this to  your attention.

RE:	JOHN H. MURRAY		DOB:	06/08/1940	UR:	158930

														

														Mr Murray has decided that he does not want to worry about his pacemaker failing and is prepared to take the risk of elective replacement of the pulse generator.
I will make the necessary arrangements for him, and he will be contacted next by our pre-admission clinic in the week prior to the procedure.
Should he develop syncope before this, he should obviously  proceed immediately to hospital.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Murray,





														RE:	COLEEN NAYLOR		DOB:	28/09/1936		UR:	707105

																					

														

														

														Diagnoses:

														Coronary artery disease.
Coronary artery bypass surgery in 2011.
Out of hospital cardiac arrest with anterior STEMI April 2021.
Managed medically given patients age and comorbidities.
LV ejection fraction of 40% with aneurysmal apex.
Chronic atrial fibrillation.
Peripheral vascular disease.
Stage 4 kidney disease secondary to hypertension.
History of left leg DVT is December 2021.
History of myasthenia gravis.
History of GI bleed.
Clopidogrel was ceased and Rivaroxaban was changed to Apixaban.

Medications:

														Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Imdur, Clopidogrel 75mg, Lasix 40mg Amitriptyline 10mg, Somac 40mg, Crestor 10mg, Nitrazepam 2.5mg, GTN spray.
I caught up with Coleen Naylor in my cardiology outpatient clinic today.
She is a delightful 86-year-old lady with multiple comorbidities as outlined above.
She has been doing reasonably well since her discharge from Redland Hospital.
She had presented to the Redland Hospital on 20.09.2022 with recurrent falls and feelings of presyncope.
It was thought that her presyncope was likely postural hypotension related.
She was discharged after physiotherapy assessment.
It was thought that her presyncopal episode was likely vasovagal secondary to dehydration and heat.
Since her discharge in September, she has been doing reasonably well.
She has regular follow up with Renal OPD as well as Neurology Team.
Her DOAC for her atrial fibrillation was ceased, because of GI bleed and rash.
She is tolerating her Clopidogrel reasonably well.
There has been no recent increase in angina frequency.
On  examination today she appeared euvolaemic, her blood pressure is 120/80mmHg,  her resting heart rate was 70bpm regular.
Given she is doing reasonably well, I have not made any changes to her medications.
If she gets increased frequency of angina, I suggest cautiously increasing her Imdur from 30mg to 60mg.
I plan to catch up with her again in 6 months.
If you have any concerns in the interim, please do not hesitate to contact me.

Yours sincerely,

														It was a pleasure to review Danut in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know he is a 60-year-old gentleman.

Background:

														Atrial fibrillation.
Rate control strategy due to patient preference.
Declined anticoagulation.
Hypertension.
Renal transplant 1996 for IgA nephropathy.

Danut’s current medications from a cardiac point of view include Aspirin 100mg, Metoprolol 50mg mane and 75mg nocte (dose increased today), Perindopril 5mg, Atorvastatin 10mg, Tacrolimus, Prednisolone, Azathioprine and Bactrim.
Danut felt well off the Flecainide.
He continues to be tired during the day.
He only gets palpitations when he lays down at night and his heart rate is generally under 100bpm when he measures it at home.
Today ECG showed him to be in AF at 112bpm.
A recent echocardiogram showed a mildly dilated LV with an EF of about 50%, a mildly dilated RV with mildly reduced systolic function and mild AR.
We are going to try and increase Danut’s nocte Metoprolol to 75mg to try and get on top of his palpitations.
He was reluctant to increase the morning dose any further, as he feels it contributes to his fatigue.
I will review him in one year with an echocardiogram but I am happy to be contacted in the interim with any new issues or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Mollee,





														RE:	JOHN NEVE		DOB:	13/06/1944		UR:	2231588

																					

														

														

														Past Medical History:
# AL Amyloidosis
   - diagnosed 2019
   - Stage 3A cardiac involvement (Mayo 2004)
     -- Associated with macroglossia and gastrointestinal system involvement
   - Haematologic relapse February 2022.

-- Initial complete haematologic response following VCD chemotherapy x 9 cycles 

														        (April to December 2019)
        --- Cardiac involvement: NTproBNP 3240pmol/L (Dec 2022), TnI 84ng/L 

														             (13/1/23); echo c/w cardiac amyloidosis (report pending)
     -- Brief haematologic VGPR with Melphalan and Dexamethasone x 5 cycles, but 

														        early biochemical progression July 2022
        --- Haematologic VGPR with Pomalidomide, Dexamethasone and Isatuximab 

														            (ALLG MM24 trial) October 2022 to present
   - known to Dr. Mollee in PPC
# LV dysfunction
   - NYHA II
   - LVEF 29% (Sept 2022)

Cardiac Medications:
amiodarone 100mg mane, frusemide 80mg mane, aspirin 100mg daily


														I had the pleasure of reviewing John Neve today in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic, accompanied by his wife.
Thank you for referring him for shared care from the perspective of his AL amyloidosis with cardiac involvement.
Thank you for detailing John’s extensive history and battle with AL amyloidosis.
He continues with you in the ALLG MM24 trial with Pomalidomide, Dexamethasone and Isatuximab.

Unfortunately, a recent transthoracic echocardiogram performed in September last year showed a moderately dilated left ventricle with severe global systolic dysfunction and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 29%.
There was also impaired right ventricular systolic function, moderate mitral regurgitation and an elevated estimated RVSP of 50mmHg.
Furthermore, a Holter monitor in September last year showed multiple sustained ventricular arrhythmias with frequent ventricular ectopic beats (11.1%) predominantly multifocal.
Non-sustained ventricular tachycardia was seen in multiple episodes and was thought to be polymorphic.
In discussion with John today, he tells me that he has had no chest discomfort with or without exertion.
He denies any further palpitations since starting Amiodarone and so far, denies any adverse drug reaction to Amiodarone.
He reports rare shortness of breath, usually when going up hill and climbing stairs.
He generally avoids those circumstances but is able to climb a full flight of stairs before needing to stop the catch his breath.
On flat ground, however, he tells me that he can walk unlimited from a cardiopulmonary perspective, being limited by musculoskeletal concerns.
He denies any orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea.
On examination today, John weight 76 kilograms fully clothed.
His home scale this morning showed his weight to be 74.4 kilograms.
His blood pressure was 100/60mmHg and his heart rate was 64bpm and regular.
This corresponded with an ECG in sinus rhythm.
His chest was clear, and his heart sounds were dual with no murmur.
His jugular venous pressure was 0cm.
He had mild pitting oedema to the proximal 3rd of his shins bilaterally.
With respect to blood pressure, John tells me that his average blood pressure on his home monitor is approximately 105mmHg systolic.

When his blood pressure decreases to approximately 80 to 90mmHg, which he has noticed has happened during the last few administrations of chemotherapy, he feels a great sense of general malaise, mental fog, dizziness when standing and low energy.
His ECG in clinic today, showed sinus rhythm with a pseudo infarct pattern consistent with amyloidosis (Q-waves in II, III, aVF, V1 – 3) and low amplitude QRS complexes.
His QTc was 462ms.
The most recent pathology tests that are available for review today were from approximately 1 week ago.
His haemoglobin was 102, white cell count of 621, platelet count of 280.
His sodium was 142, potassium 4.6, creatinine 163, and eGFR of 34ml/min/1.73m².
I note that his renal function has decreased from an eGFR of 52 in October last to 34 in a matter of 3 months.

Given that John is euvolaemic today, and his most recent urea being within reference limits (7.0mmol/L) I believe this to be likely secondary to renal deposition from amyloidosis and not from over diuresis.
John was seen today by Dr Korczyk in clinic.
We have asked him to continue his current Frusemide dose and to continue monitoring his weight every morning.
Should his weight increase to above 76 kilograms on his home scale, I have asked him to see his GP for a fluid assessment before increasing his Frusemide further.

We will arrange for a repeat Holter monitor to assess his ectopic burden after starting Amiodarone, as well as arrange a transthoracic echocardiogram to be performed sometime in March with cardio oncology protocol.
We will also ask John to have cardiac biomarkers performed around March as well and I have provided him with a pathology request form to that end.
We will aim to review John in June after the results of aforementioned tests are available.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Neve.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Ho,





RE:	MICHAL NEWIE		DOB:	09/04/1987		UR:	8048223

							



														

														It was a pleasure to review Michal via phone consultation today.
She is a 35-year-old lady who was admitted here in November with schizophrenia.
During titration of her Clozapine, she developed Clozapine induced myocarditis with an associated modest troponin rise.
Her LV function was preserved.
A cardiac MRI confirmed features consistent with myocarditis.
She was monitored for 48 hours with no arrhythmia.
She did experience some mild chest discomfort associated with the episode.
Clozapine was withheld, her troponin normalised and a repeat echocardiogram performed on 03.01.2023 shows normal left and right ventricular size and function.
Michal has been feeling well with no cardiac symptoms.
In summary, Michal had Clozapine induced myocarditis which has resolved, and she has normal left ventricular function.
She should avoid Clozapine in the future.
I am happy for her to proceed with any surgery required and she does not require any specific cardiology follow up at this time.
Please feel free to contact me in the future with any issues or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Du Plooy,





														RE:	BARRY NEWMAN		DOB:	05/07/1940		UR:	802719

																					

														

														

														Thank you very much for your referral.

Diagnoses:

														Atrial fibrillation with tachy brady syndrome.
Symptomatic.
For pacemaker implant.

Current Medications:

														Xarelto 15mg daily, Crestor 10mg daily, Perindopril.
It was a pleasure to review Barry in the cardiology arrhythmia clinic.
He presented along with his son.
He is an 83-year-old gentleman who has had atrial fibrillation for many years.
It has been paroxysmal in the past.
He has not tolerated AV nodal agents previously with significant and symptomatic bradycardia in sinus rhythm.
Currently, he has been complaining of symptomatic atrial fibrillation for a few months.
He complains of presyncope, shortness of breath, decreased exercise tolerance.
He has not been feeling well in the last 3 days.
He has had a few presentations to the Redland Hospital.
On examination today, he had no signs of heart failure except for mild peripheral oedema.
His JVP was not elevated.
ECG showed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate, heart rate of 140bpm.
I understand he has had a Holter monitor which had shown nocturnal 2.8 second pauses but he had very  uncontrolled ventricular rates.
I have discussed with Barry the need for a permanent pacemaker to be able to have antiarrhythmics, AV nodal blocking agents.
The procedure was discussed in detail with him.
Written information has been provided.
Barry is very keen to have this as he has not been feeling very well.
I will organise this for him at the PA Hospital.
I have warned him in the meanwhile, if he starts having recurrent presyncopal episodes, or a syncopal episode or signs of heart failure, to present to the hospital.
We may have to implant it as an inpatient.
I would also appreciate it if you could organise an echocardiogram for him at the Redland Hospital.

Yours sincerely, 

														

Electronically Signed On:25-Jan-2023 11:23

														

														Dr Waheed Ahmad

														Consultant Cardiologist & Cardiac Electrophysiologist

														Princess Alexandra Hospital

														

														CC:	Dr W Baig Thornlands Surgery 3 Cleveland – Redland Bay Road THORNLANDS

														QLD 4164

														



PS : Thank you organising Echo.
His LV function is not normal.
It could be AF related but probably needs coronary assessment.
It does not change my plan for PPM implant, rather important that he can have Beta-blockers safely.
I am going to try put a left bundle pacemaker to avoid further LV dysfunction by RV only pacing.
I will put him on amiodarone post PPM implant & Bicor with a view to DCCV to be organized at RLH & repeat echo post DCCV.
If his EF remains low post achieving sinus rhythm, then I will ask you to organise coronary assessment.

														RE:	HARRY  NGAIRA		DOB:	03/01/1952		UR:	2233491

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Harry, a 70 year old New Zealand citizen who became known to the PA Hospital Cardiology Department after he presented to hospital with a non-STEMI in October 2022.
He underwent a CABG performed by Dr Ura (LIMA to LAD, SVG to PDA, SVG to OM), without any intraoperative complications.
His post operative care was complicated by a mild COVID infection along with infections of his sternal wound and right leg vein graft wound.
His echocardiogram at the time showed a preserved ejection fraction of 65% with possible LVOT flow acceleration without any obstruction at rest or with Valsalva.
He had no significant valvular disease either.
Harry’s other medication issues include type II diabetes on NovoMix (HbA1c 7.8%), dyslipidaemia (LDL 1.9), hypertension, obesity, gout and previous hepatitis B.
He is a Truck Driver in New Zealand, who is a never smoker and does not drink any alcohol.
He has an upcoming court case, for which he is planning on returning to New Zealand within the next week.
Apart from social stresses, Harry has been reasonably well.
He has had no cardiac symptoms, such as syncope, chest pain, shortness of breath, and neither does he describe any orthopnoea or leg swelling.
His blood pressure recently has been poorly controlled and on examination today this was 170/90mmHg.
His right leg vein graft site had areas of chronic non-healing margins distally, however, there was no evidence of infection.
His sternal wound looked unremarkable.
His chest had scant left base crackles and his heart sounds were dual with a systolic murmur.
I note that when Harry was discharged after his bypass, he was sent home on Metformin, Pantoprazole 12.5mg, Noten 80mg, Atorvastatin, Aspirin, Allopurinol, along with his Insulin.
Multiple antihypertensives were withheld, which included an ACE inhibitor, Tamsulosin, Amlodipine and Empagliflozin.
My impression today is that Harry is stable from a post CABG perspective, however, has poorly controlled blood pressure.

Our recommendations are:

														Recommence Empagliflozin 10mg and Amlodipine.
Discharge from Dr Ahmad’s Cardiology Clinic.
Once Harry returns to New Zealand, he needs to be referred to a Cardiologist for ongoing follow up and repeat echocardiogram.

I have explained to Harry that he needs to check with his doctor in New Zealand regarding the commercial driving restrictions post bypass and he should be cleared by a medical officer before returning to truck driving.
Thank you for your ongoing care and please do not hesitate in contacting us should you require any further information about Harry’s care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Truong,





RE:	VAN GIAU NGUYEN		DOB:	25/05/1968		UR:	121864

							



														

														I saw Mr Nguyen in my clinic for follow up today.
As you know, his background is significant for ischaemic heart disease with multiple previous PCI and eventual CABG following NSTEMI in 2022 (LIMA to LAD, SVG to PDA).
He is known to have significant residual disease in his distal LCX (for trial of medical therapy) and D1 (small calibre vessel that is not suitable for revascularisation).
Other background history includes type I bicuspid aortic valve (fused LCC and RCC) with mild regurgitation, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, GORD, HBV infection, and he is an ex-smoker.
Since his CABG surgery, Mr Nguyen has been well and denies any cardiac symptoms or postural light headedness.
His current medications include Aspirin 100mg daily, Metoprolol 12.5mg BD, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, and Tenofovir 300mg daily.
He has no allergies.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 80bpm regular and his blood pressure was 140/90mmHg.

His previous echocardiogram before surgery showed normal left ventricular size with mild segmental systolic dysfunction (LVEF 49%), bicuspid aortic valve with mild regurgitation, and mildly dilated aortic root and ascending aorta (SoV 4.0cm, ascending aorta 4.2cm).
Today, I have changed the Metoprolol to Atenolol 12.5mg daily for the convenience of once daily dosing.
I have also added Candesartan 4mg daily for prognostic reasons.
Finally, I have given him a pathology request form to check his fasting LDL cholesterol again.
If  it is >1.8mmol/L, can you please start him on Ezetimibe 10mg daily?
I will see Mr Nguyen again in 6 months for follow up.
Long term, he will require a yearly echocardiogram to keep an eye on his bicuspid aortic valve and dilated ascending aorta.
Thank you for looking after Mr Nguyen.

Yours sincerely,

His echocardiogram normal LV size with moderate segmental systolic dysfunction, EF 35%.
He has a history of T2DM at the end of December his HbA1c was 8.4%, HTN, Dyslipidaemia, and is an ex-smoker (ceased 12 months ago).
Jason is a forklift driver, and he is currently not working.
He is awaiting an echocardiogram and a chart review by Dr Singbal this Wednesday.
Jason feels well since discharge.
He denies any chest pain.
He describes class I NYHA symptoms and denies any orthopnoea, PND, dizziness or light headedness.
He is currently attended our cardiac rehabilitation program here at the Princess Alexandra Hospital.

Medications

														Aspirin 100mg mane, Ticagrelor 90mg BD, Bisoprolol increased today to 2.5mg mane, Eplerenone 12.5mg mane, Empagliflozin 10mg mane, Rosuvastatin 40mg mane, Ezetimibe 10mg mane, Entresto 24/26mg BD, GTN sublingual PRN, Insulin 14 us nocte, Vildagliptin/Metformin 50/1000mg BD.

Na 139, K+ 4.2, Urea 7.8, Creat 78 and eGFR >90.

Lipid profile was very good with total cholesterol 2.3, triglycerides 1.5, HDL 1.1 and LDL 0.5.

Today I have increased the Bisoprolol to 2.5mg daily.
I will see him back in this clinic in four weeks for ongoing titration.

Dear Dr Duraiswamy,





														RE:	GREGORY J NUNN		DOB:	28/06/1962	UR:	334932

																					

														

														

														Diagnoses:

														Morbid obesity, current weight 131 kilograms.
Hypertension.
Negative myocardial perfusion scan for inducible ischaemia in 2019.
History of depression and post-traumatic stress disorder.
Impaired fasting glucose.
History of diverticulitis in the past.

Medications:

														Endep 50mg, Cialis PRN, Lyrica 150mg BD, Micardis 40mg daily, Panadeine Forte.

Investigations:

														HbA1c 4.4%, eGFR >90, total cholesterol 4.0mmol/L, haemoglobin 137gm/L.
Thank you very much for referring Gregory Nunn to my Cardiology Clinic.
He is a delightful 60-year-old gentleman who works for a Bus Driver for Brisbane City Council.
He has been experiencing on and off atypical left sided chest pain that are not related to exertion.
These chest pain only last for a few seconds.
He denied any excessive breathlessness with exercise, although he does have dyspnoea related to his weight.
He denied any symptoms suggestive congestive cardiac failure.
He does get occasional mild dependent oedema in his feet.
He denied any syncope or presyncope and denied any palpitations.
As far as his background is concerned, he is an ex-smoker.
He quit smoking approximately 10 o 12 years ago.
He has a history of hypertension but denied any  history of diabetes.
His total cholesterol is borderline.
He does have a family history of coronary disease, with his father having an MI in his 50s, and subsequently requiring coronary artery bypass surgery.
On examination today  he was comfortable at rest, his chest was clear, heart sounds were dual, JVP was not elevated, his blood pressure is 120/80mmHg.
His ECG today showed normal sinus rhythm, normal axis.
There is no significant ST – T-wave changes.
His corrected QT is 430ms, his resting heart rate was 68bpm.

Impression:

														Gregory Nunn is a 60-year-old Bus Driver who has been experiencing atypical chest pain and a background and risk factors of hypertension, prior history of smoking and family history of coronary disease.
He currently weighs approximately 130 kilograms.
He has previously undergone a myocardial perfusion scan in 2019, which did not reveal anything significant.
Given his symptoms, his risk factor profile and his profession, it is reasonable to perform more definitely testing.
Therefore, I am referring him for CT coronary angiogram, which will be performed at the PA Hospital.
He will also undergo a transthoracic echocardiogram.
I have advised him to continue to indulge in a healthy lifestyle and attempt to lose weight.
He previously used to drink excessive alcohol but has now significant cut down and only drinks occasionally during the week.
He has been using Nicotine spray intermittent and I have advised him to cease that.
I plan to catch up with him again in 4 months.
He is aware, that if he gets prolonged chest pain, he will seek medical assistance.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Barry,





														RE:	GARY O'CONNOR		DOB:	18/05/1965		UR:	8096404

																					

														

														

														Issues:

														Severe sinus venosus ASD and partial anomalous pulmonary venous drainage with severe RV dilatation.
Atrial flutter.
Previous DC cardioversion.
I spoke to Gary via telephone today in Dr Ahmad’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
He initially came to our attention after an episode of atrial flutter and subsequently had an outpatient CTCA which ended up finding anomalous pulmonary venous drainage and sinus venosus ASD.

After this was found, he was referred to our colleague Dr Valencia at the Mater Hospital and I understand there have been a few further reviews with her as well as procedures including a right heart cath.
Gary tells me that he has been referred to TPCH for consideration of surgical fixture given the significant RV dilatation.
Symptoms wise, he does not report any new concerning symptoms, including no palpitations, chest pain or change in his shortness of breath.

As he is following up with Dr Valencia and TPCH in regard to management of the atrial septal defect and anomalous drainage, we will not schedule him for further appointments with us unless there is an additional concern.

Should he require assistance in terms of management of his flutter, or you would like him to seen at the PA Hospital again, please let us know, otherwise we will wait to be referred from either yourself or Dr Valencia if we can assist any other capacity.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Caleb,





RE:	DONNA O'KEEFE		DOB:	07/05/1969		UR:	8069682

							



														Cardiovascular Diagnosis:

														Ischaemic heart disease with ischaemic cardiomyopathy.
Late presentation anterior myocardial infarction February 2020 with occluded mid LAD and mature chronic total occlusion to right coronary artery.
LVEF 38% on CMRI with no significant LAD territory viability demonstrated.
TTE on 03.02.2022: LVEF 40-45% with elevated right sided pressure in the setting of sepsis and acute illness.
Previous left ventricular apical thrombus treated with warfarin.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														  Ex-smoker.
Type 1 diabetes mellitus with recurrent HbA1c greater than 10%.
Dyslipidaemia.
Family history of atherosclerotic vascular disease.

Other Conditions:

														Chronic kidney disease.
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
Multiple medication sensitivities preventing adherence.
Previous renal haematoma while on warfarin.
Previous blood stream infection with Staph aureus.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Bumetanide 2mg mane and 1mg midday.
I reviewed Donna O’Keefe today via telehealth link.
Things are stable.
Donna has had no  palpitations, no syncope, no angina and no episodes of cardiac decompensation.
Donna is being planned for a fistular for her progressive renal dysfunction.
Donna and husband are planning on selling her home and becoming permanent nomadic caravan-based retirees.
Donna has asked that we communicate appointments and other hospital communications via email with her.
Her email address is dunna_runna@outlook.com.
Her blood pressure today is 128/88mmHg, heart rate is 70bpm, saturations are 94% on room air.
Her 12 Lead ECG shows sinus rhythm with reduced precordial R-wave progression.
Donna had tried on several occasions to up titrate her Bisoprolol to higher than 2.5mg daily but had not been able to tolerate this and was not able to tolerate even 3.75mg daily.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Continue medical therapy as listed above including Bisoprolol 2.5mg once daily.

If pharmacotherapy required for blood pressure control, consider introduction of dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (so long as Donna  has not had an adverse reaction to this previously and if this is not tolerated or there is previous intolerance of dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers documented, then consider introduction of Hydralazine 25mg twice daily  or Prazosin 0.5mg twice daily if hypertension becomes a recurrent issue.
Repeat cardiology review in 6 months.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Murray,





RE:	FRANCIS O'NEILL		DOB:	09/04/1948		UR:	899132

							





This is a short note to inform you that I caught up with Francis in my Cardiology Clinic today.
Since he was last in the clinic, he underwent a CT coronary angiogram which showed severe native coronary disease in the left main and LAD.
His LIMA to LAD and RIMA to D1 grafts were patent.
SVT to RCA graft was occluded at the ostium.
Distal disease in the right coronary artery where stenosis could not be excluded.
Francis has not been getting any exertional chest pain, in fact on his exercise stress echocardiogram there was no inducible ischaemia or chest pain with exercise.
He does however get intermittent rest chest pain.
He was noted to have large hiatus hernia on his CT scan.
I wonder if there is an element of gastroesophageal reflux disease.
Keeping that in mind, I have given him a script for Esomeprazole 20mg.
His blood pressure was also elevated today at 140/80mmHg.
If his blood pressure is persistently elevated, I would suggest changing his Ramipril  to a combination of Ramipril  plus Thiazide.
He may also need upper GI endoscopy if his symptoms failure to resolve with PPI.
I have also informed him that if he gets exertional chest pain, to get in touch with us.
I plan to catch up with him again in 6 months to follow up on his progress.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

Atrial fibrillation.
Ischaemic heart disease.
Non-STEMI 2005.
CABG 2006 (LIMA to LAD, SVG to RCA).

LVEF ~45% November 2022 with moderate MR and TR and  impaired RV function.

Dear Dr Woolward,





														RE:	ADEWALE OGUNYEMI	DOB:	09/06/1982	UR:	8097882

																					

														

														

														I had the pleasure of catching up with Adewale in Dr Wang’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you may recall he is a 40-year-old man who presented to the PA Hospital for atypical chest pain in May of 2022.

Problems:

														Chest pain for investigation.
CTCA 18.05.2022 demonstrates a coronary artery calcium score of 0 and no coronary artery stenosis.
Patient described sharp non-limiting left sided chest pain at peak exercise.
No diagnostic ischaemic ECG changes.
Isolated VEWs with no other significant arrhythmias.
No obvious inducible regional wall motion abnormalities at peak stress (111% <{JR’ 12:58 mins; 15.1METs).
Echocardiogram 17.05.2022 demonstrates a normal left ventricular sizes and systolic function.
LVEF 605 by Simpson’s method.
Normal right ventricular size and systolic function.
No significant functional valvular abnormality.

Cardiac Risk Factors:

														Hypertension.
Family history of premature CAD – Mother at 61 years of age.
Dyslipidaemia.

LDL 3.8, HDL 5.1 (May 2022)

														Diabetes.
In brief summary Adewale presented with some sharp right sided chest pain.
During his admission in May of 2022, he had an echocardiogram that was essentially normal with no significant regional wall motion abnormalities and normal left ventricular function.
During his inpatient stay, he also had a CT coronary angiogram that demonstrated a coronary artery calcium score of 0 and no coronary artery stenosis.
He was subsequently discharged with a plan to have an exercise stress echocardiogram which was performed in July of 2022.
His stress echocardiogram was unremarkable with no obvious inducible regional wall motion abnormalities and a peak stress of 15.1METs.
Given his cardiac risk factors of hypertension and a family history of  premature coronary artery disease and mild dyslipidaemia, I have made the decision to start him on Rosuvastatin 20mg daily.
In addition, he showed me his blood pressure diary that showed blood pressures ranging from 120 to 140mmHg.
Today his blood pressure was 138/90mmHg and he was euvolaemic with dual heart sounds and no murmurs.
I have started him on 1.25mg of Ramipril  daily.
I would appreciate it if you could monitor his cholesterol levels and blood pressure and treat accordingly.
We will discharge him from our clinic; however, we are more than happy to see him again should the need arise.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Efimoff,





														RE:	WENDY ON		DOB:	08/11/1956		UR:	745742

																					

														

														Past Medical History:
# ?

ASD/PFO 
    - Syncope in 1997, investigated at PAH and was informed of ?hole in the heart
    - TOE (20/7/22): PFO present, no ASD; some redundant septal tissue

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Wendy On in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
She is known to this clinic for investigation of the potential hole in the heart that was previously mentioned to her during routine investigation of syncope in 1997.
Both a transthoracic and transoesophageal echocardiogram was performed, which ultimately found a patent foramen ovale, but no atrial septal defect.
There was also some redundant septal tissue seen on the transthoracic echocardiogram.
In discussion with Wendy today, she tells me that she has been asymptomatic from a cardiac perspective.
I review her current condition with in Cantonese and explained the investigation findings to her for her better understanding.
I told her that at present, there is no indication to intervene upon the patient foramen ovale.
However, should she experience any complication, such as a potential stroke, this can be revisited at that time.
However, the occurrence of a PFO is relatively common in the community and most do not result in a cerebella vascular accident.
On examination, Wendy appeared well and in good spirits.
Her blood pressure today was 110/70mmHg and her heart rate was 78bpm and regular.
Her chest was clear, and her heart sounds were dual with no murmur.
There was no peripheral oedema.
In discussion with Dr Cox, who has reviewed the TTE and TOE images, I have reassured Wendy, as mentioned above.
If new cardiac concerns were to arise in the future, please re-refer her to us for further consideration, but in the meantime, we will discharge her from our clinic.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mrs On.

Yours sincerely,

RE:	PAUL ORMSBY		DOB:	15/11/1950		UR:	968021

							



														Paul returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
He tolerated the increase in the Entresto without any concerns.
Symptomatically he had no PND or orthopnoea.
He is sleeping on 2 pillows.
He reports NYHA II symptoms with no dizziness or chest pain.
He does complain of ongoing lethargy which has been a long term problem for him.
Paul had been quite active in the past however he has struggled to maintain any regular physical exercise.
We have talked about the importance of physical exercise, and he is keen to restart this.
I discussed attending our exercise program here at the Princess Alexandra Hospital however it is too far of drive for him.
He is interested in attending the Logan program.

Medications

														Aspirin 100mg nocte, Entresto 24/26mg mane and 49/51mg nocte (increased to 46/51mg BD today), Seretide 1 puff BD, Spiriva 1 inhaler mane, Spironolactone 12.5mg nocte, Lipitor 40mg nocte, Somac 40mg nocte, Bicor 5mg mane, Tramadol PRN, Panadol PRN.
Thank you for arranging a blood test after the increase in the Entresto on the 18th January 2023 with Sullivan and Nicolaides.
These show a stable renal function with Na 135, K+ 4.5, urea 9.1, creat 95, and eGFR 69.
On examination his blood pressure was 110/60mmHg sitting and 112/60mmHg standing, heart rate 56bpm and regular.
He had no peripheral oedema, and his lungs were clear.
Today I have discussed with Paul the logistics of getting to the clinic here, as well as our heart failure gym.
It is Paul’s preference that he be referred to the Logan Heart Failure service including the Nurse Practitioner for ongoing medication titration and potentially attending their gym program as well.

RE:	PAUL ORMSBY		DOB:	15/11/1950		UR:	968021

														

														

														

														Today I have increased the Entresto today to 49/51mg BD and asked him to see you in two weeks for a repeat blood pressure check and a Chem20.
At this time, I would appreciate it if you could check Paul’s iron levels as patients with heart failure can also be iron deficient which might be contributing to his lethargy.
If Paul is iron deficient with a ferritin of under 100 or ferritin 100-300 with saturations under 20, an iron infusion would be indicated.
I will ask the Logan Heart Failure Service to catch up with him in the coming weeks.
I will discharge him from this clinic.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Conaghan,





														RE:	WADE PALMBLAD		DOB:	27/01/1989		UR:	2184833

																					

														

														

														Past Medical History:
# Patent Foramen Ovale
   - closed percutaneously on 4/5/22
   - complicated by stroke (diagnosed on MRI)
# ?AF
   - reportedly captured by Apple watch
   - thought to be secondary to LA irritant - i.e.

PFO closure device
   - for 6 months of surveillance while taking DOAC

Medications:
Rivaroxaban 20mg daily, Paroxetine 20mg daily, Mesalazine 2.4g daily

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Wade Palmblad in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
This is a routine clinic appointment after closure of his patent foramen ovale in May last year.
Since discharge from hospital, he notified our team about the possibility of atrial fibrillation being captured by his Apple watch.
This was associated with chest discomfort and palpitations.
Dr Ahmad (Electrophysiologist) and Dr Cox had discussed the situation and had advised Wade to change his regular Aspirin to Rivaroxaban 20mg daily, which he continues to this day.
It was thought that the atrial fibrillation was likely due to left atrial irritation from the recently implanted patent foramen ovale closure device.
Since starting Rivaroxaban, Wade noticed no further palpitations, nor has his Apple watch notified him of any further episodes of possible atrial fibrillation.

As such, I have asked Wade to continue his Rivaroxaban until completing 6 months of anticoagulation and should he experience no further symptoms of atrial fibrillation or receive any notifications of an event, to then change from Rivaroxaban to regular Aspirin 300mg daily, which he needs to continue until 04.05.2023 completing 1 year at the higher dose.
Thereafter, he can change to Aspirin 100mg daily, which he needs to continue lifelong.
Should atrial fibrillation be once again detected in future, I would ask that you please verify this diagnosis as per the usual diagnostic pathway and treat according to guidelines.
Interestingly, Wade also commented that he no longer experiences the migraines after closure of the PFO.
This was a possible additional benefit of PFO closure but was not guaranteed.
Wade had also had a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram today, which has not yet been formally reported.
However, on review of the preliminary images, no colour flow across the septum was seen, even though there was a mildly positive bubble study.
In discussion with Dr Cox, no further action is required.
Given Wade’s stable progress since discharge from hospital, we will discharge him from clinic at this time.
Should there be any concerns about the PFO closure device, please re-refer him to us for further review.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Palmblad.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Comino,





RE:	JOHN PAPANTONIOU	DOB:	24/12/1960	UR:	2196284

							



														

														I caught up with this 62-year-old gentleman in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.

Issues:
1.

Stable CAD; CAC 321 (83rd centile); QScan 8.4.2022
    a. LMCA 0; LAD 10; LCx 200; RCA 111
    b. ESE 3.5.2022 – Normal LV size and LVEF 55%; Normal RV; No significant valvular abnormalities; 9:01mins; 10.2METs; Clinically, electrically and echocardiographically negative ESE for obvious inducible ischemia at a target HR response and good workload (107% MPHR)

Background:
1.

Hypertension; ?Using Minipress for BP
2.

G6PD deficiency - Dx 1979 (GP letter states Thalassemia Minor (1960) – Patient

														    states this is incorrect)
3.

Anxiety; Depression
4.

BPH
5.

Father - Cardiac arrhythmia (?AF) and CVA
6.

ADR: Sulfur – Haematuria; Tamsulosin – Haematuria; Zoloft – Diarrhoea; Aspirin   

														    – Skin rashes/Hives; Rosuvastatin - ?Fatigue
7.

Essentially non-smoker; EtOH - Nil regular
8.

Lives with wife; No kids; Works as contractor for Telstra

Medications:
Efexor 37.5mg 1 alternate days
Efexor 75mg 1 alternate days
Minipress 2mg nocte
Perindopril 2mg od

														

														As you recall he got quite fatigued when I started him on Perindopril 2mg and Crestor 20mg.
He also told me that his serum ferritin on some bloods done subsequently were quite elevated (they were elevated prior), but his liver function tests were not deranged.
I am not sure if the statins contributed to this.
He was happy to retrial the Perindopril and he is now tolerating this.
He has no cardiac symptoms.
On examination his blood pressure was 120/70mmHg, his  heart rate is 84bpm and regular and his chest is clear.

RE:	JOHN PAPANTONIOU	DOB:	24/12/1960	UR:	2196284

														

														Assessment:

														His exercise stress echocardiogram is negative for ischaemia, which is reassuring, however, he does have coronary artery disease present on the basis of his coronary artery calcium score.
What he needs is aggressive risk factor control to prevent acute myocardial infarction in the future.

Plan:

														He should continue with the Perindopril for now, which is adequately controlling his blood pressure.
I have added in Ezetimibe 10mg once a day.
If his LDLs are adequately controlled I would suggest that if you could please refer him to my colleague Dr Kostner at the Mater Hospital in his Lipid Clinic for further assessment.
I will check his progress in 18  months.
Thank you kindly for your continuing care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr De Sliva,





														RE:	ROBIN PATRICIA PARKER		DOB:	22/04/1956	UR:	1041674

																					

														I encountered Robin’s problems of atrial fibrillation after she had undergone pancreatectomy and gall bladder removal  last year.
Her ventricular rate was controlled with a combination of Metoprolol and Digoxin which had been tolerated well.
At the moment, Robin is feeling very well.
Her dietary intake is somewhat limited because of pancreatic insufficiency; however she is maintaining weight.
She does not have any cardiac symptoms at all.
Today her blood pressure was 165/95mmHg sitting.
Her pulse is 65bpm in atrial fibrillation at rest, as confirmed by 12 Lead ECG which shows Digoxin effect.
There were no abnormal cardiac signs.

Today I have increased her Candesartan to 8mg in the morning, reduced her Metoprolol to 25mg bd, in view of the slowish ventricular response to atrial fibrillation and added Flecainide at 50mg bd with food.
All this is prelude to elective electrical cardioversion which I will arrange for her.
She will be contacted by our EP Nurse in the next several months.
It is possible though that she will revert to sinus rhythm on her own.

Her blood pressure should be targeted to systolic readings in 120mmHg range, and I would advocate advance of her dosage of Candesartan to achieve this, since hypertension is a driver of atrial fibrillation.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Jao,

														

														

														RE:	PANNA PATEL		DOB:	07/10/1972		UR:	199201

																					

														

														

														Panna Patel was reviewed in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
Her husband was also present for the consultation.
She does not report any history of diabetes or hypertension.
She is not currently on any regular medications.
She has no known allergies.
She is a non-smoker.
She currently lives at home with her family and works in an administrative role.
She has a history with her younger sister reported having a history of valvular pathology and a dilated aorta, reported that she had surgery in 2022 to address this.
Panna reports that she has been feeling well.
She does not experience any chest pain.
She reports that when she goes on periodic bush walks, that she experiences some dyspnoea on heavy exertion in keeping with NYHA class I symptoms.
She does not report any history of asthma.
With her day-to-day activities, she does not experience any symptoms of chest pain or shortness of breath.
She reports that her younger sister apparently had aortic valve and dilated ascending aorta pathology that required surgical intervention.
She reports that she had surgical intervention in April of 2022.
From what she describes, it sounds that it was a difficult period afterwards and she stated that her sister unfortunately passed away in October of 2022.
Panna reports that this was a stressful period of time for her.
She reports that since December of 2022, she feels improved, and she has not experienced any further chest pain.
On examination her heart rate was 64 and her blood pressure was 110/70mmHg.
Her heart sounds were dual, her chest was clear and there was no lower limb oedema.
ECG showed sinus rhythm with T-wave inversions in the lateral leads.
She had an echocardiogram report attached to the referral and it concluded that she had normal LV size with normal systolic function with an ejection fraction of 69%.
She had normal RV size and systolic function.
There was no echocardiographic evidence of significant valvular dysfunction and she had normal aortic root and ascending aortic dimensions.
Panna does not experience any chest pain.
She does experience intermittent NYHA class I symptoms of dyspnoea.
She has a reported family history of aortic pathology.
Her echocardiogram had reported a structurally normal heart with aortic dimensions that were reported within normal limits.
If you can please monitor her in regard to her cholesterol levels with blood tests that would be appreciated.
If her cholesterol levels are elevated, I suggest encourage commencing her on a statin like Atorvastatin 80mg oral daily.
Can you also please monitor her in regard to her blood pressure and blood sugar levels.

From a cardiac perspective, in view that there was concern with regards to her close relative experiencing cardiac pathology, it would be reasonable to delineate her coronary anatomy with a CT coronary angiogram that will be arranged in an outpatient setting.
She will have plan for follow up in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic in around 4 months.
In the interim, she has been advised that if she experiences symptoms that are concerning to seek medical review.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Butler, 

														

														

														RE:	MAREE A. PATEMAN	DOB:	19/09/1963	UR:	750691

																					

														

														

														Issues:
# Patent Foramen Ovale 
   - closed 4/5/22
   - Amplatzer 30x30 cribriform occluder
# Cryptogenic stroke in March 2021
   - ILR - no AF/AFL
# HTN
# OSA

Medications:
aspirin 200mg daily (takes extra 100mg when headache), atorvastatin 80mg mane, candesartan 32mg mane, ezetimibe 10mg mane, pregabalin 150mg nocte, loratadine 10mg BD, prochlorperazine 5mg TDS, desvenlafaxine XR 100mg mane, Seretide 250/25 2 puffs BD, amitriptyline (unclear dose), rizatriptan PRN, salbutamol PRN

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Maree Pateman in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic approximately 8 months after the closure of her paten foramen ovale.
This procedure was performed in the context of cryptogenic stroke that occurred in March 2021, on the background of hypertension and obstructive sleep apnoea.
Notably, the implantable loop recorder that has been in situ for nearly 2 years has not detected any atrial flutter or atrial fibrillation to explain the possible origin of a thrombus.
Maree tells me that she has had exacerbation of her long-term headache, blurry vision and neck pain.
She has subjectively felt that the severity of all of these may have worsened since the closure.
She also tells me that she is very tired all of the time and has spontaneous sweating episodes sporadically.
Furthermore, she has noticed a reduction in her hearing acuity.
Maree has been quite diligent with taking her medications, but there was some confusion as to the dose of Aspirin she was meant to be taking.
She has been taking 200mg of Aspirin daily with a 100mg top up if she were to have a headache.
I have advised her that the recommendation for 12 months from the implantation of the closure device would be to take 300mg of the Aspirin daily.
This is meant to finish on the 04.05.2023.
Thereafter, she should continue Aspirin 100mg lifelong.
With respect to the other symptoms Maree is mentioning today, I have asked her to review them with you at her next clinic appointment.
She has multiple medications, for example, that may contribute to some or all of the symptoms she is describing.
I have advised her that there may also be other  medical conditions that have not yet been detected to explain some of her other symptoms as well.
Returning to her cardiac perspective, her most recent transthoracic echocardiogram was performed in November last year.
This showed a normal left ventricular size and systolic function with an LVEF of ~60% by visual estimation.
There was a normal right ventricle size and systolic function.
No significant functional valvular abnormality was detected.
The PFO closure device was well seated, and an agitated saline study was negative for residual shunt.
Furthermore, I have checked the implantable loop recorder data base to ensure no further arrhythmias have been detected.
Her remote monitor remains connected at present.
No arrhythmia has been detected since implantation, and her battery status is good.
Maree is not finding the loop recorder itself bothersome and at present is not seeking ex-plantation.
She tells me she might be moving remotely, where internet is not as readily available.

In discussion with Dr Cox, given that no arrhythmia has been detected in the nearly 2 years of monitoring by the implantable loop recorder, it is unlikely that an arrhythmia was the cause of the stroke.
That being said, the typical battery life of the model of the loop recorder that Maree has, is approximately 3.5 to 4 years.
Should she experience a subjective arrhythmia, she can still capture the arrhythmia and upload it to the server, wherever she may be able to obtain internet access.
If the implantable loop recorder were to become bothersome, please write to us with respect to requesting an ex-plantation of the device and we will arrange accordingly.
In summary, I have advised Maree to continue with 300mg of Aspirin daily for 12 full months since the implantation of the closure device, which completes in May this year.
Thereafter, I have asked her to continue on 100mg of Aspirin daily lifelong.
Until May this year, should she require dental or surgical procedures, please provide her with antibiotic prophylaxis prior to the procedure.
I will not make a follow up appointment to review Maree at this time.
However, should she require further cardiology input, please re-refer her to us for further review.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mrs Pateman.

Yours sincerely,

RE:	RONALD PATERSON	DOB:	16/09/1946	UR:  229152

							



														Ron returned to heart failure titration clinic today with his wife.
He reports feeling better and better every day.
He has class II NYHA symptoms.
He has hhad no chest pain, orthopnoea or PND.
He does get very occasional postural dizziness on standing quickly.
He continues to attend the Cardiac Rehab gym program here and is managing well.
He has been doing his blood pressure on his home monitor and these have been around 105 systolic.

Medications

														Pantoprazole 40mg mane, Aspirin 100mg mane, Bisoprolol 2.5mg nocte, Ramipril 1.25mg mane, Rosuvastatin 40mg nocte, Spironolactone 12.5mg mane, Ticagrelor 90mg BD.
On examination his blood pressure was 92/50mmHg sitting and 100/50mmHg standing, heart rate 56bpm and regular.
He had no peripheral oedema.
Ron has not resumed driving after his hospital admissions with a myocardial infarction and permanent pacemaker insertion, as well as a readmission with a GI bleed.
From a cardiac perspective, he was advised to avoid driving for 2 weeks after his initial admission.
Ron told me that he is feeling very well and is ready to resume driving, I have suggested that he start locally and gradually build back up.
Today I have asked Ron to change his Ramipril to a nocte dose and increase this to 2.5mg.
I have asked him to see you in two weeks for a repeat blood pressure check and blood tests.
I will see him back in this clinic in four weeks.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Problem list

														previous CABG October 2019

														moderate ischaemic cardiomyopathy (EF 41% on Simpson’s Biplane Method in November 2020) 

														Marked left ventricle dilatation (LV and diastolic volume index 101ml/m2)

														Repeat echocardiogram showing mild improvement in left ventricular function (ejection fraction 45%) with moderate LV dilatation which has remained stable.

Peripheral arterial disease

														Type II diabetes

														Hypertension

														Dyslipidaemia

														Iron deficiency anaemia

														Psoriasis 

														

														Current Medications

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Lipitor 80mg daily, Bicor 7.5mg daily, Perindopril 8mg daily, Jardiance 10mg daily, Sitagliptin/Metformin 1 tablet daily.
It was a pleasure to catch up with Joseph in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
Symptomatically he has been well.
His repeat echocardiogram has shown a marginal improvement in the systolic function with an ejection fraction of 45%.
He still has a moderately dilated left ventricle based on the left ventricle end diastolic volume index.
I feel that we should change him over to Entresto and stop the Perindopril.
He will need a 36 hour washout period after stopping the Perindopril before the Entresto can be started.
I will request Robyn Peters, Nurse Practitioner with the Heart Recovery Service to help with this transition.
I am hoping we can get some positive remodelling on the cardiac function with the change of medication.
I will repeat his echocardiogram once the dose has been up titrated to the maximum tolerated, or the full strength of 97/103mg twice daily.
I will keep him on regular follow up and repeat the echocardiogram closer to that clinic visit.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Jennkins,





														RE:	ZAKARY PAYNTER		DOB:	29/01/1999		UR:	2235472

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Zakary today 25.01.2023.

He is a 23-year-old male Correctional Officer, who has palpitations and presyncope associated with incessant atrial tachycardia from the notes, unfortunately I have no ECGs to corroborate this and I would be grateful if you have any recordings that demonstrates the arrhythmia, you could forward them through.
His ECG today demonstrates atrial bigeminy with sinus rhythm and a low atrial ectopy.
He was reviewed by Electrophysiologist Dr Deepak Arumugam who was preparing to ablate him and felt that he may have had a Crista terminalis atrial tachycardia.
However, he did not have private health insurance, and this was cancelled.
From the notes, he also has a structurally normal heart on an echocardiogram.
If you have the formal report of the transthoracic echocardiogram, I would be grateful if you could forward this as well.
His blood tests that your have kindly sent along, demonstrated normal urea, electrolytes and normal thyroid function test.
He has had a past history of depression and alopecia.
He is medicated on Metoprolol 50mg orally BD, Fluoxetine ?dose and Finasteride for Alopecia.
His palpitations have improved markedly since he stopped vaping and he is not imbibing alcohol.
He partakes of 1 caffeinated beverage and uses a pre-workout with a stimulant, and I have dissuaded him from using this.
He does not partake of illicit drugs.

At this stage, he has improved markedly on the medications and stopping vaping and he is free to use any medication he should require to manage his depression and we could mitigate this with medication and ablation in the future.

I would like to reassess where he is actually at with the burden of his atrial ectopy and atrial tachyarrhythmias and I have organised for him to have a 24-hour Holter monitor and an external loop recorder for 2 weeks and a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram and for review in 3 to 4 months.

IF he does have ongoing symptoms, and the correlation with atrial ectopy or atrial tachycardia, I believe proceeding to an electrophysiological study with a view to ablation is the best option for him.

I have informed him that this would be 70% effective enable a cure, 30% recurrence rate and a 1 to 2% risk of complication including permanent pacemaker, cardiac tamponade, DVT, PE and less than 1% chance of stroke, myocardial infarction and death.
I will review him in 4 months with results of the above investigations and decide on progression.
Many thanks for your ongoing care of the patient.
If there are any problems, please do not hesitate to get in touch with me.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Butcher,





RE:	LUKE PEACOCK		DOB:	16/07/1974		UR:	233961

							



														Luke attended the heart failure titration clinic today.
As you know this 48 year old gentleman had an anterior STEMI with PCI to his proximal LAD on the 9th December 2022.
His echocardiogram during the admission showed an ejection fraction of 31% with regional wall motion abnormalities.
He has no past medical history.
He is usually quite fit and well.

Medications

														Ticagrelor 90mg BD, Aspirin 100mg mane, Bisoprolol 2.5mg mane, Entresto increased today to 24/26mg mane and 49/51mg nocte, Eplerenone decreased today to 12.5mg mane, Atorvastatin 80mg mane, Ezetimibe 10mg mane, GTN PRN.
Luke told me that about ½ hour after taking the Ticagrelor tablet both morning and evening he feels breathless which lasts for a few hours and then resolves.
He denies any breathlessness on exertion.
However, he feels that when he initially started taking the Ticagrelor it was affecting his ability to speak but this has slowly resolved.
He feels that the breathlessness is improving slowly.
He denies any chest pain and describes class I NYHA symptoms.
He denies any orthopnoea, PND, dizziness or light headedness.
Luke works as a helicopter mechanic at Archerfield.
He is currently on sick leave, and he will return to work at the beginning of February.
He is married with two teenage children.
Blood test on the 31st December show Na 141, K+ 4.2, Urea 5.1, Creat 104, and eGFR 73.
On examination his blood pressure was 105/70mmHg with no postural drop, heart rate 55bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
Heart sounds were dual, and chest was clear.
I understand that the Bisoprolol was recently increased by yourself to 2.5mg mane.
This is likely a maximum tolerated dose for Luke given his heart rate today of 55bpm.
He told me that his heart rate can be as low as 40bpm.
I have decreased the Eplerenone to 12.5mg in order to improve the blood pressure so the Entresto can be titrated further.
I have increased the Entresto to 24/26mg mane and 46/51mg nocte.

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis.
Coronary artery status pending.
Coronary reconstructions of CT are still pending.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Ex-smoker.
Hypertension.
Obesity.

Other Conditions:

														Cirrhotic liver disease with portal hypertension, portal hypertensive gastropathy and hypersplenism with chronic thrombocytopaenia.
Diverticular disease of the colon.
Colonic polyps.
Previous alcohol intake well above guideline recommended levels.

Medications:

														Olmesartan 40mg once daily.
I reviewed Ross Penny today.
Ross is a 71 year old semi-retired Boiler Maker.
He lives at home with his partner.
He has had gradually increasing shortness of breath on exertion over the last 5 to 12 months.
He has had no syncope or presyncope.
No angina.
He has chronic liver disease, secondary to previous significant alcohol intake.
He only drinks a couple of light beers on the weekends now.
He does not smoke any longer.
He is independent with personal activities of daily living.
He mobilises independently with no gait aid.
He has no cognitive impairment.
We discussed the natural history of the aortic valve disease including a 50% risk of heart failure or death within the next year or two without procedural intervention.

In relation to transcatheter aortic valve replacement we discussed the potential risks including a risk of 5% - 10% major complications that could include: stroke resulting in permanent disability, inability to walk or talk, blindness, death or permanent nursing home placement; major vascular or cardiac complications including dissection, rupture, the need for major reparative surgery, death or limb loss; kidney failure requiring permanent use of a dialysis machine; infection resulting in the need for major open heart surgery and or death.
We also discussed a 20 - 30% risk of requiring a permanent pacemaker as a result of the procedure.
The relevant written educational material outlining these issues was also provided (UQ Version 2021).

It was discussed with him that transcatheter aortic valve replacement would potentially be a more appropriate way to management his aortic valve disease than open heart surgery, owing to his comorbid chronic liver disease, with chronic hypersplenism and thrombocytopaenia.

Plan and recommendations:

														1. Review at Heart Team Meeting with a view to transcatheter aortic valve replacement via the transfemoral approach.

With kind regards,

														

														Yours sincerely,

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Joyce, a 51-year-old female, who I had the pleasure of reviewing in Dr Ng’s clinic for follow up of her apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
Her other medical issues include hypertension and asthma.
Her current medications include Perindopril / Amlodipine 10/5mg daily and Salbutamol PRN.
I am pleased to report that Joyce has no cardiac symptoms of concern.
In particular she does not have syncope, presyncope or exertional chest pain.
She did discuss her diagnosis with her children, but they have yet to get screened for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
I have encouraged her to rediscuss this with them, which she is planning on doing.
Additionally, Joyce was also interested in getting some genetic screening for HCM and as such we will refer her to Royal Brisbane Genetic Clinic for counselling and consideration of genetic testing.
On examination today, her blood pressure was 104/60mmHg, her heart rate was regularly regular, and her heart sounds were dual with no murmurs.
She had no evidence of peripheral oedema.
Her last echocardiogram was in May 2021, that showed a preserved ejection and a pattern of increased left ventricular wall thickness consistent with apical variant hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
This was associated with mild mitral regurgitation only.
The plan is to see Joyce in 12 months with an echocardiogram and ECG.
We will await the outcome of the genetic clinic referral at this stage as well.
If Joyce has any syncopal episodes, presyncope or exertional chest pain, she should seek urgent medical attention.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Blanco,





														RE:	JORGE PEREZ		DOB:	21/11/1956		UR:	577625

																					

														

														

														Problem List:

														Chest pain for further investigation.
Hypertension.
Impaired glucose tolerance.
Varicose vein – awaiting surgery.

Current Medications:

														Somac 1 tablet daily, Diabex 500mg daily (current not taking).
Thank you for referring Jorge Perez to the Cardiology Service at the PA Hospital.
He is a pleasant 66-year-old gentleman, who runs a Spanish Restaurant in West End.
He describes some chest pain symptoms which he has been noticing for the last 3 months.

He tells me while walking on a flat ground he feels fine, however, if he has to negotiate any degree of incline or steps, he would often get chest pain, needing him to stop and wait for the symptoms to abate before he could walk again, but going up the incline from the gate to the main entrance of the PA Hospital, he tells me he had to stop a couple of times.
There is no previous  history of myocardial infarction or coronary artery disease.
His major risk factors include hypertension and impaired glucose tolerance.
I understand that you started him on Metformin, however, he seems to have discontinued that because of constipation and complaints of bloating.
He does not smoke, there is no family history of premature coronary artery disease.
His total cholesterol is just marginally elevated with an LDL which is 2.9mmol/L with an HDL, which is less than 1mmol/L.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 160/80mmHg, with a heart rate of 88bpm in sinus rhythm.
Systemic examination was unremarkable.
His ECG that was done in the clinic confirms sinus rhythm with a rate of 72bpm with some inferior Q-waves, but no ST or T-wave changes were noted.

In summary, Mr Perez is a 66-year-old gentleman whose history of chest pain when going up an incline are quite suggestive of an underlying cardiac aetiology, however, there is no definite confirmation of coronary artery disease, previous angina or myocardial infarction.

To investigate the symptoms further, I have suggested doing a dobutamine stress echocardiogram for him, as he is unlikely to be able to exercise adequately on the treadmill because of his varicose veins.
I would like to review him back with the results and I will keep you informed on the findings and plans for further management thereafter.

Yours sincerely,
