														Dear Dr Safier,

														

														

														RE:	JAMES PES		DOB:	28/11/1942		UR:	781238

																					

														

														

														Issues:
# Ischaemic heart disease
   - anterior MI 1997
   - stent LAD May 2004
   - previously known to Dr. Lim
   - TTE (2019): LVEF 52%, normal LV size and function, normal RV size and

														     function.

- cardiac perfusion scan (2019): no inducible ischaemia
# T2DM
   - HbA1c Sept 2022 7.4%
# CKD
   - baseline eGFR ~60 mL/min
# BPH
   - for TURP

Medications:
clopidogrel 75mg mane, bisoprolol 5mg mane, ramipril 2.5mg mane, isosorbide mononitrate SR 60mg mane, gliclazide 60mg MR mane, Optisulin 15u mane, duloxetine 60mg mane, mirtazapine 30mg nocte, oxazepam 15mg nocte, risperidone 0.5mg nocte, B12 injection q3months

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing James Pes today in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic, accompanied by his wife and son.

He was referred to us by the Urology Service for pre-operative assessment of his prior known ischaemic heart disease on the background of type II diabetes and CKD, prior to performing a TURP for treatment  his benign prostatic hyperplasia.
Reviewing his functional status, he mobilises with a 4-wheel walker and manages to walk at least 200 to 300 metres without stopping.
He is likely able to do more, but reaches the destination prior to the onset of significant dyspnoea.
He denies any significant dyspnoea on exertion, orthopnoea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, presyncope, syncope or palpitations.
However, James tells me that he has had approximately 8 falls in the last 3 weeks, one of which was associated with a head strike.
At the time that he was having these falls, he was also having concurrent dizziness in the setting of being unwell with an elbow infection requiring antibiotics.
He described being  unsteady while trying to reach his 4-wheel walker.
However, after cessation of the antibiotics and improving clinically from the infective symptoms, he experiences no further unsteadiness in the last week and has had no further falls.
His last investigation of his cardiac condition was in 2019, when he had both an echocardiogram and a cardiac perfusion scan.
The echocardiogram showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 52%, normal biventricular size and function.
The myocardial perfusion scan showed no inducible ischaemia.
Clinically James has not experienced any chest discomfort with or without exertion.
As mentioned above, he also does not experience any symptoms of potential decompensated heart failure.
On examination today, James appeared well and in good spirits in the presence of his family.
His blood pressure was 105/55mmHg in a seated position, and 115/55mmHg in a standing position.
His heart rate was 64bm and regular.
This corresponded with an ECG in sinus rhythm with anterior Q-waves.
His chest was clear and his heart sounds were dual, though soft.
He had no peripheral oedema and the JVP was not elevated.
James was seen in clinic today by Dr Korczyk, and we have advised James that we are pleased with his progress from a cardiac perspective.
In light of the upcoming procedure, we have asked James to discontinue his Clopidogrel and to start Aspirin 100mg daily going forward.
We would ask that the urologists please continue Aspirin through the surgery in light of his previous stent to the LAD.
Otherwise, we have asked him to continue his current medications.
From a cardiac perspective, there is no contraindication to proceeding with the TURP.
Given the stability of his cardiac condition, we will discharge him from clinic at this time.
We would be happy for James to be re-referred to us should his condition change.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Pes.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor,





														RE:	ERIC JOHN PETER		DOB:	25/02/2004		UR:	2184821

																					

														

														

														Past Medical History:
# ASD with significant shunt
   - closed 6/4/22
    - known to Dr. Challa (Logan Hospital)
    - for Aspirin 300 mg daily for 12 months (until April 2022), then aspirin 100mg

														       lifelong
    - Antibiotic prophylaxis for dental or surgical procedures for 12 months (until April 

														      2022)

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Eric Peter today in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic, accompanied by his mother.
This is a routine appointment after ASD closure in April last year.
Since his discharge, he has had a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram in December last year.
This showed a normal sized left ventricle with a normal ejection fraction with an LVEF of approximately 55%.
No regional wall motion abnormalities were seen.
He had a mildly dilated right ventricle with preserved systolic function.
The 16mm Amplatzer ASD closure device was well seated with no residual shunt.
The bubble study was negative.
No significant functional valvular disease was noted.
On discussion today, Eric has been feeling well.
He denies any palpitations or presyncope / syncope.
He has been regular with his medications, which currently include Aspirin 300mg daily.
I have emphasised the importance of continuing on the 300mg of Aspirin until 06.04.2023 after which he can decrease to 100mg daily.
He needs to continue Aspirin 100mg daily lifelong.
Eric tells me that he has not seen the dentist for some time.

I have suggested that should he schedule an appointment for dental work, unless it were to be urgent, he consider doing it after April 6, as any procedure prior to that date, will require prophylactic antibiotics.
From the perspective of the atrial septal defect which has now been successfully closed, we will not make another appointment to see Eric at this time.
However, should there be concerns around the function of the closure device, we would be happy to receive another referral to review Eric once again.
Otherwise, we will discharge Eric to the care of Dr Challa at the Logan Hospital, should any general cardiology issues require further ongoing consultation.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Peter.

Yours sincerely,

														Atorvastatin 40mg nocte, Entresto 49/51mg bd, Bisoprolol 2.5mg nocte, Thiamine 100mg nocte.
On examination his blood pressure was 120/80mmHg sitting and 124/870mmHg standing, heart rate 64bpm and regular.

Dear Tran,





														RE:	TINH PHAM		DOB:	02/02/1950		UR:	062888

																					

														

														I caught up with this 72 year old gentleman in the Cardiology Clinic today.

Issues:
1.

Mixed aortic valve disease (Moderate AS and moderate AR) + dilated LV under 

														    surveillance
    a.

Latest TTE 1.8.2022 - Dilated LV (LVEDV indexed for BSA ~114mL/m2) with 

														        LVEF 61%; Normal RV size and systolic function; ?Type 2 BAV with moderate 

														        AS (PR corrections using reported values – STJ 2.7cm; PG/MG 63/38mmHg; 

														        DSI 0.29; AVA 1.7cm2) and moderate AR; Mildly dilated ascending aorta
2.

CT chest 10.2.2022 – No pulmonary nodules; Small numerous aortopulmonary      

														    window and pre-tracheal notes; Calcified coronary vessels

Background:
1.

Hyperlipidaemia
2.

Hypothyroidism
3.

Fatty liver 
4.

Gout
5.

No DM, HTN, CVA, epilepsy, bleeding issues, active malignancy, or planned 

														    surgery; No FHx of cardiac disease 
6.

Previous ex-smoker (Ceased 3 years ago; 4-5/day for 30 years); EtOH - 1-2 beers 

														    or wine on weekends only 
7.

ADR - ?Cough from Ramipril

Medications - No list:
Crestor 40mg od
T4 100mcg od
Progout 300mg od 
Omeprazole 20mg od
Irbesartan 75mg od (Changed from Ramipril by GP ?cough) 

														

														He tells me that over the last 12 months he has noticed himself getting tired when he walks up hills.
He denies any chest pains or shortness of breath.
However, and importantly it is somewhat objective.
He still uses his treadmill at home every day in the morning.
He does 4 kilometres for over 40 minutes with a slight incline.
He has been doing this for the last 5 years.
He has not noticed any change in this in the last 12 months.
He tells me he does not stop at the end of the 40 minutes because he has to, in fact he is able to do more, but he just feels that he has done enough.
In addition to that some evenings he may walk in addition of 3 kilometres and intermittently also mows the lawn.

On examination today his blood pressure was 125/70mmHg, heart rate is 66bpm and regular, JVP is not elevated, his carotid volumes were reasonable, heart sounds were dual with a 3/6 ejection systolic murmur and early diastolic murmur at the base and his chest was clear.

Assessment:

														Echocardiographically, he does have moderate AS and AR along with the dilated left ventricle.
However, we are getting to the stage where he requires closer surveillance.
At the present time, there does not appear to be any clear change in his symptomatology, in particular with his exercise tolerance on the treadmill.

Plan:

														He needs closer monitoring with a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram in 3 months.
I will organise a chart review to look at the echocardiogram then.
He has a formal review tentatively booked for 6 months.
If there are any changes in his symptoms, then I think we should work him up for an aortic valve replacement.
Thank you kindly for your continuing care.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	CASSANDRA PHILLIPS	DOB:	04/10/1977	UR:	852017

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Cassandra, a lovely 45-year-old female, I had the pleasure of reviewing in Dr Ahmad’s Electrophysiology Clinic today.

Cassandra’s medical issues include:

														WPW syndrome.
Recurrent SVT with presyncopal symptoms.
SVT ablation performed successfully on 25.05.2021 at PA Hospital.
Previous left anterior pathway.
Pulmonary sarcoidosis lost to follow up.
Atypical chest pain with CTCA excluding any significant coronary artery disease.
Iron deficiency anaemia with ongoing menorrhagia known to the Obstetrics and Gynaecology Team at the Redlands Hospital.
Ex-smoker.
On review today, Cassandra reports that her palpitation burden has significantly improved since last review.
She describes a feeling of extra or missed beats and her event monitor have confirmed that they coincide with isolated ventricular complexes.
She denies any presyncope or syncope.
Cassandra has managed to reduce her symptom burden down by lifestyle changes, which includes deep breathing exercises, cutting out caffeine and alcohol along with losing some weight.
Despite weight loss, Cassandra has poor sleep, with insomnia as well as certain symptoms concerning for an obstructive sleep apnoea (snoring and possible apnoeic episodes).
On review today, her blood pressure was 126/70mmHg, her chest was clear, and her heart sounds were dual with no murmurs.
Her heart rate of regularly regular and her ECG today was in sinus rhythm with no evidence of pre-excitation.
Her event monitor, I am pleased to report has not picked up any sustained arrhythmias and her cardiac MRI is normal with no evidence of cardiac sarcoidosis.
Currently, Cassandra is happy to manage her symptoms with lifestyle changes; and does not want any medications to reduce her ectopic burden.
She was also not keen on going down the path of an EP study which can be considered in the future should her symptoms become bothersome.
We will see her in 12 months to assess her progress.

In the meantime, I would appreciate it if you could refer Cassandra to a Respiratory & Sleep Physician for clarification of her pulmonary sarcoid diagnosis as well as for consideration of a sleep study given her poor sleep quality.
Can you also check her thyroid function tests every 12 months to ensure they are within normal limits?
Thank you for your ongoing care, and please do not hesitate in contacting should you have any questions or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Kannarian,





														RE:	STEPHEN J. PITCHERS	DOB:	28/07/1969	UR:	8109268

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Stephen in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
He is a 53-year-old gentleman who was admitted here in August with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
He was symptomatic with palpitations and had a troponin rise to 496.
A CT coronary angiogram revealed no significant coronary artery disease.

An echocardiogram showed an increased interventricular septal diameter of 16mm with some systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve raising the possibility of an underlying hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
His CHA2DS2-VASc was 0 and he was not discharged on anticoagulation.
The plan was for an outpatient cardiac MRI.
Stephen has undergone the cardiac MRI with Q-scan and they report an interventricular septum of 10mm with no late gadolinium enhancement or other features of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
Stephen has been very well.
He has returned to cycling and tennis with no palpitations.
His blood pressure today was 120/80mmHg.
He does not report any particular symptoms of sleep apnoea.
His alcohol intake is quite moderate.
In summary, Stephen has had a single episode of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
He had a mild troponin rise and mildly increased interventricular septum in that setting, which has since resolved, and I wonder if he had a mild myocarditis.
He has no evidence of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy on the cardiac MRI.
We discussed the possibility of Stephen’s AF returning and the possible management options if that is the case.
I have not commenced him on any medication currently nor made a routine appointment to see him again, but I would be happy to do so in the future with any new issues or concerns.
He knows that ensuring his blood pressure is well controlled and minimising alcohol intake will be important to avoiding further atrial fibrillation.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Bruno,

														

														

														RE:	JUDITH POLLOCK		DOB:	24/05/1953		UR:	386907

																					

														

														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Coronary artery disease.
Potential moderate to severe ostial LMCA disease on diagnostic coronary angiogram on 12.01.2023.
Occurs in the context of CCS class II – III exertional angina and shortness of breath.
Heart failure with normal ejection fraction.
Previous left branch retinal artery occlusion.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Obesity with the metabolic syndrome.
Ex-smoker.
Type II diabetes mellitus.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Other Conditions:

														Obstructive sleep apnoea on CPAP.
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
Right cerebellopontine meningioma.
Hypothyroidism.
Impaired mobility with 4-wheel frame for mobilisation.

Medications:

														Hydralazine 25mg, Isosorbide Mononitrate 60mg, Telmisartan 80mg, Levothyroxine 75mcg, Metoprolol 50mg, Nicabate, Glyceryl Trinitrate 400mcg, Rosuvastatin 40mg, Aspirin 100mg, Duloxetine 60mg, Metformin 500mg, Esomeprazole 20mg, Paracetamol 665mg, Pramipexole 0.125mg, Breo Ellipta, Salbutamol, Clopidogrel 75mg once daily (commenced on 12.01.2023).
I reviewed Judith Pollock today at the PA Hospital.

She had a coronary angiogram performed earlier in the day which demonstrated moderate to severe ostial left main coronary artery plaque that is somewhat ambiguous with an element of endothelial folding.

Judith had been assessed by my colleague Dr M Ura, Cardiac and Thoracic Surgeon, who asked if I could review Judith in relation to potential suitability for percutaneous coronary intervention as he felt that she was high to prohibitive risk candidate for cardiac surgery in the setting of her comorbidities and poor mobility.
Judith has had several months of increasing dyspnoea and chest discomfort on exertion.

I discussed with her the potential role for invasive management of her coronary disease with further assessment (intravascular ultrasound), and an implantation of a permanent stent into the left main coronary artery as an alternative to open chest surgery.

We discussed the potential risks of proceeding with percutaneous coronary intervention including a 2 to 3% risk of significant complications that can include disabling stroke, resulting in blindness, inability to walk or talk, nursing home placement and death as well as risk of heart attack, cardiac decompensation, stent thrombosis and death.
Judith wishes to proceed.
We will make arrangements for her to have her procedure within the next 30 days at the PA Hospital.

In the interval period, I have told Judith that should she have any sudden change in her symptoms in particular, unexpected chest pain or chest pain at rest, increased shortness of breath, fainting or near fainting to call 000 and attend the hospital.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Proceed to intravascular ultrasound assessment +/- FFR assessment, +/- stenting to LMCA as a category 1 patient  (booking form submitted).

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr MacLaverty,





														RE:	JUDY D. PRESTON		DOB:	26/10/1941		UR:	2200506

																					

														

														I reviewed Ms Judy Preston today in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
She states she feels fantastic.
She does get episodes of breathlessness associated with palpitations.
These are completely random, infrequent and not related to activity.
This is most likely in keeping with her pacemaker  mediated tachycardia, which have been found on multiple device interrogations.
Her left ventricular ejection fraction on her September 2022 echocardiogram is 35%.
She remains on Sotalol 80mg bd, Dabigatran 110mg once daily and she is awaiting a left breast excisional biopsy.
She does not have any blood tests available on the system.
June 2022 blood work reveals Hb of 95g/L.
She had colorectal cancer resected in 2022 and is awaiting a left breast biopsy.
She mentions that her hemoglobin  has significant improved since and that is why she was recommenced on Dabigatran by her surgeons.
Today I have asked her to have repeat blood tests including iron studies, to ensure that Dabigatran is still appropriate.

I have also stopped her Sotalol, in view of her moderate LV dysfunction and had her device interrogated which showed multiple episodes of PMT, most terminated by the device, and our EP scientist today has adjusted her device settlings to prevent further PMT.
Hopefully this will resolve her symptoms, and her LVEF will come up on heart failure therapy that I will start her on today in form of ramipril 1.25mg daily and Bisoprolol 1.25mg daily.
I have also linked her with our heart failure titration services, for education and titration.
If her ferritin is <100 or transferrin saturation is below 25%, we will refer her for iron infusion via day therapy unit.
I have given her pathology slip for bloods today.
Once I have her Hb result, I will advise her the appropriate action on dabigatran.

If her hemoglobin is normal and she has no signs of bleeding, I would recommend she takes Dabigatran twice a day instead of once a day to give her the full protection from stroke from her underlying atrial fibrillation.
There is no prohibition from cardiac point of view to undergo the scheduled left breast excision biopsy or surgery as this is a low risk surgery and her symptoms are quite stable.
We will see her again in 3 months with repeat transthoracic echocardiogram.
ADDIT: At time of signing of this letter her Hb on 17/01/23 is normal at 136g/L and she is iron deficient with ferritin of 69 and Transferrin of 9%.
I have referred her to Day therapy unit for iron infusion.
I have communicated this to Judy over the phone today.
She has not seen the heart failure services yet, I have asked her to see yourself for titration bisoprolol and ramipril if her HR and BP allow.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Lu,

														

														

														RE:	SUSAN PRICE		DOB:	30/11/1945		UR:	652981

																					

														

														

														Issues:

														Dual chamber pacemaker in situ.
Atrial fibrillation.
Previous pulmonary vein ablation March 2017.

Current Medications:

														Flecainide 50mg BD, Metoprolol 25mg BD,  Xarelto 20mg, PPI, Magnesium.
Thank you for notifying us regarding Susan.

I understand she had an external echocardiogram performed at Queensland Radiologist Specialists in November 2022, which reported a possible small echo density attached to the right ventricular pacing lead.
We were notified of this and therefore brought her in to clinic for review.
Susan appears to be clinically well.
She does have some very occasional palpitations and she has known paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
Her burden of atrial fibrillation has been low and appears unchanged.
She reports no new infections, no fevers, sweats or other concerning symptoms.
Her device site has not been hot, red or tender and there has been no discharge from it.
She does have some chronic venous congestion of her lower limbs, and some ulcerations on his right leg which are long standing and unchanged.
There does not appear to be any current areas of cellulitis around this, it is simply the venous congestion.
On examination her heart sounds were dual with some ectopy and she was euvolaemic.
The device site itself, appears in good order with no discharge, redness, swelling or tenderness.
Her legs do show chronic venous congestion and she had some bandages on her ulcers, but there did not appear to be any significant cellulitis around the area.
Her ECG appears to be in sinus rhythm.
Clinically she does not appear to have infective endocarditis or any other concerning features.
Nevertheless, I have asked her to do some blood tests today including blood cultures and CRP.
We will also in the first instance, repeat the transthoracic echocardiogram here for assessment of whether there is any echo density attached to the RV lead.
She may require a transesophageal echocardiogram at some point, but I understand she has some problems swallowing, so in the first instance, we will arrange the transthoracic echocardiogram.

Yours sincerely,

RE:	RICHARD RANGIWAI	DOB:	09/01/1965	UR:	123274

								



It was a pleasure to review Richard in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know he is a 58-year-old gentleman.

Background:

	Ischaemic heart disease.
Aborted inferior STEMI June 2022.
CABG July 2022 (LIMA to LAD, SVG to OM).
EF 40-45% pre op.
Hypertension.
Current smoker.
Aortic root 44mm.
His current medications include Aspirin 100mg, Atorvastatin 80mg, Metoprolol 25mg BD, Ramipril 5mg and Metformin.
Today his pulse was 74bpm and regular and blood pressure was 132/93mmHg.
Richard has been recovering well, although a little slowly, from his bypass operation.
He reports he is gradually improving but continues to get some mechanical chest pain.
His chronic lower back pain has also flared up though he feels it is now back to baseline.
He has had some left ankle pain and swelling adjacent to the lower end of his vein graft wound.
I understand he tried treatment for gout, but he reports there was no improvement.
His attendance at Cardia Rehab has been limited by his back pain and so has his return to work.
In summary, Richard is recovering well, though a little slowly.
He is keen to try cardiac rehab again and I think he would really benefit from this now that his back pain has settled a bit.
I will refer him back.
I will review him with an echocardiogram in three months but have not made any changes to his medications at this stage.
Please feel free to contact me with any issues or concerns before I see him again.

Yours sincerely,

														Diagnoses:

														Ischaemic cardiomyopathy.
NSTEMI June 2022.

Severe LV dysfunction (LVEF 30%)

														Severe three vessel coronary artery disease at coronary angiography.
Heart Team consensus for best medical therapy unless symptoms refractory to optimal medical therapy.
Significant peripheral vascular disease.
Aorto-bifemoral bypass + aortic thromboendarterectomy + bilateral femoral thromboendarterectomy 2008 (Greenslopes Hospital).
Severe left carotid and moderate right carotid artery disease (asymptomatic).
Ex-smoker – quit 2005.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100 mg daily, Clopidogrel 75 m daily, Telmisartan/Hydrochlorothiazide 80/12.5 mg daily, Bisoprolol 5 mg mane/2.5 mg nocte, Atorvastatin 40 mg daily, Pantoprazole 20 mg daily, MagMin, Panadol, GTN prn, dapagliflozin 10mg daily.

														I reviewed Mario in Brisbane today.
Unfortunately, there was some confusion and he did not attend the planned echocardiogram, where we were going to reassess his left ventricular function on medical therapy.

														Dear Dr Heidari,

														

														

														RE:	ERROL SHANE REED	DOB:	24/04/1956	UR:	2114251

																					

														

														

														Diagnoses:

														Syncope.
AV node disease.
Atrial flutter.
Right parietal lobe stroke October 2022.
Echocardiogram, normal LV function October 2022.
PTSD.
Myeloproliferative disorder.
Thymoma resection March 2021.

Medications:

														Xarelto 20mg once a day, Perindopril 5mg daily, Atorvastatin 40mg once a day, Hydroxyurea 1g nocte, Esomeprazole 20mg once a day.
I saw Errol in the Cardiology Clinic today.
He is a 66-year-old man who has had presentation to  hospital with syncope, though a host of other symptoms also.
He has complex PTSD and anxiety and has self-discharged on several occasions as a consequence.
He describes syncope on multiple occasions with no particular triggers.
The atrial flutter documented with no palpitations.
Errol has had shortness of breath for the last 3 months or more, though it comes with no particular association to exercise.
There is a history of hypertension, though diabetes for Errol.
His is an ex-smoker though stopped 25 years ago.
An echocardiogram in October confirmed normal  left ventricular size and function.
On examination his heart rate was 70bpm and regular, and his blood pressure was 130/70mmHg.
His heart sounds were dual with no added sounds.
His ECG confirmed sinus rhythm with a 1st degree AV block.
His PR interval was 280ms, QRS 100ms, and QTc 416ms.
Reviewing his ECGs in atrial flutter showed periods of high-grade AV block in the absence of AV node blocking agents.
There are some challenges to Errol’s history due to his general anxiety, though he is clearly having syncope and there is evidence of AV node disease.
On this basis it is appropriate to offer him a pacemaker and I have taken through the small risks of this.
Given his chest tightness, it would be important to assess for ischaemic heart disease and I will arrange a myocardial perfusion scan for him.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Davis,





														RE:	GRAHAM A. REID		DOB:	8/05/1945		UR:	8098241

																					

														

														

														Issues:

														Ischaemic heart disease.
NSTEMI December 2021.
PCI to proximal circumflex, residual 50% mid LAD, 50% ramus and 40% proximal RCA disease.
Normal LV size and function, EF 60%.
Mild AR, mild to moderate MR on TTE 21.12.2021.

Other Background:

														Hypertension.
BPH.
Previous appendicectomy.
Previous nephrolithiasis.

Medications:

														Irbesartan HCT 200/25mg, Clopidogrel 75mg, Rosuvastatin 40mg, Atenolol 25mg, Aspirin 100mg.
I had the pleasure of seeing Graham via telehealth today in Dr Camuglia Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
Symptomatically he is doing very well and reports no chest pain, no breathlessness, no GTN use and no other concerning symptoms.
His medication list is as above, although I am not entirely sure how he takes his Rosuvastatin.
Hopefully you could clarify this as he seems to be on 40mg but take it a few times a week.
As you will know, he was transferred to us from Warwick Hospital just before Christmas of 2021.
He suffered a non-STEMI there and proceeded to have PCI to his circumflex artery.
He seems to be recovery very well from this.
His blood pressure at the Warwick Clinic was 170mmHg, his heart rate was 60bpm in normal sinus rhythm with no ischaemic changes on his ECG.

Plan is as follows:

														He can cease his Clopidogrel today.
He needs to continue Aspirin lifelong.
Could you please up titrate his antihypertensive agents.
Some like perhaps Amlodipine may be of use.
Could you please organise for him to have an echocardiogram locally in the next 12 months before we see him, mainly to assess for stability or progression of his mitral and aortic regurgitation.
We will see him via telehealth in 12 months after the echocardiogram is performed.
Could you please clarify his dosing regarding his Rosuvastatin?
He seems to have had some aches and pains but his taking 40mg what I think is a few times a week.
It may be easier just to make it 20mg daily, but I will leave this to your discretion.
We should target an LDL below 1.8.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	PAUL REZAHI		DOB:	13/04/1973		UR:	8062357

																					

														

														

														Problem List:

														Known ischaemic cardiomyopathy.
Left bundle branch block.
Previously known severe LV dysfunction (ejection fraction 25 – 30%).
Coronary angiography in 2019 – no significant obstructive disease.
Mild remodelling and improvement in LV dysfunction (ejection fraction 40% on echocardiography in 2021).
Currently NYHA class I with no symptoms of orthopnoea or PND.
Dyslexia and dysarthria with a background of intellectual impairment.
Type 2 diabetes – HbA1c 11.3%.
Non-compliant with dietary control.
Peripheral neuropathy.
Bronchial asthma.

Current Medications:

														Bicor 5mg daily, Dapagliflozin 10mg daily, Gliclazide 60mg 3 times daily, Januvia 1 tablet daily, Lipitor 10mg nocte, Lyrica 150mg twice daily, Sublingual GTN prn – to be discontinued, Symbicort nebuliser twice daily.
I had the pleasure of meeting Paul in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
Paul is a 49-year-old gentleman with some intellectual impairment and he currently lives with his parents locally.
He has presented for a scheduled review.
He was last reviewed by Dr Wahi in May 2021, with the obvious challenges of medical management of heart failure, due to non-adherence to medications and  poor lifestyle choices.
Paul reports to be stable and clinically well in the last few months.
He denies any symptoms of shortness of breath.
He denies any symptoms suggestive of orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea.
There is no history of angina.
He had an echocardiogram performed in May 2022, which has reported LV function around 40%.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 130/70mmHg, heart sounds were dual with no murmur, there were no signs of volume overload.
It is obvious that Paul is difficult patient to manage due to poor lifestyle choices and non-adherence to his medications.
However, to give him a fair chance, I have booked him for a phone review in 12 months and have suggested him for adherence with ongoing heart failure medications.
He was keen to accept Perindopril as an extra medication for his heart failure treatment, however, I did not have any recent blood tests results available.
May I please request you to consider 2.5mg of Perindopril if his kidney functions have been stable in the last 12 months.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Larkins, 

														

														

														RE:	YELENA REZNIKOVA	DOB:	30/12/1995	UR:	8028467

																					

														

														

														Thank you for referring Ms Reznikova.
I had the pleasure of reviewing her at the PA Hospital Cardiology Department today.
Yelena is a 27-year-old Junior Doctor who is currently working at TPCH.
I understand the reason for her referral is due to her symptoms of postural tachycardia and also symptoms of postural hypertension.
Yelena reports that she has had these symptoms for some time.
She sometimes feels presyncopal and sometimes palpitations with her symptoms.
She tells me that she does monitor this at times and notes that her heart rate can go from 80bpm with a postural increase of about 30.
She tells me that sometimes it is worse and postural increase is up to 40 or more.
She tells me that she can walk some distances without significant difficulties.
Her past medical history is significant for previous obesity resulting in gastric sleeve surgery.
With significant weight loss she also further had anorexia and she went from 185 kilograms to only 39 kilograms in a matter of 9 months.
She reports that related to her weight her metabolic disturbance and had cardiac arrest at one stage.
She tells me that in more recent years, her weight has been stable.
She reports that she has a history of ADHD and PTSD.
She currently takes Dexamphetamine and Clonidine.
She Clonidine at night 100 or 200mcg and has been doing so for about a year.
Yelena tells me that she has previous used Beta blockers related to her weight in Russia in the distant past.
She does not smoke and does not drink alcohol.

On examination today, her heart rate was 102bpm and her blood pressure was 100/6mmHg, heart sounds were dual with no murmurs, her chest was clear, JVP was not elevated and there was no peripheral oedema.
There was no significant postural change in her blood pressure today.
ECG today showed sinus tachycardia with 102bpm.
On further questioning, Yelena reports that she does not eat breakfast.
I feel that her symptoms of POTS / postural hypotension, could be reduced with better oral intake of sodium and fluids, especially early in the morning.
She does not avoid salt, and she definitely does not have heavy salt use at this stage.
She tells me that she does eat a lot of sugar free food.
I have advised her that she should eat breakfast every day.
I have also advised her to have at least 300 mls of extra fluids with her breakfast and to make herself well hydrated, especially in the early mornings.
I explained to her she should ideally be requiring to urinate by early afternoon.
At this stage, I do not think she requires any medications.
I will not start her on Ivabradine at this stage.
We also prefer not to use Beta blockers.
She tells me that she has a history of asthma.
Although I have not seen her echocardiogram report, she tells me that she did have a recent echocardiogram and it was normal.
I look forward to reviewing her again in 6 months.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Yaqub,





														RE:	ELISHA RICHTERS		DOB:	04/02/1979		UR:	920060

																					

														

														

														I share a Cardiology Clinic on Wednesday mornings with Cardiothoracic Surgeon, Dr Wing Lo.
He asked me to look at Elisha’s angiogram pictures, after she was referred from Ipswich Hospital to our Cardiothoracic Surgeons for consideration of bypass surgery.

Dr Lo had pretty serious reservations about Elisha’s candidacy for bypass surgery, including the fact that LAD does not look graftable as well as her smoking and COPD, body habitus and general young age.
I thought it was worthwhile trying a PCI approach to her LAD.
It is a pretty short segment chronic total occlusion, which leads into an LAD diagonal bifurcation.
The vessel looks very small and underfilled (part of the reason it is not graftable), but it may well plump up after balloon dilatation and intracoronary nitro-glycerine.
It would need to pump up to about 2mm or more, to be able to take a stent.
Hopefully then we would be able to provisionally stent the LAD and leave the small diagonal alone.
I explained this approach to Elisha and her mum today.
We discussed Dr Lo and my collective opinions on the options of bypass surgery versus stenting.
We also discussed the role of Clopidogrel.
I gave her a script for it today.
She has several cortisone injections coming up in the next few weeks on her trigger fingers, shoulder and possibly some more injection on her spine.
I have suggested she all of these dealt with in the next 2 weeks and start Clopidogrel after this.
She would then need to be on the Clopidogrel for at least a week before we do the stenting.
That would take us through to about late February which probably fits with out waiting list anyway.
She is happy with this, so we will proceed.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Ali,





														RE:	ELAINE ROBINSON		DOB:	20/12/1944		UR:	131328

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to catch up with Elaine in the clinic today.
Subsequent to my letter from 18 months ago, I noted multiple risk factors for coronary artery disease with previously normal echocardiogram, myocardial perfusion scan and respiratory function tests.
She had turned the corner last time I saw her and was actually doing really well and was well for a while before deteriorating again.
In September last year she had a presentation to the QEII Hospital after being retrieved from the Island waiting at the wharf for an ambulance and then finding that Redlands was on bypass.
Her total wait time before getting medical attention was 5 hours.
Pleasingly, her troponins were negative, and she was discharged from the QEII.
Since then, she tires easily.
She gets a wee bit of chest pain when she is walking, but nothing too pervasive.
Her main concerns were general weakness and some left shoulder and arm pain.
This pain radiates down her arm, but  mainly occurs when she is rotating her shoulder or wrist, for example, when getting dressed.
I think she is developing frozen shoulders.
I think this is a musculoskeletal issue or possible a radiculopathy from her previous neck problems but is not representative of unstable angina.
I recapped her history of iodine allergies.
It was genuine anaphylaxis which occurred about 30 years ago when having a kidney scan.
She has never had iodine since.
This, in conjunction with her chronic kidney disease (eGFR 30 to 35) makes me very reluctant to proceed to invasive coronary angiography.
She mentioned that she had a nuclear scan at Qld X-ray recently and I was able to look this up on my Qld X-ray App, noting that it was not in the electronic medical record here at the PA Hospital.
I note that it was performed on 17.11.2022 and showed no inducible ischaemia, nor any fixed scar on her heart.
I think this is pretty reassuring.
Examination today, revealed a blood pressure of 130/60mmHg and a heart rate of 68bpm and regular.
Heart sounds were dual with a fourth heart sound, the chest showed a view sparse crackles, and there was no peripheral oedema.
Finally, Elaine mentioned to me that she previous under the care of the Neurosurgeons for surveillance of a meningioma.
I looked into this and her last review was in 2019, with Dr Sarah Olson’s Team.
She was due to have one again in 2 years (2021) and I can only presume that this was missed in one of the COVID lockdowns.
I have re-referred her to Dr Olson’s Team and rebooked her a  non-contrast CT head here.
I have discussed with her the rationale behind not proceeding with any further invasive cardiac investigations at present.
I will see her again in 18 months.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Altawil,





														RE:	KEVIN ROWAN		DOB:	14/10/1956		UR:	859718

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to catch up with Kevin in the clinic today.
I last saw him about 18 months ago via phone consultation during a COVID lockdown.
About 6 months ago, it appears that he was admitted to the QEII Hospital ICU with acute pulmonary oedema.
Looking through the notes, his sodium on presentation was profoundly low at 16.
His troponins were negative, and his BNP was only mildly up.
Whilst he was in the intensive care unit, his care was complicated by a large rectus sheath haematoma which was managed conservatively.
This on top of his previous spinal haematoma whilst on Warfarin suggests that he does have some bleeding diathesis.
They got him an echocardiogram whilst he was in and I note that his ejection fraction was 55 to 60% with no significant valvular disease.
It appears that he was in quite slow atrial fibrillation at the time, with a ventricular response of only 48, although I am not quite sure what the context of this was.
After ICU, he was looked after by General Medicine.
I could not find any cardiology reviews, whilst he was an inpatient, noting that there are several cardiology teams at the QEII  Hospital.
Since discharge, he actually feels like he is going really well.
He is losing weight and going to the gym, anywhere from 3 to 6 times a week.
He mainly does cardio there, including the treadmill, cycling and rowing.
He feels good doing the exercise.
Examination today, revealed a blood pressure of 120/80mmHg and a heart rate of 80bpm in atrial fibrillation.
Venous pressure was not elevated, the heart sounds were dual, the chest was clear and there was no peripheral oedema.
In summary, Kevin was admitted to the QEII Hospital ICU about 6 months ago with profound hyponatraemia and possibly some pulmonary oedema.
His echocardiogram was normal.
His sodium levels are now normal, and his renal function is normal.
He is doing well on medical therapy.
You have currently got him on Verapamil, Hydralazine, Avapro HCT, Atorvastatin, Metformin, Gliclazide, Dapagliflozin, and Frusemide.
I will see him again in 1 year with a stress echocardiogram.

Yours sincerely,

														I reviewed this 60-year-old lady in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic with her husband today.

Issues:
1.

IHD
a. CTCA 3.6.2021 – CAC 52.1 (87th percentile); mLAD >50% stenosis due to calcified plaque (Degree of stenosis difficult to quantify due to blooming artefact); RCA <25% stenosis due to calcified plaques
b. DSE 15.6.2021 - Normal resting LV size and ejection fraction (LVEF by visual estimation >55%); Normal RV size and systolic function; No significant functional valvular abnormalities; Clinically, electrically and echocardiographically positive DSE for inducible ischemia in the LAD territory (Inducible hypokinesis of the mid anteroseptum, apical septum/anterior/inferior and apex)
c. Cath 30.7.2021 – LMCA mild irregularities; mLAD 80%; LCx and RCA mild irregularities; LVEF 65%; PCI to mLAD DES (YS); for 6/12 DAPT

Background:
1.

Hypertension; Hyperlipidaemia 
2.

Hypothyroidism (Previous thyroidectomy)
3.

GORD; Hepatomegaly and steatosis on CT 11.4.2018
4.

Ankylosing spondylitis; Under care of Rheumatology OPD PAH
5.

Degenerative disc disease lumbar spine
6.

Iron deficiency; UGI/LGI scopes 14.11.2019 – Gastric polyps; Normal colon
7.

Previous bilateral carpal tunnel and ulnar nerve release, breast lump excision,c/sections
8.

Previous seizure (Sri Lanka) 1970s - Nil recurrence, no formal diagnosis of epilepsy
9.

Non-smoker; Nil regular EtOH
10.

Nil known drug allergies
11.

From Sri Lanka; Oz since 1993; Lives with husband and 3 children; Previous teacher aide in special needs school
12.

Allergies – ISMN (Myalgia)

Medications:
Aspirin 100mg od
Metoprolol 50mg bd
Rosuvastatin 20mg od
T4 125mcg od
Perindopril 8mg od
Lercanidipine 10mg mane
Curcumin, Vit D, Probiotic
GTN s/L PRN 
Meloxicam PRN

														

														About 3 months ago she had 2 episodes of what sounds like angina.
They were 3 weeks apart, she developed central retrosternal chest tightness that radiated to her left upper arm, lasting 10 minutes.
She used her sublingual nitrates on both occasions, requiring 2 puffs with relief.
However, since then, they have much settled, and she gets the occasional little tightness once every 2 weeks.
On examination her blood pressure was 130/80mmHg, heart rate is 60bpm and regular, JVP was not elevated, and her chest was clear.

Assessment:

														It sounds like she may well have recurrence of some angina.

Plan:

I will organise a myocardial perfusion scan (she did not seem to tolerate the dobutamine stress echocardiogram previously) and see her here in 6 weeks.
If she get any bad pain, she needs to return to the hospital.
Thank you kindly for your continuing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dr Jordan Ross

														Cardiothoracic Department

														PA Hospital

														

														

														

														Dear Jordan,

														

														

														RE:	FERNANDO E SAN MARTIN	DOB:	09/05/1955	UR:	522480

																					

														

														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Severe bioprosthetic aortic valve stenosis (25mm Magna Ease 2012; Dr M Ura at PA Hospital).

Mean gradient 45mmHg

														NYHA II dyspnoea.

Mild left ventricular dysfunction (LVEF 45-50%)

														LVEF 30% at the time of initial AVR

														Minor coronary artery disease at coronary angiography in 2022 (Mater).

Other Diagnoses:

														Chronic lower abdominal / leg rash, not responsive to topical steroids.
Awaiting Dermatology review at Ipswich Hospital.
Probable hydrocoele awaiting review with Mater Urology Service.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily (commenced), Bisoprolol 5mg daily, Frusemide 20mg daily, Valsartan 1 daily (unsure of dose).
Thank  you for referring Fernando for consideration of TAVR for his bioprosthetic aortic valve stenosis.
Fernando is a 67-year-old male who underwent a bioprosthetic aortic valve replacement (25mm Magna Ease) with Dr Ura in 2012, at which time he had severe left dysfunction.
Correction of his aortic stenosis has led to recovery of his left ventricular function.
His acute post operative period was complicated by a pericardial effusion that was drained successfully.
Over the last 3 or 4 years he has noticed the insidious onset of exertional dyspnoea, which he feels is progressive.
He is limited to approximately 30 or so metres on the flat, but by the same token can walk 1 to 2 flights of stairs.
He does not suffer chest pain, nor any syncope.
He does not suffer orthopnoea and sleeps on 1 pillow.
Fernando lives with his wife.
He works full time at Australia Post packing in the city and is a non-smoker who rarely drinks alcohol.
He and his wife were planning to visit their son in England in the first half of this year.
His blood pressure was 124/77mmHg and his ECG shows sinus rhythm with a borderline left bundle branch block.
His PR interval is normal.
His heart sounds were dual with an ejection systolic murmur and mildly slow rising pulse.
His chest was clear, and he had minor peripheral oedema.
I note excoriations of his legs due to his chronic dermatitis and his left lower abdomen rash, for which you had provided clotrimazole cream earlier this week.
His echocardiogram shows mild segmental systolic dysfunction (LVEF 45-50%).
He has a dilated right ventricle with preserved systolic function.
He has severe prosthetic valve stenosis  (mean pressure gradient 45mmHg; DSI 0.19).
Fernando has preserved respiratory function on testing at the Mater Hospital in November.

Assessment and Plan:

														I agree that Fernando has severe bioprosthetic aortic valve stenosis which is symptomatic with class II dyspnoea.

The options of SAVR and TAVR were again discussed with Fernando, and the pertinent issues of coronary re-access and potential valve-in-valve procedures being heightened considerations given his younger age.
We will discuss Fernando’s case at our upcoming Heart Team Meeting and reach a consensus recommendation.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	IAN SANDERS	DOB:	20/09/1955		UR:	897652

																					

														

														

														I saw Ian in my clinic for follow up today.
Unfortunately, he developed acute gout and acute kidney injury secondary to dehydration 2 months after we started the Frusemide.
Consequently, he has not been on Frusemide for the last few months.
Since then, his peripheral oedema has worsened.
His repeat echocardiogram showed preserved LVEF.
His background is significant for ischaemic heart disease with previous inferior STEMI in February 2018, hypertension, obesity and chronic renal failure (baseline eGFR approximately 45-55 mL/min).

His current medications include Aspirin 100mg daily, Metoprolol 50mg BD, Amlodipine/Valsartan/Hydrochlorothiazide 10/320/25mg daily, Hydralazine 50mg BD and Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Allopurinol 300mg daily.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 80bpm regular and his blood pressure was 130/60mmHg.
There was severe bilateral pitting oedema to his knees.
Today, I have restarted the Frusemide 20mg daily.
I have also changed the Amlodipine / Valsartan / HCT to Valsartan / HCT 320/25mg daily in case the Amlodipine is contributing to the peripheral oedema.
Finally, I have increased the Metoprolol to 75mg bd.
I will see Ian again in February for follow up.
He will have a repeat blood test prior to his clinic appointment (pathology request form given).

Yours sincerely,

														As you know, you were seen in Cardiology Outpatient’s in July when we noted a history of chest pain.
The clinical suspicion was that this was not likely to be angina.
You went on to have a dobutamine stress echocardiogram on 14.09.2022 and this was a good result and did not suggest that there were blockages in the heart arteries.
I tried to call you today, but there was no answer, I left a message.
Under the clinical circumstance and with the negative stress test, I am happy to reassure you that there is no need for further investigations.
I would strongly suggest that you continue Aspirin along with your statin and lipid lowering therapy.
I do not see a need for you to continue Metoprolol unless there is some other reason to do so.
Thank you for involving us in your care.
Please follow up with your general practitioner, who we have copied in on this letter.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Chowdhury,





RE:	COLIN SANDS		DOB:	23/12/1968		UR:	939069

							



														Colin attended the heart failure titration clinic following a referral from Dr Peter Moore late last year.
Colin is known to me from previously.
As you know he has non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy with an initial LVEF 20-25% in 2009.
This had improved to 45% in December 2022.
He has coronary artery disease with moderate LAD and PDA disease and a severe 1st marginal disease.
He has previous alcohol excess.
He told me that he has minimal alcohol presently.
He has a history of schizophrenia, which is well controlled.
Other history includes reflux oesophagitis and Dyslipidaemia.
He smokes 50 rollies per day, and he is not contemplative about ceasing.
Colin told me that he is drinking about six litres of water per day.
He is thirsty all of the time.
He told me that when he is hot, he uses cold drinks to maintain his body temperature.
We had a long discussion about strategies that will aid him to decrease his fluid intake.
When he saw Dr Moore last, Colin’s Frusemide was increased, and Colin has increased it further to 80mg BD.
He felt that this had not improved the fluid retention.
He describes class III NYHA symptoms.
He told me that his exercise tolerance is about 20 metres.
He denies any orthopnoea or PND.
He does become lightheaded on standing.
He has had some presyncopal episodes recently.

Medications

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Ramipril increased to 5mg daily (Colin was not able to increase the dose after he saw Dr Moore as had not been to see you for prescription), Atorvastatin 40mg daily, Amisulpride 100mg bd, Tramadol 50mg bd, Pregabalin 150mg bd, Citalopram 40mg daily, Amitriptyline 50mg daily, Esomeprazole 20mg daily, Dutasteride 500mcg daily, Frusemide increased today to 80mg TDS, Spironolactone 25mg daily.
On examination his blood pressure was 110/60mmHg with no postural drop, heart rate 80bpm and regular.
There was moderate oedema present to just below his knees.
Heart sounds were dual, and chest was clear.

RE:	COLIN SANDS		DOB:	23/12/1968		UR:	939069

														

														

														

														Blood test on the 21st December 2022 showed iron deficiency with a total iron of 10, transferrin saturation 11 and ferritin of 10.
His Hb was 124.
His Na 138, K+ 4.5, Glu 5.5, Urea 7.9, and Creat 107.
I will discuss the iron results with Dr Moore and organise an iron infusion if required.
I have increased the Ramipril to 5mg mane, and I have provided a prescription for the same.
I have increased the Frusemide to 80mg TDS.
I have asked Colin to reduce the dose back to twice a day if his peripheral oedema improves and his light headedness worsens.
I will see him back in this clinic in four weeks with a blood test from Sullivan and Nicolaides just prior.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mark,





														RE:	CHRISTOPHER SAVAS	DOB:	23/02/1955	UR:	207329

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to catch up with Chris in the clinic today.
Believe it or not, he is now 2 ½ years post stenting to his LAD and left circumflex vessels.
We took some time preparing him for this, because of his history of recurrent GI bleeding from portal hypertensive gastropathy and varices.
We had a run-in period on dual antiplatelet therapy, got the stents in and got him through a couple of months of dual antiplatelet therapy before dropping off the Clopidogrel.
He has done remarkably well since from a cardiac perspective.
Whilst he was having daily angina beforehand, he has not had any problems since.
Unfortunately, he has continued to have recurrent GI bleeding.
I last saw him about 15 months ago and he has had quite a few attacks since then.
One of these involved a haemoglobin down to 47, which is obviously a life-threatening problem.
He has actually self-ceased the Aspirin for the last week.
I can understand where he is coming from.
Examination today revealed a blood pressure of 130/50mmHg and a heart rate of 60bpm and regular.
He had a soft pan systolic murmur, a clear chest and chronic peripheral oedema.
He is keen to stay off the Aspirin.
I wondered if we could get away with using Clopidogrel about 3 times a week.
Whilst it is potentially a slightly stronger blood thinner than Aspirin, at least it does not have as much GI irritation.
I have suggested he take it Monday, Wednesday and Friday.
If he continues to have problems or they get worse on the Clopidogrel, I think we will have not choice but to stop all his blood thinners and just accept that there is a risk.
The stents are 2 ½ years old now, so they should be well and truly endothelialised.
It is not ideal being on no antiplatelet drugs in the setting of coronary artery disease, it is potentially a necessary compromise.
I will see him again in 6 months.

Yours sincerely,

Medications:

														Citalopram 40mg, Clopidogrel 75mg, Lipitor 40mg daily, Vitamin B12 injections, Pregabalin 150mg twice a day, Ramipril  2.5mg daily, Thiamine 100mg daily and Oxybutynin 5mg PRN, Vitamin D 1 tablet daily.
Thank you very much for referring Susan to my Cardiology Clinic.
Susan is a delightful 68-year-old lady who attended the clinic with her husband.
She arrived in the clinic  on a wheelchair, because of her left sided hemiplegia from her previous ischaemic stroke.
Susan can mobilise with the help with a single point stick at home.
She has noticed no change in her exercise capacity.
She denied any excessive exertional dyspnoea.
She denied any syncope or presyncope.
She informs me that she has not experienced any rest or exertional chest pain.
She denied any symptoms suggestive of congestive cardiac failure.
She denied any palpitations.
As far as her background is concerned, she is a non-smoker.
She previously worked as a nurse.
She has previous consumed alcohol in moderation.
She has previously had a history of hypertension and dyslipidaemia.
She sustained an ischaemic CVA in 2014.
On examination today, she was comfortable at rest, her chest was clear, there was an ejection systolic murmur in the aortic area, which radiated across her precordium and also to carotids.
Her carotid pulse volume was moderately reduced.
Her blood pressure today was 120/80mmHg.
Her ECG today showed normal sinus rhythm, normal axis, no significant ST – T-wave changes.
There were poor R-waves in the anterior leads.
Her resting heart rate was 69bpm, her corrected QT was 444ms.
She also had loculated pericardial effusion on the inferolateral wall which has been there since 2014 but has gradually increased in size.
CT coronary angiogram would further evaluate this region.

Impression:

														Susan is a 68-year-old lady who has moderate aortic stenosis, based on an echocardiogram performed at the PA Hospital today.
Her aortic valve area was 1.1cm2, maximum mean gradient was only 22mmHg and dimensionless index was in the moderate range with DSI of 0.32.
Although she has experienced intermittent exertional dyspnoea, Susan feels that she has overall been progressing reasonably well.
Therefore, continued surveillance for her aortic stenosis is reasonable.
She will not be candidate for open heart surgery, therefore a transcatheter aortic valve replacement will be the only option.

I plan to catch up with her again in 6 months with a repeat echocardiogram and a CT coronary angiogram, which will not only evaluate her coronaries but also further evaluate her aortic valve from TAVR point of view.
She will also undergo CT TAVR along with her CTCA, in preparation for potential future transcatheter aortic valve replacement.
I will keep you updated of her progress.
I have not made any changes to her medications.

Yours sincerely,

														It was a pleasure to meet Erhard in the clinic face to face after doing a phone consultation this time last year.
He has been pretty stable from a cardiac perspective.
As you know, we see him for established coronary artery disease, with a coronary artery calcium score of 1897 and an ascending aorta of 47mm.
In the last year, he has used GTN about 3 to 4 times in the year.
His pain usually comes on at rest and GTN takes about 10 minutes to work.
Given his complex other medical history, I think this is a pretty good outcome, and indication that we should continue medical therapy and not pursue an invasive strategy.

There is a concern around a family history of Parkinson’s.

He does have bad knees and has had a few falls recently.
He has had the previous strokes, which could be contributing, but he also had a Parkinsonian like face.

I will see him again in 18 months.

														Dear Dr Jade ,





RE:	COLLEEN SCHEIWE		DOB:	23/03/1970		UR:	8108830

								

	



It was a pleasure to review Colleen today, 25.01.2023.
She is a 52-year-old lady who had a cardiac arrest on 04.08.2022.
She had 8 shocks at the scene with left ventricular fibrillation and was well resuscitated.

She had a prolonged QT post arrest, but subsequent ECGs were normal, and she had a secondary prevention ICD implanted on 11.08.2022, this was an uncomplicated procedure and she was discharged the next day.

Initially her ventricular function was impaired at 30% and a cardiac MRI demonstrated left ventricular ejection of 37%, no evidence of myocardial infiltration or scarring, mild aortic and mitral regurgitation and bilateral pleural effusions.
She had a fracture of her 2nd and 6th ribs due to the CPR.
She has a past history  of obstructive sleep apnoea and CPAP and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation which is untreated.
She quit smoking in hospital and does not partake of alcohol.
She had an echocardiogram performed subsequent to this on 02.11.2022, and the result is pleasing, it is improving, normal left ventricular size and mildly impaired systolic function.
Left ventricular ejection fraction of 46%, normal right ventricular size and systolic function, no significant valvular abnormalities.

She is currently medicated on Bicor 5mg orally BD, Atorvastatin 40mg nocte, Lasix 20mg daily, Panadol Osteo, Rivaroxaban 20mg orally daily, Salbutamol, Spironolactone 25mg orally daily, Targin 2.5 to 5mg PRN and Valsartan 80mg bd.
She has been extremely well managed, she is NYHA functional class I but she is limited by her left knee osteoarthritis.
She is waiting a left total knee replacement.
From the point of view of the general anaesthetic and surgery for her total knee replacement, she can proceed with this at 6 months after her cardiac arrest, which will be in early February.
Otherwise, she can return to work with full duties.
She is not however, to work for extended periods greater than 8 hours and not to lift weights heavier than 10 kg.
I have organised for her to be reviewed in 12 months with a transthoracic echocardiogram.
I would be happy to see her earlier should the need arise.
Many thanks for your ongoing care of this patient.

Yours sincerely,

Atrial flutter discovered following implantation of loop recorder.
Other risk factors include atherosclerotic disease in the left internal carotid artery.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
VT on recent loop recorder check.
For coronary angiogram.
If normal, for cardiac MRI.
For atrial flutter ablation.

I had a phone consultation with Crissi in view of the recent loop recorder transmission showing an episode of ventricular tachycardia that lasted for 10 seconds at a rate of 180 to 200bpm.
Crissi is not sure if she was symptomatic with that.
Crissi does complain of some chest pain, but this is quite inconsistent and the history was quite difficult take on phone consultation today.

In view of this I have referred her to Dr S Kyranis.
In the meanwhile, I have asked her to take Atenolol 25mg mane.
She will take Perindopril at night-time.
If her coronary angiogram does not show obstructive coronary artery disease, then I will organise a cardiac MRI for her.

														Dear Dr Naicker,





RE:	WOLFHARDT SCHREIBER		DOB:	04/12/1941	UR:	719446

								

	



It was a pleasure to review Wolfhardt in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know he is an 81-year-old gentleman.

His background is:

	Mild to moderate aortic stenosis.
Atrial fibrillation.
Pacemaker for high-grade AV block.
Ischaemic heart disease.
PCI to the mid LAD 2007.
PCI to the circumflex, OM1 and posterolateral RCA 1998.
Moderate in stent restenosis in the circumflex and posterolateral 2007.
Parkinson’s disease with frequent falls.
Type II diabetes.
Moderate bilateral ICA stenosis.
OSA.

Asthma

	Chronic subdural haematomas.
Wolfhardt attended with his daughter today.
He has continued to deteriorate over the last 12 months with frequent falls and weight loss.
He had an admission with a small bowel obstruction due to adhesions last year and suffered a stroke post operatively from which he apparently suffers no residual deficit.
He also had a fall in December where he fractured his sacrum and was admitted to TPCH, requiring a blood transfusion.
I note chronic subdural haematomas were noted on a CT during that admission.
His mobility generally continues to decline.
He uses a 4-wheel walker with one assist for very short distances but usually mobilises in the wheelchair.
From a cardiac point of view, he experiences no chest pain or palpitations.
His medications today were Rivaroxaban 15mg (to be changed to Aspirin 100mg), Verapamil 180mg, GTN patch 5mg (ongoing use under review), PPI and Stalevo.
On examination today, his pulse was 65bpm and irregular.
His blood pressure was 111/47mmHg.
He appeared very frail.
Heart sounds were dual with an ejection systolic murmur.
His chest was clear and he had some mild ankle oedema.
In summary, Wolfhardt is stable from a cardiac point of view but he continues to become more frail with frequent falls.
I had a discussion with him and daughter about the ongoing risks and benefits of anticoagulation, particularly in the setting of his falls and subdural haematomas.
I note his stroke risk is high but his risk of life threatening bleeding is becoming higher.
We have agreed to cease Rivaroxaban and start Aspirin 100mg daily.
His blood pressure was on the lower side today.
If this is persistently so, then I think it would be reasonable to cease his GTN patch to ensure hypertension does not contribute to any falls.
Wolfhardt and his daughter are very keen to attend ongoing reviews here and I will book a review in 12 months.

Please feel free to contact me with any concerns in the interim 



Yours sincerely,

														RE:	GEMMA EMILY SCHULTZ		DOB:	04/06/1995	UR:	2124985

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Gemma, a lovely 27-year-old female, I had the pleasure of reviewing in Dr Ahmad’s Electrophysiology Clinic today.

Her medical issues include:

														Recurrent palpitations.
Most likely due to PACs / atrial tachycardia.
48-hour Holter monitor showing premature atrial complexes, atrial bigeminy, and sinus tachycardia only.
Right bundle block and right posterior fascicular block with a low-normal systolic function.
Cardiac MRI performed in December 2021, showing an ejection fraction of 50% and a non-specific faint mid myocardial stripe in the basal septum and mild sub-epicardial enhancement in the lateral wall.
Recent diagnosis of ADHD.
Anxiety and depression.
No known cardiac family history.
Since last review, Gemma tells me that her palpitation burden has significant improved.
She certainly has not had any syncope or presyncope associated with these.
She tells me that she has been started on Vyvanse along with Bupropion for her ADHD and mood disorder.
She is also on medical cannabis.
On examination today, her blood pressure was 120/70mmHg.
Her chest was clear on auscultation and her heart sounds were dual with no murmurs.
Her ECG today was in sinus rhythm with premature atrial complexes.
Our impression today is that Gemma has symptomatic PACs with significant improvement in symptom burden.
Given that Gemma does not find her infrequent palpitations bothersome at all, we have not made any changes to her management.
We will catch up with her in 12 months via phone after a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram to assess her ejection fraction.
If her EF is stable, we will consider discharging her from our care at that point.
Thank you for your ongoing care and please do not hesitate in contacting us should you have any questions or concerns.
Please keep an eye on Gemma’s thyroid function test every 12 months.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Kemp,





														RE:	CRAIG WALTER SEYMOUR	DOB:	30/03/1966	UR:	038577

																					

														

														

														Thank you for allowing us to review Craig.
He is well known to me.
He is substantially obese (118 kilograms), with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
He has an ICD in situ.
He has had a previous alcohol septal ablation.
He has had a previous LAD stent.
He had repeat angiography in January of 2022, which showed that he did not have residual obstructive coronary disease.
He had a dobutamine stress echocardiogram in October of 2022, which showed no outflow tract gradient and no inducible wall motion abnormality.
Craig remains in atrial fibrillation which is poorly controlled.
He complains of exertional breathlessness, intermittent presyncope and tightness across his chest.
Physical examination shows that he is substantially obese, his blood pressure today was 166/104mmHg, with a heart rate between 90 and 110bpm in AF confirmed on ECG.
Craig has multifactorial breathlessness, he has poor cardiovascular fitness, obesity, moderate obstructive lung disease.
My recollection suggests that he has some form of diaphragmatic impairment as well.
From my point of view, we have excluded anything serious that we should be worried about and therefore I have reassured Craig and his wife.
The atrial fibrillation is not well controlled.
I think we should change his Sotalol over to Verapamil, as the Sotalol is not affording him any rhythm protection.
I have continued the Digoxin.
I have added a small dose of diuretic therapy as he will have a stiff heart with diastolic dysfunction.
Craig will have a Holter in 4 weeks, and we will see him in 6 weeks.
If his heart rate remains elevated across the 24-hour period, then we will consider either increasing his Verapamil or adding in a dose of Bisoprolol or Nebivolol at night.
The latter two would have less effect on his lungs than Sotalol.

If we can gain good rate control, I suspect will help with his breathlessness, but of course, unless he loses 20 to 30 kilograms, gets fitter and we remove all his other problems, he is always going to be impaired.
Thank you for involving me in his care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Vandeleur,





														RE:	GAEL SHADFORD		DOB:	03/09/1961		UR:	2235446

														

														Thank you for your letter regarding Gael Shadford.
As you know, Gael is a 61-year-old lady who lives alone.
She has a total of 6 children and is divorced.
She has a long-term history of hypertension and severe obstructive sleep apnoea.
Gael tells me that an elevated heart rate was reported in August 2018.
For about 4 to 5 years, she has been feeling relatively lethargic with reduced effort tolerance.
Atrial fibrillation was confirmed relatively recently on ECG.
I understand that since  your referral to our Cardiology Department, she has also been referred to Dr Latona, Cardiologist, for his management.
Today, Gael was overweight at 88 kg.
Her blood pressure was 140/80mmHg sitting, measurement with a large cuff.
There were no abnormal cardiac signs otherwise.
I understand that left ventricular size and function are normal.
Gael has been adherent to CPAP therapy for the last year.
It is quite possible that this lady has had atrial fibrillation continuously for 4 to 5 years.
If that is correct, then the ship has sailed regarding pursuit of enduring sinus rhythm in this lady.
However, Gael would like to undergo cardioversion, and I have made this arrangement for her here.
I have explained to her that it is likely that either sinus rhythm cannot be obtained thereby, or that atrial fibrillation will resume very soon afterwards.
Should that be the case, further pursuit of sinus rhythm would not be indicated, and her management could continue with Dr Latona.
Since her kidney function is normal, I have increased her dosage of Rivaroxaban to 20mg daily, for adequate stroke prophylaxis in the face of atrial fibrillation.

Yours sincerely,

														Dr Gus Mugwagwa

														Cardiologist

														Redland Hospital

														PO Box 585

														CLEVELAND QLD 4163

														

														

														

														Dear Gus,

														

														

														RE:	GRANT SHELDRAKE	DOB:	09/04/1965	UR:	2234907

																					

														

														

														Thank you very much for your referral.

Diagnoses:

														Long standing persistent atrial fibrillation.
Failed 2 cardioversions.
Asymptomatic.
For rate control strategy.
Hypertension.
Previous obesity.
Mild obstructive sleep apnoea.

Current Medications:

														Metoprolol 50mg BD (increased to 75mg BD), Perindopril 10mg daily, Xarelto 20mg daily, Amitriptyline.
It was a pleasure to review Grant in the Cardiology Arrhythmia Clinic.
He is a 57-year-old gentleman who presented along with his partner.
He has had atrial fibrillation for more than 2 years.
It was incidentally found during one of his shoulder surgeries.
He was completely asymptomatic, and he remains asymptomatic.
I understand he has had 2 cardioversions, one of them most definitely on Sotalol 80mg bd.
He initially maintained sinus rhythm for a few days but reverted back into atrial fibrillation.
It did not make any difference to his quality of life.
His risk factors for atrial fibrillation include previous obesity, he has lost 20 kilograms and is continuing to lose weight.
He had mild obstructive sleep apnoe, when he was bigger.
A repeat sleep study has not been required or done.
His major risk factor, which is unaddressed at the moment, is hypertension.
His blood pressure was 150/95mmHg in the clinic today.
He is on Perindopril 10mg daily.
I would assume that his thyroid function would have been checked, if not, I will ask Dr Baig to check that.
On examination today, he had no signs of heart failure.
His ECG done today showed atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of 90bpm.
I understand his echocardiogram has shown preserved LV systolic function.
In view of normal LV function and no symptoms of atrial fibrillation, I have suggested a rate-controlled strategy.
I have increased his Metoprolol to 50 mg BD, not only for a better rate control, but also to be able to improve his blood pressure control.
I do not think this will be enough to treat his hypertension, but I have asked him to check his blood pressure at home and take the readings to Dr Baig.
If his blood pressure continues to be high, I will ask Dr Baig to add on a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker e.g Lercanidipine.
He is committed to continue to lose weight.
He is an ex-smoker and does not drink alcohol except socially on the weekends.
Tighter blood pressure control would also be important to reduce the risk of cerebral haemorrhage in view of treatment with a DOAC.
I also understand that he has peripheral neuropathy, and I will Dr Baig to look into that and I will start with thyroid function and Vitamin B12, Folate and iron studies.
He should also be screened for diabetes.
I have discharged him from my regular follow up, but I would be happy to see him if there is a change in the clinic scenario.

Yours sincerely,

														Problems:

														Severe coronary artery disease with occluded LAD circumflex and severe RCA disease.
Initially in cardiogenic shock January 2022, with severe LV dysfunction, EF 15%.
Deemed too  high risk for revascularisation.
Improved on medical therapy with current EF 36% on 3D echocardiogram and minimal symptoms.
Prostatic hypertrophy.

Medications:

														Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Entresto 24/26mg 1 tablet BD, Rosuvastatin 20mg daily, Frusemide 40mg daily, Aspirin 100mg daily, Sitagliptin as prescribed.
Thomas returned for review to my clinic.
He is doing very well, functioning independently at home.
He has no symptoms.
In particularly he denies any chest pain, dyspnoea, palpitations or syncope.
On examination today, his weight was stable at 53 kilograms.
He was euvolaemic with a regular pulse at 57bpm and blood pressure at 105/68mmHg.
He had no clinical evidence of left or right ventricular failure.
His current echocardiogram shows normal LV volume with moderate LV systolic dysfunction, ejection fraction 36% on 3D echocardiogram.
I would be grateful if you could further titrate his Entresto and consider adding on SGLT2 inhibitor to his treatment.
I understand that he is due to see Dr M Ura in the clinic and I would be interested in his opinion.
From my perspective and based on the recent trial (REVIVE), I would leave him on optimal medical therapy only.
There are plans of performing a transurethral resection of his prostate.
I do not see any major contraindication providing the procedure is done under local anaesthetic and on Aspirin.
I will continue to see him in my clinic with another appointment within 6 months.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Hemming,

														

														

														RE:	TYLER SHEWARD-HUMBLER	DOB:	14/08/2000	UR:	2116262

																					

														

														

														Diagnoses:

														Eating disorder.
Recurrent syncope.
Likely vasovagal / nutritional.

Medications:

														Propranolol 40mg BD.
Thank you for referring Tyler for further assessment and management.
She is a 22-year-old woman who has had recurrent episodes of syncope.
They have often occurred in association with restriction of eating, though she has had some in association with heat.
On each occasion she will have some loss of consciousness and a rapid return to a normal level of consciousness.
She has been able to stabilise her eating and return to regular exercise and activity.
She is noticing steady gains in her effort tolerance with this.
She has had periods of sinus tachycardia also and has used Propranolol 40mg BD to good effect.
On examination her heart rate was 50bpm and regular and her blood pressure was 30/70mmHg.
Heart sounds were dual with no added sounds.
Tyler has had an echocardiogram at RBWH which confirmed normal left ventricular size and function and no valvular abnormalities.
Tyler’s symptoms would be consistent with nutritional cause or potentially a vasovagal event.
Features of inappropriate sinus tachycardia, though this is likely to settle with return to more regular exercise patterns at which stage she could wean her Propranolol.
I would be very happy to see her in the event recurrent concerns.

Yours sincerely,
