														Dear Dr Ranasinghe,

														

														

														RE:	GARY SHINKFIELD		DOB:	12/03/1958		UR:	278113

																					

														

														

														Background:

														1.
MPO-ANCA vasculitis with renal involvement.

a. Baseline creatinine with a peak creatinine of 320 in 2019.
b. MPO-ANCA 503; ANA 40, dSDNA 4, antiGBM negative.
c. Has completed three cycles of cyclophosphamide induction since April 2020.
Coronary artery disease.
a.

Previous NSTEMI in December 2019.
b. Repeat NSTEMI in January 2020.
c. Coronary angiogram in 2009 showing three vessel coronary artery disease – declined coronary artery bypass surgery at that stage.
d. On regular follow up with Cardiology Clinic – no ongoing angina, normal exercise tolerance.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Hypothyroidism

6.

Gout

7.

Peripheral vascular disease – bilateral claudication

8.
Osteopenia on BMD April 2020 – currently on Calcitriol.
Ex-smoker.

Medication:
Cyclophosphamide induction - 6 doses completed on 9/4/20
Azathioprine 100mg daily (since 26/5/20)
Prednisolone 5mg > start weaning in Aug 2021, currently 3mg (reduce to 2mg in 6 weeks)
Aspirin 100mg daily
Ticagrelor 90mg BD
Candesartan 16mg daily
Cholecalciferol 25mcg mane
ISMN 120mg daily
Levothyroxine 100mcg
Metoprolol 12.5mg BD
Pantoprazole 40mg daily
Resprim Forte 0.5 tablet daily
Rosuvastatin 20mg
Calcitriol 0.25mcg 3x/week
Aranesp 30mcg fortnightly
Amitriptyline 5-10mg
Vit B12 injection


														I had the pleasure of talking to Gary from the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
Gary has a long-standing history of MPO-ANCA vasculitis and coronary artery disease.
He has a known triple vessel disease, for which he was offered bypass surgery in 2009, however he has declined that.
Since then, he has had a further 2 events of non-STEMI in 2019 and 2020.
Since his last review, Gary seems to be doing reasonably well from the cardiac perspective.
There have been no episodes of chest pain or any other cardiac symptoms.
He has been on dual antiplatelets since 2019 and as per the last review in the Gastroenterology Clinic, it seems that he is awaiting an endoscopy to review his iron deficiency anaemia.
At this stage, he does not have any active GI bleeding.
Given is prior history of severe triple vessel disease and for bypass consideration, which never happened, I have not stopped is second antiplatelet.
His last echocardiogram from May 2022, has shown normal LV size with an ejection fraction of 60%.
The RV is of normal size and function.
There is no significant functional valvular abnormality, dilated aortic root 40mm ascending aorta 37mm.
I have booked him for a phone review in 6 months, but feel free to be in touch with us if there are any concerns in the interim.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr With,





														RE:	KENNETH N SIMPSON	DOB:	31/10/1944	UR:	2175972

																					

														

														

														I had the pleasure of meeting Kenneth, a 78-year-old functionally active gentleman in Dr Gould’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
Kenneth had a stroke event in March 2022, with MRI brain showing multi territory infarct, raising the possibility of cardioembolic phenomenon.
Subsequently he did have Holter monitoring twice, with no evidence of atrial fibrillation and hence was referred for an implantable loop recorder insertion.
He had an ILR done in October 2022 and within 1 month had a transmission of 5 hours of atrial fibrillation episode, on 21.12.2022 and hence was called in for review to the Cardiology Clinic.
Kenneth is otherwise a fit a healthy gentleman.
He denies any major medical background.
His current medications include Aspirin 100mg a day, Atorvastatin 80mg a day, Panadol PRN, and Rabeprazole 20mg once a day.
He appears well.
On examination his blood pressure was 130/80mmHg, heart sounds were dual with no murmur.
His ECG today was in sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 70bpm.
I could see that he had an echocardiogram documented in ieMR  which was done at SQ Cardiology, reporting a normal LV size and function with LA dilatation.
I do not have any formal echocardiogram report available for comment; hence I have organised one for his next review.
His CHA2DS2-VASc would be 4 given the age of 78 years and a history of stroke in the recent past.
Overall, it seems that Kenneth has been suffering from paroxysmal episodes of atrial fibrillation which could possibly be the trigger for his last episode of stroke.
At this stage, I have started him on Rivaroxaban 20mg once a day along with Metoprolol 12.5mg BD.
I have advised him to stop Aspirin.
He has a prior history of polyps and haemorrhoids, but currently there is no issue of active bleeding.
I have booked him for review in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic in 6 months with an echocardiogram prior.
Please continue with your ongoing care and feel free to contact us if you have any concerns in the interim.

Yours sincerely,

No ongoing symptoms of angina.
Hypertension.

Type II diabetes.

Current Medications:

														CoPlavix 75mg / 100mg daily, Lipitor 80mg daily to be changed to Rosuvastatin 40mg daily, Bicor 10mg daily, Perindopril / Amlodipine 10/5mg daily, Fenofibrate 145mg daily, Metformin extended release 2g daily, Empagliflozin 10mg daily, Eplerenone 25mg daily, Ivabradine 7.5mg twice daily, Pantoprazole 40mg daily, Ryzodeg and Dulaglutide as advised.
It was a pleasure to see Peter in the cardiology outpatient clinic.
From a cardiac standpoint, since his last review in November 2021, he has been well.
His exercise tolerance is normal and unchanged.
He has no symptoms of angina.
He is still carrying on with active work without any limitations.
I note that his serum cholesterol from the last lipid profile in August is still elevated with a total cholesterol of 5.7mmol/L and an LDL cholesterol of 2.7mmol/L.
He is currently on Lipitor 80mg daily, along with the Fenofibrate to help with triglyceride reduction.
This combination is not quite achieving the target.
My initial suggestion would be to change him to Rosuvastatin 40mg daily and recheck his lipids in 4 weeks.
If the total cholesterol and LDL are still elevated, I would recommend adding Ezetrol 10mg once daily to his current combination along with the Rosuvastatin.
As he is symptomatically well and no further intervention is needed, I have suggested we just do a short phone review for him in a 1 year.

His echocardiogram that was repeated in May last year as been fairly stable, his ejection fraction is still 50% with some limited regional wall motion abnormalities in the LAD distribution with just non transmural scarring.
His right heart function is normal.
I will keep you updated with his progress on the follow up phone consultation in 1 year.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Devika,





														RE:	IREEN SALINI SINGH	DOB:	17/02/1974	UR:	8093437

																					

														

														

														Diagnoses:
1.
Multifocal embolic stroke (right MCA, cerebella) September 2021.

- unclear if there is a PFO
      -- positive agitated saline test on TTE
      -- negative TOE for separation of septum or colour flow across interatrial septum
         --- negative agitated saline test on TOE
    - loop recorder implanted 22/11/22 to investigate for possible AF
2.
Post stroke seizures.

- known to PAH neurology
3.
Type II diabetes.

Medications:
aspirin 100mg daily, Levetiracetam 1g bd, Lacosamide 200mg bd, Citalopram 20mg once a day, Rosuvastatin 40mg nocte, Empagliflozin 25mg once a day, Metformin 1g bd, Lyrica 150mg nocte.
I had the pleasure of reviewing Irene Singh today in our cardiology outpatient clinic, accompanied by her carer.
She is known to this clinic for a history of multifocal embolic stroke, the cause of which is still unclear.
As you know, on routine transthoracic echocardiogram after her stroke in 2021, there was thought to be a positive agitated saline test on transthoracic echocardiogram.

This was followed up with a transoesophageal echocardiogram which did not show separation of the septum or colour flow across the interatrial septum and agitated saline test was negative at that time.

The discordant results between the transoesophageal and transthoracic echocardiogram where somewhat perplexing but led to concern about possible atrial fibrillation being the underlying cause of the multifocal embolic stroke.
Since then, the electrophysiology team at the PA Hospital implanted a loop recorder on 22nd November.
So far, no arrhythmias have been detected.
I note that she has just returned from New Zealand on the 16th from visiting her family.
She does regular exercise on a treadmill as part of her physiotherapy and rehabilitation post stroke.
She has not felt any palpitations, had any presyncopal episodes, or syncope.
One of the complications of the embolic stroke was post stroke seizures.
This occurs by way of focal seizures, with the last incident being on 04.04.2022.
She is being followed up by the neurology team at the PA Hospital who are carefully titrating her antiepileptic therapy based on serum drug levels.
On examination today, Irene appeared well.
She had a residual left arm deficit with a visible contracture.
She mobilised with a single point stick without any difficulties.
Her blood pressure was 100/80mmHg and her heart rate was 70bpm and regular.
In discussion with Dr Cox today, we have decided to place Irene on the wait list for a PFO closure in approximately 3 to 4 months.
This will allow for a total of 6 months of recording by the implantable loop recorder to assess for atrial fibrillation.

The ILR will be checked prior to proceeding with the procedure and if no atrial fibrillation has been captured since implant, we will proceed with probing the interatrial septum for a potential defect.
Should one be found, it will be closed at that time.

In preparation for the procedure, as well as her upcoming appointments with neurology and general medicine, I have arranged a repeat pathology panel today, which can be reviewed by the aforementioned teams during their reviews.
A copy of the results should also be forwarded to you for you records.
We will not make another clinic appointment at this time for Irene but will do so upon her discharge after the attempt at the PFO closure.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mrs Singh.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Eviston,

														

														RE:	KAREN SLATTER		DOB:	19/08/1962		UR:	871719

																					

														Thank you for your letter regarding Mrs Slatter.
Her brain MRI indicates 2 chronic lacunar infarcts, one in the left thalamus, and the other in the left cerebellum.
As you may know, lacunar infarcts result from occlusion of small penetrating end arteries, due to fibrinoid degeneration.
It is highly debatable as to whether lacunar infarction is associated with embolism.
Further, there exists no valid evidence that intervention for PFO or pursuit of atrial fibrillation is useful in the setting of lacunar infarction.
The evidence for such pursuit is clear when the infarct is clearly embolic in nature.
Accordingly, there will be little definite value in further cardiological investigation, according to the information which you have presented.

The patient does require assiduous attention to her cardiovascular risk factors including hypertension and hyperlipidaemia and thank you for forwarding her blood test results which indicate an LDL cholesterol of 3.15mmol/L.
You are best placed to manage these risk factors.
We will be happy to review Mrs Slatter should she develop a problem which is clearly related primarily to her heart.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	HAZEL JEAN SOLWAY	DOB:	09/04/1938	UR:	557381

																					

														

														

														Hazel came for an elective cardioversion for atrial fibrillation and associated cardiomyopathy with LV ejection fraction of 30%.
She has a pre-existing 1st degree AV block and a left bundle branch block.
She is on Apixaban 2.5mg BD, Bicor 2.5mg mane, Ramipril  1.25mg, Spironolactone 12.5mg.
She is on Madopar for her Parkinson’s.
She was in atrial fibrillation before the procedure.
I administered a single 200J synchronised DC which did not cardiovert her.

Subsequent 360 joules cardioverted her to sinus rhythm at a ventricular rate of 63bpm with a 1st degree AV block ( and pre-existing LBBB) with QRS duration of 130ms, QTc of 460ms and PR interval of 234ms.
I have asked her to continue taking all her medications and she will be seen in Dr Gould’s clinic in due course.

Yours sincerely,

														DC cardioversion was attempted today at the Princess Alexandra Hospital.
Deborah has a history of AL amyloidosis with cardiac involvement, in setting of myeloma.
Appropriate, continuous anticoagulation was confirmed.
She was on amiodarone 200mg/day.
ECG confirmed persistent atypical atrial flutter.
TOE excluded presence of left atrial thrombus.
DCCV was attempted on three occasions at 200J.
Brief sinus rhythm occurred after the third attempt, lasting ~30 seconds only.
Deborah remained in atrial flutter at end of case.
She will have ongoing follow-up with Dr Ahmad.

Yours sincerely,

														Dr J Kiss

														Condamine Medical Centre

														53 Wood Street

														WARWICK QLD 4370

														

														

														

														Dear Dr Kiss,

														

														

														RE:	BELINDA STANWAY		DOB:	18/09/1983		UR:	8111007

																					

														

														

														Belinda Stanway was reviewed in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
Her partner was also present for the consultation.
Her past history includes a non-STEMI in September of 2022.
She was transferred from Warwick Hospital to the PA Hospital and underwent subsequent angiography.
She was found to have a severe LAD lesion where she had PCI with a Xience Sierra 3.0x28 mm drug eluting stent.
Her other history includes a smoking history, hypertension and anxiety.
Unfortunately, she did not have her medication list with her today.
The discharge medications listed include Aspirin and Plavix, which she reports that she is taking.

Other medications that are listed include Atorvastatin, Fenofibrate, Ezetimibe, Metoprolol 50mg oral BD, Amlodipine 5mg nocte, Hydralazine 25mg mane and nocte, Perindopril 10mg mane, GTN 400mcg, Colgout, Sertraline and Seroquel.
Belinda reports that since her presentation to hospital, she has felt a bit apprehensive about her symptoms.
She gets intermittent symptoms of atypical chest pain.
She has not experienced any symptoms that were similar to her typical chest discomfort that she experienced prior to her presentation to hospital in September of 2022.
She reports that she required the use of intermittent doses of GTN which is now in a tablet form in view that she reports some light headedness with taking the spray.
There are some other medications which she is uncertain whether she is still taking, such as Colgout.
She reports that she also gets fatigue at times, and this can be at rest or when exerting.
Unfortunately, she is still smoking cigarettes, but she is working towards ceasing this.
This will be very helpful for her long term health and risk factor reduction.
On examination her heart rate was 65bpm and regular and her blood pressure was 100/65mmHg.
Her heart sounds were dual, and her chest was clear.
Her previous investigations from a cardiac perspective show an ejection fraction of 55% with normal LV function and normal LV size.
She had normal RV size and systolic function.
There was mild MR with a small mobile echo density noted on the anterior aspect of the mitral valve.
We had an extensive discussion about her presentation to hospital.
We spoke about the importance of adhering to the medical therapy as long as she can tolerate it.
We also discussed her efforts in  order to help cut back and cease her smoking.
We reviewed the coronary imaging and she saw how improved the appearance was after stent deployment.
Belinda was encouraged by the good results from the angiogram as well as her preserved ejection fraction of 55% after having a heart attack.
If you can please review Belinda in regard to her medications.
With regards to her tablets, if she is still on prescribed Colgout, that can please be stopped.

In view of her blood pressure, on examination today it was 100/65mmHg and she does report that at times on her measurements that she checks at home, she reports that her blood pressure is sometimes lower.
In view of that, Hydralazine 25mg tablet can be ceased as well.
She was advised that the Clopidogrel can be ceased on 26.09.2023 because that will be approximately 1 year since her presentation with myocardial infarction.
We will be looking at referring her for repeat transthoracic echocardiogram and follow up in clinic in approximately 10 months.
She was advised that if she experiences symptoms in the future that are concerning, that she is to seek medical review.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Severe degenerative mitral regurgitation (Carpentier type II).
Posterior leaflet probable fibroelastic deficiency with prolapse and flail leaflet tip.
Pulmonary hypertension.
Coronary artery disease.

Previous pulmonary embolism post varicose vein intervention

														

														

														Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Type II diabetes mellitus.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Other Conditions:

														Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
Physical frailty.
Previous bilateral varicose vein surgery.
Hiatus hernia with gastroesophageal reflux disease.
Allergic rhinitis with previous nasal septoplasty.
Bilateral breast implants.
Osteopenia.
Previous colonic polyps.

Medications:

														Metoprolol 50mg twice daily, Rosuvastatin 40mg daily, Pantoprazole 40mg daily, Frusemide 40mg once daily.
I reviewed Laraine again today.

Laraine wishes to proceed with transcatheter mitral valve repair.
We again discussed the potential benefits and risks.

														Review at PA Hospital Heart Team Meeting with view to proceeding with transcatheter mitral valve repair (TMVER) procedure.

														Dr Shane Preston

														Consultant Cardiologist

														Cairns Base Hospital 

														165 Esplanade 

														CAIRNS NORTH QLD 4870

														

														

														

														Dear Shane,

														

														

														RE:	MURPHY STELLA		DOB:	09/02/1950		UR:	2196248

																					

														

														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Early stenotic degeneration of bioprosthetic aortic valve replacement.
23mm Percival AVR in 2017 at Townsville Hospital.
Rapid increase in gradients in the last 12 to 24 months.
Possible subclinical leaflet thrombosis with commencement of DOAC on 12.01.2023.
Angiographically mild coronary artery atheroma.
Previous provoked deep venous thrombosis.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Dyslipidaemia.

Other Conditions:

														Osteoarthritis.
Osteoporosis.
Diverticular disease of the colon.

Medications:

														Rosuvastatin 10mg daily, Denosumab as directed, Apixaban 5mg twice daily (apixaban commenced on 12.01.2023).
I reviewed Stella Murphy today via telehealth link.
Her daughter Emma was also on the line via telephone hook up (Emma lives in New Zealand).
Stella has severe stenotic physiology of her suture less, surgical aortic valve replacement.
This seems to have occurred relatively rapidly over the last 12 months or so.
Stella has NYHA class II – III dyspnoea but no syncope or presyncope.
No angina.
She lives at home alone and is independent with activities of daily living.
Stella is a non-smoker and she does not drink alcohol.
I had a detailed discussion with Stella and  her daughter, regarding her situation.
I suggested in the first instance, I will need to review her CT imaging for which I will get the images transferred in the coming days.
Percival valve in most patients has a prohibitively high risk of coronary obstructive with TAVR, however this will develop entirely on the specific anatomy on CT assessment.

Given that Stella would seem to be an otherwise robust 72-year-old, it may be that redo aortic valve and aortic root surgery is a preferable option for her treatment, again this will depend on the CT assessment as well as obtaining an opinion from one of my cardiothoracic surgical colleagues.
Either way, I did discuss with Stella and her daughter that she was would be at higher-than-average risk of complications with either approach.

This could include a risk of up to 10% or more of significant complications that can include disabling stroke resulting in disability, blindness, inability to walk or talk, nursing home placement and death, a well as  major infection, permanent disability and demise.

We did discuss that a redo surgical procedure may be the more predictable and safer method of managing Stella’s situation, but this would carry the risks as discussed and the specific risk will be discussed in greater detail by my Cardiothoracic Surgical Colleagues.

We also discussed that with surgery it would likely be a larger procedure than her previous one with a more prolonged and slower recovery that may well take Stella up to 6 to 12 months to fully recover to baseline level of function, even in the absence of any procedural or periprocedural complications.
I discussed with them both, the role for a trial of DOAC therapy in the interval period while we are still assessing Stella’s situation.

I discussed with her and her daughter the introduction of apixaban, the small but real risk of bleeding, including life threatening bleeding into the bowel or brain, resulting in stroke or permanent disability and sometimes death.
I had a prescription emailed to the Nurse Coordinator at Cairns Hospital and asked Stella to commence the apixaban 5mg twice daily from today onward.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Review of CT imaging and multidisciplinary team review regarding best potential management strategy.

In the interim commence apixaban 5 mg twice daily and repeat a transthoracic echocardiogram in the first week of March 2023 to assess for any response to apixaban and potential underlying subclinical valve leaflet thrombosis.
We will stay in contact with Stella via out TAVR coordinator and we will update you following the above assessments and management planning meetings.
Comment: Subsequent CT reconstructions and image review confirm prohibitive risk of coronary occlusion with a standard TAVR procedure with any of the available prostheses.

Coronary protection with BASILICA and chimney snorkel stenting could be contemplated, but if cardiothoracic surgical assessment is that Stella is a reasonable candidate for re-do SAVR, then this would be the preferable treatment modality for her if her valve function does not improve with DOAC (plan for repeat TTE in first week of March 2023).

With kind regards,

														

														Yours sincerely,

I reviewed Helen Stephan today following correspondence that she had a hospital presentation with chest pain.

She has only required use of her sublingual nitro-glycerine once in the last couple of weeks.
She has had no prolonged or pathological palpitations, no syncope and no episodes of decompensated cardiac failure.
I discussed with Helen and her daughter (telehealth review today) regarding the potential management strategies.

														Dear Dr Trace,

														

														

														RE:	MICHAEL J. STEWART	DOB:	24/12/1962	UR:	380911

																					

														

														

														Thank you for referring Michael to my clinic for optimisation of heart failure treatment.

He is a 60-year-old gentleman with a background of ischaemic cardiomyopathy with previous CABG (LVEF 20% in 2022, medical therapy only), previous right thalamic haemorrhagic stroke secondary to uncontrolled hypertension (from non-compliance with medications), hypertension, type II diabetes, hypercholesterolaemia and obesity.
Michael is hemiplegic on his left side and is non-weight bearing since his stroke.
He lives in residential care.
Over the last few months, Michael denied any history of orthopnoea, PND, or angina.
He also denied any light headedness.

His current medications include Aspirin 100mg daily, Bisoprolol 10mg daily, Perindopril / Amlodipine 10/10mg daily, Hydralazine 25mg BD, Isosorbide Mononitrate 60mg daily, Nicorandil 10mg BD, Spironolactone 25mg daily, Frusemide 40mg daily, Atorvastatin / Ezetimibe 40/10mg daily, Empagliflozin / Metformin 5/1000mg BD, Sitagliptin 100mg daily, Insulin, Mirtazapine 45mg daily, and Melatonin 2mg nocte.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 70bpm regular and his blood pressure was 110/60mmHg.
ECG today showed sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 71bpm, left axis deviation, and poor R-wave progression anteriorly (PR 146ms, QRS 97ms, QTc 440ms).
Today, I have changed the Bisoprolol to Nebivolol 10mg daily as it tends to cause less hypotension.
In return, I have stopped the Perindopril / Amlodipine, and changed him over to Entresto 97/103mg BD with Amlodipine 10mg daily.
If he develops symptomatic hypotension, I would recommend either reducing his Hydralazine or Amlodipine dosages.
I will see Michael again in approximately 3 months for follow up.
Thank you for looking after Michael.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Quinn,





														RE:	NEVILLE STEWART		DOB:	27/04/1941		UR:	218143

																					

														

														Our pacemaker clinic has detected on the telemetry on Mr Stewart’s pacemaker a prolonged period of atrial flutter.
Neville told me about most of the problems which occurred in his life last year.

He fell onto his right hip and shoulder sustaining an inter trochanteric neck of femur fracture which required surgical repair and a right proximal surgical neck of humerus fracture which did not require repair.
Rehabilitation was prolonged.
He tells me that he developed a toenail infection which required a prolonged course of antibiotic therapy.
Incidentally, he was found to have a large infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm, for which surgery would carry risk much greater than benefit.
Neville is aware of this and accepting.
MGUS is also under review here.
At the moment Neville is living in a unit alone, although he is receiving a home care package.
He is awaiting modification to his bathroom via the Housing Commission.
Within his physical limitations, he does not seem  to have any cardiac symptoms at all.
Today, his blood pressure was 100/65mmHg sitting.
Clinically he had mild mitral valve regurgitation and an enlarged left ventricle.
The only sign of cardiac decompensation was modest lower limb oedema, to which Amlodipine may contribute.
Echocardiography indicates severe segmental systolic and diastolic impairment of his left ventricle with left ventricular ejection fraction now about 25%.
Left sided atrioventricular dys-synchrony and interventricular dyssynchrony coexist.
Examination of his pacemaker system today indicates normal function, and no recent atrial tachyarrhythmia.
I note that he has acquired Amiodarone.
Today I have stopped his Amlodipine, reduced his Perindopril to 4mg in the morning and added Bisoprolol at 1.25mg at night.
I have arranged a check his serum biochemistry including thyroid function, and a copy of these test results will come to you.
He will be reviewed in this clinic in about 2 weeks, for further titration of heart failure medications.
He will require ongoing 6 monthly checks of his biochemical liver and thyroid function on continuing Amiodarone therapy and I would be grateful for your help with this.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Kardooni,





														RE:	CATHERINE STONE		DOB:	6/04/1955		UR:	363627

																					

														

														

														Past Medical History:
# Breast cancer (left breast)
   - lumpectomy 2009 (Mater Hospital)
   - chemoradiotherapy with Herceptin
# Hypercholesterolaemia
# Large hiatus hernia with intrathoracic extension

Medications:
rosuvastatin 10mg daily, amitriptyline 10mg daily, pantoprazole 40mg daily

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Catherine Stone in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
Thank you for referring her for review of retrosternal chest pain in the setting of a known large hiatus hernia which is due for repair with the surgical team at Logan Hospital.
As you know, Catherine lives alone and is a retired Administration Officer.
She is an ex-smoker having quit in 1988.
She smoked approximately 17 years at approximately 10 cigarettes a day.
She does not drink alcohol.
From a family history perspective, Catherine tells me that her mother had an enlarged heart but was unclear of the underlying cause.
Her brother had a cardiac arrest, but Catherine was also unsure of the underlying cause of that episode.
With respect to Catherine’s symptoms, she experiences chest discomfort that she describes as crushing in nature.
These episodes occur when she is supine.

She has had 2 episodes of this chest discomfort, the first of which was after lunch and lasted 5 hours, despite taking Pantoprazole and the second episode was after having fallen asleep on the couch in a nearly flat position.
There is no exertional component to her chest discomfort.
She does not have paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea and only experiences shortness of breath in a supine position when she experiences chest discomfort.
She has occasional non-exertional dyspnoea, occurring sporadically.
Thank you for including the investigations that you have performed thus far.
These include a CT of her abdomen, done in October last year, showing a large hiatus hernia with an intra thoracic extension of the entire stomach.
She has also had a CT coronary calcium score of 32 done in October of last year.
The pathology panel done in June last year showed a total cholesterol level of 5.1, triglyceride level of 1.1, and an LDL level of 3.06, which was done on long term Rosuvastatin.
Her creatinine was 61 and her eGFR was greater than 90 ml/min/1.7m².
On examination today, Catherine appeared well and in good spirits.
Her blood pressure was 130/95mmHg and her heart rate was 96bpm and regular.
This corresponded with an ECG in sinus rhythm.
Her chest was clear, and her heart sounds were dual with no murmurs.
Her jugular venous pressure was not elevated, and she had no peripheral oedema.
Catherine was seen by Dr Korczyk in clinic today and we have advised her that her chest pain is unlikely to be cardiac in nature.
We have suggested that she should be able to proceed with the hernia repair as planned from a cardiac perspective.
We have suggested that she consider using an antacid (such as Mylanta / Gaviscon/ Tums, etc) if she were to experience repeat chest discomfort.
I would ask that you consider increasing her Rosuvastatin with a target LDL <1.8, from a primary prevention perspective.

At this time, we will not make another appointment to see Catherine in our clinic, but should her condition change or further cardiology input be required, please re-refer her to us for further input.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mrs Stone.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Hudson,

														

														

														RE:	CRAIG STOROR		DOB:	12/08/1974		UR:	585990

																					

														

														

														Craig Storor was reviewed via the Telehealth Outreach Clinic.
He had a presentation to the PA Hospital in August of 2022 with atypical chest pain and upper limb pain.
He has had a history of Wolff-Parkinson-White and had an ablation more than 10 years ago.
During his inpatient stay his troponin levels were negative.
He was noted on monitoring to have periods of non-sustained broad complex tachycardia that was asymptomatic.
He had a transthoracic echocardiogram in August 2022, that showed normal left ventricular size and systolic function with an ejection fraction of 55 to 60%.
He had normal right ventricular size and systolic function with no significant functional valvular abnormalities.
He had a CT aortogram that showed no evidence of aortic syndrome.
He had a coronary angiogram that showed a moderate left anterior descending artery disease, and minor coronary artery disese in the other vessels.
In conclusion, he had non-obstructive coronary artery disease for medical therapy.
During his inpatient stay, he was also reporting to have some joint pain and was commenced on gout therapy in the form of Allopurinol.
He was stabilised on medical therapy and discharged home.
He reports that he has been feeling since his discharge from hospital, he does not experience any chest pain.
He does report that he has been feeling very well.
Unfortunately, he reports that his cigarette consumption has increased.
He got to a point, where he was down to about 5 cigarettes a day but in the last month or so, it has increased back up to 15 cigarettes per day.
From a joint perspective, he was inquiring regarding adjustments to his medications for gout.
He was wondering if there could be an increase in his Allopurinol medication.
From a cardiac perspective, there does not appear to be any restriction to that, and he was encouraged to potentially increase his Allopurinol to 200mg oral daily.
If  you can please follow up in regard to that, that will be much appreciated.
His observations on examination via telehealth, was that his pulse was 63bpm, his respiration was 15, his blood pressure was 130/82mmHg and his oxygen saturation was 97% on room air.
His ECG showed sinus rhythm.
His medications include Aspirin 100mg oral daily, Atorvastatin 40mg daily, Metoprolol 50mg twice daily, and Allopurinol 100mg oral daily.
Craig had a presentation to hospital with atypical chest pain with normal troponins.
He had normal LV function on echocardiogram,  he had mild to moderate non-obstructive coronary artery disease on his coronary angiogram.
He has been stable on cardiac medications.
He has been advised to continue on his current cardiac medications.
If you could please follow up in regard to his joints, namely his gout, that would be appreciated.
He was advised that he can increase his Allopurinol to 200mg daily but if you could please follow up in regard to that and continue monitoring this that would be appreciated.
Please also consider rheumatology consultation if required.
From a cardiac perspective he does not require further follow up from the clinic in view that he is stable.
Please do not hesitate to re-refer him in the future if there are any concerns.

I have also encouraged him to reduce his cigarette smoking to help optimise his long-term cardiac health

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Tong,

														

														

														RE:	GEORGE STRZELECKI	DOB:	06/10/1955	UR:	156792

																					

														

														

														George was reviewed in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
His wife was also present for the consultation.
He has a past history of ischaemic heart disease, and he has been reviewed previously by my colleague, Dr A Camuglia.
His past history includes previous stents to the LAD and obtuse marginal in 2007, with subsequent LAD stenosis that required further PCI with a drug eluting stent in 2009.
He had PCI to the RCA and had FFR assessment of the LAD and left circumflex that was not haemodynamically significant.
He had a repeat angiogram in 2020, that showed patent stents with no significant epicardial stenosis on coronary angiography.
His other past history includes hypertension, dyslipidaemia, gout, and he is an ex-smoker.
His medications include Aspirin 100mg oral daily, Rosuvastatin 20mg oral daily, Ramipril  10mg oral daily, Atenolol 50mg, Nicorandil 10mg oral BD and Allopurinol.
His allergies include Duodart.
He currently works as an Audi Technician and lives at home with his wife.
George reports that he has been feeling well, but over the past 6 months, he has noticed intermittent chest pain on heavy exertion.
He reports that the symptoms are short in duration and subside when he takes a break.
This is in keeping with stable angina.
He sparingly uses his GTN spray.
He reports maybe he uses it approximately once per month.
He notes that since commencing Nicorandil, he has noted an improvement in his symptoms.
On examination his heart rate was 60bpm and his blood pressure was 150/90mmHg.
His heart sounds were dual, and his chest was clear.
There was no lower limb oedema.
His ECG shows sinus bradycardia, heart rate of 53bpm.
He underwent an exercise stress echocardiogram 30.11.2022 at Logan Heart Centre.
The conclusion of that is symptomatically positive and electrically equivocal submaximal stress test.
There were no regional wall motion abnormalities on the resting echocardiogram.
There were no regional wall motion abnormalities on the stress echocardiogram.
The stress echocardiogram was negative for inducible ischaemia at a submaximal heart rate (79%) of maximum predicted heart rate.
The stress test had equivocal findings in view of the submaximal heart rate.
George has a history of stable angina for which he has minimal GTN spray, and he has an equivocal stress test.
He has been advised to increase his Nicorandil to 20mg oral bd.
To help assess the progress of ischaemic heart disease, he will be referred for an outpatient myocardial perfusion scan.
He will then be reviewed in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic in approximately 4 months to assess his progress and the findings of the investigations.
He has been advised in the interim, that if he experiences chest pain that is not responsive to the GTN spray and he is concerned, to seek medical review.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dr Fraser

														Primary Medical & Dental

														2-10 Grand Plaza Drive

														BROWNS PLAINS QLD 4118

														

														

														

														Dear Dr Fraser, 

														

														

														RE:	NORMAN SURMAN		DOB:	02/10/1937		UR:	718031

																					

														

														

														Issues:
# Permanent atrial fibrillation
   - on Sotalol and Rivaroxaban
   - complicated by large iliacus haematoma - admitted to Logan Hospital in October

														     2022
  - CHADS-VA 4
# Ischaemic heart disease
   - previous intervention to circumflex and RCA 2014.

# Normal LV systolic function (LVEF 60-65% 2019)
# Arterial hypertension with suboptimal control.
# Previous admission with ?
vasovagal syncope.

Medications:
rivaroxaban 20mg daily, perindopril/amlodipine 10/5mg mane, sotalol 80mg mane, 40mg nocte (stopped today), atenolol 25mg daily (started today), atorvastatin 40mg nocte, esomeprazole 20mg nocte, GTN spray PRN

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Norman Surman today in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic, accompanied by his wife.
He was previously known to this clinic for atrial fibrillation on the background of ischaemia heart disease, but this is a new referral to the clinic after he was discharged.
He was referred to us after a recent admission to the Logan Hospital for an iliacus haematoma, during which his Rivaroxaban was discontinued for a short period of time.
Norman tells me that his haematoma symptoms have resolved and that he has resumed taking Rivaroxaban without any complications so far.
From a cardiac perspective, Norman has not had any symptoms.
He denies any presyncope, syncope, chest pain, or overall chest discomfort.
He also denies any orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea.
As you know, Norman is still quite active, caring for his wife, and maintaining his driver’s license.
I understand that his bilateral severe knee osteoarthritis has resulted in him requiring a 4-wheel walker to mobilise, as well as a handicap permit for parking.
His most recent transthoracic echocardiogram was in 2019, showing a normal left ventricular size and ejection fraction.
His ejection fraction was estimated at ~60 to 65% at that time.
There was also a normal right ventricular size and systolic function.
There was mild mitral regurgitation and mild tricuspid regurgitation at that time.
His left atrium was severely dilated in that study, showing a left atrial volume index of 60ml/m².

As Norman is now in permanent atrial fibrillation, in addition to his severely dilated left atrium, the use of an antiarrhythmic – Sotalol – is unlikely to add further benefit on top of rate control alone.
Therefore, when Norman was seen by Dr Korczyk in clinic today, we have recommended that he stop his Sotalol and replace it with Atenolol 25mg daily.
I ask that you please monitor his heart rate after starting this medication and titrate his Atenolol accordingly to maintain his heart rate at 100bpm or below.
Furthermore, I would ask that you please continue to monitor his renal function on a regular basis.
Should his renal function decrease, please consider whether of the dosages of his medications require adjustment.
On examination today, Norman appeared well and in good spirits.
As mentioned, he was mobilising with a 4-wheel walker due to his bilateral knee arthritis.
His blood pressure was 140/80mmHg and his heart rate was irregularly irregular with a rate between 90 and 100bpm.
This corresponded with atrial fibrillation on ECG at a rate of ~89bpm and a QTc of 485ms.
His chest was clear, and his heart sounds were dual with no murmur.
There was no peripheral oedema.
As Norman has remained stable on therapy over a prolonged period of time, we will discharge him from our clinic at this time.
However, should his condition change, please re-refer him to us for further review.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Surman.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	EUNICE SWEET		DOB:	09/09/1926		UR:	597618

																					

														

														

														Issues:

														Permanent pacemaker 2018, inserted in Tasmania

														Ischaemic heart disease.
Myocardial infarction 2012.
Previously normal ejection fraction was mild MR and mild AR 2018.

Other Background History:

														Osteoporosis.
COPD.

Osteoarthritis

														Cognitive impairment.

Current Medications:

														Aspirin 100m, Alendronate, Hiprex, a Vitamin tablet.
I had the pleasure of seeing Eunice alongside her daughter today.
Eunice is a lovely lady who moved from Tasmania a couple of years back.
She had a pacemaker inserted back in Tasmania and has been followed up from a device perspective, in our pacemaker clinic since the move.
She was seen once in the QE II Hospital Cardiology Clinic after she  moved.
She has effectively been asymptomatic and is travelling otherwise well.
She was brought into this clinic as VT was detected on her device twice in the last 18 or so months.
There was an episode on 19.10.2021 and an episode on 28.05.2022.
These are both asymptomatic as far as Eunice recalls.
There has certainly been no syncope that her daughter reports, nor is there any chest pain, shortness of breath or any other significant concern.
Eunice does seem to have some minor memory impairment, but otherwise is pretty good.
Her blood pressure today was 105/70mmHg, she was euvolaemic, heart sounds were dual.
Her ECG shows paced rhythm.

Plan:

														I have given her a script for Metoprolol 25mg bd.
If this does not cause dizziness or significant symptoms, related to low blood pressure, could you please increase this to 50mg bd.
Could you please do some bloods including full blood count, urea and electrolytes and thyroid function tests.
If there are further events detected, then I would consider adding Amiodarone.
We will continue to follow her up via the device clinic, as she is completely asymptomatic and If we detect any significant abnormal rhythms, we will bring her in for further assessment.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Su,





														RE:	DANIEL TAHURIORANGI		DOB:	09/07/1959	UR:	869473

																					

														

														

														Past Medical History:
# Atrial Septal Defect (July 2021)
   a.

Left to right shunt
   b.

Picked up alongside TIA
   c. ASD closure - 03/11/2021.
Femoral approach.

Proceduralist - Dr Stephen Cox
   d. Follow up TTE (May 2022): Negative bubble study.

Dilated right ventricle with

														       preserved systolic function.

e. periprocedural AF - not unexpected in first 6 months of device implant - no 

														       ongoing need for anticoagulation
# Transient Ischaemic Attack (July 2021)
# Lacunar infarcts
   a.

Old left middle cerebral artery territory and bilateral PICA-territory infarctions


														Medications: none

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Daniel Tahuriorangi in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
He is known to this clinic from the perspective of the atrial septal defect that was initially detected on investigation of a transient ischaemic attack and ultimately closed in November 2021.

Daniel has had the routine 6 month follow up transthoracic echocardiogram in May 2002, which showed a negative bubble study, but a dilated right ventricle with preserved systolic function was detected.

As a result, Daniel was meant to have a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram today, but unfortunately Daniel missed the appointment, not realising that he had the booking for the TTE prior to clinic  

														

														With respect to Daniel’s progress since the last clinic review, Daniel tells me that he has gone back to doing his usual activity prior to the ASD closure.
More specifically, he has returned to the gym, doing 1 hour of circuit training, involving both resistance training and boxing every other day.
He is not limited by dyspnoea and experiences no chest discomfort during these sessions.
He also denies any orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea during times of rest.
On examination today, Daniel appeared fit, well, and in good spirits.
His blood pressure was 110/70mmHg and his heart rate was 68bpm and regular, corresponding with an ECG in sinus rhythm.
I noticed in the documentation available on the electronic medical record, that it was though that Daniel had paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
His episode of atrial fibrillation was in the setting of the recent implantation of the ASD closure device.
It is not unexpected to have precipitated atrial fibrillation during the initial 6 months.
Daniel tells me that he has had no further palpitations clinically, and therefore does not require ongoing anticoagulation.
However, though Daniel has discontinued all medications, I have asked Daniel to restart Aspirin 100mg daily, and to continue this lifelong.
Given Daniel’s clinic improvement, I will ensure that he has his appointment for a transthoracic echocardiogram rescheduled in the next few months to monitor his right heart progress.
He may require further therapy if his right ventricle does not normalise.
I will also arrange for Daniel to have a clinic review in 12 months to review both his clinic progress and the result of the transthoracic echocardiogram.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Tahuriorangi.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Mirlohi,





														RE:	SUZANNA TAL		DOB:	08/02/1968		UR:	424210

																					

														

														

														Suzanna came in for review today.
She describes worsening angina in the last few months, where she is having to use her GTN spray 2 to 3 times a day.
She describes a central pressure that goes into her jaw and left arm which is consistent with her previous reports of angina.
She had made some significant improvements in her mental health and her relationship to food and she has lost some weight.
She is on maximal anginal therapy, and dual antiplatelet therapy.
Her LDL is 1.9mmol/L on Repatha and Ezetimibe which is excellent.
Her HbA1c has come right down to 6.8% which is fantastic.
I have no concerns that she not compliant with her medications.
She is aware that she has severe side branch disease that is for medical therapy on her angiogram in 2020.

Her recent dobutamine stress echocardiogram was negative for inducible ischaemia, however, the peak stress pictures were challenging with suboptimal endocardial visualisation and it was reported that other modality of coronary assessment should be considered if clinically relevant.
Today we have discussed extensively management going forward.
Given Suzanna’s recurrent angina, it is worthwhile repeating her invasive coronary angiogram, to mainly reassess the status of her previous coronary stents which had some ISR on 2020 angiogram.
She is aware that a coronary angiogram will not treat her angina unless of course there is significant disease in one of her major epicardial coronary arteries amenable to PCI.
She also realizes that  a repeat angiogram may not add additional information than what we already know about her side branch disease.

She has weighed the balances of risks and benefits and she is really interested in having another angiogram, more for her reassurance as well as to rule out any significant epicardial coronary disease.
I have discussed this with Dr Gould, and we have decided to proceed with booking her an angiogram with Dr Connors and I have consented her for the procedure.
We will review her after her angiogram.
I have asked her to continued taking all her tablets and she is getting a Webster Pack made up, which will be helpful.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Toe,

														

														

														RE:	JOHN TAREI		DOB:	24/11/1954		UR:	2184767

																					

														

														

														Thank you very much for your referral.

Diagnoses:

														Permanent pacemaker implant in New Zealand (?4 years ago).
Recent device interrogation showed atrial fibrillate and flutter.
Not on anticoagulation.
For anticoagulation commencement by GP.
Stroke.
Type II diabetes mellitus.
Ex-smoker.
Current Medications:  (As per GP letter).
Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Clopidogrel 75mg daily, Galvumet 50/1000mg BD.
It was a pleasure to review John in the Cardiology Arrhythmia Clinic.
I understand he has had a pacemaker implanted about 4 years ago in New Zealand for presyncopal and possibly a syncopal episode.
This was in the context of after he had a stroke.
He is sure that this was not a haemorrhagic stroke.
Further details are not available.
He has a history of type II diabetes mellitus.
He confirmed there is no history of hypertension.
He is an ex-smoker 4 years ago and he used to drink alcohol quite heavily as well, but since his stroke, he has abstained from alcohol.
He is not aware if he has had an echocardiogram done the past.
From the cardiovascular symptom point of view, John is completely asymptomatic.
He does not have any exertional angina / dyspnoea, orthopnoea, PND or peripheral oedema.
He also does not complain of any palpitations.
A recent pacemaker interrogation has shown atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter.
When the device clinic asked him about the symptoms, his response was positive, although today, he said he has been completely asymptomatic.
On examination today there were no signs of heart failure.
His pacemaker site looks fine.
He is almost 100% paced in RA and RV.
His ECG performed today showed AV paced rhythm.
I have discussed with John in view of his previous history of stroke, type II diabetes and hence a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 3, to consider anticoagulation.
I do not have his renal function at hand and if his renal function allows, I would ask  you to start him on a DOAC of your choice.
His Clopidogrel should be stopped.
He confirms that it was started after he had the stroke.
In the clinic today, his blood pressure was at 120/80mmHg.
He will come back in 3 months after he has had an echocardiogram done to exclude any structural heart disease.
If his echocardiogram is normal, as he is otherwise asymptomatic, I will discharge him from my clinic.
If he later on becomes symptomatic from atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter, then you could start him on a  small dose of Metoprolol and titrate it up.
I would also appreciate it if you could check his thyroid function.

Yours sincerely,

														It was a pleasure to review Radhwan in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know he is a 51-year-old gentleman.

He has a history of:

														Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.
Initially diagnosed July 2022 when presented with AF with RVR in the settling of a likely viral upper respiratory tract infection.
LVEF ~30%.
Atrial fibrillation.
Recurrent after acutely successful cardioversion 2022.
Awaiting repeat DCCV on Amiodarone.
Hypertension.
Type II diabetes.
Reactive airways disease.
Obesity.
Radhwan’s current medications include Rivaroxaban 20mg, Amiodarone 200mg, Bisoprolol 7.5mg, Entresto 49/51mg BD, Empagliflozin 10mg, Frusemide 40mg BD, Metformin and Gliclazide.

Radhwan will have some bloods and I will give him a call in the next week or two.
If they are acceptable, then we will likely start Spironolactone and may be able to up titrate the Entresto as well.

Dear Jill,





														RE:	DEIDRE ANNA TAYLOR	DOB:	13/04/1969	UR:	115783

																					

														

														

														Many thanks for asking me to see Deidre in the clinic today.
She is previously known to my colleague Dr Cameron Booth, but it appears they had a breakdown in their therapeutic relationship.
Deidre has a long family history of coronary artery disease.
She had some left circumflex stents in April 2021 and at the time had  50% LAD and a 60% RCA lesion as well.
She told me that the Cardiologist doing this procedure, told her they were both long lesions and for a while it was looking like she might need bypass surgery.
This is important to consider, 2 years down the track, thinking about what these lesions might be like now.
Deidre felt amazing for the first month or two after the stents, and then the chest pain started to return.
It initially settled with GTN but over the ensuing months she needed significant up titrations in her GTN, and the pains continued to escalate.
She is now on very large doses of both Isosorbide Mononitrate and GTN patches and previous attempts to modify her medication regime have been unsuccessful.
She also tolerates Beta blockers quit poorly.
As it stands at the moment, she describes using GTN 2 to 3 sprays once a week.
In addition to actual anginal type chest pains, she gets an internal sensation, possibly an uneasiness or discomfort, anywhere from twice a day to once a week.
Finally, she also has cold sweats about 20 times a day.
She is currently on Aspirin, Atorvastatin 80mg, Isosorbide Mononitrate 180mg and a GTN patch and Vasocardol.
Examination today, revealed a blood pressure of 140/70mmHg, a heart rate of 60bpm and no signs of cardiac failure.
I note that she had an exercise stress echocardiogram in November 2021, which did not show any inducible ischaemia.
It is now almost 2 years since her stent, and she has pretty refractory symptoms.
I do not think we are going have a clear path to reviewing her medical therapy and getting better confidence without a repeat coronary angiogram.
I have discussed this with Deidre today and explained the risks.
She is on board with this.
I will book the angiogram in the coming weeks and let you know the results.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Smith,





														RE:	MICHAEL JOHN TAYLOR	DOB:	01/03/1961	UR:	628594

																					

														

														

														I reviewed this 61-year-old gentleman with his wife today in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
He was an urgent referral from Vascular Surgery.
He has an AAA that requires an open repair currently booked for 30.01.2023.
He had a preoperative work up with a myocardial perfusion scan on 22.12.2022, that reported a small area of mild reversibility in the apical inferior segment.
Importantly he had no preceding angina prior to his AAA being diagnosed in November 2022.
He has also since had a CT coronary angiogram  on 19.01.2023 that showed a 50 to 69% proximal LAD stenosis and a distal RCA severe stenosis.

Issues:
1.

Presumed CAD/IHD
    a. MPS 22.12.2022 – No CP or ECG changes; Small area of mild reversibility in 

														        the apical inferior segment consistent with reduced coronary flow reserve.

Normal systolic function
    b. TTE 23.11.2022 – Normal LV size with LVEF 60%; Normal RV size and systolic 

														        function; No significant functional valvular abnormalities
    c. CTCA 19.1.2023 (PACS – TM/AD); CAC 480.7 (89th centile); LMCA no 

														        significant stenosis; pLAD (proximal to D1) 50-69%(moderate), pD1 25-49%; 

														        LCx no significant stenosis; pRCA 1-24%, dRCA 70-99% (severe)
2.

Incidental 5.7cm infrarenal AAA on CT chest – Not ideal for EVAR; For open AAA 

														    repair 30.1.2023
    a. CTA 25.11.2022 – 5.7x5.5cm infrarenal AAA
3.

Sinus bradycardia – Not on B-Blocker

Background:
1.

Multiple cavernoma syndrome – Under PAH Neurosurgery; Will require clearance 

														    if DAPT required 
2.

Hypertension
3.

Hyperlipidaemia
4.

COAD; Ex-smoker - Ceased 11.2022
5.

Father MI in 30s - Has had PCI/CABG
6.

NKDA
7.

Was working (until AA diagnosis) as security system/cable installer, Lives with 

														    wife; 2 children (40 and 31yoa)

Medications:
Aspirin 100mg od (Commenced 6.1.2023)
Perindopril 10mg od
Rosuvastatin 40mg nocte

														 

														As I mentioned above, prior to his AAA being diagnosed, he was very physically active at work.
He would be able to work up to 5 hours continuously, with no limiting symptoms whatsoever.
Obviously, he has now stopped since the AAA was picked up as a precaution.
Importantly he does not describe any angina, and this has been documented on repeated assessments in the last few months.
He did mention some shortness of breath when he pushed himself at work but on a regular basis has no limiting dyspnoea.
He has noticed some mild light headedness in the last couple of days, but no palpitations or syncope.
On examination his blood pressure was 125/80mmHg, with no postural drop.
His heart rate was 54bpm and regular, JVP was not elevated,  heart sounds dual with a soft ejection systolic murmur at the base and his chest was clear.
ECG shows sinus bradycardia 56bpm.

Assessment:

														He has a AAA that requires urgent surgery.

What is prognostically in his favour is that he has no significant left main coronary artery disease on CTCA (although he does have a moderate proximal LAD and severe distal right coronary artery lesions), only a small (1 segment) aera of ischaemia on the myocardial perfusion scan, no angina or other refractory symptoms, and normal left ventricular ejection fraction.

By definition he has coronary artery disease (chronic coronary syndrome) and unfortunately will be at an increase of a perioperative cardiac event, but the current evidence does not support prophylactic revascularisation to prevent this or long term outcomes.
Further to this, revascularisation will also delay surgery (PCI will require uninterrupted dual antiplatelet therapy and CABG will also require time for the sternum to heal).

Plan:

														I have explained all of the above in detail to both Michael and his wife and they understand.
I have answered all their questions.

Optimal medical therapy with Aspirin,  Statin and ongoing ACE inhibitor use is ideal and from my perspective, he should proceed with surgery, but with the understanding that a perioperative cardiac event is possible.
I have added in a 5mg topical nitrate patch.
I have counselled him regarding hypotension.
The nitrate can be ceased peri procedure to avoid hypotension and recommence post op when stable.
I would have preferred a Beta blocker, but unfortunately on account of his sinus bradycardia and risk of worsening this with up coming surgery, would not have been ideal.
I would suggest that he has post operative monitoring in the ICU, certainly avoiding hypotension and anaemia would be critical to prevent a demand supply mismatch.
I will catch up with him 3 months post operatively.
Thank you kindly for your continuing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Jackson,

														

														

														RE:	JOHN TEITZEL		DOB:	15/05/1996		UR:	8061579

																					

														

														

														I saw John in my clinic for follow up today.
He was previously admitted under my care last year following vasovagal syncope and exercise induced rhabdomyolysis.
He subsequently had a CT coronary angiogram that showed no underlying coronary atherosclerosis or aberrant coronary arteries.
His echocardiogram showed normal left ventricular size and systolic function, dilated right ventricle with preserved systolic function, and no significant valvular abnormalities.
It was felt that his right ventricular dilatation was secondary to endurance exercise training.
There was evidence of a small PFO on both the echocardiogram bubble study and CT coronary angiogram.
Following the initial presentation, John has significantly reduced his endurance exercise training for approximately 6 months.
His subsequent repeat echocardiogram showed that the right ventricle remains dilated but has reduced in size compared to before.
Today, I have informed John that his mildly dilated right ventricle is likely secondary to his regular endurance exercise training.
As it has regressed in size after he stopped training, I have discharged him from my clinic back  under your care.
Thank  you for looking after John.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	LANUOLA TEPA		DOB:	19/06/1982		UR:	8018111

																					

														

														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														TAVR in SAVR for degenerative aortic valve bioprosthesis.
TAVR in SAVR at PA Hospital with Abbott Navitor 27mm bioprosthesis on 10.12.2021.
Previous surgical aortic valve replacement in context of type A aortic dissection.
Previous pulmonary embolism.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Obesity with subsequent improvement following bariatric surgery.

Other Conditions:

														Chronic benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

Medications:

														Rivaroxaban 20mg once daily.
I reviewed Lanuola Tepa today.
She is well.
No angina, no palpitations, no syncope and no episodes of cardiac decompensation.
Lanuola had stopped her anticoagulation and I counselled her around the importance of ongoing anticoagulation therapy in her setting.
Lanuola  had a previous unprovoked pulmonary embolus, in addition she also has a prosthetic aortic valve.
A new prescription was provided for Lanuola today and she provided her undertaking to recommence this therapy.
On examination she is well.
She is euvolaemic.
No signs of cardiac decompensation.
Repeat echocardiography is satisfactory with a well seated bioprosthesis with satisfactory haemodynamics.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Rivaroxaban ongoing and indefinitely at appropriate dose for age, weight and renal function as per product information in the setting of previous pulmonary embolism.
Repeat cardiology review in 12 months.

Yours sincerely,

														I reviewed this 70-year-old lady in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
She was referred by yourself regarding her chest pain and exertional dyspnoea with a positive exercise stress echocardiogram for inducible distal LAD ischaemia.

Issues:
1.

Angina
    a.

Chest pain +ve ESE for dLAD ischemia
    b. CTPA (QXR) 19.8.2022 - No PE; No significant lung pathology
    c. ESE (RLHC) 23.9.2022 - Normal LV size and LVEF 65%; Normal RV; Possible 

														        PMVL prolapse with moderate MR; 6:38mins; 7.0METs; 88% MPHR; No CP or 

														        ECG changes; Inducible hypokinesis of distal septum and apical cap
2.

Aspirin allergy - Facial flushing and lip swelling at Redlands Hospital 2020

Background:
1.

Hypertension
2.

PMR; Bx proven giant cell arteritis; Under PAH Rheumatology
3.

Hypothyroidism + hypoparathyroidism (Previous thyroidectomy + 

														    parathyroidectomy 1996)
4.

OSA; On CPAP
5.

Osteopenia
6.

Diverticular disease; Colonic polyps
7.

Bell’s palsy; Left cervical radiculopathy
8.

Recurrent UTIs
9.

Hysterectomy + A/P repair; Appendicectomy; Tonsillectomy
10.

Ex-smoker; EtOH - Nil regular
11.

No bleeding issues, planned elective surgery, active malignancy

Medications:
*Amlodipine 5mg mane
*Atenolol 12.5mg od
*Calcitriol 0.5mcg od
*Caltrate 1 od
*T4 100mcg od
*MTx 20mg weekly
*Prednisolone 3mg od
*Folic acid 5mg weekly
*Somac 20mg od

														

														For the last 6 months she has been getting exertional chest pains with associated shortness of breath.
She describes them as being a burning or tired pain in the anterior chest, radiating to the left upper arm.
This usually occurs when walking or with other forms of exertion, like changing her bed sheets and usually settles with rest.
She has had no rest pain.
Her symptoms have improved since commencing on medical therapy, but she still gets discomfort with heavy exercise.
The last episode was about 1 week ago when she was walking briskly.
She has been given sublingual nitrate by  yourself but has not used this.
On examination,  her blood pressure was 125/70mmHg, heart rate was 54bpm and regular, JVP is not elevated, heart sounds dual with a 2/6 pan systolic at the apex, she was clear with no oedema.
ECG shows sinus bradycardia 59bpm with a  short PR interval about 105ms.

Assessment:

														It sounds like she is getting exertional angina and she does have inducible ischaemia in the distal LAD territory.

Plan:

														I have discussed the diagnosis of coronary artery disease and angina with her.
We have discussed the role of coronary angiography.
I have discussed the procedure, benefits and risk including revascularisation options, which may include PCI or coronary artery bypass grafting.
She is happy to procedure.
I will refer her to one of my interventional cardiology colleague to have this done.
She has a cruise planned for 29.01.2023.
I will see if this can be done prior to that.
She is aware that she requires angioplasty, and she will need admission for Aspirin desensitisation.
I will organise a transthoracic echocardiogram in the interim.
She will have some baseline bloods today pre angiogram.
In the meantime, I have commenced her on Clopidogrel 75mg once a day, Rosuvastatin 20mg once a day and I have added in Imdur 30mg once a day.
She has a chest pain plan and knows to use her sublingual nitrates and/or present to hospital with prolonged severe pain.
I will have a backup appointment to see her in about 6 months.
Thank you kindly for your continuing care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sean,





														RE:	AN THOAI THAI		DOB:	12/02/1952		UR:	2234390

																					

														

														

														Problems List:

														Shortness of breath on exertion for further investigation.
Current smoker – 15 to 20 cigarettes a day.
Dyslipidaemia.
Previous bowel cancer.
Peripheral vascular disease with bilateral claudication.
Left retinal vein thrombosis.
Raised calcium score on CT with significant coronary artery disease on CTCA.

Current Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Lipitor 40mg daily.
Thank you for referring Mr An Thai to the Cardiology Service at the PA Hospital.
He is a 70-year-old gentleman who is a current smoker, smoking up to 15 or 20 cigarettes a day.
He denies any symptoms of chest pain or known coronary artery disease but does report a symptom of shortness of breath on exertion, which he says has been ongoing for a few years now.
He denied any significant progression or change.
On level ground at his own pace, he can manage about 50 yards, but going up and incline or a flight or stairs is impossible for him.
He still denies any symptoms of chest pain or a previous myocardial infarction.
He initially underwent a stress test which was inconclusive with a limited heart rate response and a poor exercise tolerance because of his bilateral claudication.
However, he did not get any symptoms of chest pain and did not have any ischaemic ECG changes.

He has subsequently had a CT calcium score and a CT coronary angiogram which do show significant disease with a calcium score of only 241 Agatston units at his age is moderately elevated, but more importantly he has significant disease in his proximal LAD which Dr Vagish Singh’s report suggests is discontinuous and not pacified until about the first diagonal.
He also has a significant stenosis in the 1st diagonal branch proximally.
Likewise, the mid right coronary artery also has significant disease.
Fortunately, his transthoracic echocardiogram does show normal left ventricular size and function.
His major risk factors for coronary artery disease include, smoking, dyslipidaemia, type II diabetes which is of a recent onset according to Mr Thai and his family.
He was carrying a HbA1c level of 7.5% on a fasting sample, which I think should now be treated in light of his extensive atherosclerotic and peripheral vascular disease.
On examination his blood pressure was 110/70mmHg, with a heart rate of 72bpm in sinus rhythm.
Systemic examination was unremarkable.
His ECG confirmed sinus rhythm with a rate of 76bpm and no acute changes.
In summary, Mr Thai is a 70-year-old gentleman with extensive peripheral vascular disease and bilateral claudication at about 30 to 50 yards.
He had a non-diagnostic exercise stress test which subsequently led on to a CT coronary angiogram and a calcium score which does show extensive coronary artery disease.
I agree that he requires further investigation and the only way to get a firm handle on his coronary artery disease, would mean doing a coronary angiogram.
I have had a long and detail discussion with Mr Thai and his son about the plans of further management.
The most important step in his treatment is going to be abstinence from smoking.
I have made it absolutely clear that this might be his best opportunity to reform that habit in spite of the fact that he has been smoking for a very long time.
I will make arrangements for him to undergo a coronary angiogram in the next few weeks and we will reassess his results to plan further intervention as required.

Yours sincerely,

														It was a pleasure to review Mr Thai in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today along with his wife and an interpreter.

As you know, he is a 71-year-old gentleman with:

														

														Pericardial and likely pulmonary TB.
Presented with a large pericardial effusion November 2021.
No definite signs of pericardial constriction on recent echocardiogram in June 2022.
Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (adenocarcinoma).
Brain and bone mets detected on PET August 2022.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
Ex-smoker.
Mr Thai reports no specific cardiac symptoms.
He has ongoing fatigue, reduced appetite and some chest wall pain.
Heart sounds were dual today and he was euvolaemic with no peripheral oedema.
An echocardiogram in June showed no pericardial effusion.
Some mild ventricular interdependence was noted with no definite constriction and his IVC was collapsing.
In summary, there is minimal residual evidence of Mr Thai's pericardial TB.
It should not be causing him any symptoms currently.
I have booked him for a clinical review in one year, but of course he may not be able to attend.
Please feel free to contact me with any issues or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Chinniappa, 





														RE:	PARVATI THOMAS		DOB:	01/11/1953		UR:	8064078

																					

														

														

														Diagnoses:

														Status post coronary artery bypass surgery by Dr A Iyer in November 2019 (LIMA to LAD, SVG to PLV – PDA, SVG to ramus – OM1) – 08.11.2019.
Type II diabetes.

Dyslipidaemia

														Hypertension.
Gastroesophageal reflux disease.
Osteopenia.
Glaucoma.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg, Lipitor 40mg, Atacand 8mg, Thyroxine 50mcg, Omeprazole 20mg, GTN spray, Janumet XR 50/1000mg.

Investigations:

														haemoglobin  103gm/L, total cholesterol 4.1mmol/L, LDL cholesterol 1.8mmol/L (checked in July 2022), HbA1c 7.3%, eGFR 90ml/min.
I caught up with Paravati Thomas in my Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you are aware, she has undergone coronary artery bypass surgery in 2019, under the care of Dr A Iyer.
She has now been experiencing atypical chest pain and some local tenderness in the left side of chest, but also feels that this pain goes to her back.
She denied any classical exertional chest pain.
She denied any syncope or presyncope, denied any symptoms suggestive of congestive cardiac failure.
She describes this pain different to her previous chest pain that led to her coronary artery bypass surgery.
Her exercise tolerance has been stable.
She denied any deterioration in her exercise ability.
She is able to walk around the shopping centre without any major difficulty.
She does not smoke and denied any excessive alcohol intake.
She has multiple cardiovascular risk factors including hypertension, dyslipidaemia and diabetes.
She informs me that she is compliant with her medications.
She has not used her GTN spray for the last couple of years.
On examination, she was comfortable at rest, her chest was clear, heart sounds were dual, there was a soft ejection systolic murmur in the aortic area.
JVP was not elevated, there was no pedal oedema.
Her blood pressure is 120/80mmHg.
Her ECG today showed normal sinus rhythm, normal axis, no significant St-T-wave changes.
Her resting heart rate was 62bpm, and her corrected QT was 402ms.
She had t-wave inversion in the lateral leads, predominantly Lead I and aVL which is unchanged compared to the previous ECG.

Impression:

														She is a 69-year-old lady who is now approximately 4 years after her coronary artery bypass surgery, with background risk factors of hypertension, diabetes and dyslipidaemia.
She has been experiencing atypical chest pain, but there has been no change  in her exercise capacity.
She also has an ejection systolic murmur in the aortic area.
She will undergo transthoracic echocardiogram and exercise stress echocardiogram.
If these investigations are satisfactory, I will be discharging her from my clinic.
I have advised her to continue to indulge in a healthy lifestyle.
Her last LDL cholesterol was 1.8mmol/L.
We should aim for a total cholesterol of <1.5mmol/L, therefore please do not hesitate in adding Ezetimibe to her list of medications.
I will this in your capable hands.
I plan to catch up with her again in approximately 4 to 5 months with the results of her investigations.
She is aware that if she gets any prolonged chest pain, she will seek medical assistance.
I will keep you updated on her progress.

Yours sincerely,

														Issues:

Boston Scientific VVIR.
Chronic slow atrial fibrillation.
Not anticoagulated due to bleeding risk from scalp lesion, previous bleeding and falls.
Normal LV size and ejection fraction.
Ischaemic heart disease.
Angiogram 2016, moderate mid LAD and diagonal disease with negative DSE November 2016.

Other Background:

Metastatic prostate Ca.

Medications:

														Frusemide 20mg daily, Spiractin 25mg daily, Aspirin 100mg daily, Duodart once daily, Targin 20/10 BD, Pregabalin 75mg BD, Pantoprazole 40mg daily, Panadol Osteo 2 BD, Zoladex injections.
I had the pleasure of seeing Rex in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you will probably be aware, we have been watching his slow atrial fibrillation for a couple of years and this culminated in a presentation after a few falls at the end of last year.
He received an inpatient pacemaker in December and has been recovering well from this.
His device check was satisfactory today, his wound has healed up well and reports no complaints whatsoever.
He has no significant shortness of breath on exertion, no chest pain, no palpitations and is otherwise doing quite well.
On examination, his blood pressure is 135/70mmHg, heart sounds were dual, his chest was clear, and his ankles had no significant oedema.
He will be followed up for routine checks in the pacemaker clinic in terms of his device.
Given his frailty and other comorbidities as well as his lack of any significant symptoms, I have not arranged for him to have any regular follow up with us.
Obviously if there is some issue with the device, the Scientist will liaise with us directly.

Otherwise, if he develops new symptoms of concern, such as chest pain, shortness of breath or difficulties with managing his fluid status, please let us know and we would be more than happy to see him again in clinic.

Yours sincerely,

														Mr Tilly returns to the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic following his pacemaker insertion at the PA Hospital on 07.03.2023 for his high-grade AV node disease.
He had done really well since his pacemaker implantation.
His breathing has improved, and he is more energetic.
His blood pressure is well controlled and so is his diabetes.
His pacemaker wound looks good, and a recent check was satisfactory.
His next check up is coming up in March.
He takes Metoprolol 25mg BD, Ramipril 5mg in the evening, Atorvastatin 40mg in the evening, Metformin 500mg, Gliclazide 50mg and Sitagliptin 100mg.
He is asking whether he can come off some of his tablets.
I have told him he can come off his Metoprolol.

If he does not get any symptoms of breathlessness, you  can repeat his echocardiogram in about 2 to 3 years to keep an eye on his aortic valve.
He does not need regular review at this clinic at this point in time.

I have counselled him that his aortic stenosis will progress over time, and you can re-refer him back to us if he gets symptoms from significant aortic stenosis on your repeat echocardiogram in about 2 to 3 years.

Yours sincerely,

Issues:

Secondary prevention ACID in situ.

Out of hospital cardiac arrest September 2022, VT/

TTE mildly dilated LV with preserved systolic function, normal RV size and function, no significant valvular abnormalities.
CTCA calcium score 0.
No significant coronary artery disease.

Current Medications:
