I saw Alison alongside her family today.
Alison unfortunately had an out of hospital cardiac arrest back in September 2022, after some vigorous training.
The aetiology of this still remains somewhat unclear.
Fortunately, she only had  a limited down time and has recovered very well from this, albeit with some psychological scarring.
She tolerates the Verapamil albeit, she does report some dizziness with this, especially when standing.
Her blood pressure today was 120/70mmHg, heart sounds were dual, and she was euvolaemic.
She was scheduled to have a cardiac MRI, but unfortunately this has not yet occurred.
It is booked to happen in the next couple of months and this will hopefully eliminate whether there is any scar or other cause for her arrest.
Otherwise, she should continue on the current dose of Verapamil, and we will arrange to see her again after the cardiac MRI in the next few months.

														Dear Dr Ousmand, 

														

														

														RE:	THOMAS JOHN TOMAC	DOB:	22/02/1955	UR:	976634

														

														

														

														Issues:

														- Ischaemic cardiomyopathy
  o Late presentation anterior STEMI + APO/concurrent CAP; November 2022
  o Angiogram 5/12/22 – right dominant, occluded mLAD, minor disease otherwise 

														     (for medical management)
  o LVEF 20% with akinetic mid-distal LAD segments, satisfactory valvular function, 

														     moderate loculated pericardial effusion
  o TTE 19/1/23 – LVEF ~30%
  o Plan for OMT + reassessment of LVEF in 4-6 months
- Atrial fibrillation 
  o Diagnosed at November 2022 admission 
  o CHADSVASc – age, HF, IHD, HTN = 4
  o Rx Rivaroxaban 15mg daily 
- Hypertension
- Aspirin allergy – hives
- Dyslipidemia 
- Anxiety
- Chronic lower back pain – previous lumbar spine surgery

Medicines
Rivaroxaban 15mg daily - continue this dose
Rosuvastatin 40mg daily 
Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily - continue
Entresto low dose BD - stop, change to valsartan 80mg daily (SBP 80s)
Spironolactone 25mg daily - continue
Add dapagliflozin 5mg daily - increase to 10mg daily in 2-4 weeks
Frusemide 40mg BD - change to once daily  
Pantoprazole 40
Tramadol, pregabalin
PRN diazepam

Bloods (11/1/23)
Cr 130, eGFR 49, K 4.1
HbA1c 6.7%
LDL 1.2

														

														Review:

														I reviewed Thomas along with his wife in Dr Singbal’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today at the PA Hospital.
He was admitted under our care in November of last year with late presentation anterior STEMI and APO with concurrent community acquired pneumonia.
He has recovered slowly since this admission, although he is clearly worse functionally since he came in.
He has  ongoing breathlessness, NYHA class II – III with a fairly euvolaemic examination today.
He is also limited somewhat by back pain.
He used to be able to walk in the yard prior to his admission, but now can only walk around the house.
He has been using a 4-wheelie walker since his November admission.
He has no angina, no palpitations or syncope.
He does get significant light headedness at times.
He has been measuring his blood pressure at home and this is frequently in the 80s.
I suspect we need to pull back a little bit on his heart failure therapy to get him a bit more blood pressure to play with.
He has a good relationship with his GP and is being followed up by Heart Failure CN April Amigo from Ipswich and has some home visits as well for education.
On examination today he looked euvolaemic, his blood pressure was in the 80s, heart rate was 60bpm and regular.

He had an echocardiogram done today

														Severely dilated left ventricle with severe segmental systolic dysfunction.
LVEF 27 %.
Extensive RWMA as described (see text).
Normal right ventricular size and systolic function.

Mild AR

														

														Plan is as follows:

														- Medication changes as outlined above – changes made due to low SBP, Cr 130
- CC letter to GP and HFS Ipswich 
- See back in 4-6 months with TTE – possible consideration of primary prevention ICD in future

														  depending on LVEF recovery

														RE:	JOHN TRAHAR		DOB:	15/12/1964		UR:	8087042

																					

														

														

														Issues:
# PFO
   - closed 9/2/22
# Factor V Leiden (heterozygous)
   - Complicated by DVTs, PEs, left MCA stroke (April 2021)
   - lifelong anticoagulation with apixaban 5mg BD

Medications:
Atorvastatin 40mg nocte, apixaban 5mg BD, perindopril 2.5mg mane

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing John Trahar in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.

He is known to this clinic for closure of his patent foramen ovale, which occurred in February last year on the background of known Heterozygous Factor V Leiden, which was complicated by DVT’s, pulmonary emboli, and a left MCA stroke in April 2021.
He is meant to be on lifelong anticoagulation with Apixaban 5mg twice daily.
As you know, John works in purchasing for a hospital.
He is managing well, with the only residual complication from his stroke being difficulty finding words if he were to speak too quickly.
However, he manages very well should he pace himself.
He does not smoke, does not drink alcohol and does not use recreational drugs.
Since his last review, John feels very well.
He has no complaints and has had no issues with anticoagulation.
He is taking his medications from a self-prepared Dosette Box.
In fact, today he walked from Stones Corner to the PA Hospital without any difficulty.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 150/75mmHg and his heart rate was 72bpm and regular, corresponding with a ECG in sinus rhythm.
He tells me that his usual blood pressure on his home monitor is approximately 145mmHg systolic or above in the mornings.
Since his last review, John has had a transthoracic echocardiogram performed in July last year.
This showed that the patent foramen ovale closure device appeared well seated with no residual shunt seen on colour flow mapping.
The added saline contrast study was also negative at rest and with Valsalva manoeuvre.
With respect to ongoing management of his PFO closure device, he will continue his therapy of anticoagulation with Apixaban from the perspective of prevention.
If he requires cessation of anticoagulation for a procedure, he should resume the anticoagulation as soon as it is safe, according to the procedural team.
With respect to John’s blood pressure, given his persistent hypertension as per his home monitor readings, I have asked him to increase his Perindopril to 5mg daily.
Please review this at your next clinic appointment and continue to titrate his medications with a target blood pressure of <140mmHg systolic.
Given John’s progress to date, we will not make another appointment to see John at this time.
However, should his condition change, please re-refer him to us for further review.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Trahar.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Peter,





RE:	HUONG THI THU TRAN	DOB:	25/08/1958	UR:	597553

							







														Issues:

														Ischaemic heart disease.
Angiogram August 2022 for stable anginal symptoms - 80% mid RCA stenosis, 60% mid LAD stenosis.
Performed after CTCA and stress echocardiogram.
Planned for consideration of PCI to RCA +/- LAD.
Non-small cell adenocarcinoma.
Stage 2B.
Incidentally initially diagnosed from CTCA.
Right upper lobectomy plus mediastinal lymph node sampling 07.10.2022 – Dr Ura.
Completed cisplatin and pemetrexed chemotherapy.
For routine surveillance imaging.

Other Background:

														Dyslipidaemia.
Hypothyroidism.
Recent diagnosis of type II diabetes, A1c 6.5.

Current Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg, Metoprolol 25mg BD, Ramipril 0.625mg, Rosuvastatin 20mg, Thyroxine 100mcg, GTN PRN.
I had the pleasure of seeing Huong alongside Dr Ahmad in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you will remember, Mrs Tran initially had some work up for anginal symptoms in the form of an ESE which showed failure to augment as well as a CTCA suggestive of a severe RCA stenosis.
She underwent an angiogram back in August 2022, which showed a severe mid RCA lesion and a 60% mid LAD lesion.
The context of all this was that her symptoms were quite stable and there was an incidental finding of a lung lesion.
Subsequently she underwent a right upper lobectomy by Dr Ura and team, which was successful, and they are happy for procedures from their side of things.
She also had Adjuvant chemotherapy which has completed, and I note the revie from 12.01.2023 by the Medical Oncology Team that they will follow her up with surveillance imaging.
She has recovered fairly well from her procedure but does limit herself somewhat in what she does.
I saw her alongside her daughter today, unfortunately without an interpreter, but her daughter was able to provide quite an adequate history.
She does still describe heaviness, mostly when she exerts herself and this seems to go away with rest.
The exertion is fairly mild, such as walking around the shops.
She has not actually had to use her GTN spray.
Her ECG shows sinus rhythm at a rate of around 60 and her blood pressure was 100/70mmHg.
Her heart sounds were dual, and she was euvolaemic.

Given the completion of her lung cancer treatment as well as the ongoing symptoms and difficulty of further introducing antianginals, I discussed her case with Dr Ahmad and we would ask you  (Dr Moore), to book her for a repeat angiogram with a view for PCI of the RCA +/- the LAD, dependent on  your findings and her symptoms.

The plan is as follows

														We will refer to you for a consideration of a PCI.
I have given her a script to hold for Clopidogrel 75mg once daily and asked her to commence this 1 week prior to a repeat angiogram, unless otherwise advised by yourself.
If her blood pressure allows, Dr Van, please introduce a small dose of Isosorbide Mononitrate such as 30mg.
She has been provided education on how to use GTN and if the pain does not settle, she is to call ambulance and present to hospital.
We will arrange to see her after her angiogram.

Yours sincerely,

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Non-obstructive coronary artery disease.
Previous documented paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
Severe aortic stenosis.
Symptomatic at time of review on 22.08.2022.
Mild ascending aortic dilatation.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
Type II diabetes mellitus.

Other Conditions:

														Chronic immunosuppression subsequent to renal allograft.
Previous renal transplant allograft.
Primary renal disease was single kidney with glomerulonephritis and previous nephrectomy for renal cell carcinoma.
Prostatic enlargement.
Osteopenia.
Left native kidney cyst under surveillance.

Medications:
aspirin (aspirin 100 mg oral tablet): 1 tab(s)= 100 mg, Oral, morning (with or after food)
atorvastatin (atorvastatin 20 mg oral tablet): 1 tab(s)= 20 mg, Tablet, Oral, night
Colecalciferol (Colecalciferol 25 mcg oral tablet): 1 tab(s)= 25 mcg, Oral, morning
lercanidipine (lercanidipine 20 mg oral tablet): 1 tab(s)= 20 mg, Tablet, Oral, morning (on an empty stomach), Indication: HTN
levothyroxine (levothyroxine 100 mcg oral tablet): 1 tab(s)= 100 mcg, Tablet, Oral, morning (on an empty stomach)
metformin (metformin 500 mg oral MODIFIED release tablet): 1 tab(s)= 500 mg, Tablet, modified release, Oral, morning, Indication: DM
metoprolol (metoprolol 50 mg oral IMMEDIATE release tablet): 1 tab(s)= 50 mg, Tablet, Oral, TWICE a day
mycophenolate sodium (mycophenolate sodium 180 mg oral enteric tablet): 1 tab(s), Oral, TWICE a day, Total dose: 540mg BD --> stop
mycophenolate sodium (mycophenolate sodium 360 mg oral enteric tablet): 1 tab(s), Oral, TWICE a day, Total dose: 540mg BD
prednisolone (prednisolone 5 mg oral tablet): 1 tab(s)= 5 mg, Oral, morning (with or after food)
TACrolimus (TACrolimus 1 mg oral IMMEDIATE release capsule): 1 cap(s)= 1 mg, Capsule, Oral, TWICE a day, Indication: tx, Current dose 1mg BD
trimETHOPRIM-sulfamethoxazole (trimETHOPRIM-sulfamethoxazole 160 mg-800 mg oral tablet): 0.5 tab(s), Oral, morning (with or after food)

														

														I reviewed Kurt today.
His CT follow up demonstrates suitable vascular access for  left transfemoral balloon expandable transcatheter aortic valve replacement.
I again discussed what the procedure involves and the potential risks, including a small but real risk of loss of function in his trans bladder kidney resulting in a permanent need for dialysis.
The risk of this would be 5% or less, but there is a small but real risk of this.
In addition to this, we discussed the natural history of the aortic valve disease including a 50% risk of heart failure or death within the next year or two without procedural intervention.

In relation to transcatheter aortic valve replacement we discussed the potential risks including a risk of 5% - 10% major complications that could include: stroke resulting in permanent disability, inability to walk or talk, blindness, death or permanent nursing home placement; major vascular or cardiac complications including dissection, rupture, the need for major reparative surgery, death or limb loss; kidney failure requiring permanent use of a dialysis machine; infection resulting in the need for major open heart surgery and or death.
We also discussed a 20 - 30% risk of requiring a permanent pacemaker as a result of the procedure.
The relevant written educational material outlining these issues was also provided (UQ Version 2021).

Plan and Recommendations:

														Review at PA Hospital Heart Team Meeting with a view to transcatheter aortic valve replacement via the left femoral with a balloon expandable prosthesis as a category 2 patient.

Yours sincerely,

														Past Medical History:
# End-stage Kidney Failure
   - secondary to FSGS

   - diagnosed at age of 2
   - secondary to pneumococcal sepsis

perindopril 8mg daily, lercanidipine 20mg mane, frusemide 40mg mane, metoprolol 25mg BD

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Brad Trost in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
Thank you for involving us in his care by referring him to us for consideration of an abnormal ECG that was found during routine kidney transplant workup in October.
This showed a Wellen’s pattern anteriorly with lateral T-wave inversion in V4-6, as well as in Leads I, II, aVL.
This is in the setting of end stage kidney failure, secondary to FSGS, now on peritoneal dialysis since September last year.
As you know, Brad lives with his partner, Jade, and is independent.
He works in retail as a manager at his local Coles Supermarket.
However, after starting peritoneal dialysis, he is now less involved in the physical work, but maintains his position.
He has never smoked, does not use recreational drugs, and does not drink alcohol.
Brad does not know of any cardiac history in his family.
From the symptom perspective, Brad denies any chest discomfort of any kind with or without exertion.
He denies also any shortness of breath with activity, as well as any orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea.
I understand that in March last year, Brad had a transthoracic echocardiogram performed in the community at Exact Radiology.
The images were not available for review today, but the report states that he had a normal left ventricular and right ventricular size and systolic function.
His LVEF was estimated to be 60%.
He had also satisfactory valvular structure and function.
Brad was due for an exercise stress echocardiogram today, but unfortunately, he was unaware of the appointment, therefore missed this investigation.

I have asked for the exercise stress echocardiogram to be rescheduled at the next available appointment, so that we might clarify whether there is any concern of ischaemic heart disease, especially in the pre-transplant setting.
On examination today, Brad appeared well and in good spirits.
His blood pressure was 150/85mmHg, and his heart rate was 70bpm and regular, that corresponded with an ECG in sinus rhythm.
His chest was clear, and his heart sounds were dual with no murmur.
His examination was otherwise unremarkable.
I will arrange to review Brad in approximately 3 to 4 months with the results of the exercise stress echocardiogram.
I will leave the care of his antihypertensive therapy with his renal team, who he is due to see Brad again next week.
Lastly, I have asked Brad to be mindful of any chest discomfort that arises and does not resolve with rest.
Should this occur, I have emphasised the importance of seeking medical attention promptly.
We will write to you again after the next appointment.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Trost.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Thackwray,





														RE:	BARBARA TROTTER	DOB:	13/04/1945	UR:	209553

																					

														

														

														Issues:
# LV dysfunction
   - LVEF ~40% Dec 2022, global hypokinesis with regional variability
   - LVEF initially ~35% at Mater Hospital previously
   - unclear aetiology
# Moderate Aortic stenosis
# Stage IV CKD
   - presumed secondary to renovascular disease and diabetes
# Type 2 diabetes - declined endo input, GP managing
   - complicated by peripheral neuropathy
# CVA 1998
   - residual RLL weakness
# OSA - Not able to tolerate CPAP
# Colonic polyps – Declined further colonoscopy
# Anaemia
# Parkinson's disease
   - Mild cognitive impairment - patient reports 'pre-dementia'
# Depression
# Recurrent skin cancers

Medications (verified by HF NP with thanks) - Webster pack
Irbesartan 300mg mane, Aspirin 100mg mane, Bisoprolol 6.25mg nocte, Ostevit-D 2 tabs mane, , Dothep 75mg nocte, Esomeprazole 20mg mane, Ezetimibe- Simvastatin 10-80mg mane, Fenofibrate 48mg mane, Mirtazapine 60mg nocte, pramipexole dihydro (Sifrol) 1.5mg nocte, Linagliptin 5mg mane, Symbicort 200/6mcg 2 puff daily, Toujeo 36u mane, NovoRapid 4u lunch, 4u dinner, Diazepam 5mg PRN, Frusemide 40mg BD


														I had the pleasure of reviewing Barbara Trotter in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today, accompanied by her husband and daughter.
She is known to this clinic from the perspective of LV dysfunction and moderate aortic stenosis with multiple interacting comorbidities as listed above.
As you know, Barbara is a 77-year-old lady who lives at home with her husband and mobilises with a  4-wheel walker.
She does not much venture out of her home, except on shopping trips, which she does with her husband.
She does the washing and hangs the clothes on a dry rack, which she finds easier to do than on an overhead line.
Her husband does the driving, and she is able to complete a shopping trip with her husband without any significant difficulty.
While she has a cleaner once a month, she does intermittent cleaning in between those visits.
She also cooks her own meals.
In discussion with Barbara and her family today, I am told that she has no significant dyspnoea with or without exertion on her current medication regimen.
She also denies any orthopnoea, or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea.
Lastly, she denies any chest discomfort as well.
While I am pleased she experiences none of the aforementioned symptoms, I have emphasised the importance of seeking medical attention should any of the above occur.

Should she experience significant orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, she also has the option of potentially contacting yourself or the Heart Recovery Service Nurse Practitioner or presenting to the Emergency Department for review.
On examination, Barbara appeared well and mobilised from the waiting room with her 4-wheel walker without difficulty.
Her blood pressure during our consultation was 160/60mmHg, but I note that her blood pressure earlier with Emma, our Nurse Practitioner, was only 120mmHg systolic.

Her heart

														rate was 70bpm with occasional ectopic beats.
On auscultation of her chest there were bibasal scattered crepitations with is long standing.
Her heart sounds were dual with an ejection systolic murmur and a soft S2.
Her jugular venous pressure was measured at 1cm, with mid hepatojugular reflux.
There was no significant peripheral oedema.

With respect to further optimisation of medical therapy for her heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, I agree with the recent recommendation from Emma Harmer, our Nurse Practitioner, to increase Barbara’s Bisoprolol level to 7.5mg daily.
As Barbara uses a Webster Pack, Emma has kindly arranged for the change to be reflected in Barbara’s next Webster Pack.
Ongoing gradual uptitration of heart failure therapy will be continuing with Emma via the Heart Recovery Service.
However, I note that we are nearing the maximum tolerated doses and the choice of agents is limited by her renal function.
I have encouraged Barbara to have ongoing engagement with her multiple medical care teams, to ensure a multisystem approach to her care.
For the time being, I will arrange for Barbara to have a clinic review in approximately 1 year, unless her condition were to change.

A repeat transthoracic echocardiogram can be considered at the next clinic appointment to monitor her response to heart failure therapy, as well as to monitor the progress of her moderate aortic stenosis.
Should earlier review be required, please write to us and we will move the appointment accordingly.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mrs Trotter.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr O’Connor ,





														RE:	JOSEPH MARIA TYHUIS	DOB:	25/05/1948	UR:	311515

																					

														

														I had the pleasure of following up Mr Tyhuis in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
He is a 74-year-old man with previous bioprosthetic aortic valve replacement and CABG in 2016.
His other medical comorbidities include type II diabetes, dyslipidaemia, hypertension, obstructive sleep apnoea and NASH.
In the last clinic appointment, I made some adjustments to his diuretic medications.
I note that he is still having significant oedema.
He tells me that his legs could be quite swollen at times and then he would take 40mg of Frusemide when that happens.
He tells me he does not like taking Frusemide everyday as he has to go to the toilet frequently.
I note that he has a referral for Urology, and he tells me that he is being considered for urological procedures.
He did show me a record of his weight.
I note that there could be 4 to 5kgs difference in his weight, depending on his oedema status.
On examination today, his heart rate was 80bpm, and his blood pressure was 140/85mmHg.
Heart sounds were dual with an ejection systolic murmur.
His chest was clear, JVP was not elevated and there was mild bilateral oedema.
Mr Tyhuis reports that he does drink fluids, perhaps 2 litres a day in addition to his foods.
I have advised him to minimise his fluid intake and to drink to thirst.
I have suggested that he take a full tablet of Frusemide when his legs become quite oedematous.
He should consider taking ½ a Frusemide on a more regular basis.
He will consider trialling this.
I look forward to reviewing him again in 6 months.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Binh Van Nguyen,





RE:	EDGARDO UMEREZ		DOB:	29/05/1963		UR:	784649

							



														Mr Umerez attended the heart failure titration clinic today accompanied by his son.
He had a recent admission to the Princess Alexandra Hospital in mid December 2022 with NSTEMI and new diagnosis of dilated cardiomyopathy, EF 10-15%.
He had an angiogram during this admission and was found to have severe three vessel coronary artery disease.
He is awaiting surgical opinion with our cardiothoracic team in February 2023.
Since discharge Edgardo has been feeling well.
He describes class I NYHA symptoms and denies any orthopnoea, PND, dizziness or light headedness.
He has not had any chest pain.
His weight is stable at 57kg at home.
He has not seen you yet and he has not had a blood test since discharge.
On examination his blood pressure was 90/70mmHg with no postural drop, heart rate 88bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
Heart sounds were dual, and chest was clear.
Today I have organised a blood test to assess his renal function.
His Sodium was 138, potassium was 5.2, urea was 7.4, creatinine 115 and eGFR 60.
These are attached for your information.
I have decreased the Spironolactone slightly 12.5mg mane in an effort to improve his blood pressure and enable an increase in the Metoprolol XL This will also assist in reducing the potassium level.
He will have a review with the endocrine team tomorrow at QEII Hospital and a CTS review here at the Princess Alexandra Hospital in early February.
I will see him thereafter.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	JAXON VALENTINE		DOB:	13/08/1973		UR:	8111535

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Jaxon, a lovely 49-year-old gentleman I had the pleasure of performing a phone review on today in the Arrhythmia Clinic.
He is known to have Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome and was reviewed by Dr Ahmad in November last year.
At that stage, he was offered an EP study + pathway ablation (left posterior accessory) and written information was provided.
Jaxon had wished to further discuss this with his family before committing to the procedure.
I caught up with him via telephone today to follow up on the outcome of these discussions.
Jaxon tells me that he prefers to defer any invasive procedures for the time being.
I have reiterated the 1% risk of sudden cardiac death and advised him that this procedure can be reconsidered in the future should he change his mind, or his symptom burden increases.
Fortunately, he has not had any further episodes of palpitations since we caught up with him last.
He denies any presyncope or syncope either.
I note that he has a cardiac CT coming up in February that will be followed up by Dr Korczyk, his treating cardiologist.
Given that Jaxon is happy to be managed conservatively, we have discharged him from the Arrhythmia Clinic.
Thank you for your ongoing care and please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any questions or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Medications

														Aspirin 100mg mane, Atorvastatin 80mg mane, Metformin 1g BD, Gliclazide 90mg MR mane, Empagliflozin 10mg mane, Frusemide 20mg mane, Bisoprolol 10mg mane, Spironolactone 12.5mg mane, Ramipril increased today to 2.5mg mane, Vit D 1 tab mane, Thiamine 100mcg mane

														

														On examination his blood pressure was 105/90mmHg and 110/80mmHg standing, heart rate 80bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
Today I have increased the Ramipril to 2.5mg mane as his renal function was stable from October 2022 with an eGFR >90.
I have organised for him to have a blood test in four weeks prior to returning to titration clinic.
He has an MRI booked with Qld Xray on the Monday 6th February.
He will see Dr Singbal here thereafter.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	GLEN VAN HAEFTEN	DOB:	29/05/1972	UR:	772472

																					

														

														

														I saw Glen in my clinic for follow up today.
He continues to complain of intermittent exertional chest discomfort.
His exercise stress echocardiogram showed normal resting LV function but inducible ischaemia in the LAD territory during exercise.
His background is significant for ischaemic heart disease with previous abnormal CT calcium score (318, 97th percentile), hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia.
Glen has a strong family history of premature cardiovascular disease.
His current medications include Aspirin 100mg daily, Telmisartan 80mg daily, Rosuvastatin 10mg daily, and Esomeprazole 20mg daily.
He is allergic to Penicillin (rash), and Bactrim (anaphylaxis).
On examination today his pulse rate was 90bpm regular and his blood pressure was 110/80mmHg.
Today, I have informed Glen that his exercise stress echocardiogram was abnormal with evidence of LAD ischaemia.
Therefore, he will require an invasive coronary angiogram +/- PCI.
I have explained to him the risks of the procedure (including AMI, CVA, bleeding) and he is willing to proceed with the angiogram.
In the meantime, I have started him on Atenolol 12.5mg daily, increased the Rosuvastatin to 40mg daily, and instructed him on how to use the GTN spray.
I will see him again in 3 months for follow up.
Thank you for looking after Glen.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Miles,





														RE:	MARK VAN HAEFTEN	DOB:	16/11/1977	UR:	688693

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Mark in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
He is a 45-year-old gentleman who had a number of presentations to hospital this year with a somewhat complicated course.
He was initially admitted to the RBWH in early July with chest pain, anterior ECG changes and a modest troponin elevation.
He had an invasive coronary angiogram that demonstrated no severe obstructive coronary artery disease.
He had a cardiac MRI that suggested an LAD territory infarct.
He then presented to the PA Hospital on 18.08.2022 with similar symptoms, ECG changes and troponin elevation.
His LV function was normal on echocardiogram and a repeat angiogram demonstrated a proximal LAD lesion that was not thought to be haemodynamically significant on IFR.
A repeat cardiac MRI was planned but he discharged against medical advice.
He was prescribed dual antiplatelet therapy, a statin and Isosorbide Mononitrate on discharge for likely coronary artery spasm.
After that, he continued to experience frequent GTN responsive chest pain.
He failed to attend a scheduled outpatient review.
He continued to smoke cigarettes.
He reported compliance with his medications, though his dispensing history was not consistent with that.
He denied any recent use of methamphetamines, though he had previously smoked them.
He was then admitted on 29.10.2022, again with chest pain and a troponin rise.
On this occasion he had a significant decline in his LV function.
His EF was 42% on a cardiac MRI with evidence of LAD scar that was minimally viable.
A CTCA demonstrated a mild to moderate ostial LAD stenosis due to soft plaque extending back into the distal left main.

The initial plan was to manage Mark with aggressive medical therapy for coronary artery disease, possible coronary artery spasm and LV dysfunction as well as strongly encourage abstinence from methamphetamines and cigarettes.
However, he continued to experience quite frequent GTN responsive chest pain despite maximum tolerated medical therapy.
He subsequently underwent coronary angiography, OCT and FFR of the LAD.
The angiographic appearance was unchanged and there was no severe stenosis on angiography.
However, OCT revealed a diffusely diseased LAD with fibroatheroma and evidence of plaque erosion at the mid vessel and ostium.
FFR was 0.75 in the LAD post-hyperaemia.

The option of PCI was discussed based on the appearance of unstable plaque, haemodynamically significant FFR and recurrent symptoms despite medical therapy, acknowledging there was no angiographically severe stenosis and borderline viability on cardiac MRI.
There were concerns regarding Mark’s compliance with medical therapy in the setting of a stent.
This was discussed with him and the consequences of non-compliance including acute stent thrombosis were raised.
It was also discussed with his sister.
Mark decided to persist with medical therapy and was discharged from hospital.

His medications on discharge were Aspirin 100mg, Ticagrelor 90mg BD, Bisoprolol 5mg, Irbesartan 75mg, Isosorbide Mononitrate 120mg, Nicorandil 5mg BD, Eplerenone 12.5mg, Empagliflozin 10mg, Rosuvastatin 40mg.
Mark reports that his main issue since discharge has been fatigue and exhaustion.
This limits his exercise tolerance.
He also reports episodes of chest pain which mainly occur at night when he lays down to go to bed or when he wakes up in the morning.
They can also sometimes occur after exertion, but not particularly with it.
These episodes have all been quickly relieved with GTN.
Mark reports good compliance with his medications, only missing a couple of doses since discharge.
However, his pulse was 84bpm and regular today and his blood pressure was 140/85mmHg.

Given his heart rate and blood pressure were significantly lower when he was on hospital on medical therapy, to the point where we could not titrate his medical therapy any further, I wonder if today’s readings may represent some poor compliance with medications.
Mark also brought in his medication boxes today, asking for repeat prescriptions, and I noticed that most were dispensed in November with significant supply left.
I think Mark may be well intentioned and trying to take his medications regularly but probably missing a significant proportion of doses.
Mark asked about PCI today.
I explained that PCI may not address his current chest pain as it is not exertional and there may still be some component of coronary spasm given the quick relief with GTN.
We also rediscussed the critical importance of medication compliance if he were to have a proximal LAD stent.
I have given Mark a full set of prescriptions today and strongly encouraged him to obtain a Webster Pack from his local pharmacy.
I have suggested increasing the Bisoprolol to 7.5mg.
I will review him in 3 months but please feel free to contact me with any issues or concerns in the interim.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Ng,





														RE:	ADRIAN VAN-EYKELENBORG	DOB:	24/04/1942	UR:	591010

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Adrian, a functionally independent 80-year-old gentleman I had the pleasure of reviewing on behalf of Dr Ahmad today.

His medical issues include:

														Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis.
Progressive dyspnoea, chest pain and presyncope over the last 6 months.
No syncope.

NYHA II-III sx

														Long standing history of presyncope and dizziness.
Previously noted to have a high ventricular ectopic burden of up to 15%.
Has resting bradycardia with a 1st degree heart block and non-specific interventricular conduction delay.
Metoprolol was ceased in March 2022.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
Dobutamine stress echocardiogram performed in 2018 mentions ?
possible old inferolateral infarct at rest.
Study was negative for inducible ischaemia.
Monoclonal B lymphocytosis and iron deficiency anaemia.
Prolapsed haemorrhoid.
Previous L4/S1 fusion + L5/S1 decompression laminectomy in 2014.
Adrian lives at home with his wife, and they are both functionally independent, despite his recent worsening cardiac status.
He is a retired machinist who is a never smoker.
They have a supportive daughter, without any formal services.
He mobilises independently and until recently was able to mow his lawn as well.

His current medications include, Allopurinol 200mg,  Atorvastatin 80mg, Motilium, Ramipril 1.25mg, Pregabalin, Panadol Osteo, Aspirin 100mg, Isosorbide Mononitrate 120mg (ceased today), along with some multivitamin supplementations.
Adrian was reviewed in Dr Ahmad’s clinic in March last year.
At that stage, he complained of shortness of breath on exertion with a transthoracic echocardiogram showing moderate to severe aortic stenosis and a normal left ventricular function.
Since that review, he tells me that the shortness of breath on exertion has gotten worse and it is now associated with exertional chest pain 2 to 3 times a day.
He also is describing exertional presyncope, without any syncopal episodes.
Adrian assures me that he does not have any symptoms at rest, however, then did mention that he wakes up at night 2 to 3 times with breathlessness and also paraesthesia in his legs.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 100/70mmHg with no postural drop.
His resting heart rate was 50bm which increased to 66bpm on mobilisation.
He had an ejection systolic murmur with a clear chest on auscultation and no peripheral oedema.
He has not teeth (denture in situ).
In terms of investigations, he has had an ECG today that was sinus bradycardia with a 1st degree heart block and an isolated ventricular ectopic.
He has had a transthoracic echocardiogram today, that was consistent with severe aortic stenosis (peak velocity 4.7m/s, mean gradient 55mmHg, DSI 0.20, valve area 1cm²).
His left ventricular ejection fraction was preserved and although his right ventricle was dilated, systolic function remained intact.
His aortic valve is calcified and trileaflet in morphology with only mild associated regurgitation.
His aortic root is of normal dimension with a dilated ascending aorta of 46mm.
Our impression today is that Adrian has severe symptomatic aortic stenosis with mild conduction disease in addition to that.
Despite his symptoms, he is managing well in the community with the help of his wife and daughter and enjoys a reasonably quality of life.
Dr Ahmad and I have discussed with Adrian his diagnosis and our recommendation for further investigations for consider of a TAVR given his advanced age, rather than surgical aortic valve replacement.
Adrian was keen to pursue this further and as such, we have made the following plan.
Refer to Dr Camuglia / Dr Moore at the PA Hospital Heart Valve Clinic for consideration of TAVR.
For work up of this TAVR we have requested some basic bloods, iron studies, CT TAVR and a diagnostic coronary angiogram or CTCA.
Stop Isosorbide Mononitrate.
Commence Frusemide 20mg .
Adrian should seek urgent medical attention if his symptoms worsen, or he develops a syncopal episode.
Adrian has been advised to be reviewed by yourself next week to assess progress of his symptoms and to follow up the blood tests I have requested today.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Adrian and please do not hesitate in contacting us should you have any questions or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	PETER VELLA		DOB:	05/05/1959		UR:	2240713

																					

														

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Mr Vella in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
Mr Vella is a 63-year-old man who had a recent echocardiogram which noted severe aortic stenosis and kindly referred us by Cardiologist, Dr Naveen Dwivedi.

His echocardiogram performed on 16.11.2022 was reported as showing normal left ventricular size and systolic function, ejection fraction 69%, mild LV hypertrophy, severe aortic stenosis with mild to moderate aortic regurgitation.
The mean gradient of 50mmHg was noted across the aortic valve with AVA of 1.1cm².
Mr Vella tells me that his main symptom is that he feels tired all the time.
On further questioning, he feels tired as in lethargic, rather than sleepy or shortness of breath.
His wife, however, does report that when he does his gardening, he often stops 2/3 of the way through, rather than completing his gardening.
He denies particularly shortness of breath on physical exertion.
He tells me that his main problem at the moment is that he cannot get to sleep and sometimes wakes up with muscle aches and discomfort.
He does not have any exertional chest pain but tells me that he has indigestion sensations, especially when he lays in bed.
He was able to walk up the hill to come to the PA Hospital today without needing to stop.
Mr Vella reports about 12 months ago when he relocated from Canberra to Brisbane, he did have oedema for some time, however, the oedema since then has resolved.
He reports that when he did have the oedema, he would put his legs up.
His past medical history is significant for previous myocardial infarction in about 2012, and a stent was inserted in Canberra.
He has obstructive sleep apnoe and uses CPAP.
He tells me that he has being CPAP for about 6 months, but he finds it a struggle.
He also has a history of hypertension.
He has an elevated BMI, and he tells me that his weight has not changed recently.
He does not drink alcohol; he smokes about 1 cigarette per day and has cut down significantly.
He has not had any syncopal episodes recently.
On examination today, his heart rate was 63bpm and his blood pressure was 125/60mmHg.
His heart sounds were dual with an ejection systolic murmur.
His chest was clear, his JVP was not elevated and there is no peripheral oedema.
His ECG today showed sinus rhythm with left ventricular hypertrophy.
I explained to Vella the findings of severe aortic stenosis on his echocardiogram and the potential implications.
I  feel however, that mostly his symptoms are related to his sleep apnoea, rather than his aortic stenosis at this stage.
Given his previous coronary artery disease, however, it is also possible he has significant coronary disease now in addition to his severe aortic stenosis.
To further work him up, I will organise for him to have an invasive coronary angiogram.
I look forward to reviewing him again afterwards.
I have explained to him the nature of the invasive angiogram.
I have also given him a form to have some blood tests repeated before his angiogram.
His current medications include Aspirin, Atorvastatin 40mg daily, Ramipril  10mg, Fluoxetine.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Doctor,

														

														

														

														RE:	SAI HEI VY		DOB:	27/12/1992		UR:	8102460

																					

														

														

														I had the pleasure of talking to Mr Vy as a phone review from the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
He was seen by Dr Wahi in December 2022, with ?pericarditis and was started on Colchicine.
Mr Vy had left sided pointy tenderness of chest pain lingering over 3 months now, which does not have any similar component which he felt with the pericarditis episode in November 2021.
This episode started after an ear infection and for the last 6 weeks he has been treated with Colchicine.
His echocardiogram was reassuring with no pericardial effusion.
As per his description, the pain mostly gets worse with the physical movement and easily reproducible on palpation.
Interestingly, he also reports discoloration in the left upper quadrant.
He is otherwise a fit and healthy gentleman who works as an IT person in Brisbane.

Overall, it seems that this pain is quite atypical to be pericarditic in nature and given at this stage, we have stopped the Colchicine  and advised him to take Panadol and Nurofen on as needed basis.
I have advised him to have GP follow up to further investigate the nature of this pain and particularly this skin discoloration which he is mentioning over the phone today.
Please continue with your ongoing care and feel free to contact us if you have any concerns in the interim.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Challa,

														

														

														RE:	IAN WALLACE		DOB:	16/05/1936		UR:	612679

																					

														

														

														Diagnoses:

														Mitral valve repair for mitral valve prolapse and severe mitral regurgitation November 2022 (Dr A Iyer).
Post operative atrial fibrillation with tachy brady syndrome.

Current Medications:

														Amiodarone 25mg daily, Apixaban 5mg bd.
It was a pleasure to review Ian in the Cardiology Arrhythmia Clinic.
He is an 86-year-old robust gentleman who had a mitral valve repair in November 2022 by Dr A Iyer.
Post operatively this was complicated with atrial fibrillation with fast ventricular rate and also bradycardic episodes.
He was managed with IV and oral Amiodarone loading.
Ten to 12 weeks down the track post procedure he has been doing very well.
He has maintained sinus rhythm.
He has not had any further palpitations.
Ian knows that he has not had any preoperative atrial in the past.
On examination today, he has no signs of heart failure.
His ECG confirms sinus rhythm.
In view of post operative AF, which is quite common, I have asked him to stop Amiodarone which is a dose of 25mg daily.
This has worked for him.
There is no indication for a pacemaker.
In 6 months, if he has had no further atrial fibrillation, his Apixaban could be stopped, unless it is used for mitral valve repair.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Armour





														RE:	JANET WALLACE		DOB:	17/07/1959		UR:	8059253

																					

														Thank you for your letter about Janet.
I remember her well from her presentation here 3 years ago with dilated cardiomyopathy complicated by polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
At that time, extensive investigations did not disclose a cause for her cardiomyopathy, and she went on to receive an ICD implant.
At the moment, Janet is not limited by her heart at all.
She does not seem to have any cardiac symptoms.
She has received appropriate periodic follow up via our ICD clinic at this hospital.
Today her blood pressure was 130/75mmHg sitting.
Clinically she had mild mitral valve regurgitation and mild tricuspid valve regurgitation, but no evidence of cardiac decompensation.
The function of her ICD system is satisfactory, with no tachyarrhythmia having been recorded by the system since last review.
Pleasingly, her echocardiography has shown normalisation of her ventricular function.
Incidentally modest dilatation of the aortic root  has been discovered.
For this I recommend repetition of echocardiography in about 2 years, when progress of her left ventricular function should also be ascertained.
She will continue review by our ICD clinic of course.
I have advised Janet to continue all of her heart failure medications indefinitely.
She should not require a fluid restriction, and salt restriction should be kept to a sensible level.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Szabo,

														

														

														RE:	PETER WALLACE		DOB:	17/08/1951		UR:	110816

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to catch with Peter in the Cardiology Clinic today.
He had his cardioversion in late October and then had a readmission about a week later with musculoskeletal chest pain, depression and functional decline.
He spent about a week and a half on the General Medical Ward and was then transferred to Canossa, where he spent another couple of weeks in Rehab.
It was thought that his depression may be reactive to his daughter’s death in September as well as the stress of the bypass operation.
There was nothing untoward cardiac and he remained in sinus rhythm following the cardioversion.
They actually go a repeat echocardiogram while he was in hospital and it was unchanged, showing an ejection fraction of 55% with good AVR function.
His Digoxin was ceased, and his Metoprolol was decreased.
He tells me that he has been as happy as Larry, since he got home from Rehab.
He is looking physically better but not 100%.
His discharge medications were Aspirin, Xarelto, Metoprolol 12.5mg BD, Frusemide 40mg, Spironolactone 25mg, Atorvastatin 80mg, Gliclazide, Sitagliptin, Metformin and he was commenced on Insulin.
Examination today revealed a blood pressure of 100/60mmHg, dropping to 90/60mmHg with standing.
His wife said he is having quite a bit of postural hypotension.
There were no signs of cardiac failure.
Today I have ceased his Spironolactone as it has a pretty strong antihypertensive effect.
Hopefully he will get a bit of extra blood pressure.
He should continue the Frusemide.
The other target for consideration would be the Gliclazide as being potentially not necessary now he is on Insulin.
I will see him again in 3 months.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Wang,





RE:	CHANG WANG		DOB:	25/12/1959		UR:	037820

							





I saw Mr Wang in my clinic for follow up today.
His exercise stress echocardiogram showed inducible ischaemia in both the LAD and LCX territory (~5 segments).
As before, his symptom is predominantly exertional dyspnoea, and he denied any typical angina.
His background is significant for known underlying ischaemic heart disease, frequent symptomatic ectopic beats, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia and small infra renal AAA (2.5cm).
His current medications include Aspirin 100mg daily, Perindopril 2mg daily, Metoprolol 25mg prn, and Atorvastatin 40mg daily.
He has no allergies.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 70bpm regular, and his blood pressure was 130/70mmHg.
Today, I have asked Mr Wang to try taking the Ezetimibe / Atorvastatin 10/40mg again.
I have also organised for him to have an invasive coronary angiogram.
I will see him again next month for follow up, to see if we can up titrate his medications if required.

Yours sincerely,

														Judith returned to heart failure titration clinic today.

She reports NYHA class II symptoms.
Her appetite is robust.
Her current weight is 94kg which as slowly been increasing by 100g per day given her appetite.

Unfortunately, the medication changes requested at Dr Ng’s review on the 19th December were made into Judith’s Webster pack.

Medications

														Allopurinol 400mg nocte, Atorvastatin 10mg nocte, Co-Senna 50/8mg 2 tabs nocte, Frusemide 80mg mane, Levothyroxine 100mcg mane Thur-Sun and 150mcg Mon-Wed, Nebivolol 0.625mg nocte, Pantoprazole 40mg mane, Cholecalciferol 25mcg mane, Rivaroxaban 15mg nocte.

Dear Dr Hong,





														RE:	LYNETTE DESLEY WATKINS	DOB:	10/10/1959	UR:	048477

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Lynette a lovely 63-year-old ex-smoker, who presented to Dr Hill’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today for a post discharge appointment.

Her medical issues include:

														Ischaemic cardiomyopathy.
Diagnosed with 80% ostial left main and severe 3 vessel disease on elective angiogram performed at the Mater Hospital by Dr Kyranis on 07.11.22.
Echocardiogram suggested an ejection fraction of 20% with segmental dysfunction.
Cardiac MRI performed on 15.11.2022, showed an ejection fraction of 33% with post ischaemic scarring in the LAD territory.
Was reviewed by our Cardiothoracic colleagues (Dr Iyer) and was deemed that in light of scar in LAD territory CABG would offer relatively limited benefit.
Patient was discharged on medical therapy with the aim to review in January.
Dyslipidaemia.
Hypertension.
Family history of premature coronary artery disease.
Distant ex-smoker (in her 20s).
On review today, Lynette tells me that she has been doing very well since discharge.
She denies any chest pain or discomfort, nor does she have any postural dizziness, presyncope, syncope or shortness of breath.
Lynette’s only major issue is the fact that she gets fatigued as the day goes on but was still able to look after her grandchildren around the Christmas period.
Her current medications include, Aspirin 100mg, Clopidogrel 75mg, Bisoprolol 10mg, Valsartan 20mg, Rosuvastatin 40mg, Spironolactone 12.5mg 3 times a week.
She also has a GTN spray supply at home.
On examination today, she appeared well, with a blood pressure of 132/60mmHg, with no postural drop.
Her resting heart rate was 65bpm regularly regular, that rose appropriately to 76bpm with exertion.
Her chest was clear on auscultation, and she had no evidence of peripheral oedema.
Heart sounds were dual with no added murmurs.
Her ECG today was in sinus rhythm at 64bpm with a normal PR interval and known ischaemic changes in the anterior leads.
Our impression today is that Lynette has stable ischaemic cardiomyopathy with no ongoing symptoms of angina.
Given that she remains stable, I have discussed her case with Dr Hill, and we have decided that the best way to manage her coronary artery disease is medically.
I have taken the liberty to increase her Valsartan to 40mg today and her heart failure medications should continue being titrated by yourself and the Titration Clinic at the Logan Hospital.
I have also increased her lipid lowering therapy by adding Ezetimibe 10mg.
We are aiming for an LDL <1.4 for Lynette.
I have reiterated the chest pain pathway to her, and she should seek urgent medical attention if her chest pain lasts more than 15 to 20 minutes.
If Lynette develops symptoms concerning for ongoing ischaemia, revascularisation options can be looked into at that stage.
We will plan to see her in 6 months with a repeat echocardiogram and ECG.
However, in the meantime should she run into any troubles, please do not hesitate in contacting us.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Zhou ,

														

														

														RE:	GLORIA F. WAYLETT	DOB:	16/06/1943	UR:	402908

																					

														

														

														Issues:
1.
Multifactorial severe pulmonary hypertension.

· Pulmonary hypertension specific therapy not indicated as per consensus of 

														      meeting of pulmonary arterial hypertension committee and this information was   

														      filed on letter dated back in 2016 and again on 10th May 2022.

- Right heart catheter Aug 2022: Trans Pulmonary Gradient = 30 mmHg, PVR 6.2

														      WU
2.
Obstructive sleep apnoea, on CPAP with good compliance.
Prior pulmonary sarcoidosis.
Multivalvular heart disease.
· Calcified aortic valve with severe aortic stenosis.

TTE Dec 2022
    · Severe mitral annular calcification with elevated trans mitral gradient and mild to 

														      moderate MR.
    · Moderate TR
5.

CKD; Renal transplant 2002, secondary to renal disease from analgesic

														    nephropathy.
AV fistula both arms.

Creat 88 eGFR 55 Dec 2022
    .

Complications of immunosuppression include osteoporosis - femur fracture after 

														      7 years of bisphosphonate use
6.
Type 2 diabetes.
Diverticulosis.

Chronic GI bleed thought to be due to AS-related angioectasia
    · Double balloon enteroscopy on 09/02/2022.

· Reviewed by gastroenterology in early February 2022
    · Iron deficiency ; Iron infusion Aug 2021; Ferritin 36 Feb 2022 Hb 149 MCV 90
    · B12 deficiency (treated), requires ongoing replacement with injections every 3 to 

														      6 months.
Adenomatous colon polyps, in which surveillance is not recommended.
Atrial fibrillation diagnosed May 2021.

Rivaroxaban ceased July 2021 due to GI 

														      bleed; maintained in SR on sotalol.

Cystic right adnexa mass - stable on surveillance US Oct 2021

Medications: (Webster pack)
Atorvastatin 20mg once a day, Everolimus 500mg bd, Gliclazide 30mg bd, Frusemide 80mg bd, Prednisone 4mg mane, Sotalol 80mg bd, Slow K tablets, Bactrim ½ tablet bd and Ciclosporin 25mg bd


														I had the pleasure of reviewing Gloria Waylett in our Cardiology Clinic today.

She is known to this clinic for the complex interplay of her comorbidities including multifactorial severe pulmonary hypertension, multivalvular heart disease including severe aortic stenosis, severe mitral annular calcification with elevated trans mitral gradient and mild to moderate MR and moderate TR, on a background of chronic kidney disease with a renal transplant in 2002, diabetes, and chronic GI bleeds thought to be secondary to AS related angioectasia.
Furthermore, she has had atrial fibrillation diagnosed in May 2021 and continues on Sotalol to maintain sinus rhythm.
Rivaroxaban has been discontinued since July 2021, due to GI bleed.
Gloria lives in a share house with her sister.
She shares her home chores with her and manages to vacuum the apartment slowly in multiple sessions.
She does her own shopping and walks with a  4-wheel walker when outside of the house.
She buys preprepared meals and reheats them, not doing any more elaborate cooking.
When she comes to the hospital, she uses a single point stick and furniture walks when she is inside her own homes.
She does not drive.
While she has not smoked herself, she has significant passive smoke exposure from her family smoking inside in her youth.
With respect to Gloria’s functional capacity, she has significant dyspnoea that limits her activity.
Nevertheless, she is able to trim the edge of her lawn with a whipper snipper and use a hedge trimmer, both of which approximately 5 minutes at a time, without stopping.
Her neighbour mows the remainder of her lawn.
She does not experience any presyncope while doing yard work.
She also reports having had no syncopal episodes.
With respect to the investigations, since her last review, Gloria has had a transthoracic echocardiogram in December last year.
This showed a normal left ventricular size and ejection fraction and a normal right ventricular size and systolic function.
Severe aortic stenosis with mild regurgitation was seen.

Significant mitral annular and valvular calcification with moderately elevated trans valvular gradient and mild regurgitation was seen as was moderate tricuspid regurgitation with elevated pulmonary pressures.
A CT coronary angiogram was performed 2 days ago.
Unfortunately, this has not yet been reported.
On examination, Gloria appeared relatively well.
Her blood pressure was 145/55mmHg and her heart rate was 70bpm and regular.
On auscultation of her chest, she had bibasal crepitations.
Her heart sounds were dual with an ejection systolic murmur in the aortic region and a pan systolic murmur in the mitral region.
There was peripheral oedema to the knees bilaterally, which has been a long-term issue.
Importantly, Gloria’s hope for what we can do for her is that she can return to what she was doing previously.
I discussed with her today in clinic the complex interaction of her multiple comorbidities.

In discussion with Dr Cox, we will discuss Gloria’s case at a multidisciplinary team (heart team), where specialists in interventional cardiology, cardiac imaging, and cardiothoracic surgery, will discuss her case and provide a consensus recommendation as to the optimal management strategy.
I have liaised with our TAVR coordinator, Kellee Korver, to facilitate this.
I will arrange to review Gloria in approximately 6 weeks to convey the outcome of the heart team meeting.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Ms Waylett.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Wardle,





														RE:	JANICE WEBB		DOB:	28/12/1952		UR:	358387

																					

														

														

														Cardiovascular Diagnosis:

														Ischaemic heart disease.
Primary PCI to RCA with three drug-eluting stents, for inferolateral STEMI at Princess Alexandra Hospital on 20/09/2019.
No evidence of inducible ischaemia on dobutamine stress echo on 18/08/2021.
Moderate aortic stenosis with a possible bicuspid aortic valve.
Indeterminate aortic valve morphology on TTE with family history of bicuspid aortic valve.
TTE on 23/11/2020:  LVEF 50-55% with normal RV size and systolic function and moderate aortic stenosis.

Cardiovascular risk factors:

														Obesity with the metabolic syndrome.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
Relapsed smoker.
Type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Other conditions:

														Osteoarthritis with chronic bilateral knee pain and reduced mobility.
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
Previous iron deficiency anaemia with no sinister pathology on upper and lower endoscopy.
Diverticular disease of the colon.
Previous total knee joint replacement.
Obstructive sleep apnoea.
Degenerative back disease with chronic back pain.

Medication:

														Metformin XR 1 g mane, Dulaglutide 1.5 mg/0.5 mL pen once weekly, Aspirin 100 mg one mane, Spironolactone 25 mg one mane, Frusemide 40 mg one mane, Valsartan 160 mg one morning, Nebivolol 5 mg half mane, Isosorbide mononitrate one and a half tablets mane, Atorvastatin 40 mg one mane, Ezetimibe 10 mg one mane, Pantoprazole 40 mg one mane, Bisacodyl 5 mg one mane, Thiamine 100 mg one mane, Trelegy Ellipta 100/52.5/25 one puff mane, Paracetamol 665 mg prn, Hydroxocobalamin 1 mg/mL injection once every three months, Salbutamol 100 mcg two puffs four times daily prn, Glyceryl Trinitrate 400 mcg one spray under tongue prn.
I reviewed Janice today.
She attended the appointment with her daughter and granddaughter.
Things are stable.

She has recommenced smoking cigarettes and I have counselled her around the critical importance of smoking cessation with pharmacotherapy assistance if required in order to reduce her risk of cancer, heart attack, stroke and death , as well as to improve her shortness of breath.
Janice underwent a total knee replacement at the Mater Hospital without significant perioperative issues.
I understand that she is being assessed for knee joint replacement on the contralateral knee.

On examination blood pressure was 174/85mmHg, heart rate was 70bpm, respiratory rate 18, JVP not elevated, heart sounds dual with a 3/6 ejection systolic murmur to the carotids, with preserved carotid pulse upstroke and volume.
Lung fields clear, but reduced breath sounds throughout consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and no pitting peripheral oedema.
Her 12 Lead ECG shows sinus rhythm 72bpm.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Smoking cessation with pharmacotherapy assistance if required and Janice has been counselled around this today (see discussion above).
Repeat cardiology review in 3 months with a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Hudson,





														RE:	LESLIE WHEILDON		DOB:	15/09/1946		UR:	1104851

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Leslie, a lovely 76-year-old gentleman I had the pleasure of catching up with via telehealth, on behalf of Dr W Ahmad.
As you are already aware, Leslie was admitted under the care of PA Hospital Cardiology Unit in October last year with a delayed presentation inferolateral STEMI.
His angiogram showed an occluded RCA, severe LAD + diagonal disease along with moderate LCx disease.
Leslie underwent a cardiac MRI that revealed RCA territory scar but a viable LAD territory.
He was seen by the cardiothoracic team and discussed at our Heart Team Meeting where the consensus was that he was not suitable for surgery.
Leslie subsequently underwent successful PCI to his mid LAD with 2 drug eluting stents on 17.10.2022 (performed by Dr Fetahovic).
His ejection fraction at the time of admission was approximately 30%.
Leslie was discharged on dual antiplatelet therapy along with appropriate heart failure medications.
Since discharge I am pleased to report that Leslie has been feeling fantastic.
He denies any chest pain, dyspnoea, dizziness or syncope.
He denies any heart failure symptoms, nor does he have any bleeding complications from his blood thinners.
On examination today his heart rate was 67bpm with a blood pressure of 139/73mmHg and oxygen saturations of 97% on room air.
I note that he has had a recent blood test through S & N where he was iron replete with a good haemoglobin and renal function.
He has had a transthoracic echocardiogram in Toowoomba last week that shows that his ejection fraction has improved to 49% with no significant valvular abnormalities.
Our impression today is that Leslie has stable ischaemic cardiomyopathy and is progressing well from a post STEMI perspective.
Unfortunately, he has had no had any up titration of his heart failure therapy since discharge and as such I have taken the liberty of increasing his Bisoprolol to 7.5mg today.
I have advised him to see you in 2 weeks and if he is tolerating this from a blood pressure perspective, then please increase his Eplerenone to 25mg.
You should have a heart failure titration plan sent to you by our pharmacist from October 2022.
If you do not have a copy of this, please do not hesitate in contacting our outpatient department, who would be happy to resend you this titration plan.
Given that Leslie is stable, we have discharged him from our care and as such would appreciate if you could refer him to the Toowoomba Hospital Cardiology Department for long term follow up.
Please keep an eye on his lipid profile.
We are aiming for an LDL <1.4.
He is to continue dual antiplatelet therapy for 12 months post PCI (stop 17.10.2023).
His Aspirin is to continue lifelong.
Once again thank you for your ongoing care and do not hesitate in contacting us should you have questions or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

														I saw Kathleen in my clinic for follow up today.
She has been well and asymptomatic from the cardiac point of view over the last few months.
Clinically, she is in NYHA class I.
She also denied any side effects from her medications.
Her background is significant for dilated cardiomyopathy with CRT-D in-situ, previous atrial fibrillation, and increased BMI, previous 1st seizure in 2021, ankylosing spondylitis.
Her current medications include Rivaroxaban 20mg daily, Bisoprolol 10mg daily, Entresto 24/26mg BD, Spironolactone 25mg daily, Dapagliflozin 10mg daily, and Frusemide 20mg prn.
She has no allergies.
On examination today, her pulse rate was 65bpm regular, and her blood pressure was 100/70mmHg.

Her repeat echocardiogram showed severely dilated left ventricular with mild to moderate global systolic dysfunction (LVEF 40%), normal right ventricular size and systolic function, and mild mitral regurgitation.
In summary, Kathleen’s LV function has significant improved over the years.
Today, I have not made any changes to her medications and will see her again in 1 year with another repeat echocardiogram.
Thank you for looking after Kathleen.

Dear Dr Hanna,





														RE:	MIRANDA WHITEHEAD	DOB:	30/03/1965	UR:	267714

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Miranda in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know she is a 57-year-old lady who recently had some possible wall motion abnormalities noted on an echocardiogram.
She reports that her main concern over the last six months was profuse diuresis when standing from bending.
She experienced no chest pain with this and it would settle after a number of minutes.
She also reports very chronic dyspnoea on exertion for than five years, although her exercise tolerance on the flat is unlimited.
She would need to stop several times if she was walking up a steep hill.
She does get some sporadic heavy central chest pain, but this is not related to exertion at all and is not associated with any symptoms such as dyspnoea or diaphoresis.
The echocardiogram reported an ejection fraction of 61% with hypokinesis of the mid to apical anterolateral segments.
This hypokinesis was potentially new compared to an echocardiogram in 2015.
You organised a CTCA which demonstrated a calcium score of 0 with normal coronary arteries with no plaque or stenosis.

This all occurs on a background of:

														Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia (recent LDL 2.12mmol/L).
OSA on CPAP.
Fatty liver on ultrasound some years ago.
PCOS.
Never smoked.
Miranda’s current medications are Perindopril 4mg, Atorvastatin 20mg, Metformin 500mg (PCOS).
On examination today, ECG showed her to be in normal sinus rhythm at 80bpm.
Her blood pressure was 120/800mmHg.
Heart sounds were dual with no murmurs and her chest was clear.
She had very mild pitting ankle oedema.
In summary, it is possible that Miranda’s echo was difficult to interpret and the wall motion abnormalities were artefactual, given her normal coronary arteries on CTCA.
A remote ischaemic event seems less likely.
I will organise an echo with contrast here to improve endocardial definition and review her by phone with the result.
I will keep you updated on her progress.

Yours sincerely,

														Mr Wijayaratna was reviewed in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
This was follow up in the setting of his history of ischaemic heart disease.
In March of 2021, he presented to hospital with a non-STEMI and underwent a PCI to the LAD with 2 stents and 1 stent to the diagonal branch.
His current medications include Aspirin 100mg daily, and Atorvastatin 20mg oral daily and GTN spray PRN.
He reports that he has reduced his dose of Atorvastatin in view that he was experiencing muscle pain.
Currently he is tolerating the dose of atorvastatin 20mg.
He reports that he has been feeling well.
He has not experienced any chest pain.
He is currently tolerating his medications.
He exercises regularly with walks 3 times a week and also going to the gym several times a week as well.
He has not experienced any symptoms with chest pain while doing his exercise activities.
He reports that he has been very focused on his exercise and also trying to maintain a balanced diet.
On examination, his heart rate was 80bpm and his blood pressure was 120/80mmHg.
His heart sounds were dual, and his chest was clear.
He had an echocardiogram in 2021, that showed normal LV size and systolic function with an ejection fraction of 60%.
He normal RV size and systolic function and there were no significant functional valvular abnormalities.
He underwent an exercise stress test in February of 2022 that was negative.
His ECG from today’s consultation was sinus rhythm.
Mr Wijayaratna has been very well from a symptom perspective since his original presentation to hospital.
He is currently tolerating his medications and is not affected by symptoms.
I have encouraged him to continue with his active lifestyle with regards to his exercise and his focus on his diet and to continue on his current medications.
Considering his he is feeling well, he will not require further cardiology follow up in clinic.
If you can please follow him up with regards to his blood pressure and cholesterol levels that would be appreciated.
If there are any concerns in the future, please do not hesitate to re-refer as required..

														Diagnoses

Postural hypotension.
Hypercholesterolaemia.
Anxiety/depression.

Echocardiogram with normal LV function and no valvular abnormalities 2019,

														

														Medication 

														Atorvastatin 20 mg once a day, Sertraline 50 mg daily, Fludrocortisone 50mcg daily.
Valerie came in for review today.
She has been stable in the 18  months since I last saw her.
There is no significant postural hypotension for her and takes care when standing quickly.
She does have some shortness of breath on exertion, which has been present for 6 to 12 months.
She is short of breath with relatively light activities, through it has been some time since she did any regular exercise.

The PR interval was 160ms, QRS 87ms, and QTc 446ms.
Valerie has relatively stable blood pressure and no ongoing postural symptoms.
I have continued her Fludrocortisone as a consequence.
I have arranged a myocardial perfusion scan to reassess her LV function and to exclude ischaemia, though I suspect her breathlessness relates to her chronic deconditioning.
I would be happy to see her if there are ongoing concerns or abnormalities with the MPS.

Dear Dr Wang,



														RE:	PHILLIP WILLETT		DOB:	01/07/1971		UR:	642376

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Phillip in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know he is a 51-year-old gentleman who was referred for a DSE by the Kidney Transplant Team late last year.
During that test he developed inferior ST elevation.
He was admitted for coronary angiography, which revealed chronic total occlusion of the proximal RCA as well as a severe long mid LAD lesion.
He was reviewed by the Cardiothoracic Surgeons and his case was further discussed in the Heart Team Meeting.
It was thought reasonable to offer him coronary artery bypass grafting despite his lack of regular cardiac symptoms.
He has been reviewed by Dr Jordan Ross and is on the waiting list for an elective CABG.

This occurs on a background of:

														End stage renal failure due to hypertension.
Ongoing haemodialysis.
Hypertension.
GORD.
Morbid obesity (weight 135 kilograms).
Gout.
Previous intracerebral haemorrhage left basal ganglia 2015.
His medications from a cardiac point of view include Aspirin 100mg, Atorvastatin 80mg, Ezetimibe 10mg, Metoprolol 50mg PRN when blood pressure above 160mmHg, Perindopril 8mg, Hydralazine 50mg PRN.
Phillip has been well with no chest pain or other cardiac symptoms.
He has had no bleeding issues on the Aspirin.
His dialysis is going well.
In terms of risk factors, his LDL was 2.5mmol/L on admission recently and Atorvastatin was commenced at that time.
We should recheck this and ensure it is now under 1.6mmol/L.
His blood pressure fluctuates with dialysis.
He is not smoking.
I will organise to review Phillip in six month and he will remain on the waiting list for his CABG, but please feel free to contact me in the interim with any new issues or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

														Dr Katrina Della Bosca

														Wolston Correctional Centre

														176A Grindle Road

														Dear Dr Della Bosca,

														

														

														RE:	JEFFREY L. WILLIAMS	DOB:	03/02/1981	UR:	2134852

																					

														

														

														Jeffrey Williams was reviewed via telehealth for a cardiology consultation.
He is currently at Wolston Correctional Centre.
His referral was in the setting of palpitations.
He describes episodes of intermittent palpitations that he noticed for some time.
The last episode of palpitations that he noticed was after very heavy exercise approximately 6 months ago.

Since then, he was reportedly advised to reduce his caffeinated beverage intake and he has also noticed that by reducing his exercise intensity his symptoms of palpitations after exercise have subsided.
He reports that he exercises approximately 1 hour a day, and this can involve weights, as well as running exercises and he does not experience any chest pain or palpitations.
He exercises approximately 5 times a week.
He notices at time, especially at night, he experiences episodes where his heart skips a beat and then goes back to beating normally.
He does not notice this during the day.
In speaking with Jeffrey, it does not bother him during the course of his day and he is able to go about his day daily activities.
He describes a previous episode that sounds to be consistent with vasovagal episode or faint after a gym session.
He noted prior to it, feeling a bit flushed and he did not experience any chest pain or palpitations prior to the episode.
He reports that he may be out for approximately a couple of seconds and then recovered as he was told by a bystander in the facility.
He did not report loss of control of his bodily functions.
He reports that it was an isolated episode.
He does not report any history of sudden cardiac death in the family.
He does report a previous smoking history.
On examination, his heart rate was 79bpm and his blood pressure was 115/71mmHg and he is 100% on room air for oxygen saturations and these are the observation from telehealth.
An ECG that was forwarded for the consultation showed sinus rhythm.
The ECG was 31.01.2023.
He had a normal PR interval and a normal QTc interval of 419ms.
With regards to Jeffrey’s symptoms of palpitations, he reports that his symptoms have mainly subsided over 6 months ago and it does not affect him on his day-to-day activities.
He does notices intermittent symptoms at night when he is rested.
He has been advised that try to reduce the episode of palpitations, that he continue to try to avoid heavily caffeinated beverages and to maintain adequate hydration.
With regards to his exercise activity, he was advised to exercise within his limits.

From a cardiac perspective, since his symptoms of palpitations are minimally intrusive and he is able to partake in exercise activity, without being affected by symptoms, he was advised to continue with the current management.
Of note, he had previous blood investigations that have shown thyroid function that was normal with a TSH of 1.7, a  GFR of 81 and a haemoglobin  of 157.
From a cardiac perspective, Jeffrey will not require further cardiac investigation currently.
If in future, his symptoms change in severity, then this can be reassessed.
In the interim, we have not made any further arrangements for him to be followed up in the cardiology outpatient clinic.
Please do not hesitate to re-refer him if there are concerns in the future.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

RE:	HARRY WILLS		DOB:	21/01/1955		UR:	170657

							



														Harry returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
He remains well and he has no concerns.
He underwent his iron infusion on the 12th December 2022.
Blood test on the 3rd January 2023 show Na 142, K+ 4.6, Phosphate 0.73 (this is just under the reference range of 0.80), Urea 8.0, Creat 99, and eGFR 68.

Medications

														Aspirin 100mg mane, Bisoprolol 3.75mg mane, Creon 25000us TDS, Entresto 97/103mg BD, Esomeprazole 20mg mane, Dapagliflozin 10mg mane, Eplerenone increased today to 25mg mane.
Harry continues to describe class I-II NYHA symptoms, and denies any orthopnoea, PND, dizziness or light headedness.
On examination his blood pressure was 115/70mmHg sitting and 110/70mmHg standing, heart rate 68bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
Today I have increased the Eplerenone to 25mg mane.
I have organised for him a blood test in three weeks to assess his renal function given this change, as well as reassess his Phosphate levels.
In a small amount of cases Phosphate levels can be reduced following IV Iron Carboxymaltose.
I will see him back in this clinic in four weeks.

Yours sincerely,
