Dear Dr Rajina,





														RE:	JONATHON WILSON	DOB:	28/06/1967	UR:	8110864

																					

														

														

														Issues:

														Ischaemic heart disease.
Delayed presentation STEMI September 2022.
Borderline viability assessment, PCI to LAD.
CTO mid circumflex, PCI December 2022.
CTO RCA unsuccessful PCI January 2023.
Commercial License.

Background:

														Type II diabetes mellitus.
Obesity.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Current Medications:

														Isosorbide Mononitrate 60mg mane, Aspirin 100mg daily, Clopidogrel 75mg daily, Atorvastatin / Ezetimibe 80/10mg daily, Bisoprolol 5mg BD, Entresto 49/51mg BD, Eplerenone 25mg daily, Metformin 500mg nocte, Empagliflozin 10mg mane, GTN PRN.
I have the pleasure of seeing Jonathon in Dr Camuglia’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
I also supervised his exercise stress test last week.
As you will be aware Jonathon had a myocardial infarction back in September of last year, which showed 3 vessel disease.
We initially though this might be amenable to bypass grafting, but given his borderline viability, he proceeded to have PCI to his mid LAD.
He was then booked for a staged procedure to attempt to open the chronic occlusion of his circumflex and RCA arteries.
The circumflex artery was able to be successfully intervened on, however, we were unable to successfully open the CTO of the RCA.
Symptomatically, Jonathon is doing quite well.
Since his staged procedures, he reports a significant decrease in the frequency of his pain.
He uses his GTN spray about once per week and it settles quite promptly.
He is tolerating his medical therapy quite well but does report some occasional dizziness.
There is no severe chest pain, and he is not short of breath significantly.
He had an exercise stress test done last week for commercial license purposes.
He has not been driving his truck since his event.
He was able to do 9 minutes and 10.2 METs, whilst on therapy.
Whilst he did get some non-limiting pain and some inferior ST depression, this ST depression was not to the severity that would restrict him from continuing with his commercial license.

Similarly given he was able to do 9 minutes and his frequency of chest pain is quite minor, there is no reason to pursue another attempt at PCI of his RCA at this point and we will continue medical therapy.
On examination his blood pressure was 115/70mmHg, heart sounds were dual, chest was clear, and he was euvolaemic.
His ECG showed sinus rhythm at a rate wound 70bpm.
My impression is that Jonathon is symptomatically quite well and has a quite manageable number of symptoms.
I have discussed him with Dr Camuglia, and we are both in agreeance that he can satisfactorily continue holding his commercial license, with the proviso of the routine once a year check and EST.
There is also no current indication to pursue further PCI.
We will pursue medical therapy ongoing for now, reserving repeat PCI attempts for significant escalation of symptoms.

Plan is as follows:

														I have booked him to us in 12 months.
We will arrange for an exercise stress test for his commercial license prior to that review.
He should continue on the same medications.
He should continue on both Aspirin and Clopidogrel once daily.
He can cease his Clopidogrel on 05.01.2024 but should continue Aspirin lifelong.
I have provided him with the necessary commercial license paperwork, but should he have any trouble with this, could you please assist.
We are happy for him to continue to hold his commercial license and that he has satisfied the parameters required form a cardiac side of things.
Could you please continue to monitor his diabetes?
Could you please continue to monitor his blood pressure?
Could you please continue to monitor his LDL with a target <1.4?

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	JONATHON WILSON	DOB:	28/06/1967	UR:	8110864

																					

														

														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Ischaemic heart disease.
Delayed presentation ST elevation myocardial infarction.
In September 2022.

Borderline viability assessment as a result of Heart Team plan and procedure with PCI to LAD (with residual chronic total occlusion to mid circumflex artery and mid right coronary artery),

														Nadir LVEF 20-25%.
LVEF approximately 45% on TTE today, 07.12.2022 at the Princess Alexandra Hospital.
Subsequent successful revascularisation to left circumflex artery with stenting procedure on 04.01.2023 but unsuccessful concomitant PCI procedure to right coronary artery on 05.01.2023.

Cardiovascular risk factors:

														Obesity with metabolic syndrome.
Type 2 diabetes mellitus.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100 mg daily

														Clopidogrel 75 mg daily

														Atorvastatin 80 mg daily

														Ezetimibe 10 mg daily

														Bisoprolol 5 mg twice daily

														Eplerenone 25 mg daily 

														Empagliflozin 10 mg daily

														Metformin 500 mg daily

														

														Jonathon underwent an exercise stress test on 17.01.2023.
He exercised to a good workload for age and gender.
There was no significant ischaemia on exercise stress assessment.
His peak stress ECG findings were equivocal at worst and resolved promptly in recovery.
There was no definite persistent horizontal down sloping ST depression.
No definite angina.
Overall, Jonathon is in a suitable and satisfactory situation to return to commercial driving and he has clearance to do this subject to annual cardiology review.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Jonathon is clear to return to commercial driving, subject to annual cardiology review.
Repeat cardiology review in 12 months in my clinic at the PA Hospital.

Patient underwent primary PCI to LAD with drug eluting 

														    stents.

Previous history of PCI to RCA in September 2016 in Townsville, requiring 

														    multiple stents in the right coronary artery.

														    2016.

This is a short note to inform that I reviewed Kenneth Wood via telephone today.

His last stress echocardiogram he was in August last year.
He informs me that his LV ejection fraction has also improved and is between 45-50%.

Dear Dr Wadhwani,





RE:	ANTHONY WOTTON		DOB:	30/09/1979		UR:	8114608

							



														Anthony attended the heart failure titration clinic today with his partner Taya.
This is on the background of an admission to the Princess Alexandra Hospital during December 2022 with new atrial fibrillation with RVR.
During this admission Anthony was diagnosed with new heart failure.
An ECHO on the 12th December showed severely dilated LV with severe systolic dysfunction, EF 20-25%.
Dilated RV with reduced systolic function.
Flail P2 segment of mitral valve with severe regurgitation.
Moderate tricuspid regurgitation and elevated pulmonary pressure.
Angiogram showed normal coronary arteries.
Anthony was given an iron infusion on the 16th December.
The current plan is to optimise Anthony’s heart failure medications initially and he will meet with the Cardiothoracic surgeons next month to discuss his surgical options in regard to his valve.

Anthony’s other past medical history includes alcohol drinking 4-5 can Bourbon daily (nil since discharge), smoking methamphetamine 3 times per week (nil since discharge), cigarette smoker (nil since discharge), childhood asthma, and right fibula break as a teenager.
Anthony is a truck driver and is currently on Centrelink sick leave.
He is aware that he cannot drive commercially until he is cleared by Cardiology.
He lives in a rental with his partner Taya and 4 teenage children who come and go.
Taya is employed as a factory worker.
Since discharged Anthony has progressively been feeling better.
He reports NYHA class II symptoms with no PND or orthopnoea.
He sleeps on one pillow.
This is a vast improvement compared to discharge where he had constant orthopnoea, PND and NYHA class III-IV symptoms.
He does get light headedness.
He described this as light headedness all of the time which worsens on exertion.
He feels dizzier when walking up a hill for example.
He has not felt like he would faint or lose consciousness.
He has had no chest pain.
He has a normal appetite.
Unfortunately, he is not doing any regular exercise.

Medications

														Rivaroxaban 20mg mane, Ramipril 2.5mg mane, Bisoprolol 2.5mg mane, Spironolactone 12.5mg mane, Digoxin 125mcg mane, Frusemide 40mg BD, Panadol PRN.

RE:	ANTHONY WOTTON		DOB:	30/09/1979		UR:	8114608

														

														

														

														Thank you for arranging a Digoxin level with 4cyte pathology on the 27th December.
This shows a level of 0.41 which is within normal limits.
Renal function at QML show normal renal function with a na 140, K+ 4.7, urea 6.2, creat 81, eGFR >90 (attached for your records).
On examination his blood pressure was 102/60mmHg sitting and 106/60mmHg standing, heart rate 70bpm and irregular.
He had no peripheral oedema, and his lungs were clear.
Today I have asked Anthony to move both the Ramipril and Bisoprolol to nocte doses to aid in his daytime blood pressure and hopefully resolve some of his dizziness.
I called Anthony 7th February, the dizziness has greatly improved therefore I have asked him to increase the Bisoprolol to 3.75mg nocte, I will see him back in this clinic on the 24th of February.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	REINDER WOUDENBERG		DOB:	25/04/1941	UR:	526514

																					

														

														

														Problems:

														Cardiomyopathy with predominant RV involvement.
Significant RV dilatation with functional TR and elevated estimated pulmonary arterial pressures.
Possible underlying sleep apnoea, awaiting further tests.
Moderate LV systolic dysfunction, EF 30 to 35% on echocardiogram.
COPD with severe emphysema.
Bilateral pulmonary emboli in 2021 on lifelong anticoagulation.
Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis.
Chronic atrial fibrillation.
Peripheral sensory neuropathy.

Medications:

														Amitriptyline 10mg added at night, other medications unchanged including Bisoprolol 5mg, Frusemide 80 / 40 / 40, Perindopril 4mg daily, Rivaroxaban 15mg daily, Methotrexate and Folic Acid weekly.
I saw Reinder today.
He has been distressed by ongoing issues with abnormal sensation in his feet on walking.
Initially he thought that this was due to a significant peripheral oedema, which sounds very unlikely.
His increased diuretic regimen led to significant improvement in that, but his symptoms persistent.
He does seem to have a sensory deficit in both feet.
He also has difficulties in falling asleep.
He is due for a sleep study in the coming weeks.
On examination today, his venous pressure was only mildly raised at +4cm.
Pulse was irregularly irregular at 82bpm, blood pressure 100/62mmHg.
I have made no changes to his diuretic regimen but decided to start him on low dose of Amitriptyline 10mg at night.
This will hopefully improve his symptoms.
I will continue to see him in my clinic with his review in 6 months.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Kahawita,

														

														

														RE:	RICKY XAVIER		DOB:	27/02/1954		UR:	1100588

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Ricky in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know, he is a 68-year-old gentleman who was admitted here a couple of times in March with troponin negative chest pain.
He underwent an exercise stress echocardiogram which was negative.
This occurs on a background of a coronary artery calcium score of 167, hypertension and poorly controlled dyslipidaemia.
Ricky’s LDL was 6.0mmol/L here in March and I notice it was 4.3 in January with yourself.
Unfortunately, he has been intolerant of many different statins due to muscle aches.
He has tried Atorvastatin, Rosuvastatin and Pravastatin.

Ricky has not had any further significant chest pain and has been quite well for the last few months but did have a rough time this year with anxiety which has improved with Citalopram and some psychology input.
He also had a COVID infection, with which he felt quite unwell, and recurrent muscles aches and pains, which he attributes to the statin.

I have reassured Ricky that his stress echocardiogram means that he does not have any tight narrowing or blockages in his arteries currently, but he is certainly at risk of future cardiovascular events and the best thing he could do to prevent these is to control his cholesterol.
I have suggested that if his cholesterol remains poorly controlled on his upcoming blood tests, you may consider trialing Ezetimibe.
If he is intolerant of Ezetimibe as well as statins or if his LDL remains high despite therapy with Ezetimibe, then he would likely be a candidate for Repatha, the PCSK9 inhibitor.
I would be more than happy to see him again if this was required to provide his initial prescription.
I have not made any routine appointments to see Ricky at this stage but please feel free to contact me with any issues in the future.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Xiao,

														

														

														RE:	ZAI MING YANG		DOB:	12/06/1933		UR:	1009109

																					

														

														

														Thank you for referring Mr Yang to my clinic for further management of chronic atrial fibrillation and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

He is an 89-year-old gentleman whose other background history includes stage IIIa chronic renal failure (baseline eGFR ~50ml/min, creatinine 115umol/L), previous femoral embolectomy in 2017 in the context of AF without anticoagulation, and severe visual impairment due to retinal detachment and central retinal vein occlusion.
Mr Yang recently started complaining of increased exertional dyspnoea and ankle swelling.
However, the symptoms significantly improved after he was restarted back on Frusemide.
He is otherwise stable from the heart failure point of view and is in NYHA class II in the last few weeks.
Mr Yang also complained of intermittent postural light headedness due to hypotension.

So far, he denied any syncope

														

														His current medications include Apixaban 2.5mg BD, Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Ramipril  1.25mg daily, Digoxin 62.5mcg daily, and Denosumab 60mg 6 monthly.
He has no allergies.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 80bpm irregularly irregular, and his blood pressure was 90/55mmHg.
There was minimal bilateral pitting oedema.
His ECG today showed atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 66bpm (QRS 84ms, QTc 449ms).
Today, I have changed the Bisoprolol to Nebivolol 2.5mg daily in view of his symptomatic hypotension.
I have also organised for him to have an echocardiogram to reassess his LV function.
I will see him again in 2 months for follow up.
We will need to weigh him at that time and if he is >60kg at that stage, we will need to increase his Apixaban to the appropriate dosage to 5mg BD.
Thank you for looking after Mr Yang.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Geldreich,





														RE:	CARMEN ZELTINS		DOB:	09/01/1935		UR:	1143720

																					

														Thank you for referring this lady who attended my clinic with her daughter, Leanne, today.
Carmen is an ex-smoker of some 20 years and has been rather healthy for all of her life.
She has type II diabetes complicated by hypertension.
Her general functional capacity has reduced over the last year or so.
She does not have any specific cardiac symptoms however, and none of syncope.
Carmen lives alone, but she does have a cleaner who visits periodically, and her daughter does not live far away.
I note a past history of anaemia, treated with iron infusion.
Bradycardia was found incidentally on examination.
Today her blood pressure was 140/70mmHg sitting.
There were no abnormal cardiac signs apart from bradycardia.
ECG today reveals severe sinus bradycardia with junctional escape rhythm at about 45bpm, with occasional capture from the sinus.
Right bundle branch block with left anterior fascicular block coexists.
Today, I explained to Carmen and her daughter, the nature, risks and strategy of permanent pacemaker implantation.
Carmen agrees to proceed.
I will make the necessary arrangements for her, and she will be contacted next by her pre-admission clinic in the week prior to the procedure.
I have given Carmen some literature to read on the subject of pacemakers.
Dr Geldreich, I would like you to know if you have a question regarding heart rhythm, I would be very happy for you to call my office on 07-3176 2992 and leave a message for me to return your call.

Yours sincerely,

														Diagnoses:

														1.
Symptomatic PVCs currently well controlled on Metoprolol 25 mg bd.

- Awaiting Holter monitoring

														2.
Non-obstructive coronary artery disease on a CT coronary angiogram performed at the Wesley Hospital.
History of dyslipidaemia on statin.
History of ground-glass nodule in both lungs.
Type 2 diabetes.
Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease.
Non-smoker.
History of gastric intestinal stromal tumour (GIST) resection in China with follow up by General Surgery at the Princess Alexandra Hospital.
Hypertension.

Medication:
Crestor 10 mg daily, Jardiance 10 mg, Lipidil 45 mg, Metformin 1 g tds, Nexium 20 mg, Symbicort inhaler, Metoprolol 25 mg bd, Candesartan 32 mg daily.
This is a short note to inform you that I reviewed Xiuying in my Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
Since her last visit to the clinic, she has been getting intermittent palpitations.
She informs that occasionally she checks her heart rate, and it is around 27bpm.
I wonder if this artefactually low heart rate because of PVC’s.
She denied any classical exertional chest pain.
She does not experience any syncope or presyncope.
Clinically she appeared euvolaemic today.
Her resting heart rate was 70bpm, her blood pressure was 120/80mmHg.
She also experiences left should pain, which appears to be more musculoskeletal, therefore, it may be worthwhile referring her to a physiotherapist to evaluate a symptom rhythm correlation.
I am ordering a 24-hour Holter monitor.
If there is any significant PVC burden, then I may have to refer her to my Electrophysiology colleague.
I will catch up with her again in 4 to 5 months with the results of her Holter monitor.
I will keep you updated of her results.
